DOC.HEAD: Harvard President Derek Bok Criticizes Higher Education's Critics
DOC.TEXT: Harvard University President Derek Bok struck back at conservative critics of higher education, saying problems stem from a decade of tax cuts and federal deficits rather than ``liberal'' education practices. In his 19th annual report, issued Thursday, Bok warned that the criticism could end up hurting higher education. Conservatives who rose to prominence in the political climate of the 1980s ``saw universities as liberal strongholds populated by cocksure, opinionated professors,'' Bok wrote in the 40-page report. These conservative critics have attacked higher education ``more savagely during the past 10 years than at any time in my memory,'' Bok said. ``Most of the charges are flawed because they ignore basic conflicts and contradictions in the demands society makes on universities,'' he wrote. ``Continued criticism of this kind ... threatens to do needless damage to the public confidence so important to maintaining a strong system of colleges and universities.'' ``What is needed ... is not an end to criticism but a criticism that is less given to rhetorical excess, more careful with its criteria for judgment,'' Bok wrote. Bok addressed several areas of controversy, including the conflict between teaching and research. Last month, the faculty of Harvard Medical School approved a set of guidelines governing outside work for faculty members. ``One signal comes from all the critics who deplore the neglect of teaching and the stress that universities place on published work,'' Bok said. ``The other makes the opposite point through a system of powerful incentives and rewards that offers fame, fortune and ample funding to successful scientists and scholars.'' Bok said teachers are not always motivated by private gain when undertaking outside pursuits and said that research usually benefits a university. But Bok did say schools need to delineate how much time can be spent on outside pursuits. He said restrictions are inadequate at many institutions. Bok also decried what he called ``hostile publicity'' about rising tuition costs. Bok said most news reports about expensive tuition are focused on a few high-powered universities such as Harvard, Stanford, Yale or Princeton when in fact most undergraduates attend public universities where tuition is less than $2,000 per year.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Blast FEMA at Congressional Quake Housing Hearing
DOC.TEXT:
The mayors of Oakland and San Francisco heaped scorn on the Federal Emergency Management Agency over its handling of housing relief for people left homeless after the October earthquake. San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos accused the agency of behaving as if it were ``protecting the public treasury against the victims of the disaster'' in testifying Thursday before the House Subcommittee on Housing and Community Development. The 7.1-magnitude quake that struck Northern California on Oct. 17 killed 67 people and did millions of dollars in property damage.
Agnos and Oakland Mayor Lionel Wilson complained that the agency displayed ``arrogance and a lack of compassion'' toward people stunned and suddenly homeless. Alameda County Supervisor Don Perata said, ``I'm here to communicate a lot of anger, a lot of frustration Oakland has over the way FEMA has treated us ... if these people worked for me in Alameda County they would be summarily dismissed,'' ``There may be difficulties within a bureaucracy, but there should be no excuse for treating people you are empowered to serve with disrespect, callousness and as though they were the enemy seeking to come into your home in the dark of night to steal your silverware,'' Perata said. One FEMA rule required that applicants had to have lived in a building at least 30 days to qualify for assistance, Wilson said. Those who live in a place for short periods, then move on, were the hardest hit, he said. ``Only when FEMA was challenged by a lawsuit did FEMA agree to meet the needs of such persons, an agreement which was not implemented in good faith,'' said Wilson, pointing to a letter containing an official objection. Agnos suggested that house equity should be available as collateral for loans to repair damaged houses, not just cash. This would help retired people who own or have large equity in their homes, but who haven't got immediate cash resources to get the job done, he said. Agnos also recommended that $44 million from the president's discretionary fund be allocated to help rebuild affordable housing, another 2,200 rental assistance vouchers be provide until units are rebuilt, and an extension of FEMA assistance. Lorri Jean, FEMA deputy regional director, said the agency had been heavily burdened with Hurricane Hugo relief when the earthquake hit. Many agency members in her region already were committed to the Hugo program, she said. ``It was necessary for FEMA to initiate a concentrated hiring and training program in order to meet the shortages of personnel,'' she said. The elected officials generally praised the actions of the federal Housing and Urban Development agency, Red Cross volunteers, and the state Department of Housing and Community Development for their response to the disaster. According to reports made to the Association of Bay Area Governments, Santa Cruz County lost between 4,000 and 5,000 dwellings, some 3,400 homes were lost or damaged in Alameda County, and more than 5,000 units were damaged or destroyed in San Francisco City and County. Local officials have said the need $3 billion in state and federal aid to recover from the earthquake. Figures on how much FEMA has spent weren't available.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Said to Have Nuclear Facilities, Without Using Them _ Yet
DOC.TEXT: The United States believes North Korea has the facilities to build nuclear weapons but is not moving rapidly on the work, says a senior Pentagon official. U.S. officials have evidence the North Koreans have built a reactor as well as a reprocessing facility to separate plutonium, the material used to make nuclear weapons, Henry S. Rowen, assistant secretary of defense for international security affairs, said Thursday. ``I would not want to characterize it as a slow pace but a deliberate pace,'' Rowen told reporters at a news briefing in which he assessed North Korea's work on manufacturing nuclear weapons. ``However, it's not galloping ahead at a great rate. ... It's a concern to us and the Japanese.'' The Pentagon official said the United States raised the issue of North Korea's building nuclear weapons in talks in Washington last weekend between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. ``We hope that their influence would be enough to get it under control, get at least inspectors in there, preferably to end the whole thing, end the separation business,'' Rowen said. ``So far, it hasn't borne fruit.'' The United States hopes the Soviet Union would have some influence with the communist regime in North Korea. U.S. officials have expressed concerns about the potential proliferation of nuclear weapons. CIA Director William Webster said in congressional testimony last year that 15 or more nations, including many from the developing world, could possess nuclear weapons early in the next century. Webster also has said that many developing countries are working on ballistic missiles, which could be used to carry nuclear or other weapons to their targets. Five nations have said they have nuclear weapons: the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Great Britain and France. India exploded a single atomic device in 1974 but said it was a non-military explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Investigating Abuses at Detention Center
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is investigating charges that immigration guards beat and sexually harassed inmates at a detention camp for aliens seeking political asylum. Mike Lempres, who oversees the Immigration and Naturalization Service detention centers, flew to Miami on Thursday to check into the charges, which have been turned over to Justice's civil rights division. ``Should any of these allegations lead to a finding that there are abuses, the abuses will not be tolerated,'' Lempres said after touring the Krome Avenue camp. Krome is the only center in Florida that holds illegal aliens while immigration considers their claims for asylum. Most are Cubans, Haitians and Central Americans who claim political persecution in their homelands. Lempres said he suspects the abuse allegations stem from ``a few bad apples.'' ``The conditions I see there are not inhumane,'' he said. Refugee advocates spoke of sexual harassment and beatings that have prompted some refugees to give up their appeals and accept deportation. ``Things there are so unbelievably bad,'' said Cheryl Little, an attorney for Haitian Refugee Center Inc. ``Acts of serious abuse abound.'' Ms. Little said she has more than 100 affidavits from detainees and said she has been seeking a thorough government investigation for more than a year. ``I left home trying to escape the violence of Haiti,'' said Lavidieu Conserve, a former Krome detainee. ``And I come here and am badly beaten.'' Another Haitian immigrant, Chantale Pierre, said camp guards repeatedly fondled her and propositioned her. The women sometimes give in to guards' sexual advances because they are promised they will be released, those gathered Thursday at the Haitian Refugee Center said. Women are subjected to repeated searches and are ``manhandled during these searches,'' Ms. Little said. People are threatened with deportation if they complain, she said. ``I have had countless clients tell me they can no longer take the conditions at Krome. They made the decision to return to Haiti ... living in hiding there,'' said attorney Esther Cruz. Lempres, asked about this charge, responded: ``I can tell you we don't discourage these people from filing the asylum applications.'' Immigration officials said detainees usually spend only 41 days at Krome, but that if they fight deportation, they can remain as long as a year. The camp, a former Nike missile base on the edge of the Everglades, has been used since 1980 to hold undocumented aliens. The compound of one-story, non-descript dormitories held 444 detainees Thursday. Ms. Little said an earlier federal probe was flawed because the detainees weren't safeguarded against retaliation. Ignacio Lopez, 27, from Guatemala, said each guard is like a dictator with his own rules. While food is plentiful at the camp, he said, guards sometimes force them to rush their meals, throwing away their food after a few minutes. Former detainee Sony Dujon compared camp guards to TonTons Macoute, the feared secret militia of Haiti's deposed Duvalier regime. The Rev. Thomas Wenski called for an end to the practice of detaining aliens at Krome while their appeals are heard. He said there are willing sponsors to take responsibility for them, and they pose no threat to the community. ``There is humiliation and indignity,'' said the Roman Catholic priest, who ministers in Miami's Little Haiti neighborhood. ``The worst problem is the people are innocent. They came here only to seek freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: Troubles Along Border Have Chinese Watching Their Minorities
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Chinese leaders are warning of domestic religious and ethnic conflict, apparently fearing the nationalist tumult in neighboring Central Asia could spread to Mongols, Manchus, Moslems and Tibetans in China. A spread of ethnic violence and religious fundamentalism from Soviet Asia, and democratic impulses from Mongolia, could threaten Beijing's long-nurtured concept of unity and harmony between Han Chinese and the nation's 55 minorities. Martial law has been in effect in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa for more than a year, following recurrent anti-Chinese riots. Last week, troops were reportedly dispatched to three cities near the Soviet border to put down unrest among Moslem ethnic groups. The government has barred foreign travelers and journalists from the region. Premier Li Peng in February said ``a tiny number of separatists, under the mantle of nationalism and religion, oppose socialism and sabotage the unity of all Chinese nationalities.'' China, he told officials in charge of minority affaris, ``should wipe out all separatist activities while they are still in the embryonic stage.'' Beijing's minority problem pales before that of the Soviet Union, where almost 50 percent of the population is non-Russian. In China, the 86 million members of non-Han ethnic groups are less than 8 percent of the 1.1 billion population, and many have long been assimilated into Chinese culture. But ethnic groups inhabit lands comprising 60 percent of China's territory, stretching from the Himalayas of the southwest to the Silk Road deserts of the west and the endless steppes of the north. Tibet has been the most volatile region. Many Tibetans stubbornly resist China's claims to sovereignty, and dozens have died in anti-Chinese riots in Lhasa since late 1987. At least 4,000 Tibetans demonstratd in Lhasa last month to mark the anniversary of martial law, according to spokesmen for Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, but China denied the report. Beijing refused entry to all foreign journalists and tourists, and operators didn't put phone calls through. The Buddhist Tibetans deeply resent China's past policies of religious and cultural persecution. Their feelings are shared by the Uygurs and other Moslem groups, more than half the 14 million people of arid Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region to the north. Xinjiang borders on Soviet Kazakhstan, Kirghizia and Tadzhikistan and shares cultural ties with their restless peoples. In addition to 7.3 million Huis and 6 million Uygurs, scatterings of Kazaks, Kirghiz, Tatars, Russians and Tajiks are also found in Xinjiang and other border provinces. Asian diplomats in Beijing said a dispute over a mosque in Xinjiang's remote western desert town of Kashgar sparked last week's unrest in which up to 50 were killed, according to unconfirmed reports. They said the rioters were from the Kirghiz ethnic group. The disturbances were the worst since May, when about 150 Moslems were arrested for attacking the Communist Party headquarters in Urumqi. They were upset over a Chinese-language book they said blasphemed their religion. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Li Jinhua on Thursday denied any knowledge of the reported clashes in Kashgar. Chinese officials have sought to keep news of the unrest from spreading by barring foreigners from the region and refusing to answer queries from foreign journalists and diplomats. But Chinese officials have frequently warned of potential trouble in the area. The regional Communist Party chief, Song Hanliang, said after a tour of Kashgar and other areas of southern Xinjiang in February that ``every place and work unit now has hot spots.'' He called for greater control over religious activities, saying the government must not allow religion to be used to promote separatist tendencies. Xinjiang's government chief, Tomur Dawamat, also warned last month of ``social scum'' aided by foreigners who sought to ``oppose Xinjiang remaining in the big family of the motherland.'' China has said little about the democratic pressures in Mongolia that forced that country's Communist Party leadership to resign. But according to one Soviet diplomat, the Chinese believe there is a real danger the Mongol reform movement will spill over into China's Inner Mongolia. Some 3.5 million Mongols live in the region, more than the 2 million ethnic brothers across the border in Mongolia. But China's Mongols, who conquered the country under Genghis Khan in the 13th century, are outnumbered in Inner Mongolia by 18 million Hans. They also lack the cultural and religious unity of the Tibetans and Moslems. China's anti-religion and forced assimilation policies of the 1950s and 1960s led to bloody clashes, including a failed Tibetan uprising in 1959 that drove the Dalai Lama into exile. Since the late 1970s Beijing has tried to make amends by rebuilding places of worship and encouraging traditional culture and language. Minorities are exempted from the one-child population policy and are beneficiaries of educational and anti-poverty programs. The government pledges it will improve its record of appointing non-Hans to official positions. At least in the south, along the border with Vietnam, Laos and Burma, the policy seems to be working. The 14 million Zhuangs _ China's largest minority group _ the 5.5 million Yi people and the 5 million Miaos live quietly in remote farming villages, known more for festivals and colorful costumes than political consciousness.

DOC.HEAD: Pulitzer Winners Whoop It Up
DOC.TEXT: Jim Murray never figured his much-read sports columns would pull a Pulitzer Prize. ``I always thought Pulitzers were for overturning a government or exposing a scandal in the stock market,'' said the 70-year-old Los Angeles Times sports columnist, who won the prize for commentary. ``I thought Walter Lippmann got Pulitzers, not us guys.'' Murray, who's been writing columns for 30 years, is the fourth sports columnist to win a Pulitzer Prize. Across the country Thursday, champagne flowed freely as winners of the coveted prizes whooped it up. ``We haven't had this much excitement in this town since the Union cavalry and the Confederate cavalry chased each other up Main Street in 1862,'' said Bill Coughlin, executive editor of the Washington (N.C.) Daily News, covered with champagne in a newsroom ringing with shouts and marching music. The Daily News won one of two Pulitzers for public service journalism for revealing that the city water supply was contaminated with carcinogens. The Philadelphia Inquirer won the other public service Pulitzer, for revealing a threat in blood supplies. The newspaper has taken 17 Pulitzers in 16 years. Gilbert Gaul, 38, who wrote the prize-winning series, won a Pulitzer for investigative reporting at the Pottsville (Pa.) Republican in 1979. Nicholas D. Kristof, 30, and Sheryl WuDunn, 30, of The New York Times, who were married shortly before going overseas in March 1989, took the international reporting prize for their coverage of China's political turmoil. ``Champagne will be a bit tough to find but we'll certainly celebrate with Great Wall wine,'' Kristof said in Beijing. At the San Francisco Chronicle, co-workers dragged a stunned Allan Temko, 66, winner of the criticism prize, off to celebrate. ``Is it true?'' asked Temko. ``How extraordinary. I've always been a bridesmaid.'' ``I'm literally speechless,'' said Tamar Stieber, 34, of the Albuquerque Journal, whose reports linking the dietary supplement L-tryptophan to a rare blood disorder won the specialized reporting prize. ``It's wonderful of course _ kind of like a lifelong dream,'' said Dave Curtin, 34, winning feature writer, at the Colorado Springs Gazette Telegraph. Curtin wrote about a family's struggle to recover after its members were severely burned in an explosion that leveled their home. David C. Turnley's images of world upheavals won him the feature photography prize. The winning portfolio by the Paris-based photographer for the Detroit Free Press _ ``The Year in Revolution'' _ contained eight pictures from China, two from the Berlin Wall, two from Czechoslovakia and eight from Romania. Turnley, 34, got the word in Johannesburg, South Africa, in a conference call his editors set up, supposedly to talk about pending assignments. ``All I can say is I really wanted to win it in Buffalo and now I have,'' said Tom Toles, 38, at The Buffalo News, who won for his cartoons. ``Buffalo has had its hard times and I have a special feeling for the city.'' Not everyone was surprised. ``I can't say it was unexpected,'' said Executive Editor Robert Ingle of the San Jose Mercury News, winner in general news reporting for its coverage of the Oct. 17 earthquake. ``Everybody who saw our coverage from the outside and the inside said it was extraordinary.'' In Minneapolis, Executive Editor Joel Kramer of the Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul told a packed newsroom that ``old-fashioned gumshoe reporting'' produced the story that won the investigative reporting prize. The winner by Lou Kilzer, 39, and Chris Ison, 32, exposed the St. Paul fire chief's alleged ties to people who profited from arson, like companies that received millions of dollars in insurance money. But 90 minutes into the celebrating, Kramer announced: ``This party's almost over. We've got to put a paper out tomorrow.'' Author Oscar Hijuelos, 38, was relaxing at a friend's house when he heard his book won the prize for fiction. ``The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love'' tells of Cuban brothers who immigrate to the United States and find minor celebrity on an episode of ``I Love Lucy.'' ``This is so unexpected,'' Hijuelos said. ``My mother will be happy.'' Writer Dale Maharidge and photographer Michael Williamson of The Sacramento Bee won the general nonfiction prize for ``And Their Children After Them.'' The book picks up 50 years after James Agee's ``Let Us Now Praise Famous Men,'' about 22 Alabama sharecroppers. ``I really felt my odds were better in the lottery than for this,'' said Williamson. Sebastian de Grazia, 72-year-old winner of the biography prize for his ``Machiavelli In Hell,'' said a celebration was planned at his Princeton, N.J., home with ``the traditional bottle of red wine.'' ``It has to be Tuscan wine,'' he added, in honor of his subject. Poetry winner Charles Simic, 51, was in Delaware on a reading tour. ``I always hate to get these calls from my wife,'' he said. ``I always think something happened, like the car got wrecked or the basement is overflooded. But I could hear by her voice there was something special, and she told me right away. It astonished me.'' Second-time Pulitzer winner August Wilson, 44, who earned the drama prize for ``The Piano Lesson,'' said his first thought was ```Wow, this is No. 2.' It made me want to go right to my typewriter and start another one.'' Composer Mel Powell, 67, was giving a lesson when he learned he had won the music prize for ``Duplicates: A Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra,'' which was commissioned for the Los Angeles Philharmonic. ``I expect (my students) will pay much more attention to what I say now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Slightly, Nikkei Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened slightly against the Japanese yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange lost moderately. The dollar closed the week at 158.42 yen, up 0.42 yen from Thursday's close of 158.00 yen. After opening at 158.27 yen, the currency ranged between 158.22 yen and 158.48 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 409.28 points, or 1.38 percent, closing at 29,213.92. The Nikkei index gained 182.92 points Thursday. In the bond market, the price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds slipped 0.26 points to 86.04 as of 3:00 p.m., down from Thursday's close of 86.30. Their yield rose to 7.350 percent from the previous day's 7.295 percent. Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., attributed the Nikkei index's fall to index-linked arbitrage selling after Thursday's gains. Such arbitrage trading attempts to take profits from differences between stocks and stock index futures.

DOC.HEAD: Asking Price For a Sentimental Journey Can Top $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: A pilot on a sentimental journey once upon a time could pick up a surplus World War II fighter for about $2,000. But the asking price now can soar higher than $1 million. Hoping to cash in on a craze that has become a rich man's hobby, the Museum of Flying in this city with a rich aviation history plans an auction of historic aircraft on May 19 and 20. ``We believe this will be the most historic auction of antique aircraft ever,'' museum President David Price said. ``It's like mounting a Broadway show. You don't know if it's going to work until opening night.'' Apollo astronauts Wally Schirra and Buzz Aldrin were among aerospace notables who showed up Thursday to lend their support at a preview of the planes listed for sale. Planes that were once abandoned in rusty hangars and barns have been lovingly restored. P-51 Mustang fighters that once escorted bombers through Nazi flak sport fresh paint jobs and jaunty names like ``Stiletto.'' A few years after the war, Price said, a shrewd bargainer could pick up a surplus Mustang at a country air field for as little as $2,000. The same plane now commands a $500,000 pricetag or better. A rare restored P-38 Lightning twin-boom fighter of the sort that once knocked down Japanese ``Zero'' fighters in the Pacific is on the auction block for more than $1 million. Rarity dictates price. ``Unfortunately, they are perishable,'' Price said. ``If you don't fly them, they deteriorate. And sometimes, they crash.'' Proceeds of the auction will support aviation scholarships and museum restoration. Price hopes some investors or altruists will buy airplanes, then keep them at the museum where they will be maintained in flying condition. A rich history has flamed the passion for buying and flying such planes, said Price, who operates golf courses for a living but comes to life when he is flying a Spitfire dubbed ``Evelyn.'' Hundreds of thousands of people attend air shows every year and the Air & Space Museum in Washington is the best attended of all the Smithsonian Institution displays. ``The fighter planes hark back to chivalry and knighthood,'' Price said. ``The men who flew them were heroes, and everyone responds to that, I think.'' Children, particularly, are drawn to the flying exhibits, Price said. ``The kids can smell the gasoline, and they can see that these airplanes are not relics,'' Price said. ``They're not mummified.'' ``These planes are works of art in their own right,'' said Donald Douglas Jr., whose father built the DC-3 and countless other planes made famous in war and peace. The auction will be held at the museum grounds, next to the Santa Monica Airport's runways, on the site where Army Air Corps planes built by Douglas departed in 1924 on a historic round-the-world flight. One of the biplanes from that flight hangs in the museum. Another is at the Air & Space Museum in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Prostitute In Barney Frank Controversy Pleads Innocent to Drug Charges
DOC.TEXT: The male prostitute at the center of ethics allegations against Rep. Barney Frank has pleaded innocent to drug and assault charges stemming from a traffic confrontation with an off-duty police officer. District of Columbia Superior Court Hearing Commissioner Kaye Christian on Thursday ordered Stephen L. Gobie held in lieu of $2,500 bond and scheduled a status hearing for May 8 before Judge Joseph Ryan. Gobie was charged with possession of marijuana, possession of drug paraphernalia, simple assault and destruction of property in connection with the Wednesday incident. Each of the four misdemeanor charges carries a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Gobie did not speak during his four-minute appearance. His plea was entered by his attorney, Lawrence Baskir, who attorney asked for a jury trial. Gobie was arrested Wednesday afternoon after D.C. Police Officer Karen Zibrat noticed an automobile being driven erratically, nearly striking her personal car and another vehicle, said police department spokesman Officer Ed Wilson. When Zibrat approached the car at a stop light, Gobie got out, jumped on the roof of her car and broke through the sunroof, said Wilson. Gobie fell into the car, where he struggled there with Zibrat, according to the police account. Gobie became well-known last year when he said he had been operating a prostitution service out of the Capitol Hill apartment of Frank, D-Mass. Gobie, who was living with Frank at the time, said the congressman was aware that his home was being used for those purposes. Frank admitted he paid Gobie for sex but has denied any knowledge of the prostitution service. The House ethics committee is investigating Gobie's allegations. Gobie was tested for drugs following his arrest, but the results were not made public.

DOC.HEAD: Gallery Settles Fraud Charges in Case of Art That's Not Famous
DOC.TEXT: Customers who thought they were buying original prints by four famous artists will share in a $635,000 settlement between the government and Austin Galleries after the works turned out to be phony. Illinois-based Austin collected a total of about $2 million at galleries in Chicago and California for prints that were worth $50 each, said Heather Hippsley, a Federal Trade Commission attorney. Customers were told the prints were limited editions by Salvador Dali, Marc Chagall, Pablo Picasso and Joan Miro and would be good investments, Ms. Hippsley said. The prices ranged from a few hundred dollars to several thousand dollars, she said. Austin and its president and sole shareholder, Donald Austin, will pay $625,000 to settle the case. Another Austin official, JoAnne Granquist, will pay $10,000, the government said. The FTC will notify Austin customers of the settlement, but Ms. Hippsley said she did not know how many people were bilked. The agreement will become final when approved by a federal judge in Chicago. As part of the deal, Austin also will surrender 400 prints, which the government claims are fakes. Donald Austin was away from gallery headquarters in Palatine, Ill., and not available for comment Thursday.
DOC.HEAD: Congressional Black Caucus Asked to Help in Police Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Black U.S. Capitol Police officers who have complained of racial discrimination have asked for help from the Congressional Black Caucus. ``We are black police officers and expected the Congressional Black Caucus to be the first in line to support our cause,'' Sgt. Ronald L. Richardson, executive director of the Capitol Police chapter of the National Black Police Association, said Thursday. ``It has become crystal clear that even after following all the rules and going through all the proper channels, no one on Capitol Hill is serious about our plight,'' Richardson told a news conference. Black officers say top commanders, all of whom are white, have discriminated in promotion and training practices and engaged in racial harassment. There are 1,238 officers on the force, including 336 blacks. Among the top ranks of lieutenant, captain, inspector, deputy chief, assistant chief and chief, there are 61 whites and four blacks. The top-ranking black officer is a captain. Responding to the allegations, Capitol police spokesman Dan Nichols said that it ``has been our position that we do not want to mediate these issues through the press.'' ``We have asked and are awaiting them to come forth with substantive issues,'' Nichols said.
DOC.HEAD: Undercover Agents in Personnel Fight
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators are charging that Immigration and Naturalization Service officials unlawfully retaliated against undercover agents in Houston for writing to their congressmen. The complaint filed Wednesday with the federal Merit Systems Protection Board said the retaliation came after the anti-smuggling agents told lawmakers a change of assignment compromised their undercover identifies. The 18-count complaint filed by the U.S. Office of Special Counsel sought disciplinary action against three officials of the Houston district office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, alleging they engaged in ``prohibited personnel practices.'' Named in the complaint were District Director Ronald Parra, Deputy District Director Michael McMahon and Carey Murphy, assistant district director for investigations. The agents complained about a switch from anti-smuggling duty to employer-relations work created by a 1986 immigration law. Not only were their undercover identities jeopardized, they said, but they were told to falsify time cards and record time spent on employer relations as anti-smuggling hours. After writing to lawmakers, the six agents and two supervisors received low performance appraisals or were pressured to take unwanted transfers, according to a separate investigation by the General Accounting Office. INS spokesman Duke Austin said the Merit Systems Protection Board is the ``appropriate forum'' for the complaints and would not comment further.

DOC.HEAD: Engine Fails on Portland Airliner; St. Louis Plane Forced to Return
DOC.TEXT: One of three engines failed on a United Airlines Boeing 727 but the aircraft landed safely, authorities said. None of the 147 passengers and crew were injured. The engine on the Calgary, Alberta-to-San Francisco Flight 1531 failed midway between stops in Spokane, Wash., and Portland. The plane landed at 5:10 p.m. at Portland International Airport, said a dispatcher for airport operator Port of Portland who refused to give her name. United officials were trying to determine the cause of the engine problem. In St. Louis, meanwhile, a TWA jetliner bound for Moline, Ill., returned to Lambert Airport on Thursday night after it lost tread from a landing wheel during takeoff and a hydraulic hose severed, a spokesman said. TWA Flight 641, a DC-9 with 89 people aboard bound for Moline, Ill., and Sioux City, Iowa, landed safely and nobody was injured, TWA spokesman Don Morrison said. Morrison said the DC-9's pilot operated its landing gear manually. He said the tire stripped of its tread was still inflated when the plane landed.

DOC.HEAD: Record Closed in Trial on Sunken Treasure; Ruling Still Months Away
DOC.TEXT: Gold that sank with the SS Central America rested at the bottom of the Atlantic for more than 130 years; no one knows when the answer to who owns the treasure will emerge from the courts. ``There has to be some end to this,'' said U.S. District Judge Richard B. Kellam as he closed the record on the case Thursday after eight days of arguments over who should have ownership of the fortune _ Columbus-America Discovery Group, which located the treasure, or a group of insurance companies, which paid off the loss in 1857. Originally, more than 40 insurance companies filed for a stake in the treasure. That has been whittled down to about 10. Columbia University and two treasure hunters also are seeking part of the pie. The New York City school claims sonar surveys done by one of its researchers and paid for by the two businessmen were used to locate the wreck. Kellam gave all sides 60 days in which to submit briefs on their arguments, followed in 21 days with replies to the briefs. Oral arguments are scheduled for July 11. After reading the voluminous file of the proceedings and going over the boxes of exhibits, Kellam will issue a decision. Attorneys from all sides have said any ruling most likely will be appealed to the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The gold was lost when the SS Central America sank 1{ miles below the Atlantic surface off the coast of South Carolina in an 1857 hurricane. The ship was en route from Panama to New York City carrying gold and passengers from the California gold fields. The portion of the gold cargo insured was estimated at $1.2 million at the time. Columbus-America officials say the current value of the gold could be as high as $1 billion. The Ohio-based group has raised about one ton of gold ingots and coins; about two tons remains on the ocean floor, they said. Columbus-America attorneys have argued that only through scientific research and technology was the group _ made up of more than 100 investors _ able to locate the wreck. Columbus-America said it spent $10 million in the 13-year search and is entitled to the ownership of the treasure. The insurance companies say they paid off on the loss and never abandoned their implied ownership of the treasure. Not all of the gold was insured. Business records that would include descriptions of the insured cargo and proof the claims were paid no longer exist.

DOC.HEAD: Fair Skies Over Much of the Nation, Chill in the East
DOC.TEXT: Fair weather prevailed today over much of the United States, with rain in parts of the nation's midsection and chilly temperatures in the East. Rain fell in Kansas City, St. Louis, Rapid City, S.D., and North Platte, Neb. Morning fog settled over Omaha and Los Angeles and skies were cloudy in portions of the West and Northeast, including San Diego and Pittsburgh. North-central Kansas received snow Thursday, while a thunderstorm accompanied by hail up to a half-inch in diameter and winds gusting to 40 mph hit Casper, Wyo. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered Thursday over the northern Rockies and central Plains, while snow fell on western New York state and western Pennsylvania. A high Thursday of 91 degrees in Las Vegas broke the city's record for the date, 89 degrees in 1988. The high temperature Thursday in the Lower 48 states was 103 degrees in Borrego Springs and Palm Springs in California. DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Fear Of Stigma, Isolation Add to Rural Mental Health Woes
DOC.TEXT: Years of financial hardship have touched off record numbers of suicides and raised the incidence of drug-taking, depression and child abuse in rural America, officials say. Mental health problems are growing faster in rural areas than in cities, but rural mental health services remain woefully inadequate, according to a parade of witnesses Thursday at the first of three nationwide hearings by the National Advisory Mental Health Council and the National Mental Health Leadership Forum. ``Rural America has gone through some wrenching times,'' said Bob Bergland, executive vice president of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association. ``Mining, timber and farming went to pot in the past decade,'' he said. ``The repercussions were painful _ record numbers of farm foreclosures, high unemployment and a death spiral for many rural enterprises.'' Paul Lasley, associate professor of sociology at Iowa State University said the isolation, fierce independence and fear of being stigmatized set rural residents apart from urbanites with mental disorders. ``When adversity struck in rural America, the victims were often left alone to deal with their problems,'' he said. Lasley recalled how one central Iowa farmer asked to resign from his church's board of deacons once it was learned he had lost his farm. ``At the very time that social support was needed, his own church cast him aside,'' he said. Myrt Armstrong, executive director of the Mental Health Association in North Dakota, said that out of 70 suicides in North Dakota last year, 20 were directly farm-related. ``In the heartland, we have always lived by rules like `where there's a will, there's a way' or `hard work never killed anyone' or even `you reap what you sow,''' she said. ``But those who have had a steel determination and have worked extremely hard are reaping a bitter harvest, often ending in depression and suicide.'' That stoic independence admired in rural people has become a roadblock to seeking help, Bergland said. ``Heaven knows you'll never get a farmer to walk voluntarily into a mental health center and ask someone to hold his hand,'' he said. Several who spoke described farm families who cling to their privacy and fear letting others in on their problems. That, in turn, deepens their isolation, raises their anxiety, and leads them to feeling guilty and ashamed. The key to restoring the fabric of rural America, the experts said, lies in dispelling the fear of reaching out for help. Bergland suggested that mental health facilities be combined with other health-care centers to lessen the stigma, and that mental health training be geared more toward the needs of rural communities. Said Armstrong: ``The only hope for people in this kind of trouble lies in other people _ people who can listen, help sort things out, and make intelligent referrals to other resources.'' ``The fabric of rural life has been torn, and once mended will never be quite the same again,'' she said. ``Healing is possible, and we hope that if we pay attention to the healing process, and mend the fabric with care, we will wind up with a whole cloth once again.''

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Falls, Dollar Up Moderately
DOC.TEXT: Prices fell in light trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today, and the dollar rose moderately against the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 182.92 points Thursday, lost 409.28 points, or 1.38 percent, closing the week at 29,213.92. Trading was thin, with 320 million shares changing hands on the market's first section, down from Thursday's 430 million shares. ``Volume was extremely small. The index came down on small-lot selling amid a wait-and-see mood, rather than in active buying and selling,'' said a dealer with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities who spoke on condition of anonymity. The dealer said many market participants retreated to the sidelines to watch movements in the foreign exchange and bond markets. Yoshihide Koyama, an equity analyst with Nikko Securites, also attributed the decline in the Nikkei index to investor worries over speculation that Japan's central bank may raise its official discount rate once again in an attempt to halt the yen's recent decline. A Bank of Japan official refused to comment on the speculation. On March 20 the bank raised its key rate, charged on loans to commercial banks, by 1 percentage point to 5.25 percent. Higher interest rates tend to support a country's currency but discourage stock investment. On the foreign exchange market, the dollar ended the week at 158.42 yen, up 0.42 yen from Thursday's close of 158.00 yen. After opening at 158.27 yen, the currency ranged between 158.22 yen and 158.48 yen. Currency dealers said trading was quiet throughout the day as most overseas markets were closed for the Good Friday holiday. Kouhei Kuroda, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the dollar stayed in a very narrow range because of the small number of market players and no major market-related news. On the bond market, the price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 85.90 points, down from Thursday's close of 86.30. Their yield rose to 7.380 percent from the previous day's 7.295 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister: France Victim of `Flase Trial' Over Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said France had been the victim of a ``false trial'' after newspapers across Europe criticized his praise of Libya for aiding the release of three hostages held by Palestinian guerrillas. The hostages _ a French woman, her Belgian companion and their young child _were freed in Beirut this week and emerged from seclusion Thursday, when they met briefly with the media. But they refused to answer questions, saying any comment might jeopardize efforts to free four other Belgians being held. Since arriving in France on Tuesday, Jacqueline Valente, Fernand Houtekins and their daughter, Sophie-Liberte, had stayed at a military hospital outside Paris. Later Thursday, the three left for Belgium, according to Ms. Valente's brother-in-law, Andre Metral. At the news conference, Houtekins said the Belgian government had requested ``total discretion'' while it negotiated to free four of his relatives still in captivity. Meanwhile, France insisted it did not deal directly with the Fatah-Revolutionary Council, led by terrorist Abu Nidal, and denied obtaining the hostages' freedom by agreeing to give Libya three Mirage fighter jets. Dumas, questioned Thursday by the Senate Committee on Defense and Foreign Affairs, said there were ``no transactions with the abductors'' and ``no link'' between the hostages and the three warplanes. The hostages' release was obtained through contacts with several Arab countries, including Syria, Morocco and Egypt as well as Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi, he said. President Francois Mitterrand Thursday sent telegrams of thanks to Morocco's King Hassan II, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Algerian President Chadli Bendjedid. Dumas said the release of the airplanes _ which had been held for four years after Libya sent them back to France for repairs _ did not violate a European Community embargo on arms deliveries to Libya. Since the hostages' release, questions have emerged about several details of their abduction. The daughter of Houtekins and Ms. Valente was widely described as a 2-year-old, born in captivity after the family's yacht was seized in the eastern Mediterranean in November 1987. But Metral said Wednesday the girl was 4, roughly the age she appears to be physically. That led to speculation in the French press that the group may have been abducted much earlier than previously reported. Metral also said the ex-hostages were held in Lebanon, not Libya as widely believed. The Abu Nidal group reportedly has linked freedom for the remaining Belgians to the release of a Palestinian jailed in Belgium for a terrorist attack. In addition to the hostages held by Abu Nidal's organization, 18 Westerners are held in Lebanon, mainly by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups. They include eight Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped on March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: LA County Coroner Quits As Understaffed Office Buckles Under Load
DOC.TEXT: The county coroner announced his resignation amid reports that the high homicide rate is straining his staff, slowing autopsies and causing bodies to be left on the streets for hours. Ronald Kornblum, 57, will step down July 1 after eight years on the job because the administrative job was unfulfilling and he wants to resume teaching and writing, Coroner's Department spokesman Bob Dambacher said Thursday. The office has come under fire for moving too slowly on autopsies, leaving bodies at crime and accident scenes for hours and, most embarrassingly, bouncing corpses onto freeways from old coroner vehicles with bad door locks. A recent audit found that staff shortages coupled with a high homicide rate is straining the coroner's office to the breaking point. Kornblum, who declined to comment on his resignation, took over as coroner for the nation's most populous county in 1982. He replaced Thomas Noguchi, who was removed for serving as a consultant on cases outside the county. The low-key Kornblum's style contrasted with Noguchi, the ``coroner to the stars'' who wrote a best-selling book about his better-known cases. As the chief medical examiner-coroner, Kornblum directed a staff of 160 responsible for an annual caseload of about 18,000 deaths, including 7,000 bodies that require autopsies. ``Overall, the report indicates the coroner is fulfilling his legal responsibilities but is experiencing operation and managerial difficulties,'' Los Angeles County Auditor-Controller Mark Bloodgood said in a letter accompanying the audit. Kornblum said he agreed with most of the report's suggestions and that the office was implementing some of them, but he said certain changes _ such as processing all bodies in 24 hours _ were impossible. ``Considering the limited size of the department's budget and the overwhelming workload, this goal is neither achievable nor realistic, although highly desirable,'' he said. Kornblum was defended by some county officials, including Supervisor Pete Schabarum, who first disclosed Kornblum's resignation. ``He has made significant improvement in the department and demonstrated leadership and strength. He has really turned that operation around,'' Schabarum said in a statement. Kornblum previously served as the department's chief of forensics medicine. Before that, he was medical examiner-coroner for Ventura County.

DOC.HEAD: Appeal Filed in Divorce Battle Over Seven Frozen Embryos
DOC.TEXT: A judge's ruling legally protecting seven frozen human embryos gives them greater rights than much more developed fetuses have under abortion laws, a laywer says in an appeal. Judge W. Dale Young, saying that life begins at conception, issued the ruling in September in the divorce case of Junior Lewis Davis and Mary Sue Davis. The only contested portion of the divorce was what to do with the seven embryos, which the Davises created in December 1988 in an in vitro fertilization program at a Knoxville hospital. The two-day-old embryos have been frozen since then. Testimony at the divorce trial indicated the embryos have developed to between four and eight cells each. Mrs. Davis, 29, testified that said she wanted control of the embryos in an attempt to have children. She cannot have children naturally. Davis, 31, said he did not want the embryos used in any fashion _ especially by his ex-wife _ without his consent. After hearing four days of testimony, Young accorded the embryos the same legal status as children would have in a custody dispute between their parents. He then awarded custody of the embryos to Mrs. Davis, though he also barred her from using them until appeals are decided. Davis' lawyer, Janet Mayfield, filed an appeal Thursday in the state Court of Appeals. ``Inexplicably, Judge Young determined that all the previous decisions and statutory guidelines were irrelevant for determining when the unborn enjoy a protectable legal status,'' the appeal says. The appeal also contends Young should not have strayed into the field of morals and ethics in reaching his decision. ``Judge Young has independently quantified the value attributable to the existence of a four- to eight-cell embryo being maintained in frozen storage, notwithstanding that such conclusions have eluded scholars, legislators, philosophers, religious leaders, ethicists and theologians since the inception of the technology,'' Mayfield wrote. And despite his ruling that ``life begins at conception,'' Young did not have the authority to give the embryos legal standing, the appeal argues. ``Neither the state laws nor the federal constitution ... confer any protectable legal status upon the unborn before viability,'' the appeal says, adding that the decision ``cannot even be reconciled with well-accepted methods of birth control.'' Attorneys for Mrs. Davis, who is remarried and living in Florida, have 30 days to respond to the appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Four Given Death Sentences for Economic Crimes
DOC.TEXT: A Shanghai court sentenced four people to death and four others to life in prison for economic crimes, a Shanghai daily reported. The Liberation Daily, in its Thursday edition seen in Beijing today, said two others were given sentences of five to three years. All 10 were tried together, and their crimes included embezzling, receiving bribes for signing contracts and demanding large amounts in compensation from foreign businessmen unable to meet contracts, the newspaper said. The graft totaled $274,000, it said. China's official press recently has carried numerous reports of death sentences being handed down as part of a government campaign against corruption, prostitution and other crimes. Canton executed 31 criminals on one day in January, according to the reports. In the past month, five people were executed in Shanghai for robbing taxis, six were executed in Canton for abducting and raping women, three were sentenced to death in a city near Canton for selling tainted alcohol and four were sentenced to death in northern Shaanxi province for robbery, according to the reports. China does not release figures on the number of people executed each year, although foreign human rights groups say it could be in the thousands. Most cases are not reported in the national press. Those given the death sentence have the right to appeal. But almost all appeals are rejected, and executions, generally with a bullet to the back of the head, usually are carried out within days of sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Pilgrims Trace Christ's Path in Tense Old City
DOC.TEXT: Christian pilgrims carried crosses along the traditional route of Jesus Christ's martyrdom today to mark Good Friday amid tensions over a Jewish settlement established in the Christian quarter of the old city. Thousands of pilgrims began processions along the Via Dolorosa at 9 a.m., stopping to sing hymns and pray at the Stations of the Cross leading to the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, venerated by many Christians as the site of Christ's tomb. Dozens of paramilitary border police armed with assault rifles and tear gas grenades walked in the narrow streets of Jerusalem's old walled city along with Christians from around the world. The heavy police presence followed rioting Thursday near the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, but most of the pilgrims seemed more intent on tracing the path of Christ than in getting caught up in the friction between Jerusalem's Christians and Jews. ``Jerusalem is beautiful. I could not imagine it until I saw it,'' said Mervat Azer, a travel agent from Jersey City, New Jersey. ``We are praying near the place where Christ was buried. ... Tomorrow his light will be very bright.'' Paul Christiansen of Copenhagen, Denmark, said he was saddened by the pain Jesus suffered on the cross and by the current religious trouble in Jerusalem. ``We noticed yesterday there was tear gas and fighting,'' said Christiansen, 29. ``It is sad. Why it is necessary for people to fight?'' The rioting came as Christian clerics and their supporters protested the settling of 150 Jews in the old city's Christian quarter. Police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters after a priest tore down a poster showing the Israeli Star of David that had been placed over a cross on the door of a disputed building. Greek Orthodox Church officials maintain the sale of the building to the Israelis was illegal and have taken their case to court. Lower court rulings have said the Jewish settlers must return the property to the church, decisions which are being appealed. Jerusalem's old city is divided into jealously guarded ethnic quarters that are home to 50,000 Moslems, about 7,000 Christians and 4,000 Jews. The entire area is caught up in the Israeli-Palestinian struggle since the old city is part of the land captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel has annexed the walled city, which includes the last remnant of the ancient Jewish Temple, and surrounding Arab east Jerusalem into its capital. But the city's 140,000 Arab residents want to be part of a Palestinian state. The annexation of the territory also is not recognized by most foreign governments. Palestinian Christians, whose numbers are shrinking compared to both Moslems and Jews, saw the settlement of the Jews under police guard as particularly offensive since it occurred during Easter week. Today's colorful processions appeared to come off without any trouble beyond the usual pushing and shoving along the narrow stone streets. As the Greek Orthodox began their procession at about 10:30 a.m., women ran from the crowd to kiss the 2-yard-long cross partly supported by Diodorus I, the Greek Orthodox patriarch of Jerusalem, who collapsed during the police tear gasing Thursday. Waves of pilgrims were pushed along the Via Dolorosa, sometimes with Israeli police holding hands to clear a path. The city was especially crowded because both the Eastern Orthodox churches and the Western Latin-rite churches were celebrating Easter on the same day. The Easter celebrations by the two churches, which can sometimes be five weeks apart, also came amid the Jewish Passover festival and the Moslem's Ramadan month of fasting. Israeli officials estimated 45,000 foreigners would visit Jerusalem during during Easter week. In the past, scuffles have broken out on days in which the Latin and Orthodox Easter processions intersect, but Rene Koutroulis of New York City said members of the two churches seemed to have put aside their conflicts for the holiday. ``Everybody, I think, is united, and I see on their faces that they came in good faith,'' said Ms. Koutroulis, who is active in Greek-American welfare work. ``Today we are united. Tomorrow we may fight again.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman With Interest in Jack the Ripper Ruled Insane
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered psychiatric care instead of prison for a woman who tried to murder a man with an ax in a ritual she allegedly hoped would resurrect Jack the Ripper. Circuit Judge William D. Gardner found Deborah Kazuck innocent by reason of insanity of attempted first-degree intentional homicide and ordered her sent to a psychiatric hospital. A jury earlier Thursday had convicted her of the charge. Ms. Kazuck, 27, allegedly told police that in a previous life she was the mother of the 19th-century serial killer who stabbed and disemboweled at least five London prostitues in the autumn of 1888. She testified Wednesday that she never plotted the May 29 attack and only struck the man with the ax when he tried to sexually assault her. But two co-defendants, Ramona Barry and Catherine Lipsham, said Ms. Kazuck had asked them to lure the victim, Jeffrey Meka, 27, to an apartment where they planned to kill him. The plot, they said, was called a ``kacking,'' a word combining ``Jack'' and ``killing.'' The two pleaded guilty to the same charge last week under a plea agreement that lawyers said included a recommendation for lenient sentences. They are to be sentenced on May 25. They said Ms. Kazuck proposed killing Meka, draining his blood and eating his kidneys during a ritual to revive Jack the Ripper. Meka said he was lured to the apartment and discovered Ms. Kazuck behind a shower curtain. He said she lurched at him with the ax and opened a gash over his eye that required 50 stitches. ``I honestly feel the judge did the right thing here,'' defense attorney Alan A. Olshan said, adding he didn't think Ms. Kazuck understood either decision in the trial. A first phase of the trial involved the criminal charge. The second phase, during which Ms. Kazuck waived her right to a jury, involved her plea of innocent by reason of mental disease or defect. Ms. Kazuck admitted she was fascinated with Jack the Ripper, and regularly carried a backpack containing a hatchet, a drill and knives. Defense psychiatrist William Cowley said Ms. Kazuck suffered from paranoid schizophrenia and could not understand her acts were wrong. A state psychiatrist, Frederick Fosdal, said she suffered from a schizoid personality disorder but had no mental illness and should be held responsible for the crime.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We haven't had this much excitement in this town since the Union cavalry and the Confederate cavalry chased each other up Main Street in 1862.'' _ Bill Coughlin, executive editor of the Washington (N.C.) Daily News, of the newspaper's Pulitzer Prize.

``There is humiliation and indignity. The worst problem is the people are innocent. They came here only to seek freedom.'' _ Roman Catholic priest Thomas Wenski, on the treatment of aliens at an Immigration and Naturalization Service detention camp in Miami that is under scrutiny by the Justice Department.

``Now Charlie the Tuna has a reason to smile.'' _ U.S. Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., a Dolphin protection advocate, of the decision by three U.S. tuna canners not to deal in tuna captured along with dolphins.

DOC.HEAD: Three Northern California Newspapers Win Journalism Honors
With PM-Pulitzers, Bjt
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: Reporting and photographs from the Oct. 17 earthquake won Pulitzers for the Oakland Tribune and the San Jose Mercury News, while their competitor, the San Francisco Chronicle, won for architecture criticism. The Tribune award for spot news for photojournalism was its first Pulitzer since 1950. ``The work of this staff prevailed over all of the other entries because of its incredible clarity, the intensity, the closeness to the action, the way our staff really got in close, and the compassion for the victims,'' Robert Maynard, the Tribune's publisher, said as the newspaper's staff celebrated noisily in the background. The Tribune's photographers recorded the devastating earthquake's traumatic detail, including rescue efforts on the collapsed highway in Oakland, the San Francisco Marina District ablaze and chaos across Northern California after the 7.1-magnitude temblor struck. The photos were picked up by wire services and used in publications around the world. Maynard recalled when he began rebuilding the newspaper seven years ago, many people gave the Tribune poor odds of surviving in the competitive San Francisco Bay area market. ``And we just persevered and built our team, and kept getting better and better, knowing that if there ever was a day like Oct. 17, we would be able to rise to the challenge,'' he said. The Mercury News won its Pulitzer in the general news category for its coverage of the quake and its aftermath, and Executive Editor Robert Ingle said the award wasn't unexpected. ``Everybody who saw our coverage from the outside and the inside said it was extraordinary,'' he said as employees celebrated in the newsroom. ``It was the most extraordinary staff effort I have been involved in 28 years of newspapering. In about five hours after the earthquake we produced 12 open pages of solid reporting, photographs and graphics ... and we delivered that throughout our circulation area except for a few scattered areas in the mountains,'' he said. San Francisco Chronicle architecture critic Allan Temko responded to news of his Pulitzer just as co-workers dragged him away for an impromptu celebration. ``Did I win?'' he said as applause was heard in the background. ``Is it true? How extraordinary. I've always been a bridesmaid.'' Writer Dale Maharidge and photographer Michael Williamson of The Sacramento Bee won Pulitzers in the general non-fiction category for their book, ``And Their Children After Them.'' Maharidge said he and Williamson spent three years commuting from Sacramento to Alabama for their book that picked up where James Agee left off 50 years ago with ``Let Us Now Praise Famous Men.'' Maharidge and Williamson found 11 of the original group of sharecroppers interviewed by Agee plus 117 descendants. Most were still living in poverty. ``We are completely surprised,'' said Williamson. ``I really felt my odds were better in the lottery than for this.''

DOC.HEAD: St. Paul Mayor Overlooked by Census
DOC.TEXT: One citizen whom the U.S. Census Bureau almost missed this year was Mayor Jim Scheibel _ but officials promised to right their mistake. Scheibel's apartment was among the 5,000 households in the St. Paul area that didn't receive census forms in the mail. ``I'd been promoting the census and the importance of filling out the forms when I realized I didn't have a form,'' Scheibel said this week. ``They almost didn't count the mayor.'' Rod Swenson, district manager of the St. Paul census office, called Scheibel this week to assure him that a form was on the way.

DOC.HEAD: Journal Pulitzer Winner: Prize an Unexpected Surprise ^With PM-Pulitzers, Bjt ^With LaserPhoto AQ4
DOC.TEXT: On Monday, Tamar Stieber taped a plastic bag over the hole where her car's passenger window used to be and wondered how she was going to pay for the repairs. On Thursday, the Albuquerque Journal reporter won the top prize in journalism, a Pulitzer, for specialized reporting. Her stories late last year led to the national recall of a popular dietary supplement, L-tryptophan. Ms. Stieber mused that she might use her prize check of $3,000 to fix her car, which flipped last weekend when she swerved to avoid a tumbleweed north of Albuquerque. She escaped unhurt. Ms. Stieber, 34, became an instant celebrity in the Journal's Santa Fe newsroom when the Pulitzer awards were announced Thursday in New York. She was swamped with congratulations from friends and fellow reporters and with telephone messages requesting interviews. She later traveled to Albuquerque, but not in her own car, to receive the well-wishes of staffers at the Journal's headquarters. She joined the newspaper last May. ``I didn't expect it (the Pulitzer),'' she said. ``I was writing stories, working on deadline and I wasn't thinking of prizes.'' Her horoscope this week ``talked about love, not the Pulitzer Prize,'' she said. Ms. Stieber first reported in November that three doctors in Santa Fe and Los Alamos had uncovered an unusual connection between their patients and L-tryptophan. The patients were suffering from a sometimes fatal blood disorder called eosinophilia-mylagia syndrome, which caused severe muscle and joint pain. A week after Ms. Stieber's first article appeared, reports of eosinophilia-mylagia syndrome surfaced in Arizona, Oregon, Mississippi, Texas and Missouri. ``That's when I realized that this wasn't just a local phenomenon,'' she said. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued a do-not-use recommendation. L-tryptophan, an amino acid fermented mainly in Japan, has since been recalled by the FDA. More than 1,400 cases of EMS have been identified. Ms. Stieber said covering the story was grueling and time-consuming. She said she had to overcome the apprehension of doctors to act on then-unproven allegations that the common supplement may have been dangerous. ``The first week I couldn't sleep,'' she said, describing the laborious week spent with her ``adrenalin really going.'' Ms. Stieber credited her colleagues on the staff of the Journal North, the newspaper's northern edition, for covering her regular beats during the hectic first weeks of the L-tryptophan story. ``It was a story that required persistent reporting by Tamar, working closely with her editor, Tim Coder,'' said Gerald Crawford, editor of the Journal in Albuquerque. ``They had to overcome a number of obstacles, including considerable skepticism and resistance from some state officials who feared it would trigger a `scare.' ``Without these stories, it's difficult to say when or even if the relationship between L-tryptophan and eosinophilia would have been made,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Rodney Dangerfield of Editorial Cartooning' Gets Some Respect
With PM-Pulitzers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tom Toles, the Buffalo News cartoonist once labeled the ``Rodney Dangerfield of editorial cartooning,'' has gotten journalism's most respected prize _ the Pulitzer. And the best thing about winning the Pulitzer for editorial cartooning, Toles told colleagues who crowded into his cubicle Thursday to celebrate, was that it came to him in the place he holds most dear. ``All I can say is I really wanted to win it in Buffalo and now I have,'' the soft-spoken cartoonist said. ``I'm from here. I've had job offers from other cities but Buffalo has a special meaning to me.'' ``Buffalo has had its hard times and I have a special feeling for the city,'' he said. Toles, 38, grew up in suburban Hamburg. His father was the business editor of the Buffalo Times until it folded in 1939, but Toles said he never planned to go into journalism, much less cartooning. ``I drew as a kid _ every kid draws _ but I never took an art lesson,'' he said. Toles was a staff artist for the campus newspaper at the State University of New York at Buffalo. He was hired in 1973 as a graphic artist at the now-defunct Buffalo Courier-Expresss. He initially did caricatures and other illustrative work, but found his vocation when Douglas L. Turner, then the paper's editor, asked him to do an editorial cartoon one day. Since Toles joined The Buffalo News when the Courier-Express folded in 1982, his work has been syndicated nationally by Universal Press Syndicate, and he was a finalist for the 1985 Pulitzer in editorial cartooning. A cover story in the Washington Journalism Review in December 1988 called Toles the ``Rodney Dangerfield of editorial cartooning'' because he was well-respected in the profession but not well known nationally. His bare-bones style of drawing, unconventional use of multiple frames, self-described ``strange'' sense of humor and employment by a newspaper not prominent nationally all contributed to his obscurity, the magazine said. Murray Light, editor of the News, said he knew that obscurity would someday vanish. ``We always had confidence that this day would come,'' he told Toles. ``We're just absolutely so totally gratified for you and your talent.'' Toles, known for his environmentalism and outrage at military spending at the expense of social programs, was honored for a selection of 10 cartoons representing his best work of 1989. He said he thinks of his cartoons ``as an ongoing series, rather than specific ones,'' but singled out cartoons on the subjects of flag-burning and former President Reagan's farewell as among his favorites. Toles is the second Buffalo News cartoonist to win a Pulitzer. The late Bruce Shanks won the 1958 prize for a cartoon portraying an American worker pondering newspaper accounts of corruption among union leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Nearly Motionless In Light Trading, Gold Markets Closed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was nearly motionless in extremely light European trading this morning with almost all financial centers closed for the long Easter weekend. Bullion markets were closed in London and Zurich. Markets in Milan, Belgium and Austria were the only ones open for business, which dealers said was virtually nonexistent. ``It's a good day to read the newspaper,'' said one dealer for a major foreign bank in Milan. ``There's virtually nothing going on.'' The dollar stood at 1,229.50 lire at mid-morning in Milan, down from Thursday's close of 1,231.50 lire. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.42 yen to a closing 158.42 yen. Dealers said trading was quiet because most overseas markets were shut for the Good Friday holiday. In Milan, the dollar was selling for 1.6727 West German marks, down from 1.6730 marks in late European trading on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk Says he Left Cambodia at Advice of Thai Officials
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian guerrilla leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today he left his new home inside Cambodia on the advice of Thai officials after heavy shelling by government forces. The prince denied he intended to flee Sereipheap, which he declared his home in February. The village is in a part of northwestern Cambodia the guerrillas call ``liberated zones.'' ``In reality it was my Thai escorts who decided to take me by car to Surin,'' he said. The prince issued the statement in response to a British Broadcasting Corp. report, which said he suffered ``a humiliating defeat'' in Wedensday's attack by government troops. Sihanouk said that on Thursday he received a letter from Thai Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defense Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh saying he was deeply concerned about the prince's security. He quoted Chavalit as writing: ``According to our intelligence, (Phnom Penh) units in the area ... will continue to harass the village with long-range weapons ... which is certainly not safe for (you) and your family to go back to at the moment.'' Chavalit said Sihanouk should remain in Thailand until the situation improved, and the Thai government would provide him with security, the guerrilla leader said. The Bangkok Post said the shelling began near Sereipheap early Wednesday and Sihanouk and his wife, Princess Monique, and other family members were evacuated about midday. At first they took shelter in bunkers in the village because the attack was not expected to intensify, the report said. They were later moved to ``a safe location in Thailand'' after leaving most of their belongings in Cambodia, the report said. The other 700 villagers were evacuated at the same time and there were no casualties, the report said. Sereipheap literally means ``freedom village'' in the Khmer language. The prince, who heads the three-faction guerrilla alliance fighting the Vietnamese-installed government, returned to Cambodia to boost the morale of his fighters. Sihanouk, backed by the United States, last fled Cambodia when Vietnamese troops invaded the country in late 1978. He lived for the next 11 years in exile, dividing his time between China, France, North Korea and Thailand.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Penitents Nailed To Crosses To Mark Death of Jesus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD that penitents nailed to crosses for about 10 minutes; INSERT new 4th graf; pickup 5th pvs, `About 500...'
DOC.TEXT: Filipino penitents were nailed to crosses today, and others whipped themselves bloody as Asia's only predominantly Christian nation marked the crucifixion of Jesus. About a dozen people were nailed to crosses in several communities of central Luzon island, including a woman faith healer in Kapitangan in her 14th Good Friday crucifixion. Police said another 10 penitents were nailed to crosses in Cutud, about 15 miles west in Pampanga province. Penitents were nailed to the crosses for up to 10 minutes. About 500 people filled the yard outside a church in this farming village to watch the crucifixion on a concrete stage at the edge of a rice field. They shouted at photographers and onlookers to make room for them to see the event. About the same number of people jostled each other to watch the crucifixion from an adjacent lot, where vendors sold food and drinks and others set up gambling tables. A man wearing dark glasses chanted Latin prayers under a blazing noontime sun as two men dressed as Roman centurions hammered four-inch nails into the palms and feet of faith healer Lucila ``Lucy'' Reyes, 32. Her followers, mostly women, burned incense and sang religious songs. Others wept as Miss Reyes went into a trance, her body shaking on the wooden cross. A follower placed a bottle of coconut oil at the foot of the cross for ``benediction'' in treating ailments. Hours earler, male penitents with cloth-covered faces, whipped their backs with wooden sticks tied to a lash in an annual ritual to ``wash'' their sins or repay God for some miracles. They would lie face down on the concrete pavement on churchyard in front of pictures of the 14 Stations of the Cross while being whipped on the buttocks by their companions. In Cutud, about 3,000 people, including foreign tourists, turned out to watch the crucifixions, which took place after flagellants wandered through the dusty streets flogging themselves with sticks of bamboo pitted with bits of glass. Those crucified in Cutud included Mario Castro, 40, who was nailed to a cross for his 10th straight Good Friday. Castro said he pledged to undergo the bizarre ritual to give thanks for the recovery of his mother from a serious illness. Castro said today's ordeal marked the end of his crucifixions because he was now ``spiritually fulfilled.'' The crucifixions are a major tourist attraction, but they brought a mixed response from foreigners. ``The Philippines is free to do this,'' said Didier Moreau, 44, of Digon, France. ``This is just a Filipino play.'' But a Japanese Christian, Hiroko Kawashima, 26, stared in disbelief at the Cutud festivities and said: ``If Japanese non-Christians could see this, they would not want to convert.'' Origins of the annual crucifixion are difficult to trace. Local residents say the practice was introduced by Spanish friars in the 16th century, but others claim it is a more recent phenomenon.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Gunboat Sinks Guerrilla Dinghy
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli gunboat fired on a rubber boat carrying three Palestinian guerrillas off the southern Lebanon coast overnight, sinking it, security sources said today. The fate of the guerrillas could not be determined, a source said on condition of anonymity. He said the gunboat intercepted the dinghy Thursday off the coast opposite the Palestinian refugee camp of Rashidiyeh, south of Tyre. Israeli sailors ``shouted orders to the three guerrillas aboard the dinghy to surrender, then opened fire from machine guns,'' the source said. The guerrillas did not return fire and the dinghy sank, he said. Israeli gunboats patrol Lebanon's southern coast to prevent Palestinian guerrillas from infiltrating by sea into Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Bush Popular Among Blacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Replaces slashes with hyphens in lead, and grafs 4-5.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has a 56 percent approval rating among blacks, a huge increase over the ratings given former President Reagan, according to a new CBS News-New York Times poll. Only 13 percent of blacks supported Reagan at about the same point in his presidency, CBS Evening News reported Thursday. In May 1982, Reagan had a 73 percent disapproval rating among blacks; in the current poll, 26 percent of blacks surveyed disapproved of Bush, said Kathleen A. Frankovic, of the CBS network's polling division. CBS-Times polls conducted during Reagan's entire time in office found he had an average 67 percent disapproval rating among blacks, Frankovic said. The new survey is the fourth consecutive Times-CBS News poll in the last six months in which a majority of blacks said they approved of Bush's handling of his job, the Times reported in today's editions. For the last 30 years, five out of six blacks have voted for the Democratic presidential candidate, no matter who the nominee was, CBS reported. In the new poll, one out of 10 blacks said they probably would vote for Bush against a Democratic candidate in 1992, while another 20 percent said their choice would depend on who was running, the Times said. One-third of the blacks surveyed, and 46 percent of the whites, said their opinion of Bush had improved since he became president, the Times said. Blacks were evenly divided on whether Bush is doing a good job handling the war on drugs, while whites approved 56 percent to 35 percent, the Times said. White respondents gave Bush an overall approval rating of 75 percent to 14 percent. The telephone poll of 1,515 adult Americans, including 403 blacks, was conducted March 30-April 2. The margin of error for the entire survey is plus or minus 3 percentage points; for blacks it is 5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Dates Announced For Premier Li Peng's Visit To Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng will visit the Soviet Union April 23-26, becoming the first Chinese head of government to travel to Moscow since 1964, the Foreign Ministry said today. The ministry said in a statement that Li ``will have an extensive and in-depth exchange of views with Soviet leaders on the bilateral relations and major international issues of common concern.'' Li was invited to visit the Soviet Union in May, when Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev made the first trip to Beijing by a Soviet leader in three decades. Pro-democracy activists in China used the visit to promote their demands for reforms, but the movement was crushed in June. China's leaders have since taken a hard-line Communist approach, ignoring Moscow's reform program of glasnost and perestroika. The exchange of visits has marked the end of decades of hostility between the two socialist states and signaled a gradual warming of political and economic relations. Soviet sources said Li will meet twice with Gorbachev in Moscow and will make a one-day trip to Kiev. They said it is likely the two leaders will sign an agreement to promote bilateral trade and an accord of general principles on easing military tensions along the 4,300-mile common border. China and the Soviet Union split over ideological differences around 1960, and fought a brief border war in 1969. Relations have steadily improved since the mid-1980s when Gorbachev came to power, particularly after Gorbachev withdrew Soviet forces from Afghanistan and pledged to reduce Soviet military forces in Asia. However, China has emphasized it will never return to the close relations with the Soviet Union it had in the 1950s. Chinese leaders have also distanced themselves from the democratic reforms now taking place in the Soviet Union and East Europe.
