Although China has not publicly commented on such actions as the Soviet Communist Party's renunciation of its monopoly on power, internal documents reportedly have branded Gorbachev a revisionist. Li studied electrical engineering in the Soviet Union in the 1950s and favors traditional Soviet-style central planning and emphasis on heavy industry.

DOC.HEAD: Sharp Increase in Cases of Hepatitis A Reported
DOC.TEXT: Reported cases of hepatitis A in the United States increased 58 percent between 1983 and 1989, the federal Centers for Disease Control said. Hepatitis A, a liver inflammation usually linked to poor hygiene or drug use, causes fever, fatigue and aches. In rare cases, it can be fatal. The CDC said the number of cases increased from 9.2 per 100,000 population to 14.5 per 100,000 from 1983-89. However, the Atlanta-based agency noted Thursday that many who get the illness show no symptoms and their cases go unreported. The best-known method of spreading hepatitis A is when a hepatitis carrier handles food such as salads, sandwiches or other items that are not cooked. However, ``it is important to stress that a majority (of hepatitis cases) are not associated with food-borne outbreaks,'' said Dr. Miriam Alter, a CDC hepatitis specialist. ``About a third are associated with close personal contact with someone else who has the disease. About 12 percent are associated with day-care centers, and there, too, the disease is also acquired from someone else who had it,'' she said. Six percent of the cases are brought back to the United States from developing countries, where hepatitis is endemic, and the cause of about a third of the cases cannot be traced, she said. There also are increasing reports of the illness being spread through sharing of contaminated needles by drug users. There is no vaccine for hepatitis A, but infection can be prevented with gamma globulin shots after exposure takes place.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Thatcher Meeting in Bermuda to `Stay in Touch'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs Bush comments aboard Air Force One; picks up 5th graf pvs, Bush planned ...; Bush arrives Burmuda 9 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today his meeting with British Minister Margaret Thatcher in Burmuda is an important effort for the Western allies to ``stay in close touch in these times of dramatic change in Europe.'' Bush, who departed nearby Andrews Air Force Base shortly after daybreak, told reporters en route that ``Thatcher has a clear view of the reality of the world.'' Their meeting was one of a series Bush plans with NATO allies in advance of his five-day summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev beginning May 30. In a wide-ranging exchange with reporters, Bush was asked about Gorbachev's comment to visiting U.S. senators that Moscow can solve the secession crisis in Lithuania without any ``lectures'' from Washington. ``I can understand his position,'' Bush said, adding that the Soviet view is largely an internal matter. Because of history, we don't view it that way. I will continue to say what I think.'' Discussing the East German legislature's resolution asking forgiveness for Nazi atrocities, Bush said, ``I'm inclined to think you ought to forgive, not forget ... I think forgiveness is something I feel very strongly about.'' Bush said his meeting with Thatcher one of a ``continued series of consultations. It is extremely important that allies stay in close touch in these times of dramatic change.'' ``I feel I have a very frank and open relationship with Margaret Thatcher,'' Bush said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said on Thursday that Bush ``wants to go into the session with Gorbachev with a firm view of the attitudes of other members of the alliance.'' Next month's superpower summit, arms control negotiations, the unrest in Lithuania and German reunification headed the agenda for today's the daylong session. Bush planned to brief Mrs. Thatcher on his talks last week with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. At the time, the Soviet Union indicated it might be willing to accept a unified Germany that is not neutral. The United States insists that a unified Germany be part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Britain favors a somewhat slower approach toward German reunification than the United States and the rest of the NATO alliance. On Lithuania's strive for independence from the Soviet Union, the two countries agree on the need for restraint. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher, who flew to Bermuda on Thursday, planned to take time out from their discussions of global issues to participate in Bermuda's Good Friday kite-flying celebration, a tradition started by a Sunday school teacher seeking to explain to his students Christ's ascent into heaven. A joint news conference was planned at the conclusion of the talks. ``It's not a meeting to make decisions. It's a consultative meeting,'' Fitzwater said. ``This is a meeting to stay in touch.'' He said the president hopes to meet frequently with allied leaders, suggesting that not enough of this had been done in the past. Bush is scheduled to meet next week with French President Francois Mitterrand in Florida. ``The United States and Britain believe that in this period of rapid change, the cohesion and stability of the Western alliance is most important,'' Fitzwater said. ``The United States is firmly committed to Europe's stability and defense and to the continuing role of NATO.'' Many Britons say the focus on Eastern Europe and Mrs. Thatcher's political problems at home have detracted from the special relationship that was forged between the United States and Britain under the Reagan administration. Mrs. Thatcher comes to the session with her popularity at home at an all-time low. There were riots in London last month over the imposition of a ``poll tax'' on the head of every household, and consumer prices in the country have jumped by 8.1 percent. Interest rates have climbed to 15 percent. A recent opinion poll found Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party trailing the Labor Party, 54 percent to 32 percent. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher last met in November at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. Bush planned to play golf Saturday before returning to Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Confident He Can Form Next Government
DOC.TEXT: Likud leader Yitzhak Shamir said today he is certain his political rival Shimon Peres will not be able to form a government and that he will succeed where Peres failed. The right-wing Likud's efforts to thwart a coalition led by Peres' Labor Party picked up steam today when legislator Avraham Sharir, who defected from Likud to Labor last week, indicated he would return to his old party. Another legislator, who announced Wednesday he was quitting Parliament to avoid following his ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel party into a Labor coalition, withdrew his resignation today before it took effect. That could mean one more vote for Peres. But even with that vote _ and if he manages to hold on to Sharir _ he still would only have 60 votes in the 120-member Parliament, not enough to get his coalition approved. Peres, who only last week boasted he had the necessary support to head Israel's first Labor government in 13 years, appeared glum today. ``Listen, if everything is lost, everything is lost,'' he told Israel radio. Israeli media reported grumblings in the center-left Labor Party that Peres should be replaced by the party's No. 2 man, Yitzhak Rabin, who gained popularity among voters as a hard-line defense minister. Rabin was the last holdout in Labor for continuing the party's coalition with Likud that collapsed March 15. Labor engineered the fall after Likud refused to accept U.S. Middle East peace proposals. Shamir, meanwhile, said in a newspaper interview he was convinced that Peres would not be able to form a coalition by the time his mandate expires April 26. ``I think I have a chance to form a government when I receive the mandate,'' Shamir, now caretaker prime minister, told the conservative daily Maariv. Peres was given three weeks to form a new government by President Chaim Herzog on March 20. The term was extended by two weeks on Wednesday after defectors from Agudat Israel robbed him of a majority. If Peres does not succeed, Herzog could then turn to Shamir. Peres argued today that while the Likud leader may be able to sabotage Labor's efforts, Shamir does not have enough votes for a majority either. Shamir said Thursday he didn't rule out another coalition government, but Peres said such a partnership was impossible because of differences over peace moves. Labor has accused Likud of thwarting peace efforts by refusing to accept proposals by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III to hold preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in Cairo. Peres' troubles began Wednesday when lawmaker Rabbi Avraham Verdiger resigned. Fellow Agudat legislator Eliezer Mizrahi then announced he also could not support Labor because of its readiness to trade land for peace with the Palestinians. The defections deprived Peres of his 61-59 majority.

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl Helicopter Pilot Getting Bone-Marrow Transplant in Seattle
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet helicopter pilot who stopped radiation spewing from the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by dropping tons of sand and concrete will undergo a bone-marrow transplant in the United States this month, doctors say. Anatoly Grishchenko, 53, made five flights in three days through heavy ionizing radiation in a mission to entomb the reactor. He apparently is the first Chernobyl victim to come to the United States for medical treatment, doctors at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center said Thursday. ``This is not the normal type of patient. ... We do hope to learn some things,'' said Dr. Patrick G. Beatty, an associate professor of medicine at the University of Washington. ``It's new territory.'' Grishchenko has pre-leukemia, typified by low counts of platelets needed for clotting and of white blood cells to fight infection and disease, he said. He will stay in Seattle for about three months after the surgery, planned for April 27, Beatty said. Soviet authorities said two people died in an explosion and fire that destroyed the atomic reactor north of Kiev April 26, 1986, and 29 more people later died of injuries. Dr. Margulis Yakovlyevna, a Soviet hematologist who acted as translator for Grishchenko at a news conference, said the test pilot ``is afraid over the treatment, but he is sure everything will be all right by the end of the trip.'' The name of the donor, a French woman located through bone marrow registries in nine countries, is being withheld, said Dr. John Hansen, clinical research director at the center. Hansen said the operation was not performed in the Soviet Union because doctors there felt they lacked sufficient experience. The Soviet Union plans to open half a dozen bone-marrow transplant centers within the next two years and while Chernobyl is not the sole reason, ``it's the first factor,'' she said. Hospital officials said the Soviet government will pay for the operation. Bone-marrow transplants usually cost between $150,000 to $185,000. Grishchenko recovered from an initial bout with radiation sickness but was found to have pre-leukemia in September 1988. Hansen and Beatty rated his chance of recovery at 25 percent to 75 percent. Grishchenko said he could see little of the plant through the ``heated air'' but could tell ``it was destroyed.'' Despite lead plates on the Mi-28 helicopters and a lead-lined suit he wore, Grishchenko said heat from the radiation was intense. No one he knew resisted orders to participate in the operation, although ``no one in his group of pilots didn't speak of the danger,'' the translator said. ``He knew something about the order of danger to himself.'' Grishchenko and a handful of others in the operation were named heroes of the Soviet Union, a designation equivalent to the Congressional Medal of Honor.

DOC.HEAD: East German Government Ready for Unification Talks
With PM-Germany-Future, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 2nd pvs, `I am...' to UPDATE with West German minister calling for talks. Pick up 3rd pvs, `Parliament chose...'
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's newly named prime minister, Lothar de Maiziere, said he is ready to begin the process of uniting his economically troubled nation with West Germany. ``I am very satisfied all the excitement of the last days and weeks is over and we can get down to work,'' he told West German television Thursday night. West Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said in an interview published today that it is time for the two German nations to prepare for unification talks with the superpowers. Genscher told the Cologne Express newspaper there was the ``highest measure of agreement'' between the two Germanys and that ``with such a common interest we Germans could be the architects of an undivided Europe.'' Genscher has called for a meeting with his newly appointed East German counterpart, Markus Meckel, to begin laying the groundwork for a united German position in the unity talks. Parliament chose de Maiziere as prime minister on Thursday and embraced the Christian Democrat leader's sweeping plan for rapid reunification of Germany. One of de Maiziere's first acts as prime minister was to ease travel restrictions between the Germanys during the four-day Easter holiday, which started today. The nation's first freely elected legislature also apologized to Jews for Nazi atrocities and promised to pay reparations and seek diplomatic ties with Israel. Israel has long demanded reparations and an East German apology for Nazi crimes as a condition for diplomatic relations. By approving de Maiziere's broad coalition Cabinet, Parliament set up a transitional government whose main task will be to negotiate the terms of creating a single Germany. Before Parliament met, members of de Maiziere's coalition Cabinet agreed that a united Germany should remain part of NATO and that East Germany should merge its currency with West Germany's by July 1. But the coalition also demanded that East Germans retain some of their socialist benefits, such as housing and job guarantees. De Maiziere said reunification may not come next year, as West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has said. ``It can be realistic, but it doesn't have to be realistic,'' he said of Kohl's prediction. Unification talks will be held with West Germany and the four victorious World War II allies that divided the country: the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France. The 400-member Parliament put de Maiziere and his 24-member Cabinet in power by a vote of 265-108, with nine abstentions. Eighteen lawmakers were absent. The government replaces the Communist caretaker government that had been running the country since East Germans overthrew the hard-line regime of Erich Honecker in October. In a series of conciliatory gestures, Parliament affirmed the legitimacy of Poland's postwar borders, which include former German lands. It also apologized for East Germany's role in the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, which crushed the Prague Spring reforms, and for the deaths of 20 million Soviets during World War II. De Maiziere, a 50-year-old lawyer whose conservative coalition finished first in the nation's first free elections March 18, rose to power by promising Western prosperity through quick unification. The government's agreement on reunification contained several compromises that could put de Maiziere at odds with Kohl, his mentor. It calls for a 1-1 conversion of East German marks for West German marks when the nations merge their currencies. West Germany's central bank has proposed a 2-1 rate for all but small savings accounts.

DOC.HEAD: Civil War's 15th Anniversary, New Mediation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with pope issuing Good Friday appeal. Pick up 4th pvs, `The pact...'
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's civil war entered its 16th year today, and an Arab League envoy renewed efforts to settle the conflict, which has killed 150,000 people. The latest stage of the war, a battle for power in Lebanon's Christian enclave, continued with artillery and machine gun skirmishing. Pope John Paul II, meanwhile, issued a new appeal for a halt to the ``fratricidal'' fighting, saying dialogue and negotiation are the only solution to Lebanon's conflicts. ``The drama of Lebanon must end ... Lebanon must live again,'' the pontiff said in a Good Friday message to Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir. Lakhdar Ibrahimi, an Algerian diplomat, arrived in Beirut late Thursday with proposals for implementing a peace pact to end the conflict. The pact was worked out by Lebanese legislators under Arab League auspices in the Saudi Arabian resort of Taif in October. It calls for equal distribution of political power between Moslems and Christians. The plan has not been carried out, however, because it has been rejected by renegade Gen. Michel Aoun, whose troops have been fighting the rival Lebanese Forces militia for 73 days in a struggle for control of the Christian enclave. Aoun accuses Lebanese Forces chief Samir Geagea of trying to force implementation of the Taif accord in the 310-square-mile enclave northeast of the capital. Aoun has described the accord as ``a pact of capitulation'' because it does not include a fixed timetable for the withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops from Lebanon. Syrian soldiers have been deployed in predominantly Moslem regions of Lebanon since Nov. 1976, in line with a peacekeeping mandate from the 22-nation Arab League. Aoun's troops and Geagea's militiamen skirmished today in east Beirut and the Christian hinterland of Kesrouan province. The savage intra-Christian confrontation broke out Jan. 30, and by police count it has killed 875 people and wounded 2,369. Aoun's rejection of the Taif accord has prevented Syrian-backed president Elias Hrawi, elected Nov. 24, from spreading his authority to the Christian enclave. A government source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Taif accord ``will not be put into effect before a settlement to the Aoun obstacle.'' ``Geagea has declared loyalty to President Hrawi and has called on the legitimate government to spread its authority to his areas of influence. Aoun is the obstacle now,'' the source added without elaboration. Ibrahimi held a two-hour meeting Thursday night with Hrawi's prime minister, Salim Hoss, in Moslem west Beirut. Ibrahimi told reporters later that he informed Hoss of a plan worked out by the foreign ministers of Algeria, Morocco and Saudi Arabia to carry out the Taif accord. Heads of state of the three nations were asked by an Arab summit last May to form a special committee to work out a settlement to the Lebanese conflict, and their effort resulted in the Taif accord. The national leaders then asked their foreign ministers to prepare the plan to carry out the accord, and they reached agreement in meetings last week in Rabat, the Moroccan capital. ``It's a very important report,'' Ibrahimi said without further elaboration.

DOC.HEAD: Prolonged Crisis Looming in Soviet Union, CIA Director Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTs 4th graf, Generally, to make Petrov's affiliation George Washington University instead of Georgetown
DOC.TEXT: CIA Director William H. Webster foresees a ``deep and prolonged'' crisis in the Soviet Union, with a deteriorating economy and ethnic unrest accompanying President Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms. U.S. specialists on the Soviet Union generally agreed with the assessment offered by Webster in a speech in Boston on Thursday, although some said better times may be ahead for the Soviet economy. ``I would say it's just one side of the story,'' said Stephen F. Cohen, professor of politics and director of Russian studies at Princeton University. ``It's the downside of the story. I think there's an upside of the story, too.'' ``Generally, there is continued decline,'' said Vladimir Petrov, professor emeritus of international affairs at George Washington University. ``At least people complain more. But Russians are used to deprivation. How long their patience will last is another matter.'' ``Some say that maybe they are coming to a turning point with the economy in a year or two, but who can tell?'' Petrov added. Eric Green, Soviet analyst with the American Committee on U.S. Soviet Relations, said, ``I think the events in the Soviet Union would tend to justify that they are deteriorating. The one bright spot is that talk is now turning toward really radical economic reforms.'' Webster, addressing the World Affairs Council of Boston, said, ``The crisis we now see in the U.S.S.R. will likely be deep and prolonged.'' ``Gorbachev's reforms have undermined the Stalinist system that he inherited and have put the Soviet Union on the road to a new political system, but the new system that he is trying to create is not yet ready to take the place of the old one that he has discarded,'' the CIA chief said. ``Economic conditions have deteriorated. Crime is increasing. Ethnic turmoil is escalating. And now Moscow faces perhaps its greatest challenge _ attempts by individual states to secede from the union.'' Speaking of Lithuania's declaration of independence, Webster said, ``The situation is tense, and cool heads are needed all around.'' Regarding the Soviet economy, he said that ``attempts to head off consumer discontent have met with very little success.'' ``Gorbachev has some very unhappy consumers on his hands,'' Webster said. Analyst Green agreed, saying, ``They perceive that the situation is getting worse in terms of food and it is exacerbated by the fact their wages are increasing without any increase in goods to buy. There are some indications that this could lead to widespread unrest.'' As to Gorbachev's future, Petrov said, ``Obviously, concern is major. For a while he could get away with it because everybody realized the economy was in such a mess that no one could be held responsible. But now that he has achieved the ultimate power, he is the man to point at.'' On the other hand, Petrov said, ``To challenge him you would need somebody and something which today in my view simply is not available.'' Webster also said that elections in Eastern Europe ``do not guarantee an easy transition from communism.'' ``They will have to be accompanied by tough reforms _ reforms that are going to bring home the hardship of unemployment, higher prices and inflation,'' he said. Webster said unemployment in Poland has jumped from 55,000 in January to more than 250,000 and is expected to reach the million mark by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BAGHDAD
Company says Iraq Has 44 Pieces of Suspected Gun Tubing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with company saying identical shipments already received by Iraq, new quotes and details. Pickup 5th, ``Even if ...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has already received 44 pieces of tubing identical to eight sections seized as suspected parts of a gigantic gun, the British manufacturer said today. ``I am sure that most people will recognize the absurdity of suggestions being made that these pipes are in fact guns,'' said Tony Peck, spokesman for Sheffield Forgemasters. He said the eight sections are random parts of a 26-section assembly that would be 511 feet long. Press reports have described the tubing as possibly making up a 131-foot-long gun barrel, which would be the longest ever made. Iraqi officials have said the tubing, formally seized by Customs officers on Thursday, was intended for use in a petrochemical plant. Customs officers seized the eight sections of forged steel tubing on the docks at Middlesbrough after a Ministry of Defense expert determined that it could be a weapon. ``There is no question it could be used as a barrel of a large artillery gun to fire a projectile of some considerable size. It is definitely subject to export licensing controls,'' said Douglas Tweddle, chief investigator for the Customs and Excise Office. The company said it had two contracts for 26 sections each, and it had delivered 44 sections to the Ministry of Industry and Minerals in Baghdad. ``All consignments to date have been cleared by Customs and Excise,'' the company said. Peck said each contract for 26 sections would form a tube 511 feet long. The eight sections seized by Customs were random parts of one 26-segment order, and ``do not join up in any way, shape or form,'' he said. Those who claim the pipes are part of a gun, Peck said, ``may now care to make some new calculations which hopefully will persuade everyone how farfetched the story is.'' Iraq claims it is the target of a smear campaign orchestrated by Britain and Israel since last month's execution of a London-based journalist in Baghdad. ``Even if we buy a box of chocolate from Britain, they will say Iraq will use it to produce an atomic bomb,'' Iraqi Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz told reporters on Thursday. The paper of the ruling Baath Party, Al-Thawra, criticized the British government for collaborating with the U.S. administration to reimpose its hegemony in the Arab world and to help the Israelis to maintain their occupation of the Arab land. ``This flagrant hostility toward Iraq reveals that the predecessors of the British Empire want to avenge the strikes dealt to their empire by the Iraqi people,'' the paper said. The army daily, Al-Qaddissiya, said Iraq will not heed what it called ``a systematic campaign of slander launched by the British government'' and will continue its efforts to acquire modern technology. ``Iraq, which fought for eight years in defense of its sovereignty and existence'' in the Iran-Iraq war, ``will not surrender even a minute part of its rights and dignity,'' Al-Qaddissiya said. Iraq has been the focus of international criticism for two months over a series of incidents. The latest was President Saddam Hussein's statement that he would use binary chemical weapons if attacked by Israel. Chemical weapons are banned under a 1925 international agreement. Saddam's threats came after Iraq ignored international pleas and hanged an Iranian-born British journalist branded by Baghdad as an Israeli spy. They also followed accusations by the United States and Britain that Iraq had tried to smuggle atomic bomb triggers into the country, a charge Iraq has denied.

DOC.HEAD: Man Orphaned in 1906 Quake Becomes 68th Victim of 1989 Earthquake
DOC.TEXT: A 90-year-old man who was left an orphan in the 1906 San Francisco earthquake became unofficially the 68th victim of last October's quake. John James McDonald died April 6 at Monterey Convalescent Hospital, where he was moved after being treated for head injuries at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City. McDonald was found injured in his apartment in Belmont, 25 miles south of San Francisco, two days after the Oct. 17 earthquake. Friends who had been unable to reach him by telephone alerted the manager of the building where he lived. Shirley Wedlake, who had known McDonald more than 50 years, said he never talked much about the 1906 earthquake which left him an orphan at age 6. ``All he knew was that he was picked up by someone and taken in and raised for a few years. He wasn't even sure that his name was McDonald,'' she said. ``He took the name of the family that took him in.'' McDonald worked as a machinist and later as a security guard. He left no survivors.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 25 Killed in Tribal Warfare
DOC.TEXT: Suspected extremists from the Bodo tribe bombed railway lines, a road and a major bridge and launched street attacks, killing at least 25 people, authorities said today. It was the most violent outburst so far this year by tribespeople fighting for a homeland in India's isolated northeastern state of Assam. At least 43 people have died since the beginning of the year. All major train traffic was halted in the state after the bombings Thursday night and early today. The main road connecting Assam to the rest of the country also was cut when a bomb blew up the bridge on the National Highway. Police launched a dragnet for the militants, but no arrests were reported. The violence occurred in Assam's Kokrajhar district, 80 miles northwest of Guwahati, the state capital. The area has been the scene of a Bodo tribe bush war against the Assam state government for two years. The Bodos, who are of Mongol origin and are mostly animists, want to carve out their own state in the hills between the Brahmaputra River and the kingdom of Bhutan. The region is about 280 miles northeast of Calcutta. The area, where most of the 4 million Bodos live, covers one-third of Assam. Tribal leaders say they need their own state within the Indian nation to protect their ancient culture from discrimination by the Assamese, who are mostly Hindu. Violence began Thursday morning when a bomb blew up a small truck on a road outside Kokrajhar town, killing eight civilians. Police said the target of the bomb was a police patrol that was to pass that way in the evening. Suspected militants then fatally shot a woman and seriously injured her husband outside Kokrajhar, police said. The couple apparently supported the Plains Tribal Council of Assam, a Bodo rival of the more radical All Bodo Students Union. On Thursday evening, a bomb exploded on the Northeast Frontier Railway line near Bijni, just east of Kokrajhar, derailing three cars of an express passenger train running into the Indian heartland. At least three people were killed and 12 others seriously injured, police said. At midnight, suspected militants blew up the main bridge over the Manas River, also in the western part of the state. At about 3 a.m. today, two bomb explosions on the frontier railway near Kokrajhar blew up another western-bound passenger train, derailing eight cars and leaving at least 13 people dead and more than 40 injured, police said. A Bodo spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the ``stalling tactics'' of the central government ``may add an unwarranted dimension to the agitation.'' A fifth round of talks on the Bodo issue is scheduled to begin April 18. About 98 percent of the Bodos follow a religion called Bathou, which includes the worship of spirits believed to inhabit trees and rocks. Most of the others are Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Soviet Statement on Katyn Forest Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Corrects 15,000 figure to about 4,000 in 1st graf; about 11,000 others were killed elsewhere.
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of a statement by the official Soviet news agency Tass admitting Soviet responsibility for the massacre of about 4,000 Polish officers in the Katyn Forest during World War II. The text was translated into English by Tass.

The need to elucidate the circumstances of the death of Polish officers interned in September 1939 has long been raised at meetings between representatives of the Soviet and Polish leadership and in broad public circles. Historians of the two countries have conducted a careful investigation of the Katyn tragedy, including a search for documents. Just recently, Soviet archive workers and historians discovered some documents concerning Polish servicemen who were kept in the Kozelsk, Starobelsk and Ostashkov camps by the NKVD security police. It follows from these documents that in April-May 1940, 394 of the 15,000 or so Polish officers kept in the three camps were transferred to the Gryazovetsk camp. The larger part, however, were ``turned over to'' the NKVD administrations in the Smolensk, Voroshilovgrad and Kalinin regions and never mentioned in NKVD statistical accounts since. The discovered archival material puts direct responsibility for the atrocities in the Katyn Forest on (secret police Chief Lavrenti) Beria, (V.N.) Merkulov and their henchmen. The Soviet side, expressing profound regret over the Katyn tragedy, declares that this tragedy is one of the gravest crimes of Stalinism. Copies of the discovered documents have been passed over to the Polish side. The search for more archival material continues.

DOC.HEAD: King Agrees To Let Opposition Form Government
DOC.TEXT:
King Birendra today agreed to let an opposition alliance form an interim government, a top opposition leader said, ending five days of uncertainty following the legalization of political parties. Ganesh Man Singh, leader of the centrist Nepali Congress Party, said the new interim government will be formed by the end of next week. He said the king made the decision during a 65-minute meeting at the royal palace in Katmandu. A statement by the Nepali Congress Party at the end of the meeting said: ``His Majesty approved the idea submitted by Mr. Singh that it (formation of a new govermnment) should not be delayed any longer, and in case His Majesty is not prepared to head the government, permission be granted to the multiparty leader.'' The Nepali Congress Party and its ally, a left-wing coalition called the United Left Front, had said they would not join the interim government unless the king or their own nominee heads it. Singh told reporters after the meeting that it was possible the 44-year-old king would head the government. He did not elaborate. But political observers have said it is unlikely the Harvard-educated monarch will accept the post. The spokesman for the royal palace was not available for comment today. On Sunday, King Birendra bowed to nationwide protests and lifted a 29-year ban on political parties but did not explain how a new government would be formed or what role he would play in it. Political parties were banned in Nepal when the democratically elected government formed by the Nepali Congress Party was dismissed by King Mahendra, Birendra's father.
The Nepali Congress Party went underground to push for a restoration of multiparty democracy, and the left-wing coalition joined the campaign. The movement was formally launched Feb. 18 and drew support from academicians, professionals and peasants. It peaked with a series of strikes and demonstrations last week.
Witnesses said 200 people were killed April 6 alone when police fired on pro-democracy protesters. The government said only 10 people were killed. Birendra is the heir of the Shaha dynasty that has held the throne since the middle of the 18th century. Many Nepalis, especially illiterate farmers who form the bulk of the country's 17 million people, view him as the reincarnation of the Hindu god Vishnu.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Found in Contempt for Not Wearing Bra in Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note Contents
DOC.TEXT: A woman was found in contempt for not wearing a bra during a court appearance by a judge who said the women's attire was ``offensive.'' ``She was improperly dressed for the courtroom because it was my impression and several other people's impression that her breasts were obviously showing,'' Municipal Judge Don West said. Melissa Thurston, 21, said she was humiliated by the judge's action Wednesday and said her attire was not inappropriate. ``I was wearing a high neck sweater,'' Ms. Thurston said. ``It wasn't see-through or anything. He had to be staring right at me.'' Ms. Thurston was in court on a theft charge for failing to return rented videotapes. She was found guilty, fined $300 and sentenced to 15 days in jail, but the judge said the fine and jail sentence would be suspended once $170 in restitution was paid. There was no fine or sentence for the contempt, the judge said. Ms. Thurston said she was jailed for five hours Wednesday on the contempt charge, but West said she was detained until she made restitution. West said state law allows him to find anyone in contempt who ``impaired respect due authority.'' ``The court found her offensive and informed her of that,'' the judge said. ``I've been on the bench eight years and never had a problem like that.'' Ms. Thurston said she never wears a bra, and put on a jacket when asked by the judge. ``He told me never to come into his courtroom or any place like that again,'' he said. ``There was a courtroom full of people _ about 50 or 60 _ I was so humiliated I didn't want to turn around.'' Ms. Thurston appeared before West again Thursday on a charge of failing to register a motor vehicle. She said she wore a bra and was issued a warning on the charge. ``By the way,' the judge said, `she was properly attired today.''

DOC.HEAD: Teaneck Family Plans Suit in Officer's Killing of Teen-Ager
DOC.TEXT: There were no reports of violence overnight in this community torn by the killing of a black teen-ager by a white police officer, police said today. However, one black teen-ager, Maurice Jones, predicted: ``Things won't go back to normal, not until the cop goes on trial for murder.'' Thursday night's calm followed a night of violence Wenesday. Teen-agers smashed windows and overturned cars after a peaceful candlelight protest over Tuesday's shooting of 15-year-old Phillip Pannell of River Edge. ``We had no incidents at all,'' police Capt. Walter Pinches said today. A group of black students from 14 northern New Jersey colleges planned a peaceful march through the streets of Teaneck at noon today. The Union of African Student Organizations says it hopes the event will defuse tensions and provide a positive role model of peaceful demonstration for teen-agers in this borough of 37,000 people eight miles from New York City. About 1,000 people attended Wednesday night's candlelight vigil, in which they called for a special prosecutor to investigate Pannell's death. He died from a single gunshot wound in the back; some of his friends disputed police reports that a gun was found on his body. After the vigil, witnesses said, police pushed the crowd into the parking lot of the police headquarters and some people were trampled. The crowd retaliated by turning over several police cars and throwing rocks and other debris through the windows of the municipal building. Seven people, including four officers, were injured, none seriously. Police Chief Bryan Burke said six police vehicles were destroyed and the windows of many downtown businesses were shattered. On Thursday shopkeepers on Teaneck Road, a main thoroughfare, swept up the broken glass while teen-agers on spring break roamed the streets. Gov. Jim Florio said he saw no reason to appoint a special prosecutor because the county prosecutor is a deputy attorney general. ``I am being kept informed of events there, and I will await further investigation before determining what other action by state officials may be required,'' Florio said. Franklin Wilks, an attorney for the teen-ager's family, said he notified the borough, county and state that a lawsuit was planned. Thelma Pannell, Phillip's mother, said at a news conference that the lawsuit would help keep the case open and criticized police for their relations with blacks. ``They can kill all the black kids until people realize that it could be their sons who get killed,'' she said. Officer Gary Spath, 29, who shot Pannell, reported to the prosecutor's office for questioning Thursday. Burke said Spath, who was responding Tuesday night to an anonymous telephone tip that a teen-ager had drawn a gun on another youth, has been placed on medical leave.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Receive Soviet Acknowledgement With Anger, Tears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with official Tass statment, British comment; Picks up 15th graf, `About 4,250 ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Katyn
DOC.TEXT: The Katyn massacre of Polish officers has seared the national consciousness for 50 years, and Poles received Soviet acknowledgement of responsibility today with tears from the memories and anger at the delay. ``I regret that my mother could not live until this day,'' said Wanda Zadrozna, crying as she recalled her father's murder in the Russian woods. A statement and apology by the official Soviet news agency Tass today reversed decades of insistence that the Nazis murdered the 4,000 officers, as well as 11,000 others killed elsewhere. The Soviets had rejected the crush of evidence by historians worldwide. But for Poles, for whom Katyn symbolizes a long series of Soviet crimes against their nation, the impact was defused by the decades it took to set the record straight. ``There is a great regret that it took 50 years and the wives of those people didn't live until this day,'' Mrs. Zadrozna said. ``But whatever happens now, it is good that the truth will be finally written in history,'' she added. A leader of an organization called the Katyn Family, bringing together relatives of victims, expressed happiness at the admission. ``I feel a great joy now that after so many years the truth has been revealed,'' said Bozena Lojek, whose father-in-law died at Katyn. ``I have already received dozens of telephone calls from members of the Katyn Family. ... For us, it is a great success.'' She said there is no statute of limitations on such a crime, so the admission will have ``many political and economic consequences.'' In London, the British government welcomed Moscow's admission. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the ``terrible things'' that Stalin did cannot be forgotten. ``It's good that criminals admit their crimes,'' Solidarity leader Lech Walesa said in Gdansk. Walesa called the Soviet admission ``an act of moral justice which has been awaited for a long time.'' He said there must also be ``punishment of those guilty of the genocide,'' reparations stemming from the Soviet occupation of eastern Poland in 1939 and free access to Soviet territory that is ``emotionally important'' for Poles. The Tass statement came during a three-day Soviet visit by Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski. Jaruzelski met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and planned to visit Katyn on Saturday where an outdoor Mass in Polish was scheduled to honor the victims. About 4,250 bodies of the officers, the cream of Poland's intelligentsia called up from the reserves at the start of World War II, were found in mass graves near the western Russian city of Smolensk. The Soviets interned the officers at a camp in Kozielsk shortly after the Red Army invaded Poland at the outbreak of the war. At the time, the Soviet Union and Germany were joined in a non-aggression pact. The remains of more than 10,000 other officers held at camps in Starobielsk and Ostashkow have never been found, and word on their fate remains as a key demand by organizations representing their families. The Katyn bodies, shot in the back of the head and stacked in layers, were found by the Nazis in April 1943 and immediately used for propaganda purposes against the Allies. The Soviets maintained that the Nazis killed the officers in 1941 after they invaded the Soviet Union. Poland's Communist governments after the war echoed the Soviet explanation, but most Poles and Western historians concluded that the massacre of ``class enemies'' was committed by the Soviet secret police on Josef Stalin's order in late April and early May 1940. ``We have been missing those people for so many years,'' Mrs. Zadrozna said. ``They were not ordinary people. They were people of science, good, wise people and, unfortunately, nothing can make up for this loss. ``It is not only I who have been missing them personally, but the whole country has been missing them,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope Contamination Minimal, NASA Says
DOC.TEXT: The $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope will get slightly more dusty as it awaits a new launch date on space shuttle Discovery, but the amount of contamination is expected to be minimal, NASA said today. ``We've done all the cautionary things that we can,'' said Fred Wojtalik, a NASA project manager. ``(But) we're going to get some degradation. Some particles are going to come into the Hubble that we just can't avoid.'' Scientists want no more than 5 percent of the surface of Hubble's 94-inch mirror, the finest ever made, covered with dust or other debris once the telescope reaches orbit, Wojtalik said. A 2 percent rate of contamination was expected if Discovery had been launched on time Tuesday, Wojtalik said. That is expected to rise to 2.1 percent _ still well within limits _ as a result of the delay until the new launch date, April 25. Clean air was being circulated inside Discovery's sealed payl420. By Jennifer Dixon.
DOC.BYLINE: ALIENS-ABUSES: Charging That Guards Harassed, Beat Aliens
DOC.TEXT: MIAMI _ The Justice Department is investigating charges that immigration guards beat and sexually harassed inmates at a detention camp for aliens seeking political asylum. Slug PM-Alien Abuses. Sent as a0467. By Dan Sewell.
DOC.BYLINE: TUITIONS: College Costs Still Going Up _ But Not So Quickly
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ The new decade may bring a reprieve for parents and students worried by spiraling college tuition and fees, two higher education groups reported today. Slug PM-College Tuition. Sent as a0434. By Education Writer Tamara Henry.
DOC.BYLINE: ART-SEX: City's Clean-Cut, Conservative Reputation a Burden?
DOC.TEXT: CINCINNATI _ Large crowds visiting a museum being prosecuted for showing sexually graphic photographs reveal that for many residents, this city's clean-cut, conservative reputation is an unwanted burden. Slug PM-Mapplethorpe-Cincinnati. Sent as a0454. By Joe McDonald.
DOC.BYLINE: MOORE: Former Governor Could Get More Than 30 Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: CHARLESTON, W.Va. _ Former Gov. Arch A. Moore, a Republican who served three terms in a heavily Democratic state, could serve up to 36 years in prison for kickbacks, coverups and other crimes committed in his last term and two campaigns. Slug PM-Moore Indicted. Sent as a0443. By Jill Wilson.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CN2, file photo of Moore.
DOC.BYLINE: RAIN FOREST: Help May Be on the Way for Amazon Rain Forest
DOC.TEXT: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil _ Defenders of nature say the appointment of Jose Lutzenberger, a noted ecologist, as Brazil's environment minister could signal an end to wanton destruction of the Amazon rain forest. Slug PM-Saving the Amazon. Sent as a0409. By Peter Muello. Also sent April 7 as b0113 for use today. LaserPhoto RIO1 sent April 7.
DOC.BYLINE: DRUMS OF CASH: FBI Following Trail of Suspected Drug Money
DOC.TEXT: VEGA BAJA, Puerto Rico _ The FBI is investigating residents of this coastal community after several unearthed millions of dollars believed hidden by drug traffickers and went on a buying binge, the U.S. attorney says. Slug PM-Millions in Drums. Sent as a0458. By Susana Hayward.

DOC.HEAD: Court Decision Means Seized Property Must be Returned to Traffickers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to CLARIFY that court decision was late last year, government just now realizing implications. Pickup 7th, `At the...'
DOC.TEXT: A senior official says a recent Supreme Court decision means Colombia will have to return most if not all of the property seized from drug traffickers, dealing a grave blow to the anti-drug campaign. Judges have already returned 33 of the 430 farms, houses and other properties _ worth at least $23 million _ that were confiscated by presidential decree, the official said Thursday. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The Supreme Court ruling late last year overturned the presidential decree. The official's comments indicated the government now realizes how devastating the court's decision was. ``I think this may mean the war against traffickers is lost,'' he said. Some judges have taken bribes from alleged traffickers who want their farms back, and ``those judges who resist will almost certainly be killed,'' the official said. The government's 8-month-old war on drugs that began when the leading presidential candidate was slain by traffickers. The government began confiscating properties and extraditing drug barons to the United States for trial. At the same time, traffickers announced a counteroffensive in which 200 people have died. Barco's order to seize properties of suspected traffickers was one of his main weapons in his fight against drugs. According to his decree, a federal court was to determine the final status of the properties. Owners were to present themselves before the court and prove they had no ties to drug trafficking in order to recover their possessions. However, the Supreme Court late last year shifted the burden of proof to the administration, ruling no property can be permanently seized unless the owner has been found guilty of a crime. Many of the owners are charged with crimes but have not been found guilty. Traffickers have traditionally bribed or intimidated Colombian judges. Since August, 15 people have been extradited, but authorities have not captured many people considered leading traffickers, including reputed Medellin cartel leader Pablo Escobar. That drug cartel is considered among the leading groups smuggling cocaine into the United States. ``Pablo Escobar has not yet been found guilty of any crime. Legally he has a right to his properties,'' said the official. The government official accused Barco of lacking foresight in his handling of the anti-drug campaign. ``Before the Supreme Court decision, I told President Barco that we should target the 50 farms that we knew belonged to Pablo Escobar,'' he said. The seized farms could provide land for 20,000 peasant families if the state could carry out a program to redistribute the property, he said. But he said such a program was virtually impossible. ``The only way for the government to maintain control of these properties is through new legislation,'' he said. And any law would have to be passed by Congress, which is controlled by drug traffickers, the official said. His comments came one day after a car bomb exploded in the cocaine trafficking center of Medellin, killing 20 people, including eight members of an elite police anti-drug squad. Drug traffickers have been killing police officers in Medellin in retaliation for the crackdown on drugs. In Medellin, anonymous callers to local media said the cartel had carried out Wednesday's attack in retaliation for the torture and murders of traffickers by police. The government has denied the charge against the force. Authorities say the drug lords have offered to pay $4,300 for each police officer killed in the city of 2 million, Colombia's second-largest.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Encouraged by Signs from Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new with Bush remarks, editing to conform
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he was encouraged by signs that the Soviet Union is eager to conclude the main elements of a treaty to reduce long-range nuclear arms before his May summit with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. During a flight to Bermuda for a meeting with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Bush told reporters he welcomed Gorbachev's statement to some Democratic senators in Moscow on Thursday that he expected to initial the framework of a strategic arms treaty at the Washington summit. ``He was quite upbeat there,'' the president said. ``I viewed that as a very positive statement. We are sending the same signals to our negotiators and policy-makers.'' After a week of mostly downbeat comments about the outlook for overcoming major negotiating obstacles, the Bush administration switched to a more optimistic tone on Thursday. Ronald Lehman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said in an interview with The Associated Press, ``I think it is highly likely we will get all the major issues resolved by the summit.'' In remarks to Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and six other senators, Gorbachev ``stressed his determination'' to make enough progress in the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks to allow the main provisions of a treaty to be initialed at the Washington summit that begins May 30, Mitchell told reporters. The START treaty is aimed at reducing the superpowers' arsenals of long-range nuclear weapons by up to 35 percent, and may provide the impetus for followup negotiations to make deeper reductions. Lehman's prediction marked a departure from earlier comments by other administration officials following last week's meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. That session left administration officials dismayed at what they considered a Soviet reversal on some aspects of the START talks. The main problem, they said, was a change in the Soviet position on including sea-launched and air-launched cruise missiles in the pact and on provisions to guard against cheating. Specifically, the Soviets argued that the treaty should count air-launched cruise missiles carried by tactical fighters as well as heavy bombers, according to U.S. officials. The United States wants the rules to cover only heavy bombers, and to count only those air-launched cruise missiles with ranges above 600 miles. The Soviets want the range limit to be 360 miles. The Soviets also revived a demand they had dropped last fall that the proposed treaty require the two sides to declare limits on the number of sea-launched cruise missiles they would deploy. Administration officials have said they are willing to issue a separate declaration specifying the maximum number of sea-launched cruise missiles they plan to deploy, but do not want that statement required by the strategic arms treaty. Lehman said he thought disagreement over cruise missiles could be ironed out before Gorbachev's scheduled arrival May 30 for talks with Bush. ``But I cannot guarantee that,'' Lehman said. ``If so, I think we should be able to conclude a START treaty by the end of the year or early next year.'' Lehman declined to discuss a reported U.S. proposal to limit the number of multiple-warhead mobile missiles on each side. He referred to Baker's comment last week that ``there are some things we just don't comment on, and particularly if there's some chance that they are under consideration as part of our negotiations.'' The issue is particularly sensitive because of uncertainty about how the Soviets will respond and whether the matter could create a new obstacle to a START treaty. One U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, predicted that the issue would not ``hang up START.'' Despite disagreements over cruise missiles, the two sides have reached agreement on most of the proposed 500-page treaty, U.S. officials have said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LOS ANGELES
Report: Space-Borne Seeds Could Produce Toxic Tomatoes
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with chief NASA scientist on project denying report; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Tomato seeds distributed to schoolchildren were exposed to cosmic radiation during six years in space that could produce poisonous fruit, it was reported today. But a NASA scientist called the report ``unfounded and unreasonable.'' ``There is no validity that this presents a hazard to school children,'' said William H. Kinard, chief scientist for the Long Duration Exposure Facility (LDEF), which carried the seeds as one of 57 experiments. An unsigned memorandum from a NASA contractor described the danger as ``remote,'' according to the Los Angeles Times, which obtained a copy of the memo. But the memo said the research director at Park Seed Co., which gave NASA the seeds, ``seemed to favor against'' eating the tomatoes. The Times said the memo was written by Nelson Ehrlich, associate director of the aerospace education services program at Oklahoma State University, which oversees NASA's school programs. ``There is a remote possibility that radiation-caused mutations could cause the plants to produce toxic fruit,'' the memo said. Radiation levels in space are higher than those on Earth. No such warning was included in written materials sent to 180,000 teachers involved in the experiment designed to give 4 million students the chance to study the effects of space exposure on living tissue. Kinard, who is at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, said that no tomatoes have been grown from the seeds, which were brought back to Earth in January when the LDEF was retrieved from orbit by the space shuttle Columbia. ``To think that from this very, very small sample we have in space that something strange is happening is just unfounded and unreasonable,'' he said. Kinard said he had been in contact with officials at the Park company, in Greenwood, S.C., and ``there is not a report from Park that says that. ... They are as much taken aback (at the report) as we in NASA are.'' Jim Alston, research director for the seed firm, did not return telephone calls immediately. The Times said National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials on Thursday admitted there was an ``infinitesimal'' risk of poisonous tomatoes. They defended the decision not to warn teachers and students about eating the tomatoes, saying they should not be eaten as part of the experiment anyway, the newspaper said. The Space Exposed Experiment Developed for Students (SEEDS) was among 57 experiments carried aboard an 11-ton satellite launched by shuttle astronauts in April 1984. About 12.5 million seeds were stored on board in aluminum canisters. The satellite laboratory was to remain in space only 10 months, but because of delays and the Challenger explosion, it wasn't retrieved until January, when the shuttle Columbia brought it back to Earth. Frank Owens, deputy director of NASA's educational affairs division said the two-page document obtained by the Times was ``not an official NASA memo.'' The memo apparently was sent by mistake about two weeks ago to the NASA-JPL Teaching Center in suburban La Crescenta, which has been distributing the seeds throughout Southern California. ``It was not meant to get out like it has gotten out,'' Ehrlich said of the memo Thursday. ``Even though the possibility is there, it is extremely remote. People shouldn't have fears.'' He said the memo was meant as ``background information'' for about 30 employees making school presentations nationwide. One Los Angeles participant in the experiment, the city-run Barnsdall Art Park, dropped out after learning of the memo this week. A special planting ceremony involving children in an after-school educaion program had been scheduled for Wednesday, but park officials at the last minute substituted potted seedlings for the space-exposed tomato seeds. ``I just couldn't believe that these would be handed out to kids to grow with such a potential for catastrophe,'' said Richard Stretz, the park's educational coordinator. ``I immediately went out during my lunch hour and bought 12 different kinds of potted tomatoes and we planted those instead.'' An official with the urban gardening program at the University of California Cooperative Extension in Los Angeles also expressed concerns. ``I think it is a great project, but I can't recommend it to any more schools just for safety reasons,'' said Rachel Mabie, youth gardening coordinator for the Common Ground Garden Program. ``Kids will eat anything that they grow.''

DOC.HEAD: Jailed Raceboat Driver Sentenced in Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: A former champion raceboat driver was sentenced today to 10 years and five months in federal prison for attempting a dramatic helicopter escape from a federal prison. Benjamin ``Barry'' Kramer, 34, will serve the sentence consecutive with a life term stemming from a drug smuggling conviction in Illinois in 1986, said U.S. District Court James Kehoe. Kramer, who also was sentenced to five years last year for possession of a weapon by a convicted criminal, is awaiting sentencing by a federal court judge in Fort Lauderdale on several racketeering counts. He appeared in court today using a crutch because of injuries suffered in the unsuccessful April 17, 1989, escape attempt from the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami. Kramer grabbed the landing skids of the helicopter, but the craft snagged a wire atop the prison fence and crashed, injuring Kramer and pilot Charlie Clayton Stevens. Stevens and two others pleaded guilty to taking part in the escape attempt. Another defendant was found guilty. Kehoe also fined Kramer $100,000. The value of confiscated property and fines for his previous convictions total nearly $70 million.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Judge Refuses to Register Young `Rambo'
DOC.TEXT: A 5-month-old boy in the northeastern city of Salvador is nameless because a judge refused to register him as ``Rambo,'' the newspaper O Globo reported Friday. The boy's father, Miraldo de Moura Eugenio, is a fan of the U.S. movie character and promised to name his first son Rambo, the paper said. But Judge Luiz Fernando Brito refused to register the name, citing a Brazilian law that forbids parents to give children exotic names that might cause them embarrassment in the future, O Globo said. The paper said the boy's mother suggested that as a compromise the boy be named Sylvester Stallone, the actor who plays Rambo. No decision was announced, but Brazilian law also bans the registration of foreign names.

DOC.HEAD: Feminists Break Up `Harassed Husbands' Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Women hurling rotten eggs, tomatoes, slippers and watermelons broke up a meeting of men who claim they are persecuted by their wives, Press Trust of India said. The National Indian Front against Atrocities by Wives was meeting Thursday in the central Indian city of Nagpur. The group claims that men often are wrongly accused of torturing their wives. Women's groups say the number of crimes against women is grossly under-reported. According to government reports presented to Parliament recently, nearly 1,000 women across the country were burned to death in 1988 by husbands and in-laws demanding bigger dowries from the brides' families. While national figures are not yet available for 1989, 112 dowry deaths were reported in New Delhi alone last year. R.P. Chugh, secretary general of the group meeting in Nagpur, claimed that 75 percent of the charges lodged against husbands were false, Press Trust reported. Another speaker, M.C. Gupta, exhorted the front's members to unite against ``atrocities'' by their wives. At that point, members of women's activist groups interrupted the meeting with loud boos and started hurling eggs, tomatoes, watermelons and slippers, Press Trust said. The men fled, but the women captured Gupta and a second man and held them for two hours while they burned the front's banners, the news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Islanders Agree to Stop Dolphin Slaughter, U.S. Conservationist Says
DOC.TEXT: A team of wildlife conservationists recruited Buddhist monks and students to help persuade a group of villagers to stop killing dolphins for food, an American conservationist said Friday. Michael Bailey, a director of Earthtrust, said he and six colleagues from the preservation group spent the past two weeks on Penghu island, where villagers for years have eaten dolphins. Bailey said in an interview that conservationists flew to Penghu, 60 miles southwest of the main island of Taiwan, last month when it was reported the villagers had captured 60 dolphins. He said the residents slaughtered some for food and kept the rest in a pen as tourist attractions. But, Bailey said, several dolphins died because of polluted water in the harbor. The conservation group, based in Hawaii, helped teach the villagers how to keep dolphins in captivity for tourists. He said Penghu residents welcomed Earthtrust's suggestion to develop the island, known for its coral reefs and varied sealife, into a tourist resort. Bailey said he also has encouraged Taiwan authorities to enact legislation to ban the slaughter of dolphins. This week, three U.S. tuna canners, including the world's largest, StarKist, decided not to buy or sell tuna captured along with dolphins. Environmental groups predicted the move by companies selling the StarKist, Bumble Bee and Chicken of the Sea brands will save some of the estimated 100,000 dolphins that die annually in huge nets used to catch schools of tuna.

DOC.HEAD: Gangs Arrested for Forging Visas
DOC.TEXT: Gangs that forged U.S. entry visas and other documents for Burmese trying to leave the country have been uncovered, and 13 people were arrested, the government newspaper said Friday. Police discovered six rings involved in the forgeries. One group charged up to $9,000 for forged visa stamps and signatures, the official Working People's Daily reported. In addition to U.S. entry visas, the groups forged entry visas for South Korea and documents required by the Burmese government for people wishing to leave the country, the newspaper said. It said the six ringleaders were among the 13 arrested. Since the fall of 1988, Burma has been ruled by a military junta that brutally crushed a pro-democracy uprising. The country's economy is shattered and employment opportunities for educated Burmese are few. Rangoon has relaxed some of the regulations on travel abroad but extensive documentation is still needed before exit permits are granted.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Hundred People Evacuated After Chemical Fire
DOC.TEXT: About 800 people were evacuated from their homes Friday after fire broke out among chemicals including potassium cyanide at a research center, Essex police said. Four policemen and two civilians were treated by a doctor at the scene but were not hospitalized, said an Essex police spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The fire broke out in a workshop at GEC-Marconi Research in Chelmsford, 30 miles northeast of London. The firm does research work on defense contracts. Police said nearly 60 firefighters fought the blaze for two hours. After the fire was put out, the people were allowed to go home. Chief Superintendent Alan Gilling said the cause of the fire was under investigation, but there was no suspicion of arson.

DOC.HEAD: Luis Trenker, Italian Film Actor, Writer and Director, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Luis Trenker, a film maker whose career spanned five decades, died in his sleep early Friday at a hospital in Bolzano, his family said. He was 97. Born in 1892 in South Tyrol of German parents, Trenker served as a pilot in World War I before he embarked on his film career. He made his acting debut in 1921 in Arnold Fanck's ``Marvels of Ski.'' In the early 1930s, Trenker became a film director and writer. His first film was ``Mountains in Flames'' in 1932. It was inspired by his wartime experiences. One of Trenker's best-known works was ``Il Figlio Perduto'' (The Lost Son) made in 1934 and set in New York. Before the war, Trenker was an accomplished climber, with many first ascents to his name. Mountains were his first love and formed the backdrop for many of his films. Trenker made many documentaries. He was also a prolific writer, publishing approximately 100 novels.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Basque Associate Arrested in France
DOC.TEXT: A man believed to be a military instructor for the Basque separatist group ETA has been arrested in northern France and faces possible extradition to Spain, authorities said Friday. The suspect was identified as Isidro Garalde Bedialauneta, a Spaniard who was released in January after serving five years in a French prison for ETA-related activities. He was arrested Thursday in Douai and will be held while Spain files an extradition request, police said. Police in Spain said Bedialauneta has been identified as a key ETA military instructor by Henri Parot, a Frenchman arrested earlier this month in Spain. Parot was arrested when he tried to run a police roadblock with a load of explosives in his car. Parot is believed to be the leader of a French network of the ETA, which is fighting for independence for the three-province Basque region in northern Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Ager Killed When World War II Shell Explodes
DOC.TEXT: Two teen-agers found a World War II artillery shell in a ditch, and one was killed and the other wounded when it exploded, officials said Friday. The youths found the partially buried shell late Thursday. Olivier Delerive, 17, was killed when he tried to pull it out of the ground. His companion, Christophe Amblanc, 15, suffered leg injuries and was hospitalized in Bethune, a town in northern France.

DOC.HEAD: Tourist Complex Target of Bomb Attack
DOC.TEXT: A restaurant and several bungalows in a tourist complex were wrecked by bombs early Friday in the latest in a series of attacks by Corsican separatists, police said. Police said an anonymous caller claimed responsibility for the attack on behalf of a wing of the Corsican National Liberation Front. It seeks independence from France and opposes tourist development on the Mediterranean island. The front has claimed responsibility for four previous attacks on tourist facilities since November, Police said seven of 32 buildings at the seaside complex near Propriano were destroyed or damaged in the attack. The complex was unoccupied at the time, except for a caretaker. There were no injuries, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Robbery Victim Kills Thief on Subway, Flees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with three robbers sted four, robbers armed with retractable knife, not gun, new description of robbery. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A man shot and killed one of a group of young men who robbed him on a subway car, then fled at the next stop, police said today. The thief's companions also fled when the train reached the next subway station in the borough of Brooklyn. The robbery was committed late Thursday by a group of three young men in their teens or early 20s who were among a group of about 18 people traveling together, Transit Authority police spokesman Al O'Leary said. The shooting recalled the 1984 case of Bernhard Goetz, the subway gunman who shot four teen-agers he said were about to rob him. Goetz was cleared of attempted murder charges, but served a jail term for illegal gun possession. O'Leary said robbery victim was described as being in his late 40s or early 50s. He said the robbers ``grabbed him, lifted him up, went through his pockets, took his wallet and threw him back on the seat.'' He said the group had a gun, but it was not used by the robbers. ``They apparently were passing it around, examining it,'' said O'Leary. The assailants had a retractable razor knife, he said. The accosted man fired three shots, one of which hit a robber in the chest. The robbers and the shooter bolted at the next stop. Police were questioning companions of the robbers as well as independent witnesses to the shooting. The dead man's identity was not released pending notification of family. As in the Goetz case, the robbed man was white and the accosters were black, but police are not ascribing racial motives to the incident, O'Leary said. He cautioned against comparisons to the Goetz case. ``The major difference is Goetz believed he was going to become a crime victim, and in cases since, the people who reacted had already been victimized. Very different situations in the eyes of the law,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Jam Borders on Holiday Weekend
With AM-Israel-Easter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The borders opened by a revolution were clogged by traffic Friday as West Germans celebrated their Easter weekend by heading into suddenly fashionable East Germany. Protesters upset with heavy traffic blocked a Berlin-area bridge that was the scene of many spy swaps between East and West in past years. The government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, which assumed power Thursday, eased passport checks to deal with the holiday crush. Border guards were just glancing at the passports of Germans, rather than opening them to verify identifications. Long lines of cars clogged border points, and most of the traffic was heading from west to east. East Germany and East Berlin in general have become tourist meccas since the October revolt ended four decades of Communism. ``One hundred people have come through here at just my counter,'' said Peter Muller, an employee at an East Berlin currency exchange office. A line of eastbound bumper-to-bumper traffic stretching about 40 miles was reported near the West German city of Hannover. A snarl of 30 miles was reported at the border crossing of Helmstedt. The Glienicker Bridge between West Berlin and the East German city of Potsdam, the scene of numerous spy swaps between East and West during the Cold War period, was blocked by about 50 protesters for 30 minutes. The protesters were angry about the heavy traffic and demanded the bridge be closed to vehicles. In the historic East German city of Weimar, parking downtown was banned because of the crush, the government news service ADN said. Downtown parking also was banned in the East German city of Schwerin. Traffic was reported heavy throughout the Germanys on Friday, the traditional start of the long Easter weekend. Most Germans had the day off. Much of the traffic problems in East Germany have been attributed to the antiquated system of roads. Some experts say it will cost billions of dollars to upgrade them to accommodate increased traffic from the West. West Germany expects to spend about $117 million this year just to make basic repairs to the new border crossings. About 10,000 property-damage accidents involving West German and East German vehicles have occurred since Jan. 1, the HUK association of auto insurers announced this month. That compared to an average of 4,500 for the same period in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Telethon To Raise Money for Victims of Nuclear Disaster
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Peace Fund will try to raise funds worldwide for victims of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident with a telethon on April 26, the fourth anniversary of the disaster, chess master Anatoly Karpov said Friday. Karpov, the fund's chairman, said the 24-hour telethon will be broadcast from Moscow on Soviet state television, which is negotiating with American networks about the possibility of showing it in the United States as well. He said preliminary agreement had been reached for broadcast in Japan and ``great interest'' had been shown in Central Europe. A toll-free number is being set up for people wishing to make contributions, but no specific goal has been set, he said. ``The children are suffering. They need your help now. If we can't help them, tomorrow is going to be late,'' said journalist Marat Yegorov, first deputy chairman of the Byelorussian Peace Fund. Karpov and other members of the delegation spoke through a translator. The telethon is being sponsored by the Soviet Peace Fund in association with the International Childhood Leukemia Association of Reston, Va., and Union Chernobyl U.S.A. of Anchorage, Alaska. There has only been one previous fund-raising telethon in the Soviet Union, held in January by a children's welfare organization, Karpov said. Dr. Leonid Kelner, executive director of the Leukemia Association, said estimates of the number of children suffering from leukemia as a result of the accident range from the tens of thousands to 160,000. Karpov and others said the Soviet telethon would seek to raise funds, medical equipment and food for 1.5 million persons suffering because of high doses of radiation. They said the telethon would reconstruct the chain of events in the first few days after the 1986 diaster at the Chernobyl nuclear sation. It will take viewers into the homes of people in the Ukraine and Byelorussia still suffering from the effects of the radiation, they said. Soviet and foreign government officials, scientists, writers and artists will participate, they said. Soviet movie star Ludmila Gurchenka will be hostess. The U.S. Information Agency arranged the delegation's visit to the United States, which also included stops at the United Nations and the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, the scene of an accident in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Toll-Free Lines Stay Open for Last-Minute Taxpayers
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service will keep its toll-free telephone lines open through Saturday afternoon to help taxpayers rushing to meet the midnight Monday deadline for filing 1989 tax returns. The IRS said Friday that telephoned tax questions also will be answered into the evening Monday. Numbers to call are listed in the instructions for filling out Forms 1040, 1040A and 1040EZ. Taxpayers with Touch-Tone telephone service may use the IRS Tele-Tax lines 24 hours a day. Tele-Tax is a system of tape-recorded explanations of more than 140 specific topics, including pensions, dependents and the child-care credit. Phone numbers and topics also are listed in the IRS instructions. The IRS expects one of every five tax returns to be filed next week _ 23 million out of 111 million due this year. Four of every five returns have been qualifying for refunds. Those who wait until the final hours to file will have to wait another eight weeks or so before receiving any refund. When a return is filed on time, the IRS is required by law to pay interest on any refund that is not paid within 45 days.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Admit Responsibility For Katyn Massacre of Polish Officers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th pvs, `Although the...' to UPDATE with Gorbachev giving Jaruzelski archive material. Pick up 11th pvs, `The Soviet...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union today admitted for the first time that its secret police murdered 15,000 Polish officers during World War II, including thousands in the Katyn Forest, in what it called ``one of the most horrifying Stalinist crimes.'' The Tass news agency issued an official statement and apology as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski. Western historians concluded years ago that the Soviets were responsible for killing the captive officers, many of whom were shot in the back of the head, but Moscow's refusal to admit it was a barrier to better Soviet-Polish relations. Jaruzelski is scheduled to visit Katyn on Saturday. Until today, the Soviet Union had blamed Nazi Germany for the Katyn massacre. The Katyn Forest, located near Smolensk southwest of Moscow, was captured by Germany during World War II, and later recaptured by the Red Army. While the Nazis invaded Poland from the west in 1939 to start World War II, the Soviets invaded from the east. Germany and the Soviet Union had signed a non-aggression pact that assigned them spheres of influence in Eastern Europe. At the beginning of the war the Soviets captured the officers, whom the Soviets could have considered a threat as potential future leaders. Stalin had killed many members of his own officer corps in the 1930s, accusing them of disloyalty. The Katyn massacre of the Polish officers was first disclosed in 1943 by the Nazis, who attributed it to Stalin's secret police. More than 4,000 bodies have been found in a mass grave in the forest. An additional 11,000 Polish officers were killed elsewhere and their bodies have never been found. Records indicate that only 394 of the prisoners held at Katyn were transferred to the Gryazovetsky prison camp, and the rest were turned over to the NKVD, the predecessor of the KGB. Although the Tass statement referred specifically to Katyn, it tied the fates of all 15,000 officers together. All of the officers disappeared entirely from NKVD records, Tass said. At their meeting in the Kremlin, Gorbachev gave Jaruzelski copies of material from Soviet archives pertaining to the Poles imprisoned in the NKVD camps, Tass reported. It did not report any comments the two leaders may have made about the Soviet statement on Katyn. The Soviet statement said the archive material discovered recently allowed officials now to blame Stalin's secret police Chief Lavrenti Beria, his protege V.N. Merkulov and ``their henchmen.'' ``The Soviet side, expressing its deep regret in connection with the Katyn tragedy, states that it is one of the most horrifying Stalinist crimes,'' Tass said.
