Today's Soviet admission came one day after East Germany's new Parliament apologized to Jews for Nazi atrocities and apologized for the deaths of 20 million Soviets during World War II. In Warsaw, Poles received Soviet acknowledgement of responsibility with renewed expressions of anger at the delay and tears over the massacre that has seared the national consciousness for 50 years. ``I regret that my mother could not live until this day,'' said Wanda Zadrozna, crying as she recalled her father's murder in the Russian woods. ``It's good that criminals admit their crimes,'' Solidarity leader Lech Walesa said in Gdansk. He called the Soviet admission ``an act of moral justice which has been awaited for a long time.'' He said there must also be ``punishment of those guilty of the genocide,'' reparations stemming from the Soviet occupation of eastern Poland in 1939 and free access to Soviet territory that is ``emotionally important'' for Poles. Several Soviet newspapers' reports recently have placed the blame for the murders on the Soviet side, but until today, the government had not admitted it. Viktor Filatov, editor of Voyenno-Istoricheskii Journal, said he plans to publish archives proving that Josef Stalin's secret police killed at least 4,500 of the 15,000 Polish prisoners, the Interfax news agency said Thursday. ``The fate of the rest is yet to be established,'' he told Interfax, the information agency of Radio Moscow. But, he said, ``the newly surfaced archival documents add to mounting evidence of the repressive policy that Stalin's regime pursued toward both Soviet and foreign citizens.'' Filatov said he did not have the documents in hand and he did not give a date of publication. On March 22, the weekly Moscow News published a two-page report rebutting allegations that Nazi invaders mowed down Polish officers held prisoner just south of the western Russian city of Smolensk. Other articles have called for the truth about Katyn, and a special government commission was established last year to investigate the massacre. No date has been given, however, for release of its findings.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Thatcher Meet in Bermuda; Discuss Wide-Ranging Issues
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf pvs, bgng ``I'm looking... with 3 grafs on morning meeting; picks up 6th graf pvs, bgng, However, high-level...; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today welcomed a declaration from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that he wants to initial a nuclear arms agreement with the United States next month. ``We are sending the same signals to our negotiators and policy-makers,'' Bush said. The president also expressed understanding for Gorbachev's objections to ``lectures'' from Washington about Lithuania. However, Bush said, ``I will continue to say what I think.'' Bush made the comments as he flew to this Atlantic Ocean island for talks with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on changes in Eastern Europe and Bush's five-day summit with Gorbachev beginning May 30. On an overcast day, Bush and Mrs. Thatcher reviewed the Bermuda Regiment in front of the oceanside Government House before sitting down for a closed meeting. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher met for just over two hours in their morning session and, according to a statement by presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, discussed a ``full range of international issues facing the North Atlantic Alliessional and political leaders. It was added when he found professional organizations lacked basic texts _ even Roberts Rules of Order. _American corporations would underwrite costs of the books, their investment to be justified by the marketing and public relations dividends their sponsorship would deliver. What a great way for American companies to become known in the new market economies of Europe, he muses, contemplating how they might benefit from a simple notation on the rear cover _ Compliments of XYZ Company, for example. _Foundations, U.S. government agencies, associations and other groups might participate as joint sponsors. _Title selection would be made by a board comprised of U.S. publishers, editors, educators, librarians and government officials. Educators and publishers in selected foreign countries might also make suggestions. _Administration and development would be through a not-for-profit organization, perhaps ``International Friendship Books Inc.,'' that Benjamin is ready to develop and direct. For Benjamin, the idea isn't new. For years he has traveled the world, and wherever he went the idea was nurtured. Earlier, he had hoped to develop the plan for China and India, but scarcity of U.S. products there delayed him. When Eastern Europe's socialist nations decided on market economies, rather than economies dictated centrally by Communist officials, the idea became more urgent. Much depends on the cooperation of U.S. companies, but Benjamin thinks he'll get it. Why? ``First, as media, books are one of the few games in town,'' he says. In Eastern Europe, he explains, access to conventional advertising ``is either non-existent or severely limited.'' Next, he says, ``books are highly revered and respected by these people,'' read and reread, passed on to others, and read again. ``They're never discarded.'' It's a rare situation in which everyone seems to win. Benjamin, a well- trophied golfer who spends many hours on the course and who still must work at his own business, says he isn't afraid of the added task. He says simply, ``I'd like to repay some of the dividends and fulfillment my work has given me over the years.''

DOC.HEAD: Women's Group Vows to Topple Sexism in Sumo Wrestling
DOC.TEXT: A group of Japanese women is trying to knock down a centuries-old rule that bars members of their sex from the sumo wrestling ring. Though the group argues that sexism has no place in national sport, it is not pressing for women to actually participate in the 2,000-year-old sport with the giant male grapplers. Instead, the Women's Action Group simply wants to send a woman into the ring to present its new ``Women Fans' Award.'' But things are not that simple in this society where men still have a stranglehold on sumo wrestling. ``I don't know why, it's just been that way since long, long ago,'' said a Japan Sumo Association official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It's always been against the rules for women to get into the ring _ simple as that.'' Michiyo Inobe, a member of the Women's Action Group, said her group of 500 members, mostly women, decided against calling for the rule's outright abolition because they were afraid public sentiment could go against them. ``I think it is a kind of miniature of Japanese society in general, but many people in Japan accept sumo as a man's world, as a special society of its own,'' Inobe said. The ban on women in the ring is believed to be based on beliefs in Shinto, Japan's native religion, that women are impure. ``At the very least, we are more pure than the dirt and straw ring,'' a statement from the group said. The rule became an issue in December, when the chief Cabinet secretary at the time, Mayumi Moriyama, wanted to present the Prime Minister's Cup to the winner of the New Year's Tournament. Mrs. Moriyama, a member of Parliament and the first woman ever to hold the important Cabinet post, said she would present the government award from within the ring, not from below. Sumo officials refused to part with their males-only tradition, saying the sumo ring, a raised mound of clay 14.8 feet across, is ``sacred.'' The association also pointed out that the award was generally presented to the winning wrestler not by the chief Cabinet secretary but by a non-Cabinet level vice minister. After a flurry of media coverage, Mrs. Moriyama said she had made her point and dropped the request. The affair didn't end there, though. At each of the six annual sumo tournaments, 25 awards are presented, including five by foreign embassies. The women's group decided it wanted a woman to present its new Women Fans' Award. ``Sumo calls itself the national sport,'' said the women's group. ``Women make up 51 percent of this nation. A good deal of sumo's popularity comes from the support of women.'' Indeed, the 2,000-year-old sport has gained many female fans. Schoolgirls are allowed to join in local competitions. ``It's not true that they can't change the rule because it is part of sumo tradition,'' Inobe said. ``They have made many changes to keep up with the times.'' Women were not allowed to even watch sumo bouts until 1778 _ and then only on a tournament's final day. It took another hundred years for women to gain access to all 15 days of the tournaments.

DOC.HEAD: Frankie and Annette Taking Beach Blanket Party on the Road
DOC.TEXT: Frankie Avalon and Annette Funicello, the squeaky-clean fun couple of 1960s ``Beach Blanket'' movies, are hitting the road to introduce another generation to their corny world of surf and song. ``Frankie & Annette'' embark on a first-ever concert tour with Easter weekend appearances at Knott's Berry Farm, a down-home kind of place known for fried chicken, boysenberry pie and a replica of Independence Hall. ``There's a generation of people out there who welcome us with open arms,'' Avalon said Friday by telephone from his Ventura County home. ``It really is for the family. We aren't targeting the Guns 'N Roses audience.'' It also seems appropriate that Dick Clark, ``America's oldest teen-ager,'' was tapped to arrange the 35-stop concert tour. The tour runs through Oct. 5 and includes stops in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Maine, Florida, Wisconsin, Oregon. Avalon, 50, said there was a resurgence of Frankie & Annette popularity a few years back with the movie ``Back to the Beach,'' a 3-decade-later look at the beach-movie craze. Avalon, a father of eight who grew up in the same south Philadelphia neighborhood as Mario Lanza, Bobby Rydell and Chubby Checker, sings his hits ``Ginger Bread,'' ``Venus'' and ``Beauty School Dropout.'' Funicello, the 46-year-old former Mouseketeer who has three children, sings ``Tall Paul'' and several duets with Avalon, including ``Beach Party'' and ``Beach Blanket Bingo.'' Film clips of their beach blanket movies are also shown. ``This is the first time for her to go out and do live concerts, and she loves it,'' said Avalon, adding he and the former Mickey Mouse Club star have remained close friends through the years. ``The most asked question is, `How come you two didn't get married?' We tell them, `Because we're already married,''' Avalon said of the on-screen marriage in the last beach blanket movie. Avalon said he and Funicello recently broke in their act at Yakima, Wash., and ``they absoutely loved the show.'' ``The great thing that's happened through the years is there has never been any resentment about our image in our pictures. The adults know us from the pictures and the kids know us from `Back to the Beach,''' Avalon said. ``It's nice, really.'' There is still more big-screen action planned for the pair. They will team for another beach movie later this year, a spoof on jungle pictures called ``Surfin' Safari.'' ``Well, I'm not one of your great surfers,'' Avalon concedes when pressed about his wave riding expertise, ``but I've been on a board.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Sen. Chiles Enters Florida Governor Race, Discusses Medication
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs with Chiles saying he took prescription drug for depression. Pickup 4th graf, bgng `I look around....'
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. Lawton Chiles, one of Florida's most popular politicians, came out of retirement to enter the gubernatorial race and within hours was fielding questions about his use of an anti-depressant drug. The Democrat resigned from the Senate in January 1989 saying he was ``burned out'' by big-money politics and the grind of the federal bureaucracy. He said Thursday he wanted to keep Florida from being beaten down by the same problems and vowed to unseat Gov. Bob Martinez with a no-frills campaign. Republican officials began circulating rumors about Chiles' depression almost immediately after his announcement, and Chiles discussed the issue with reporters from several newspapers. ``I've had depression and sought treatment,'' Chiles was quoted as saying. ``I think I was depressed about what was going on in the state. ... Now I'm going to do something about it.'' Chiles, 60, said he has been taking the drug Prozac, the most frequently prescribed anti-depressant, since resigning from the Senate. He said he is just now completing his treatment with the drug and acknowledged that his depression could become an issue in the race. He did not immediately return a phone call today by The Associated Press. In entering the race, Chiles said he would limit campaign contributions to $100 even though His two Democratic opponents, Rep. Bill Nelson and state Sen. George Stuart, have already raised nearly $6 million between them for the Sept. 4 primary. That figure has already been surpassed by Martinez, a Republican. ``I look around in this country and I hear those voices in the countryside,'' Chiles said. ``One of those things I hear is that money doesn't vote. People vote.'' Chiles literally walked across the state in his first successful senate campaign in 1970. He swept home in the 1976 and 1982 re-elections, and became chairman of the influential Senate Budget Committee.. His running mate will be former Rep. Kenneth ``Buddy'' MacKay, who lost his bid in 1988 to capture the Senate seat vacated by Chiles. Martinez, who is winding up a tumultous first term in office, said Chiles' candidacy only boosts his re-election bid. ``They have some difficulty figuring out how they're going to beat me,'' he said. ``It's just part of their struggle to figure out how they're going to stay in power in the state of Florida when the tide is going against them.'' After leaving the Senate, Chiles became director of the LeRoy Collins Center for Public Policy, a think tank at Florida State University in Tallahassee. He resigned from that position late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Reported Killed in Bus Blast
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE casualty toll. Pickup 5th pvs, `On Wednesday...'
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in a crowded city bus in New Delhi on Friday, and one news report said 10 people were killed and 27 wounded. Police and hospital sources confirmed only three deaths and 24 wounded. No one claimed responsibility for the explosion, but Moslem separatists in Kashmir claimed responsibility for three similar attacks this week. A senior police official said the bomb was so powerful it ripped through the bus and badly damaged a jeep nearby. ``It is the work of professionals,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The United News of India news agency reported 10 deaths and 27 injuries, but officials were unable to confirm the reports. On Wednesday, a bomb exploded in a crowded train near Bombay, and 34 passengers were hurt. A Moslem militant group fighting for secession of the northern Kashmir valley claimed responsibility for that attack. The same group claimed responsibility for the bombings of two police stations in New Delhi on Tuesday. At least nine policemen were injured in Tuesday's blasts. The dispute over Kashmir dates back to 1947, when Indian and Moslem Pakistan were partitioned along religious lines. The old princely state of Kashmir was predominantly Moslem, but its Hindu ruler opted to join India. Today, the Kashmir region is divided between India and Pakistan along a disputed frontier. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the region. Indian Kashmir is part of the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir. It is the only state in India with a Moslem majority. The great majority of India's people are Hindus.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Police Patrols, Easter Pilgrims Parade Through Jerusalem
LaserPhotos JRL 2,4
DOC.TEXT: Under heavy security a day after religious riots, pilgrims from around the world carted wooden crosses through Jerusalem's Old City on Good Friday to commemorate the passion and death of Jesus Christ. The traditional procession route along the Via Dolorosa, or Way of Sorrow, was jammed with people praying and singing. The narrow street echoed with chants in Greek, English, Spanish, Italian and Arabic. Security was heavier than usual following riots in the Arab Christian quarter of the old, walled city a day earlier. Among those standing with candles watching Friday's procession was Rene Koutroulis of New York City, who was pleased to see people from different Christian sects worshiping together. ``Everybody, I think, is united, and I see on their faces that they came in good faith,'' said Ms. Koutroulis. ``Today we are united. Tomorrow we may fight again.'' Israeli police Thursday fired tear gas and rubber bullets to break up demonstrations by Greek Orthodox clerics and stone-throwing Palestinian youths protesting the establishment of a Jewish settlement in the Christian quarter. A court ruling late Thursday ordered the settlers out and appeared to cool tempers among the protesters. The settlers said they would appeal the decision. On Friday, scores of police and paramilitary border troops armed with assault rifles and tear-gas grenades patrolled the Old City. No major incidents were reported. Still, pilgrims who paraded to the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, the basilica that covers the tomb of Christ, were reminded of the Holy Land's political problems. An Palestinian flag, hung surreptitiously overnight by Arab activists, flew throughout Good Friday from the cross atop the venerated church. Palestinian flags are outlawed in Israel. Jerusalem's Old City is divided into jealously guarded ethnic quarters that are home to 50,000 Moslems, about 7,000 Christians and 4,000 Jews. The entire area is caught up in the Israeli-Palestinian problem since the Old City is part of the land captured by Israel from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. For most Christians, Good Friday is the most solemn of holy days in the church calendar and the preface to one of the most joyful, Easter Sunday. Lidwien van Dongen, 27, of Denhaag, the Netherlands, said she was ``very impressed that people from all over the world come to Jerusalem to walk the way Jesus walked.'' Mervat Azer, a travel agent from Jersey City, N.J., said she had not been able to anticipate the beauty of Jerusalem or the feelings she would experience praying here. ``We are praying near the place where Christ was buried,'' she said. ``Tomorrow his light will be very bright.'' Although Thursday's violence had ended by the time of the Christian processions, the day was not without moments of drama. At one point, a man whose clothes were splattered with blood and mud ran through the crowd of pilgrims. It turned out to be Swedish actor Dolph Lundgren, who was being filmed by an American crew for the movie ``Cover Up,'' about a journalist in Israel. The script called for Lundgren to fall to one knee, get up and resume his run. But an Israeli plainclothes officer, thinking Lundgren was in trouble, rushed to his assistance. The scene was reshot. The city was especially crowded because both the Eastern Orthodox churches and the Western Latin rite churches are celebrating Easter Week at the same time. The Christian feast this year also overlaps with Ramadan, the Moslem month of fasting, and Passover, the eight-day Jewish commemoration of the Israelites' flight from Egypt. Israeli officials estimated 45,000 foreigners would visit Jerusalem during Easter week.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Cancer Won't Slow Him Down, Seeks Re-election
DOC.TEXT: A terminally ill judge who is expected to live less than another year is seeking re-election and vows he'll be able to serve out the four-year term. Jackson County Circuit Judge Robert T. Mills, who has asbestos-related lung cancer, said Thursday he hasn't slowed down despite doctors' prognosis that he has only nine months to live. ``I ran for re-election last year and plan to serve out this term,'' Mills said, ``and I am planning to run for re-election again and serve out that term.'' Mills, who is on the ballot for a June 5 primary, was re-elected last year and has served on the bench for nearly 10 years. Mills is one of more than 3,000 asbestosis victims, most of them former employees of Ingalls Shipbuilding in Pascagoula, who are suing 18 asbestos manufacturers in Mississippi courts. Asbestos was frequently used as fireproofing and insulation; at Ingalls it was used as structural reinforcement material. Ingalls is not named as a defendant in any of the suits. Mills claims he contracted mesothelioma after working 22 months at Ingalls in the late 1950s and early 1960s to get money for law school. His lawsuit, filed in December 1988 and amended last August, seeks $20 million. The only cause of mesothelioma is ``exposure to asbestos fibers from asbestos-containing insulation products and equipment,'' according to the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: New Policy Would Ease AIDS-Immigration Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is setting new immigration rules for foreigners with AIDS who want to attend conferences in the United States, an administration source said today. But the White House will not support a move in Congress to take AIDS off a list of diseases used to bar entry to the country, the source said. The action would allow foreigners to come to the United States to attend a conference without revealing whether they are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, said the source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Pressure has been building on the administration by AIDS activists to remove HIV from the list of contagious diseases. Dozens of organizations are protesting the policy by boycotting an AIDS conference in San Francisco in June. Under current policy, a foreigner with HIV who wants to come to the United States must apply for a waiver. The Justice Department has been expediting that process for people who want to attend conferences, including the AIDS conference in June. Under the new policy, which was expected to be announced on Friday, foreigners who want to attend a U.S. conference would not have to reveal whether they have HIV and would be allowed to enter the country for 10 days, said the source. ``The person will never be asked if they have AIDS, so they won't have to lie or be recorded some place as having HIV,'' the source said. The new policy would apply only to individuals who are attending a business, academic or scientific conference, the source said. ``This is our best assessment of what the best solution to the problem is,'' the source said. ``We were looking for something that will work and can happen.'' Congress in 1987 put HIV on the list of contagious diseases, and though the federal Centers for Disease Control recently recommended that it be removed, the administration has said it lacks the authority to do so. A bill introduced in Congress last week would give the Department of Health and Human Services authority over the list, opening the way for HHS to act on CDC's recommendation. But the administration is convinced the bill, introduced by Rep. Rowland, D-Ga., would not be passed even with White House support, said the source.

DOC.HEAD: Fall in Inventories and Surge in Sales Reported
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories fell in February for the second time in three months while sales surged in another sign that the economy has avoided a recession, the government said Friday. Inventories on shelves and backlots shrank 0.4 percent, the steepest drop since December 1986, to a seasonally adjusted $794.6 billion in February, the Commerce Department reported. Sales, meanwhile, rose 1.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted $535.4 billion. It was the largest increase in seven months. All of the strength came in manufacturing, the sector of the economy that had been most affected by sluggishness resulting from the Federal Reserve Board's high interest rate policy. In January, business sales rose 0.4 percent, enough to stay ahead of the 0.3 percent increase in inventories. ``I think the economy is picking up a little steam and we'll see a decent first half,'' said economist David Berson of the Federal National Mortgage Association. He and other analysts view the combination of surging sales and falling inventories is a sign of strength. A sharp buildup in inventories can lead to a recession. Retailers and wholesalers with too many goods stop ordering more. In response, factories cut production and lay off workers. The February activity sharply reduced the ratio of business inventories to sales to 1.48, down from 1.51 in January. That means it would take 1.48 months to exhaust inventories at the February sales pace. ``That suggests as much as anything that this economy has skirted a recession,'' said economist James Annable of First National Bank of Chicago. The inventory decline was steepest at retailers, where backlogs dropped 0.9 percent. Production cutbacks by auto companies have allowed dealers to reduce their stock of cars by 2.2 percent despite sluggish sales. Wholesale inventories declined 0.2 percent while factory backlogs edged down 0.1 percent. Manufacturing sales surged 3.3 percent in February, while retail sales fell 0.3 percent and wholesale sales declined 0.1 percent. In an advance report earlier this week, the department said March retail sales fell 0.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Hotel Fire in Bombay; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out in Bombay's biggest hotel and forced the evacuation of hundreds of guests from the high-rise, but the blaze was put out Friday and there were no casualties, hotel officials said. The blaze began late Thursday in the five-star Oberoi Towers. It started in the basement of the 36-story hotel, which has 700 rooms. The cause of the fire was not immediately known, but one hotel staffer said it was probably due to a short circuit in the basement. Deputy Chief Fire Officer M.G. Sirkhot said hundreds of firefighters extinquished the blaze Friday night. Authorities evacuated more than 1,000 guests from Oberoi Towers and the adjacent Oberoi Hotel, placing them in other hotels in the city. Sirkhot said firefighters contained the fire to the basement, but smoke billowed from several floors of the building, which faces the Arabian Sea.

DOC.HEAD: Taj Mahal West or 125-Story Megabuilding? Trump's LA Plans Unclear
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's new Taj Majal casino in Atlantic City, with its minarets and huge stone elephants, has left many here wondering _ or worrying _ what the mega-developer plans for an encore. But details concerning Trump's grand design for the site of the historic Ambassador Hotel remain by and large the sultan's secret. Three months ago, the New York billionaire revealed he had become a partner in a group that bought the boarded-up hotel with the intention of razing it and building a new project. The development at the 24-acre site on Wilshire Boulevard would be Trump's first in the nation's second-largest city. He's hinted that he may try to put up the world's tallest building, a tower of 125 stories or more, if plans for a similarly outsized building are thwarted in New York City. Such talk has worried environmentalists _ Bob Hattoy of the Sierra Club quipped that Trump was giving the city an ``edifice complex'' _ but it remains just talk. ``We haven't formally announced anything in terms of how tall or how wide,'' said Barbara Res, the Trump Organization vice president who is shepherding the deal. Whatever its shape, the $1 billion project would give Los Angeles something it lacks _ a landmark comparable to the Eiffel Tower or Rockefeller Center, Res said in a recent telephone interview. ``We anticipate having a major shopping area, a luxury hotel _ a very large one with a very, very large banquet and ballroom facility, maybe on the order of 50,000 square feet _ a lot of office space and a housing element,'' she said. The Ambassador was home to the Cocoanut Grove nightclub where the rich and famous in Southern California came to play, but is perhaps best known as the place where Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated in 1968. The hotel, its glamour now faded, finally closed in January 1989. With no specifics to react to yet, not even an artist's concept, the potential opponents of Trump's development are left with little to say. ``There's nothing on the table,'' said Jay Rounds, executive director of the Los Angeles Conservancy, a non-profit historic preservation group. ``We don't deal in critiques of press conferences.'' A spokesman for Mayor Tom Bradley, reflecting the views of several local politicians, said, ``We need to wait until we see specifics of the project before we can discuss it in detail.'' The scarcity of details on design or financing has prompted speculation that Trump wanted the publicity only to gain leverage against New York officials who have held up his plans for a 150-story tower on the Hudson River. ``Perhaps the fact that I go out to L.A. will change things in New York,'' Trump told The New York Times in February. He denied trying to play New York and Los Angeles off against each other, but added his plans for the world's tallest building ``could go to either place, and it will only go to one.'' Could such a building be put up in an earthquake-prone area? ``There's no inherent reason why you can't build a building in the range of 125 stories to be resistant to an earthquake,'' said Wilford Iwan, a professor of earthquake engineering at the California Institute of Technology. But Iwan added that really big structures ``tend to be quite flexible,'' and the way such a building would sway in a quake or strong wind could make people inside feel uncomfortable. Another concern is fire, especially since city fire officials acknowledged that the 1988 inferno in the 62-story First Interstate tower, then the state's tallest building, came perilously close to exceeding the metropolitan area's firefighting resources. Among those who voice few doubts about Trump's intentions is Jackie Goldberg, president of the city's Board of Education. The Los Angeles Unified School District, which is busing 4,000 Wilshire-area students at a cost of $6 million a year, wants to take over the property as the site for a desparately needed new high school. But the board has found itself stymied repeatedly by the Trump organization, Goldberg said. ``We're involved with somebody here who is accustomed to getting his own way, and has the funds and the lack of public scrutiny to do it,'' Goldberg fumed. When school officials asked the state Allocation Board for $120 million to pay for the land, they discovered that lobbyists hired by Trump already had persuaded members of the obscure state agency to withhold the funds. The board instead ordered district officials to work out a compromise with the billionaire developer, whose representatives offered to find an alternate site for the school.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Luciano Pavarotti said Friday he will make his first performance at Moscow's Bolshoi Theater. Next month's concert will help raise money for earthquake rebuilding in Soviet Armenia. The Italian tenor said he will give the first in a series of benefit concerts, entitled Overture for a New Europe, in the Soviet Union. The concerts, organized by Italy's Emilia Romagna region, will help pay for the construction of a $30 million hospital in Spitak, Armenia, a town devastated by earthquakes in December 1988. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, are expected to attend the May 3 concert at the Bolshoi, organizers said. Pavarotti will also perform May 4 and May 6 at other Moscow theaters and May 8 in Leningrad. He will be supported by the Arturo Toscanini Orchestra, pianist Leone Magiera and flutists Giorgio Zagnoni and Andrea Griminelli. A spokeswoman for the Emilia Romagna region, Tina Alborese, said Italy had so far contributed $4 million to the Armenian hospital project. Other funds were being provided by the Finnish government and the International Red Cross, she said.

Cartoonist Matt Groening looked to his own family when choosing first names for his animated TV clan ``The Simpsons.'' But any similarity ends there. ``The Simpsons are relatively stupid and ugly. My family is smart and clever _ and a little more attractive,'' Groening said in an interview being published in US magazine's April 30 issue. ``But I did drive my younger sisters crazy in the same way as Bart.'' Bart, the Simpson son, is the only member of the cartoon crew that doesn't share a name with the Groening family. The cartoonist's parents are named Homer and Marge, and he has sisters named Maggie and Lisa. In addition, Groening said his year-old son is named Homer _ and for a very good reason. ``When you name an incredibly inept cartoon character after your father, you are forced to name your firstborn child after him as well,'' said Groening. ``Whether or not my kid will forgive me, I don't know.''

Tennis star Chris Evert has agreed to lend her name to a new line of women's casual clothing at Montgomery Ward & Co., company officials said. Evert is the first of several celebrities the company plans to sign for its women's wear business, chairman Bernard Brennan said Thursday. Evert's line will be called ``Chrissie'' and will include casual pants, tops and jackets that may be worn to work. It will not contain clothing intended for tennis or any other athletic activities, said Dan Levy, president of Ward's apparel group. Levy said Evert's line of clothing will be in the stores in July. Ward approached Evert just before her September retirement at the U.S. Open in Forest Hills, Brennan said. ``Chris Evert had the most credibility of anybody we tested,'' said Brennan.

Musician Tom Waits said that the first time he heard a SalsaRio Doritos corn chip commercial, he could barely believe his ears: The singer was copying Waits' gravely style grit-for-grit. ``I was shocked,'' Waits testified Thursday in his trademark infringement case against the chip maker. ``I think he studied me closely. I heard things I do with my voice that I've never heard anyone else do, a certain intimacy.'' Waits said the singer, Stephen Carter, copied ``my phrasing, my timbre, my voice, my approach.'' ``It embarrassed me,'' Waits said. ``I had to call my friends and tell them, `If you hear this thing, please be informed it's not me.' I was on the phone for days. And people kept calling me.'' Waits, 40, is suing under federal trademark laws and under a California common law, established in a case involving Bette Midler, that outlaws imitating a professional singer's distinctive voice for commercial use. Waits' lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court against Frito-Lay Inc. and ad agency Tracy-Locke Inc. Anthony Liebig, attorney for Frito-Lay and Tracy-Locke, said the gravely, jazzy voice used by the singer in the ad was like that of many performers, not just Waits.

The death of his close friend Divine persuaded director John Waters to ditch a technique he'd used in virtually all his cult film classics. ``I will never have another man play a woman. Divine was irreplaceable,'' said Waters, who cast the 300-pound actor as the female lead in films such as ``Pink Flamingos'' and ``Hairspray.'' ``He was almost a human animation. You can't duplicate that,'' Waters said. Waters stayed true to his word in his current film ``Cry Baby,'' which stars Johnny Depp (as a man) and Amy Locane (as a woman). Divine, who died in 1988 at age 42, may be gone but he's not forgotten, Waters says in the April 30th issue of US magazine. The director and some friends recently visited the actor's grave in suburban Maryland. ``We all went at Christmas and decorated a tree there,'' Walters recalled. ``People left chocolate donuts there. It was great.''

The surprising success of her hit single ``Luka'' left singer-songwriter Suzanne Vega feeling more isolated than inspired. Her song about an abused child netted Vega three 1988 Grammy nominations, and she went on a yearlong world tour in support of her ``Solitude Standing'' LP. But she says it took her almost another year to begin writing again; her follow-up album, ``Days of Open Hand,'' was just released. ``I didn't want to hear any music, I didn't want to write anything,'' Vega told Entertainment Weekly in an interview published in its April 20 issue. ``I felt I had nothing to say except, `I'm really tired. I'd like to go home, please.''' Vega says she's confident about the quality of her new album, although she's not sure how her fans will respond. ``Some people always want you to be more political, or they want you to be more extreme,'' she said. ``Some people want you to have more choruses that you can sing along to. They want you to write happier songs. ... I feel I can just work on my own path.''

DOC.HEAD: President, Prime Minister Take Part in Good Friday Tradition
With AM-Bush-Thatcher, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher interrupted their discussions about global issues Friday to take part in a tradition of Bermuda _ flying a kite on Good Friday. The leaders were in good cheer as they greeted a group of 20 children on the grounds of Government House, where the two were holding a day of talks. The president and the prime minister took the strings of kites that already were aloft in 30 mph winds. Bush maneuvered his with a pumping motion; Mrs. Thatcher used a gentler easing of the string. One of the children, 10-year-old Matthew Figueiredo, said Bush told the youngsters that he kept a couple of Chinese kites at the White House and that, ``if it were a bit calmer, it would be perfect for flying kites.'' The tradition of Good Friday kite flying was started by a Sunday school teacher seeking to explain to his students Christ's ascension into heaven. En route to Bermuda, Bush had told reporters that he has a ``large inventory of kites.'' ``I'm often told to go fly my kite,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Faces Age Discrimination Complaint
DOC.TEXT: The musicians union and two members of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra have filed age discrimination complaints against the ensemble. The American Federation of Musicians' complaint filed with the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission claims music director Yoel Levi has made it clear he wants younger musicians ``so he can mold or shape them.'' The union and violinist Benjamin Picone, 66, and principal harp player Judith Beattie Ryan, 42, filed their complaints April 6. Levi, 39, who joined the orchestra in September 1988, was out of town and could not be reached for comment. ASO Executive Director J. Thomas Bacchetti declined comment, saying that the orchestra had not been served with complaint papers. Ms. Ryan, a member of the orchestra since 1969, and Picone, a member since 1959, were notified earlier this year that they would not be rehired after 1991. Ms. Ryan and Picone want to hold onto their jobs and force the orchestra to pay their attorney fees.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Oil Spill Trial Set for June
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. and its shipping subsidiary are scheduled for trial June 18 on federal criminal charges stemming from the Exxon Valdez oil spill. The trial date was set in an order filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Anchorage. Exxon and Exxon Shipping Co. pleaded innocent to the charges at separate arraignment proceedings Monday. A federal grand jury handed up an indictment Feb. 27 charging the companies with two felonies for allowing the Exxon Valdez to be operated by incompetent crew members. They also charged the oil giant with three misdemeanors, including violating the Clean Water Act and the Migratory Bird Treaty. Thousands of birds, fish and other wildlife died in the aftermath of the nearly 11 million-gallon spill, the nation's largest, on March 24, 1989. More than 160 lawsuits are pending against Exxon by the state, environmentalists and private individuals for unspecified damages. The skipper of the Exxon Valdez, Capt. Joseph Hazelwood, was convicted last month of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil into state waters but was acquitted of more serious charges.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Roughly a quarter of a billion ``peeps'' and ``bunnies,'' those ubiquitous Easter marshmallow treats, will be tucked in countless Easter baskets Sunday, and many will go stale _ on purpose. ``We make one for every man, woman and child in the country,'' said David Shaffer, vice president of Just Born Inc., a company fueled by sugar and nostalgia. The bunnies and chicks, called ``peeps'' by the company, have been around since 1953, so baby boomers are instinctively filling their children's baskets with the yellow, pink and white confections, he said. ``I think nostalgia pretty much sums it up,'' Shaffer said Thursday. ``It's kind of odd, I never thought of it that way. But we've had a product that's been around so long that it brings back childhood memories.'' There is considerable debate over proper peep eating. Most people, Shaffer concedes, like them stale. ``It's kind of ironic because we go to a great deal of expense to keep them fresh,'' he said. Achieving that certain level of staleness is an art, he said. ``There's the slow process, where they'll tear the cellophane and leave them out, and they'll dry out and shrivel up. ``Others who can't wait that long and can't stand to see them die a slow death do the flash-freeze approach by putting them in a frost-free freezer. A frost-free freezer sucks the moisture out, and they'll do it to a peep in no time flat.'' Shaffer's preference? ``I personally don't care for fresh marshmallow,'' he said. ``I don't like them stale, but a little firm.''

He's a cute little critter. Walks on a leash, is housebroken and obeys commands to ``sit,'' ``come,'' and ``stay.'' Some say his kind makes a better household pet than a dog. But if the Costa family doesn't get rid of Sir Humphrey Swine, they may be forced to move out of their mobile home in this town 15 miles northwest of Orlando. Humphrey is a Vietnamese potbellied pig, a breed that has become a pet fad in some parts of the country. Suzanne Costa, who paid $700 for the 15-pound porker, says Humphrey doesn't bite or dig through trash as many dogs do. Adults weigh 50 to 150 pounds. ``He's part of the family,'' said Mrs. Costa, 24. ``I'll be heartbroken if we lose him.'' But Manager Gary Cottle of Rock Springs Mobile Home Park told her that having a pig violates Orange County code enforcement laws. County officials say pigs belong on farms, no matter how cute and smart they may be. Anyone found guilty of keeping a pig in a non-agricultural area could be fined $250 a day, said Joanne McMurray, assistant zoning director for the county. Mrs. Costa, her husband, Joe, and their two daughters say there are worse pets than a little pig. ``If the guy next door wanted to keep rattlesnakes, it's OK,'' Mrs. Costa said. ``Imagine if they got loose. Humphrey wouldn't hurt anyone.'' In suburban Miami, Broward County commissioners have reclassified the potbellied pig as an exotic pet. ``I think these are the kinds of pets that neighbors would rather see than pit bulls, especially in urban areas,'' said Commissioner Nicki Grossman. ``We're pet-friendly down here.''

DOC.HEAD: Grateful Dead Banned in Bay Area Because of Troublesome Fans
DOC.TEXT: The Grateful Dead, a San Francisco Bay area institution since the late '60s, has been banned from the University of California, Berkeley, and Stanford University. Both bay-area schools have told the band it is no longer welcome to perform its annual concerts on their campuses because of troublesome ``Deadhead'' fans, some of whom who like to camp out and use drugs while awaiting concerts. UC Berkeley police Lt. Pat Carroll said 30 to 50 arrests are made each summer when the Dead does its three-concert stand. Most arrests are drug-related, Carroll said. At Stanford, police said they arrest about the same number of people and could arrest many more if they had the manpower. One UC Berkeley official said the problem is that ``Deadheads,'' fans who follow the band to their shows across the country, come early and stay late. ``They tend to come and camp for a week in the grove of trees outside Frost,'' the Stanford amphitheater, said Stanford Associate Dean of Students Michael L. Jackson. ``And they stay for days afterward.'' Band spokesman Dennis McNally expressed disappointment about the decisions, saying the group has worked to discourage the ``bazaar-like atmosphere'' that develops outside the concerts. He said the band is trying to halt sales of anything outside its concerts, and discourages camping. The Grateful Dead has been around since 1967, gaining attention as a ``hippie band'' that gave free concerts in Golden Gate Park. But it was the 1985 ``In the Dark'' album that became the Dead's most successful to date, producing the band's first No. 1 hit, ``Touch of Gray,'' with its repeated lyric line, ``We shall survive.'' David Gans, an Oakland author and Dead expert, said ``In the Dark'' attracted a huge new generation of fans. He said banning the Dead from UC Berkeley's Greek Theatre and Stanford's Frost Amphitheater ``shows how our society has changed. Obviously, there is a drug scene. This is what the local constabulary has seized upon.'' ``I know of grandmothers who are fans. I know multigenerational families from San Leandro who love the Dead,'' Gans said.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Suspect Sought for Questioning in DEA Bombing Pleads Innocent
DOC.TEXT: A man sought for questioning in connection with a bombing that gutted a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration office pleaded innocent Friday to cocaine charges and was ordered held without bond. Jeffrey Alan Matthews, 23, formerly known as Jeffrey Ciganek, entered the plea to federal charges of conspiracy and possession with intent to deliver cocaine. The charges stemmed from indictments issued against Matthews, his brother John Lewis Ciganek and two others two days before the March 17 bomb blast and fire destroyed the Fort Myers DEA office. No charges have been filed in the bombing itself. No one was injured but damage was estimated at $4 million. U.S. Magistrate George T. Schwartz ordered Matthews held without bond after federal prosecutor Russ Stoddard noted Matthews had been a fugitive for 25 days before his arrest Monday in Orlando. Stoddard also read from a transcript of a telephone conversation Matthews reportedly had with a government informant the night before the bombing. In that conversation the informant reportedly told Matthews he wasn't going to testify against him but asked what would happen if he did. Matthews replied, ``You talk and you're history,'' the prosecutor said. Defense attorney Robert Hill did not challenge the government's argument that Matthews should stay behind bars but said he has been denied phone cals with his attorney and other privileges.

DOC.HEAD: New York Governor Made $301,000 in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo made almost $301,000 in 1989, more than half from speaking fees, and paid more than $92,000 in taxes, a review of his state and federal tax returns showed Friday. As governor, Cuomo was paid $127,244 last year. His salary is $130,000 a year but he was paid slightly less because of state payroll scheduling and tax deferring. He was paid $151,150 for speaking engagements across the country last year, minus $3,000 for expenses for a net of $148,150. Cuomo, considered a potential 1992 Democratic presidential contender, also made $25,426 in interest, dividends and taxable tax refunds. The governor paid $63,572 in federal taxes and $28,549 in state taxes, according to the joint returns filed by him and his wife, Matilda. That amounts to slightly under 31 percent of their gross income for the year. The Cuomos are eligible to receive refunds of $3,852 from the federal government and $374 from the state. They are having that money applied to their estimated taxes for 1990; Cuomo pays estimated taxes because of his outside income. In addition to paying taxes, Cuomo returns $30,000 of his salary to the state, representing a raise the legislature passed despite his opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Group Asks: Who Killed The Easter Bunny?
DOC.TEXT: An animal rights group, pegging its protest to the Easter holiday, said Friday that more than half a million rabbits are killed annually in cosmetics testing laboratories. Volunteers from the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, clad in hooded black robes representing the ``grim reapers'' of companies they say slaughter rabbits, carried a bloodied toy rabbit in a satin coffin and shouted, ``Have a cruelty-free holiday!'' The 20 PETA protesters marched outside the headquarters of the 270-member Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association in downtown Washington, but police did not allow them to enter the building. ``Consumers don't realize that 530,000 cute, cuddly rabbits ... our symbol of Easter ... are abused by industry, especially cosmetics industries, every year,'' said Kathy Snow Guillermo, PETA's Compassion Campaign director. Irene Malbin, a CTFA spokeswoman, said her organization believes PETA is missing the point. ``We put human health and safety before anything else,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``We don't believe our children should be guinea pigs.''

DOC.HEAD: US Welcomes Iraqi Offer to Destroy Chemical Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Friday it welcomes an offer by Iraq to destroy chemical weapons but does not believe the destruction should be part of a deal under which Israel would destroy its chemical and nuclear arms. ``We have made clear that we oppose linking the elimination of chemical weapons systems to other issues or weapons systems,'' said Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman. ``That said, we would of course welcome any offer to destroy chemical weapons,'' he added. On Thursday, Sen. James A. McClure, R-Idaho, said that during conversations in the Iraqi city of Mosul, Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, repeated an offer to destroy his arsenal of chemical and other non-conventional weapons if Israel agrees to eliminate chemical and nuclear weapons. Boucher noted that more than 70 nations are negotiating a treaty that would ``ban chemical weapons from the face of the earth.'' ``Were the question of chemical weapons to be linked to other issues, we think it would only delay the conclusion of this very important treaty,'' Boucher said. ``As far as nuclear weapons go, we have consistently urged all countries to join the non-proliferation treaty and abide by its provisions and safeguards,'' Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Peruvian Promises to Bring Discipline to Peru
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Fujimori, a soft-spoken agricultural engineer who enjoys growing rosebushes in his backyard, has suddenly become the man most likely to take the helm of Peru, one of Latin America's most ungovernable nations. The 51-year-old Japanese Peruvian came out of nowhere in Sunday's presidential election to rob a majority from novelist Mario Vargas Llosa and force him into a runoff. Pollsters say the centrist independent's popularity is growing daily as Vargas Llosa's support declines. With the likely support of leftist parties in a June runoff, Fujimori appears unbeatable. The Lima press dubbed his rise the ``Fujimori phenomenon.'' Headlines told of Vargas Llosa getting swept away by a ``tsunami,'' a tidal wave of ``Fujimania.'' ``Imagine the inability of these political parties to manage an electoral campaign. It makes me laugh that they've come out looking so ridiculous,'' Fujimori said in an interview with The Associated Press, one of his first since the election. He compared his campaign strategy to the martial arts. ``You take advantage of the forces of the other, boom boom, wherever they lead,'' he said, slicing his hand through an imaginary brick. Vargas Llosa, also an independent, and his right-of-center Democratic Front coalition spent more than $3.6 million on his campaign, according to the respected news magazine Caretas. Fujimori, who sold a house, his car and a tractor to raise campaign funds, spent about $180,000. He claims to be the only candidate truly independent of ``professional politicians.'' But he has shown political skill, which some say he honed during his years as a university rector in a country where universities are highly politicized. In the early days of his campaign, he posed for photographers dressed as a samurai warrior and a karate expert. He said it was necessary to get attention. Within days after Sunday's vote, Vargas Llosa was meeting with advisers and pondering his political future at a friend's beach home south of Lima. He reportedly considered dropping out of the race. Fujimori, meanwhile, was attending to the pack of reporters camped in front of his middle-class Lima home, posing for pictures with some Chinese squash and handing out flowers from his garden. Fujimori has avoided specifics throughout his six-month campaign, speaking instead of broad social goals like improved health care and revitalizing industry. Analysts say Fujimori's success was due to voters' alarm over Vargas Llosa's explicit plan for drastic austerity measures and their wariness of the old-time politicians in the Democratic Front. Fujimori is one of five children and the oldest son of Japanese immigrants who came to Peru in 1934 from the city of Kumamoto on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu. His father worked at various jobs, including an upholstery shop he opened in downtown Lima. The family lost the business during a boycott of Japanese businesses during World War II. Fujimori earned a degree in agricultural engineering from the National Agrarian University in 1960, and later served as the school's rector from 1984 to 1989. He has studied in France, Belgium and the United States. He speaks Spanish, Japanese, English, French and German. Though his parents were Buddhists, Fujimori grew up a Catholic in this overwhelmingly Catholic country. He doesn't mind if people view him as smart, honest and hard-working because he is Japanese. But he says he's ``100 percent Peruvian,'' and has only an ``ancestral connection'' to Japan. He describes himself as studious, introverted, without any ``common vices,'' and says working is his hobby. He works 12 to 13 hours a day and refuses to eat or drink anything between meals. ``I don't want to be distracted,'' he said. Usually dressed in a three-piece suit, Fujimori appears stiff and serious when he meets with the public, but voters have warmed to him and his promises of discipline and hard work. He says his political movement, called simply Change 90, is an ``expression of people who are tired of the old, corrupt political parties and who just want to work.'' Fujimori has support in Peru's growing evangelical community, whose leaders see in him the simple, honest president the country needs. One of his two vice-presidential candidates is Carlos Garcia, a Baptist pastor. The other is Maximo San Roman, a bread factory owner who has perfected ways of making bread from carrots and sweet potatoes.

DOC.HEAD: Nepal's King Would Allow Opposition to Lead Interim Government
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra has agreed to let an opposition alliance head an interim government, a leader of the 7-week-old pro-democracy movement reported Friday. A separate opposition statement said it was willing to allow the king himself to head the government, but it would step in if he chose not to. The king, who has generally stayed above the daily management of the government, was believed unlikely to assume its leadership. The political uncertainty stems from Birendra's proclamation five days ago, after popular demonstrations, that he would lift the 29-year-old ban on political parties. Birendra then invited the Nepali Congress Party and United Left Front, which together led the pro-democracy movement, to join the interim government. On Friday, after a 65-minute meeting with the king at the Royal palace in Katmandu, Nepali Congress leader Ganesh Man Singh said the 44-year-old monarch was ready to allow the opposition to lead an interim government until elections can be held. The meeting was the first between Birendra and the 75-year-old Singh since the pro-democracy movement burgeoned in February. The government of this Himalayan kingdom first reacted to the pro-democracy campaign with a bloody crackdown. Witnesses said 200 people were killed when security forces fired on a crowd of 200,000 marching to the palace April 6. The government said 10 people were killed and 107 that day. Singh was invited to the palace Friday after the Nepali Congress Party and the seven-party United Left Front set nine conditions for joining the interim government. The conditions included an assurance that the new government would not be headed by a member of the non-partisan national assembly, the Rashtriya Panchayat, which is dominated by loyalist legislators. Calling the king the ``lesser of the two evils,'' the Nepali Congress said it was willing to allow the king to head the council of ministers until general elections can be held. A statement issued by the Nepali Congress after the palace meeting said Birendra agreed that in case he was ``not prepared to head the government, permission be granted to the multiparty leaders (to form the interim government).'' Singh said the king has also agreed to discuss the other eight conditions, which include dismissal of the present government, dissolution of the Rashtriya Panchayat and reforms in the constitution. The constitution gives the king absolute legislative, executive and judicial powers. ``Unless these preconditions are met, we will not form the government,'' Nepali Congress President K.P. Bhattarai told reporters. He said the king reacted positively to the demands. However, he did not elaborate. Singh said ``by next week we will sort it out.'' ``By the end of next week, a new government will be formed,'' he added. Political observers have said that the king is unlikely to accept the government's leadership. No royal spokesman was not available for comment. While Singh was meeting with Birendra, Foreign Minister Pashupati Rana indicated his government would not accept an opposition member as head of the interim administration. ``Our position is that the interim government has been constituted,'' Rana told reporters, referring to the present government of Prime Minister Lokendra Chand appointed after his predecessor resigned April 5.

DOC.HEAD: `Dear Gorbachev' Letter Solves Sock Shortage
DOC.TEXT: Don't tell 19-year-old Andrei Umrikhin that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev does not care. After trying for a year and a half to buy some new socks in his small village in southern Russia, Umrikhin sent a letter directly to Gorbachev. A little more than a month later, the creaky Soviet retail system coughed up new socks not only for Umrikhin and his family, but for the whole village. It was not only socks that appeared in the local store. Toothpaste and soap did, too. ``To tell the truth, I still wonder whether it was all a coincidence, or whether the socks really were from the Central Committee,'' said Umrikhin, reached by telephone in his village of Beloye, about 280 miles south of Moscow. ``At first, I prayed for Gorbachev, but I don't believe in him any more because after five years of perestroika, I had to write him a letter to get a pair of socks,'' he added. ``But personally I am very grateful to him and to the whole party apparatus for helping me out in such a predicament.'' Sergei Borodin, the ideology chief of the Communist Party in Umrikhin's district, said the young man is really a ``no-good loafer.'' He said Umrikhin spent his time selling unofficial newspapers until authorities put a stop to it, and he was trying to get back at them. Umrikhin said he endured holes in his socks for months until he was called for the spring draft. It occurred to him he would have to appear before young nurses at the local clinic in his old socks, and it was more than he could bear. He wrote to Gorbachev at the end of February. ``Dear Mikhail Sergeyevich, please send me and my family some socks,'' he recalled saying in his letter. ``But because we are rather hard pressed financially, send us cheap socks, please, if you can. And I beg you not to think that this is some kind of prank. I am positively serious about it.'' Umrikhin's mother makes about 90 rubles a month, just above the official poverty level, as a cleaning woman. He earns about the same amount and his twin brother has a student's stipend of about 70 rubles a month. Their 13-year-old brother lives with them in about 20 square yards of space _ half a rundown duplex with no modern conveniences. Three weeks after writing Gorbachev, Umrikhin received a postcard saying his letter had been registered at the the General Department of the Communist Party Central Committee in Moscow. Two weeks later, the district party secretary called Umrikhin and told him to go to his local distribution center for consumer goods. There, he was referred back to his local store and sold a pair of new socks for 1.70 rubles _ about the cheapest available in the Soviet Union. ``And the next day, after standing in line with other villagers this time, I officially bought the same kind of socks for the rest of my family,'' he said. His story appeared in the Kursk newspaper Young Guard under the headline ``Socks from Gorbachev'' at the beginning of April and was picked up by a national newspaper. Borodin, the local Communist Party official, said it all was done to embarrass party leaders. ``It was an act of malice and revenge,'' he said. ``It was nothing substantial to make a fuss about, just socks! Every region any time may be struck with a temporary shortage of something or other. These things do happen. So what? Should everybody write a letter to Gorbachev?''

DOC.HEAD: Five Policemen to Stand Trial for Abuses During Peace Protest
DOC.TEXT: Five police officers will stand trial on charges of using unnecessary force to break up a ``human chain'' peace demonstration in December, police said Friday. The district commander who ordered force to be used in dispersing the protesters will be transferred from his post, police said. The state prosecutor, Dorit Beinish, recommended the actions in a report that blamed the police for aggravating the protest Dec. 30. Officers charged protesters, clubbed them and fired tear gas and rubber bullets as they tried to link arms around Jerusalem's walled Old City. More than 50 people were injured in the melee, including an Italian tourist who lost her eye when a water cannon shattered the glass of her hotel window. ``The source of escalation did not lie with the protesters, but with the action of the police,'' Beinish wrote in the 17-page report, according to the Ha'aretz and Davar newspapers. A Justice Ministry spokeswoman could not be reached for comment because of the Passover holiday. According to the newspapers, the prosecutor's report also criticized the internal police investigation of the affair for failing to identify the officers who fired the rubber bullets, despite news photographs and TV footage of the incident. ``The claim that it is impossible to identify those who opened fire is unacceptable and therefore the investigation must be completed,'' Beinish wrote. Her report also criticized the police commander on the scene for not having first warned the protesters to leave before ordering them dispersed by force. Police spokesman Roni Yeshayahu said Police Commissioner Yaakov Turner had adopted all the state prosecutor's recommendations and would reopen the investigation. He said criminal charges would be brought against three officers accused of beating a photographer, and two other officers would be brought before a disciplinary court on charges of using unnecessary force. The state prosecutor's report resulted from appeals from peace activists and tourists who took part in the protest and complained of excessive use of force by police. The police action prompted formal complaints from the Italian government and European Community, and the European Parliament recommended that some cultural and technological exchange activities between Europe and Israel be suspended.

DOC.HEAD: High School Tennis Star Slain in Quiet Suburb
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The slaying of a high school tennis star who police believe may have been killed because he informed on gang members has stunned this peaceful suburb. The killing of Charles Hardison, 16, was only the second in 20 years in this affluent town just south of Boston's inner city, Milton police said. ``Charles had the personality that every man in the world would like to have,'' said Jim Smith, who coached Hardison in tennis for the past eight years. ``If you could bottle it, you could make a million dollars. He was destined to be a leader.'' Hardison's mother, Adlene, went to wake him Thursday morning but found his bed had not been slept in. She found him in the basement with four gunshot wounds, three to the head, police said. There was no sign of a struggle, robbry or forced entry, leading investigators to believe that Hardison knew his killer, police said. Mrs. Hardison had arrived home the previous night and found her son's keys in the lock. Neighbors said he often forget to remove his keys from the lock. Mrs. Hardison apparently assumed he'd gone to sleep. Students at Milton High School, where Hardison was the top-ranked tennis player, said the shooting may have been connected to an incident last year in which members of a Boston gang crashed a party given by a friend of Hardison's. The party later turned violent. Hardison, reportedly angered because one of his friends was injured, cooperated with police, pointing out the home of the girlfriend of one alleged gang member, some students said. A Milton police officer said Friday that the department was investigating the possibility of a gang link in the killing. Boston Police Deputy Superintendent William Celester, who runs the police station in the gang-plagued Roxbury section, said Milton police had contacted detectives there about the killing. School officials said Hardison was not involved in gangs or drugs and had never been a discipline problem. Student anger over Hardison's death spilled over into an assembly Thursday, a school official said. At the assembly, one student denied that her boyfriend, reportedly a gang member, had killed Hardison, said Vice Principal Paul Dorsey. ``(Other students) walked out as the girl was speaking,'' he said. ``My interpretation might have been that they didn't believe her.'' Eva Price, a neighbor of the Hardisons who had known Charles since he was 5, said the youth recently had helped a neighbor clean up his yard. ``I looked out my window Sunday morning and said `I don't believe it.' He was helping him rake his leaves,'' she said pointing to an adjacent lawn. ``He was working harder than the guy's son.'' Price said the killing raised concerns for the safety of her own three teen-agers, even on a street where birdcalls are louder than passing cars. ``Everybody wants to know what triggered this,'' she said. ``I won't let my kids stay alone here, not until police tell me what happened. It does worry us.'' Price also said she disagreed with neighbors who declined to talk to reporters. ``He's a wonderful kid. He died a violent death and it should be known that he was into (good) things,'' she said. School officials said Hardison, who was black, helped found the high school's Students of African Descent. He was also the top-ranked tennis player in the Bay State League, school officials said. ``He was truly an outstanding tennis player,'' Dorsey said. Smith said Hardison played outstanding tennis while on a club-sponsored trip to the Soviet Union last August. Hardison won all five of his matches, leading the team to a 32-22 win over the Soviet teams.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says More Control of Police Needed; March Broken Up
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for story slugged South Africa-Drugs on news advisory.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Friday the government is not doing enough to control police and that police actions against peaceful demonstrators are damaging the climate for black-white negotiations. Also Friday, police fired tear gas to disperse about 1,000 Moslems protesting growing drug use in their neighborhood, witnesses said. The marchers included mixed-race men, women and children who gathered at a mosque in Salt River, outside Cape Town, with placards that read, ``We Don't Want Drugs.'' They said drug use and drug dealing had become a pervasive problem in the area. Mandela, speaking in the northeastern town of Likazi, said the government should do more to reign in police. ``Police look at every grievance and demonstration (by blacks) as an act of war,'' the African National Congress leader said. He said this has hurt the climate for formal negotiations between blacks and whites on changing the constitution to give blacks a share of power in South Africa. The ANC postponed groundbreaking talks with the government after a police shooting last month left at least 11 protesters dead. The discussions have been rescheduled May 2-4. ``I told President F.W. de Klerk at our last meeting that ... if one white person was killed by police, white South Africa would shout at the top of its voice,'' Mandela said. If a number of whites ``were killed by police, there would be a mass upheaval and the government would fall.'' Mandela, addressing 1,500 members of the militant South African Youth Congress, called on young blacks to be disciplined and work to end the factional fighting that has claimed hundreds of lives since February. ``If you are a member of the ANC, you will be tolerant of other people's views,'' Mandela said. ``Those who use violence or coercion against other political or youth movements are not disciplined members of the ANC.'' A visiting European Community delegation met Friday in Johannesburg with the Pan Africanist Congress, a rival of the ANC. The delegation, led by Irish Foreign Minister Gerard Collins, held separate talks Thursday with de Klerk and leaders of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party. ``Our meeting with leaders from such opposing camps as the Conservative Party and the Pan Africanist Congress is motivated by the desire to ensure that all political groups in South Africa realize it is their responsibility to bring about change,'' Collins said. Police told organizers of the anti-drug march that they lacked the manpower to protect the demonstrators and would have to break up the march. The demonstrators decided to proceed, but after they marched one block, police fired at least 12 rounds of tear gas, witnesses said. The crowd quickly dispersed. Later, the marchers regrouped at the mosque and accused several local youths on the streets of selling drugs. There were several heated exchanges, but no injuries or arrests were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Four Convicted of Using Extortion to Collect Debt
DOC.TEXT: Four men, including the son of a reputed crime family boss, were convicted Friday of using extortion in an attempt to collect a $40,000 debt from a stockbroker who was later slain. ``It was a good verdict based on the evidence,'' said the prosecutor, Assistant U.S. Attorney Kevin March. Convicted on two extortion counts were Anthony Accetturo Jr., 24-year-old son of a reputed captain in the Lucchese crime family of northern New Jersey; brothers Robert and Raymond Basha; and Michael Monahan. The men were accused of kidnapping stockbroker Christopher James Loiselle last fall, threatening him and assaulting him in an attempt to collect $40,000 he had borrowed from the Bashas, who own a jet ski business in Hollywood. On March 15, three days after the extortion trial was to have begun in Tampa, Loiselle was found dead with five gunshot wounds to the chest. U.S. District Judge Anthony Alaimo then moved the trial here because of publicity in Tampa about the death. Authorities said all of the defendants have passed polygraph tests denying any knowledge of Loiselle's slaying, which remains unsolved. Alaimo ordered the defendants held until sentencing, and did not set a sentencing date. The four men, all from Hollywood, face up to 20 years in prison on each of the two counts, March said. Jurors, who had been deliberating since Wednesday, were unable to reach a verdict on a racketeering conspiracy count and a charge that the defendants used violence to further their racketeering operations. Acceturro and Raymond Basha were found innocent of kidnapping Scott Stockholm, a friend of Loiselle. The jury was unable to reach a verdict on that count against Robert Basha and Monahan. U.S. Attorney Robert W. Genzman will have to decide whether to seek a new trial on the charges that were not resolved. Loiselle, 30, a stockbroker who was living in Largo, borrowed the $40,000 for his struggling brokerage business. The Bashas loaned Loiselle the money last August at 50 percent interest, telling him it came from organized crime and there would be violence if he did not repay, prosecutors charged. Loiselle was kidnapped Sept. 27 after failing to repay, prosecutors said. Monahan and the Basha brothers threatened him, then took him to Accetturo, who beat him and threatened him further before releasing him, the government said. Loiselle went to authorities, and arrests were made Oct. 24. Defense attorneys contended the Bashas, owners of R&R Jet Tech Inc. in Hollywood, were respected young businessmen who merely wanted to get their money back from Loiselle. The defense described Loiselle as a con man and thief who needed the $40,000 because he had stolen money from his business. Peter Aiken, an attorney for Accetturo, had argued that the government's case was an attempt to strike back at his father, Anthony Accetturo Sr., who was acquitted in 1988 in Newark, N.J., following a 21-month trial on racketeering charges.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Fail to Reach Agreement on Lumber Products
DOC.TEXT: Trade negotiators ended talks Friday without reaching an agreement on U.S. demands that Japan remove restrictions on imports of wood products. There are three areas in which Washington has been trying to remove trade barriers, and lumber products remain the only one unresolved. ``There are still significant differences in our positions,'' a U.S. official in Tokyo told reporters. ``We have made substantial progress on many points, but some issues remain to be discussed further,'' said a Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We have concluded our talks at this round after agreeing to hold another round of talks in the near future.'' The American official, who also spoke on condition he not be named, said U.S. negotiators felt they could reach an agreement before June 16, when Washington must decide whether to take retaliatory action for foreign trade practices it considers unfair. ``I think there is momentum to resolve the negotiations,'' the U.S. official said. ``There is strong interest in a resolution on both sides.'' Last year, the Bush administration designated Japanese trade in wood products, satellites and supercomputers as areas in which U.S. products face unfair trade practices under the ``Super 301'' clause of the U.S. trade law. The two governments recently reached agreements on greater access to Japan's satellite and supercomputer markets. Talks on lumber trade, which began Monday, faced mounting disagreement mainly because of Japan's complicated housing and construction regulations, the Japanese official said. ``We have discussed their assertion that Japan's construction standards are so complicated that they are hard to understand,'' he said. ``Our position is that we can't afford to lower our safety standards on housing.'' U.S. industry and government officials say a Japanese law banning the construction of three-story wooden apartments unfairly limits wood imports. They also say Tokyo's product specifications and tariffs for lumber unfairly discriminate against imports of high-value finished and semi-finished wood products. By importing mainly raw timber, they say, Japan is protecting its own uncompetitive, traditional timber processing industry. Japanese officials say such restrictions are necessary safety precautions in earthquake-prone Japan. Wooden structures are limited by law to single-family dwellings up to three stories, and to two-story multiple family housing. Most apartment buildings in major cities are built of steel and concrete. Officials from both sides said progress had been made in all areas of discussion but declined to explain remaining disagreements. The U.S. official said he expected the talks to resume ``very soon,'' but did not specify when or where the next round of negotiations would take place. Last year, the United States exported $2.8 billion in wood products to Japan, mostly unfinished logs. Industry officials estimate that if trade barriers were eliminated, the market would expand by $2 billion and 17,000-20,000 new U.S. jobs would be created.

DOC.HEAD: Competition for Students, Drop in Aid Blamed for Rise in Tuition
DOC.TEXT: Competition for students and drops in government support were the main reasons for huge tuition jumps at private and public colleges during the 1980s, says a new study. And while experts predict some relief in the 1990s, they say the price of higher education will still rise faster than inflation _ at least until the baby boom's babies start to hit college age. The report by Arthur Hauptman, an authority on higher education finances, says the shrinking number of college-age youths has played a major role tuition increases. ``The continued decline in this age group through the mid-1990s suggests that college charges probably will continue to outpace inflation for the forseeable future,'' Hauptman concludes. But he adds that ``it is difficult to imagine that consumers will be unlimited in their willingness to pay steadily rising college prices'' and suggests they will rebel at some point against price increases that are double the inflation rate. From 1980 to 1987, the average boost in tuition and fees was slightly under 10 percent annually _ nearly twice inflation. ``The College Tuition Spiral,'' Hauptman's report for the College Board and American Council on Education, concluded that cutbacks in state aid during the early 1980s were a major factor in tuition increases at public colleges. Private colleges raised tuition to pay for better facilities, services and faculty salaries in attempts to maintain their share of a shrinking pool of potential students, the study said. The schools also used some of the money to expand their own student aid programs, a need provoked by cuts at the federal level. Furthermore, Hauptman wrote, with stagnating enrollments, schools could no longer spread fixed costs over a growing number of students. Plus they had to spend more to counsel and recruit non-traditional students. Hauptman said an economic downturn in the next few years could force public institutions dependent on strained state resources to raise tuition but prompt private colleges to hold the line to keep from discouraging prospective students. The trend of the 1980s was in sharp contrast to the late 1970s, when tuitions and other charges grew more slowly than inflation.
