DOC.TEXT: NBC News urged a federal appeals court Friday to reverse a $5.3 million libel judgment won by entertainer Wayne Newton, saying a 1980 broadcast was guilty of only one thing _ aggressive journalism. Newton's lawyer, Morton Galane, argued that a jury found NBC had ``ill will'' toward Newton and said the verdict should stand. But NBC lawyer Floyd Abrams said the report linking Newton to organized crime figures was correct. Abrams, a noted First Amendment lawyer, argued that investigative reporting would suffer if the decision were upheld. The two lawyers spoke during 30-minute oral summations to their arguments at the hearing before the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeal. The court's decision will be announced at a later date. A Las Vegas federal jury decided in December 1986 that the network had willfully libeled Newton by claiming he had ties to organized crime. The jury gave him the largest libel award in history _ $19.2 million in damages. Presiding U.S. District Judge Myron Crocker of Fresno eventually reduced that award to $5.3 million. Numerous media groups, including rival networks CBS, ABC and Fox, several major newspaper chains and The Associated Press have joined NBC's appeal of the libel verdict. During Friday's hearing, Judge William Norris of the three-member panel likened the NBC team to Robert Woodward and Carl Bernstein, the Washington Post reporters who broke the Watergate scandal. ``Would a jury have a basis for finding Carl Bernstein and Robert Woodward had ill will in pursuing the Watergate story?'' he asked Newton's lawyer. Galane said they would not because those reporters were ordered by their publisher to verify every fact through at least two sources. But Norris suggested the Newton case might discourage investigative reporting and prevent stories comparable to a Watergate scandal from being uncovered. ``We tread a very fine line here to make sure that future Woodwards and Bernsteins are not inhibited in pursuing their stories,'' said Norris. Galane responded, ``We are not intending to inhibit such goals,'' and declared at one point: ``We're not here to launch an attack on the media or the First Amendment.'' But he maintained that NBC had erred by not interviewing Newton about its allegations. Abrams countered that Newton had refused numerous requests for such an interview. Newton, who listened to the arguments from a front row seat, later told reporters he still feels the impact of the 1980 broadcast that linked him to reputed mob figure Guido Penosi. ``The effects of what they said will last me the rest of my life,'' he said. NBC reporter Brian Ross said he and his co-defendants, producer Ira Silverman and executive producer Paul Greenberg, were ``very optimistic'' about having the verdict overturned. All three attended the hearing. The case began Oct. 6, 1980, with Ross' report ``Wayne Newton and the Law.'' Ross reported that Newton had gone to Penosi for help with a problem and that unnamed federal sources were looking at Newton's relationship to two East Coast crime figures. The reports said one mobster had bragged of earning an interest in Las Vegas' Aladdin Hotel, which Newton owned at the time. Newton claimed the report left the impression that his October 1980 purchase of the Aladdin was tied to organized crime _ which he denies. Newton later sold the hotel. Abrams told reporters outside court: ``I think that a loss in this case would make it very difficult for the press to report about investigations and suspicions about prominent public figures, particularly in their own community.'' Judge Dorothy Nelson and chief appellate Judge Alfred Goodwin joined Norris on the panel. Nelson expressed interest in an NBC argument that the case should have been moved out of Las Vegas. Abrams said the defense submitted data on ``Mr. Newton's general adulation in Las Vegas'' but was unable to win a change of venue. ``It was nearly hopeless for us to get a fair trial in Las Vegas,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New York-Bound Kurt Masur Also Plans to Keep East German Post
DOC.TEXT: East German conductor Kurt Masur, named this week to be music director of the New York Philharmonic, said Friday he will keep his orchestral post in Leipzig even after he starts the new job. But despite an active role in his country's democratic revolution last year, he said he has no plans to follow fellow artists such as Czechoslovak playwright Vaclav Havel and Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa into politics. ``Being a musician is a wonderful profession,'' Masur said. ``Why should I change?'' Masur, 62, spoke in a telephone interview while in Paris to conduct a performance of Bach's St. Matthew Passion with the National Orchestra of France and choral groups from Leipzig at a medieval church in suburban Saint Denis. ``It just isn't true that I'm leaving Leipzig,'' he said, denying reports that surfaced after his New York appointment. ``Lots of conductors work with two, even three orchestras at a time.'' ``In fact, I'll be conducting fewer performances in New York than in Leipzig,'' he said. ``I have an indefinite contract with the Gewandhaus Orchestra. I grew up there, I was taught by Gewandhaus musicians, and I would be foolish to leave an orchestra that we have built up as a wonderful family.'' The New York Philharmonic announced Wednesday that Masur would conduct a minimum of 14 subscription weeks and four weeks of other activities each season. Masur, who succeeds Zubin Mehta in New York, said he was very excited about the post, which he has accepted for a five-year period beginning in 1992. ``I would like to build up chamber music life inside the orchestra itself the way we did in Leipzig,'' he said. ``It builds up the qualities of the orchestra and gives more exposure to the musicians.'' Last year, Masur played a major role in avoiding violence during the revolution that swept East Germany. In early October, during a demonstration of thousands of people in Leipzig, he gathered a clergymen, an opposition activist and three local Communist Party officials at his home and then taped a statement, broadcast through loudspeakers, saying the party committed itself to negotiation and nonviolence. The statement represented a change in approach from that of hard-line Communist ruler Erich Honecker, forced to resign Oct. 18. ``I was needed at that moment and I did what was necessary,'' he said. ''I will live in Leipzig, hoping that life will go as we imagined it during the revolution. Masur said he was not sure that German unification would be beneficial to East German artists. ``Their future is in danger, financially,'' he said. ``This is still a big question mark for me.'' ``Freedom is a wonderful gift for our country, but like in sports (where government subsidies for East German athletes are likely to be curtailed), nobody should expect things to be better. It's simply not true.''

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Forum Begins Coalition Talks With Christian Democrats
DOC.TEXT: The conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum began coalition talks Friday with the Christian Democrats to form a non-Communist government, the state news agency MTI reported. The Democratic Forum captured 165 of Parliament's 386 seats in elections Sunday, 29 short of a majority. The elections were the first free balloting in Hungary in 43 years. A meeting Thursday of 1,186 Democratic Forum delegates met and gave formal approval to coalition talks with the Christian Democrats and another conservative party, the Independent Smallholders' Party. The coalition would control 60 percent of Parliament. The party has ruled out any coalition with reform-minded Communists, who ran as the Socialist Party. The Smallholders won 43 seats, the Christian Democrats 21 seats and the Socialists, 33 seats. The Democratic Forum emphasizes Hungarian tradition and Christian values and favors the introduction of market forces into Hungary's socialist economy at a gradual pace to soften the effects of inflation and unemployment. The second strongest party, the Free Democrats, was formed by former leading dissidents and campaigned for rapid economic changes. The party won 96 seats and will most likely head the opposition. It was not known when negotiations with the Smallholders would begin, but Democratic Forum leaders said the new government would be formed in mid-May at the earliest. Democratic Forum's deputy chairman, Ferenc Kulin, said his party would demand ``the strategically important portfolios'' in any future government. He said the party wanted to control the ministries of foreign affairs, finance and interior, but not defense. Kulin quoted party leader and likely prime minister-designate Jozsef Antall as telling Thursday's conference that the new government will ``extend a hand in friendship to the peoples of the Soviet Union, if they remove the handcuffs.'' Hungary's first democratically elected Parliament will convene May 2 to elect a speaker, who will automatically serve as interim president until a new president is elected. Socialist Matyas Szueroes has served as interim president since October, when a series of constitutional reforms were adopted.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Takes Own Life After Killing His Estranged Wife
LaserPhoto LH2
DOC.TEXT: A man distraught over the breakup of his marriage wounded two men, killed his estranged wife and held two children hostage overnight, then killed himself Friday to end a 17-hour standoff, police said. The bodies of Mike Purcell, 38, of Collinsville, Va., and Jeannie Purcell, 33, of Lexington, were found in separate bedrooms of Mrs. Purcell's sister's house about 4 p.m. EDT, said Police Chief Larry Walsh. Police decided to storm the house after a breakdown in negotiations, which began early Friday. ``He was getting worse instead of better. He wanted us to kill him,'' Walsh said. ``We had no alternative but to move on him.'' Walsh said Purcell appeared to have killed himself shortly after police began an assault with tear gas and percussion grenades. But Mrs. Purcell apparently had been dead since 11 p.m. Thursday, he said. Walsh said Purcell had many mood swings during the negotiations but always seemed to be in control. ``He played mind games. He would talk in circles,'' the chief said. Police had been patient with Purcell because they were concerned about the lives of Mrs. Purcell, unaware she was already dead, and officers at the scene, Walsh said. The children _ Troy Jamison, 4, and Brittany Jamison, 1 _ had been held hostage overnight and released about 10 a.m. Friday. Troy is the son of Mark Jamison and Brittany is the daughter of Liz Jamison, Mrs. Purcell's sister. They all lived in the house. Purcell stayed out of the sight of police snipers. ``He was smart. He knew what he was doing,'' Walsh said. Police said the incident began about 10 p.m. Thursday when Purcell, armed with a 9mm pistol, allegedly shot Wayne Deaton, who had arrived to pick up Mrs. Purcell for a date, and Mark Jamison, Mrs. Purcell's brother. Both remained hospitalized Friday, Deaton in critical condition and Jamison in serious condition, hospital officials said. ``I saw him with the gun,'' Liz Jamison said of Purcell. ``He shot at me and made my sister go upstairs. That's when I ran out the back door to the neighbor's house and called the police.'' Ms. Jamison said her sister and Purcell had been married three years. On Jan. 19 and again on Feb. 1, a Fayette District Court ordered Purcell to stay away from his wife because of domestic violence. But he violated both protection orders and was held in contempt of court each time, said Police Lt. Drexel Neal. During the standoff, Purcell became upset when television reports touched on that aspect and demanded an interview with a reporter to give his side of the story. Deborah Moore of WVLK-FM said Purcell told her by telephone that he had been distraught ever since his wife left him without warning in October.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Says He Paid Noriega For Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 4 grafs after the 7th, ``His payment,'' to UPDATE with testimony on dispute with Noriega.
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian convicted of drug dealing testified Friday that he gave ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega $4 million in cash for protection of a cocaine laboratory to be built in Panama. Boris Olarte Morales has been a key prosecution witness in the trial of fellow Colombian Jose Abello Silva, who is charged with conspiracy to import drugs into the United States. Olarte, 27, who pleaded guilty in May 1987 and has been cooperating with the government, said during defense cross-examination that he was smuggling marijuana and cocaine in 1983 when he met Noriega and asked him about doing business. He said he returned to Noriega's home a few weeks later. ``I told him there were some people interested in opening a laboratory to process cocaine in his country and I asked him, was it within his power to protect that operation,'' Olarte tetified. He said Noriega assured him he could provide protection. Olarte said he delivered $4 million in two large suitcases to Noriega, and received 10 percent of the money for setting up the operation. His payment of that bribe is cited in a 1988 indictment in Florida accusing Noriega of drug conspiracy. Olarte said he returned to Panama in early 1984 to let Noriega know that his backers were unhappy with the protection. ``The people that pay him through me to protect the operation in Panama, they were kind of upset,'' Olarte said. ``I said, `You supposed to be protecting the operation over there' and he didn't. ``He said he protected what he was to be protecting, but his people was doing more than they were supposed to do.'' Noriega is accused in the 1988 indictment of agreeing to permit the Medellin cartel to establish and supply a cocaine laboratory in Panama. The indictment says a dispute developed between members of the cartel and Noriega over the seizure of that cocaine laboratory, despite payment by members of the cartel. Olarte also testified during cross-examination Friday that he gave a fellow Tulsa jail inmate $20,000 as a down payment for an armed escape, in which armed mercenaries in helicopters were to help him escape from jail. He said the other inmate never carried through with the plan. Olarte was indicted in Tulsa in 1986 for conspiring to import cocaine. He testified that after he tried to get out of jail, he agreed to plead guilty and work for the government by May 1987. He said he then made a series of phone calls to drug partners in Florida and Aruba in which Abello allegedly got involved in the conspiracy. Abello was indicted in September 1987. He was arrested in Colombia and extradited last October to face charges in Tulsa.

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders Man Resentenced in Lottery Scam
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania's state Superior Court overturned two sentences against a man who pleaded guilty in 1988 to forging a bogus lottery ticket so he could win an unclaimed $15 million jackpot. The court said in an opinion issued Thursday that it agreed the five- to 10-year concurrent sentences against Henry Arthur Rich on conspiracy and forgery charges were ``an abuse of discretion.'' The court ordered Rich to be resentenced on the charges. But it left intact a two- to four-year sentence for theft by deception and a one- to two-year sentence for unlawful use of a computer. Rich worked for a computer firm used by the Pennsylvania Lottery. In an appeal, Rich argued the conspiracy and forgery sentences exceeded guidelines set by the state, and the judge failed to provide an explanation for the deviation as required during sentencing in December 1988. Michael Moyle, a spokesman for the state attorney general, said the decision was under review. He said the office might appeal to the state Supreme Court or wait for the resentencing. During trial, prosecutors said Rich searched for high-value, unclaimed tickets in the lottery system and printed a near-perfect copy of a winning ticket from a July 1987 Super 7 jackpot. After forging the ticket, authorities said, Rich enlisted Mark S. Herbst, a former video store clerk, to turn in the ticket. The lottery awarded the first installment, nearly $470,000, but officials detected the scam after noticing the ticket was not from the location where it had been sold. Herbst, after pleading guilty to theft by deception and other charges, was sentenced to a two- to four-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Company Involved Scoffs at British Allegations of Huge Iraqi Gun
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Thatcher, Bush comment, other. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: A British company accused of preparing steel tubes to make a 131-foot-long gun for Iraq called the allegations absurd Friday and said it had already shipped part of the order to Baghdad. Customs officers on Thursday seized eight sections of forged steel tubing on the docks at Middlesbrough after a Ministry of Defense expert said they could be used to build a weapon. Some arms experts said such a gun could hit Middle East targets hundreds of miles away. Others doubt the tubes could be used to make such a monster gun. ``There is no question it could be used as a barrel of a large artillery gun to fire a projectile of some considerable size. It is definitely subject to export licensing controls,'' said Douglas Tweddle, chief investigator for the Customs and Excise Office. Iraqi officials and the manufacturer, Sheffield Forgemasters, say the tubing was intended for use in a petrochemical plant. The company says the pipe sections were part of an assembly 511.8 feet long. ``I am sure that most people will recognize the absurdity of suggestions being made that these pipes are in fact guns,'' company spokesman Tony Peck said. The company said it had two contracts for 26 sections each, and had delivered 44 sections to the Ministry of Industry and Minerals in Baghdad. Some weapons experts had said a gun with a barrel the size of the tube seized by Customs _ 131 feet long with a 39-inch bore _ could fire nuclear or chemical warheads as far as Tehran or Tel Aviv, each within 350 miles of Iraq's borders. ``If this is a gun we are probably going to have to rethink the laws of physics,'' Ian Hogg, a former lecturer in ordnance design and construction, told The Daily Telegraph. ``I can't see it withstanding the interior explosion of the size necessary to push a 10-ton missile up a 40-meter tube.'' ``If they did manage to get all the other necessary components I wouldn't stand within a mile of the thing if they tried to fire it. It would blow itself to pieces,'' said Phillip Wright, chief executive of Sheffield Forgemasters. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who talked with President Bush in Bermuda on Friday, said, ``The experts are still considering and confirming as to whether it is a gun or simply large steel piping. ``They have not yet made up their minds if it is a gun.'' Bush commended British intelligence and law enforcement agencies for seizing the tubing shortly before it was to be shipped to Iraq. ``Anything we can do to keep guns or chemicals out of the hands of terrorist nations, we should,'' he said. If it turns out the tubing was an illegal weapons export, ``I would encourage and would offer our cooperation to guarantee a total banning and firming up the ban of weapons or potential weapons to countries that are illegally getting them. ``It is our purpose to keep such things out of the hands of the Iraqi government,'' Bush said. Tweddle said it wasn't necessary yet to determine whether the material was intended to be a gun, only that it could be used that way and thus came within the provisions of Britain's embargo on arms shipments to Iraq and Iran. ``The goods are now seized. Investigations will continue to prove intent and to establish whether offenses have been committed,'' he said. Britain banned all arms sales to Iraq and Iran after the outbreak of the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Despite the 1988 cease-fire, the embargo remains. The Independent newspaper reported in Friday editions the manufacturing method _ ``of special pre-stressed, layered compressed steel _ the `autofrettage' technique'' _ was the same used to make gun barrels. The Times of London quoted an unidentified Customs official as saying the seized materials matched a design by Gerald Bull, an American arms expert found murdered in Brussels last month. Jane's Defense Weekly has identified Bull as a designer of South Africa's G5 155mm howitzer, which has been sold to Iraq. The Times quoted the Customs official as saying: ``The manual describes precisely what we have got: the manufacturing process, the methods, what it will fire, the length of the barrel, everything. We are now absolutely certain that it is not only a gun, but a gun made according to a Bull design.'' A Customs spokesman could not be reached for comment on the Good Friday holiday. No one answered the telephone at the agency's press office.

DOC.HEAD: Moore's Downfall Came in Parking Lot Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT Leaberry's middle initial. SUBS 12th graf bgng `There was... to ADD quote from Leaberry lawyer declining to comment on case; picks up 13th graf, `Prosecutors said.
DOC.TEXT: Arch A. Moore Jr., the patriarch of the state Republican Party and former three-time governor, rode so high for so long against political odds that many thought he would never come down. But now federal prosecutors have him in a box. He has admitted kickbacks, coverups and other crimes in office and agreed to testify, possibly against other power brokers in West Virginia politics. Moore's image began unraveling when he met secretly with his former campaign manager in a Parkersburg parking lot three months ago to discuss how they would both lie to a federal grand jury investigating Moore, authorities said. The former governor told John F. Leaberry ``they would both falsely deny to federal investigators and-or the grand jury that there had been cash collected or used illegally,'' authorities said in an indictment announced Thursday. They ``discussed the fact that approximately $35,000 in cash had been collected by them or others during (Moore's) 1988 election campaign,'' according to the indictment. Two days later, Moore denied to federal investigators that he met with Leaberry or knew about the $35,000 in cash, authorities said. He denied both incidents again in a meeting last Monday at the U.S. attorney's office in Charleston, they said. That's when federal prosecutors revealed that Moore's once-trusted aide wore a microphone for the U.S. Justice Department during the parking lot meeting, and they had a tape of Moore's words to Leaberry. U.S. Attorney Michael Carey says the recording of Moore's Jan. 8 conversation led directly to Moore's decision Thursday to agree to plead guilty to five counts of extortion, tax fraud, mail fraud, and obstruction of justice. ``The strength of our case caused him to plead guilty and the tape was part of our case,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Joe Savage. Federal authorities Friday refused to say why Leaberry, Moore's 1988 campaign manager and a former state official, wore the recording device. They said only that Leaberry had been subpoenaed to testify before the grand jury in Charleston. Leaberry's lawyer, John B. Carrico, said Leaberry was out of town Friday but declined to comment further. ``I'm not at liberty to discuss it,'' he said. Prosecutors said that, under the agreement with Moore signed Thursday, he could be named in additional indictments as an unindicted co-conspirator and he agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors in other investigations. The same officials would not elaborate Friday on how they intended to use the ex-governor. ``It's premature to say he'll be testifying in any specific trial,'' Savage said. However, the Charleston Daily Mail, quoting unidentified sources Friday, reported that Moore will be a prosecution witness in the trial of William T. Ellis, a limited partner in the Tri-State Greyhound Park dog track in nearby Nitro. Ellis was indicted on charges of arranging a $100,000 bribe to an unnamed state official and that official's political party. Moore was reached by telephone Friday in West Palm Beach, Fla., but he refused to talk to a reporter. Moore, who turns 67 Monday, is scheduled for arraignment April 26, authorities said. He faces up to 36 years in prison and up to $1.25 million in fines. Moore served as governor from 1969 to 1977 and 1985 to 1989 and was considered the dean of Republican politics in this strongly Democratic state. He battled almost constantly with the Democratic-controlled Legislature, but won voter approval of a constitutional amendment giving the governor broad new power to set the state budget. Once before, he had been indicted for wrongdoing in office but was acquitted. Hours after Moore's indictment Thursday came another indictment of former state Senate President Larry Tucker, charging the Democrat with two counts of obstructing the Internal Revenue Service, one count of lying to a grand jury and one count of perjury. Tucker, who already has served half of a six-month federal sentence, faces a maximum of 18 years in prison and $520,000 in fines in connection with work he allegedly performed for a nursing home.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Mrs. Thatcher Say They're Committed to Finding Terrorists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Lockerbie in 5th graf, Pan Am
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday reassured relatives of two Pan Am 103 victims that the United States is committed to bringing to justice the terrorists who bombed the plane. ``We will continue to do everything we can in cooperation with the U.K. and other countries to get to the bottom of this cowardly, dastardly incident,'' Bush said at the conclusion of a joint news conference with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Mrs. Thatcher said ``no one wants to solve that terrible tragedy more than we do.'' But ``we simply can't pull solutions out of the hat. It's a question of patient, continuous work on that investigation and patient, continuous determination to try to defeat terrorism.'' Pan Am Flight 103, en route from London to New York, exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988. All 259 people on the plane and 11 people on the ground were killed. Bert Ammerman of River Vale, N.J., and Dr. Jim Swire of Bromsgrove, England, called on Bush and Mrs. Thatcher to issue a communique condemning the attack and renewing their determination to catch those responsible. ``As the leaders of the two greatest powers in the free world, it is incumbent upon you to form the nucleus of a concentrated effort to mobilize an effective global strategy to combat terrorism,'' they said in a letter to Bush and Mrs. Thatcher. ``If the United States and the United Kingdom do not stand firm on combating terrorism, but rather acquiesce to politically expedient solutions, we will have compromised our nations' ethics.'' Bush said the record of the United States and United Kingdom in speaking out against terrorist acts was clear. ``But I don't think it hurts to reiterate our conviction that these dastardly terrorist acts must stop.'' He said the United States had ``formed a commission, and I know great inquiry has gone on in the U.K.'' Mrs. Thatcher said authorities had gotten ``quite a long way'' in the investigation, but that it wasn't completed. Mrs. Thatcher said she understands the frustrations of the relatives. ``We, too, wish there were far less terrorism in the world,'' she said. Bush said: ``We understand and we do care,''

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militants Kidnap Former Deputy, 2 Killed
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants on Friday kidnapped a former member of the state legislature and Indian security forces killed two Moslem demonstrators in Kashmir, news reports said. At least 269 people have been killed since a government crackdown of Moslem separatists began in Kashmir in January. Most of the victims were Moslem militants and their supporters who died in clashes with the security forces or while defying curfew. Government troops intensified patrols after the former Congress Party lawmaker, Amirullah Khan, was kidnapped by militants from his home in Shopian, 37 miles northwest of Srinagar, a senior police official said. Earlier this week, Moslem secessionists in Kashmir abducted and killed three hostages, including a prominent educator. The kidnappers were demanding the freedom of three of their jailed comrades. Indian troops shot and killed two Moslem demonstrators at Bhaderwah, 120 miles north of Srinagar, after they attempted to lead a procession following Moslem Friday prayers, officials said. On Thursday, gunfire broke out along the tense frontier of Kashmir and one Indian soldier and five Pakistani troops were killed, the New Delhi-based United News of India reported. In Islamabad, a spokesman for Pakistan's defense ministry said he had no information of the shootout or any Pakistani casualties. ``There were no casualties on our side,'' said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But he added: ``Firing along the cease-fire line is a normal phenomena. It happens almost every day.'' The unresolved fate of Kashmir dates back to 1947 when Indian and Moslem Pakistan were partitioned along religious lines. The old princely state of Kashmir was predominantly Moslem, but its Hindu ruler opted to join India. Today the Kashmir region is divided between India and Pakistan along a disputed frontier and has twice been the cause of war between them. The Indian part of Jammu-Kashmir is the only state in India with a Moslem majority. Nationwide, Hindus form 82 percent of India's 880 million people, while Moslems comprise 12 percent. India has accused Pakistan of fomenting the secessionist violence in Jammu-Kashmir.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Call on Gorbachev to Back Off Lithuanian Sanctions Threat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 24th graf: ``Bush praised,'' to CORRECT ``breeches'' to `breaches''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher urged Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday to call off his threatened economic sanctions against breakaway Lithuania. ``Now is no time for escalation,'' Bush said after he and the prime minister met for several hours of discussions. ``It is time for talk'' between Moscow and the Lithuanians. Said Mrs. Thatcher, ``I abide by the statement the president just made.'' The president and the prime minister met with reporters hours after the Soviet news agency Tass reported that Gorbachev had given the Lithuanian government two days to rescind its ``anti-constitutional actions'' or face the imposition of sanctions. Bush traveled to Bermuda, at Mrs. Thatcher's invitation, to discuss a variety of global issues _ including German unification, NATO and the situation in Lithuania _ in advance of his meeting next month with Gorbachev. The president said he would cooperate in tightening export laws if British investigators determine that a seized load of tubing destined for Iraq amounted to an illegal weapons shipment. Both emphasized their agreement on most issues particularly on the position that a unified Germany should be a permanent member of NATO. At a pre-dinner black tie reception with Mrs. Thatcher aboard the British naval vessel HMS Arrow, the president plunged into a crowd of 400 to 500 cheering bystanders to shake hands. Bush was to play golf Saturday before returning to Washington. The two leaders took a break from serious matters Friday to join about 20 children in a Good Friday tradition of flying kites. The Bermuda ritual was begun by teacher trying to explain to his students Christ's ascension into heaven. Even as he criticized Gorbachev's threatened sanctions, Bush welcomed as ``a positive statement'' the Soviet president's remark to a delegation of U.S. senators on Thursday that the two leaders might be able to initial an arms control pact when they meet in Washington in six weeks. Bush said the ``slant'' of Gorbachev's remarks to the senators was more encouraging than what he had heard from Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze when the two met last week. Reacting to a news agency report that Gorbachev had tightened the pressure on Lithuania with the threat of an economic boycott, Bush said there was little more the Western allies can do to stay Gorbachev's hand without risking a break in East-West relations. ``I am troubled by it,'' the president said of the report, adding that all he knew was what he had read in a brief dispatch from Moscow. ``I know there is a great desire on the part of Americans to know what we might do, what can be done,'' Bush said. But he said that even if he had a response he was not sure he would make it public. ``The answer'' in Lithuania ``is dialogue and peaceful change,'' Bush said. Later, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater was asked if the administration had anything further to say about Lithuania. He replied: ``No. Actually it is less certain now what happened. What we are trying to do is sort out what happened and what it means.'' Both Bush and Mrs. Thatcher reacted to Gorbachev's statement to the visiting senators that he did not need further lectures from outside about his policy toward the Lithuanian attempt to break free of Soviet control. Mrs. Thatcher said she was ``not lecturing anyone'' but is ``entitled to express my view the problem cannot be solved by force.'' ``We have a duty to say what we think,'' she declared. She said she thinks the situation should not be resolved by force. Bush said he felt he was ``on the rigt track'' in urging Gorbachev to proceed with negotiations in lieu of using force. Mrs. Thatcher said British experts had not yet determined if a shipment of metal tubing for Iraq _ halted Thursday at the last moment _ contained the makings for an enormous gun barrel rather than, as Iraq claimed, sections of pipeline. Bush praised the British for catching the shipment in time. ``There has been superb cooperation between the United States and the United Kingdom in trying to avert breaches in the law,'' he said. En route to Bermuda for his sixth meeting with the British leader in his 15-month presidency, Bush welcomed Gorbachev's ``very positive statement'' on the prospects for reaching a nuclear-arms accord at next month's superpower summit. ``We are sending the same signals to our negotiators and policy-makers,'' Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One. Earlier in the day, the president was greeted by the prime minister under overcast skies at a breezy arrival ceremony on the grounds of the 33-acre, oceanside Government House. After reviewing brightly uniformed and helmeted members of the Bermuda Guard, the two leaders went inside for their meeting. In his remarks on the way to Bermuda, a self-ruling British colony, the president said he was ``very upbeat'' about the Thatcher meeting _ one of a series of three face-to-face, pre-summit sessions with allied leaders. He met with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney in Toronto on Tuesday and plans to meet Thursday in Key Largo, Fla., with French President Francois Mitterrand. The president said he welcomed Gorbachev's comments on initialling a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START) at their Washington summit. ``I viewed that as a very positive statement,'' Bush said. He said he was eager to meet next week with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, who headed the senatorial delegation that met with Gorbachev. Bush shrugged off Gorbachev's comment to the senators cautioning the United States against preaching to the Kremlin about Lithuania. Moscow views the Baltic republic's March 11 declaration of independence as illegal. ``I don't view that (Gorbachev's remarks) as a hostile comment, but I view it as a reiteration of his well-known position'' that the dispute in Lithuania is an internal Soviet matter, Bush said. By the same token, Bush added, ``I will continue to say what I think on this subject.'' Bush has voiced his support for the self-determination rights of Lithuanians but has urged restraint on both sides. Asked if he feared that Soviet hard-liners advocating greater use of force in Lithuania were gaining influence, Bush said: ``There is some speculation on that. ... But we cannot read the tea leaves with total clarity when it comes to pressures inside the Kremlin.'' He also welcomed the East German government's public apology to Jews for Nazi atrocities. ``I'm one who believes in forgiveness,'' the president said. ``And this is a good day for forgiveness.'' He added: ``I'm inclined to think we ought to forgive, but not forget. I'm a Christian. I think forgiveness is something I feel very strongly about.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged With Killing Six Women
DOC.TEXT: A 22-year-old man was charged Friday with killing six of seven women strangled here since September and with the assault Monday night of another woman whose attack was interrupted by a passerby. The charges against Ray Shawn Jackson of Kansas City were announced at a news conference held by police Chief Larry Joiner, Jackson County Prosecutor Albert Riederer and Kansas City Mayor Richard Berkley. Joiner said that the six strangled women had all been lured to the areas where they were slain, in or near Gillham Park in midtown, by the promise of obtaining crack cocaine. Many blacks have said authorities and the media failed to give the case adequate attention because the victims were black prostitutes and drug addicts. ``Gillham Park has become a death trap for black women,'' Ron Finley, a member of the Ad Hoc Group Against Crime, said before Jackson's arrest. The chief said the charges were the outcome of thousands of hours of investigation that speeded up again last week after the death of Michelle Mitchell, 22. Circulation of a composite drawing of a man believed to be a suspect in her death produced more than 300 phone calls, Joiner said. Detectives were told that Jackson, who is also black, matched the description of the drawing and that he had been bragging about killing a woman in Gillham Park. Joiner said officers found him at a relative's house where he stayed periodically. The chief said Jackson had no history of violence or any prior arrest record, but that it was his understanding he had used drugs. ``I don't think I can get into his motives,'' Joiner said. In addition to the killing of Miss Mitchell, whose body was found on April 5, Jackson is charged with killing Annette Stewart, 33, whose body was found Sept. 16; Kimberly Creer, 22, found Sept. 20; Tresa Williams, 21, found Oct. 22; Janice Berryman, 36, found Oct. 28; and Tonya Ward, 23, found Jan. 18. The investigation has not produced evidence linking Jackson to the death of the seventh woman, Brenda McCoy, 33, who was found Sept. 26, Joiner said. But the 27-year-old black woman assaulted on Monday night had identified Jackson from a photograph as her assailant, he said. According to police statements, the woman said she was walking on the street and noticed someone following her. She said he asked to join her and she refused, and that later the man came at her from behind, knocking her down and dragging her into some bushes where he began choking her. The woman said the assailant was scared away by a man out walking his dog. Jackson told detectives he killed the six women after offering to get cocaine for them, according to police. He said he packed mud in one woman's mouth, and removed his victims' clothing and scattered it around after killing them.

DOC.HEAD: Fire in Bombay's Biggest Hotel Forces Evacuation of 1,000 Guests
LaserPhoto BOM1 of April 13
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of firefighters battled flames Friday at a 36-story luxury hotel after a late-night blaze forced the evacuation of more than 1,000 guests. No casualties were reported from the fire that started Thursday night in the basement of the five-star Oberoi Towers Hotel, Bombay's biggest. At one point, it appeared that most rooms were on fire. Navy helicopters swooped low Friday to look for anyone who might have been trapped. Firefighters equipped with oxygen tanks were lowered onto the terrace to search the top 10 floors, but they found no one. The firefighters had contained the fire to the basement Friday, said Deputy Chief Fire Officer M.G. Sirkhot. White smoke billowed from the building, which faces the Arabian Sea. The cause of the fire was not immediately known, but one hotel staffer said it was probably due to a short circuit in the basement. Authorities evacuated more than 1,000 guests from Oberoi Towers and the adjacent Oberoi Hotel, placing them in other hotels in the city.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Favors Forgiving East Germans for Holocaust
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4-7: ``In a,'' with comment from Wiesenthal center
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday that he was inclined to forgive the East Germans for their role in the murder of millions of Jews during the Holocaust. The East German legislature accepted responsibility Thursday for the Nazi atrocities during World War II and sought assurances of forgiveness from Israel, the Soviet Union and Jews around the world. ``I'm one who believes in forgiveness,'' Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One just before takeoff for Bermuda and his one-day meeting with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``It's a good day for forgiveness for those of us who have faith.'' In a statement received in Washington, the Simon Wiesenthal Center of Los Angeles said the president's remark was ``morally wrong and politically dangerous'' because ``the generation of Germans who perpetrated the Holocaust can never be forgiven for their heinous crimes.'' ``Indeed, the only people who could have granted them forgiveness perished in the gas chambers,'' the center said in a statement. ``While the Jewish people do not hold those individuals born after the Holocaust to be responsible for the crimes of their forefathers, nonetheless the legacy of Auschwitz must be permanently embedded into the conscience of the German nation,'' the statement said. The center is a private group devoted to education about the Nazi murder of 6 million Jews and the capture of Nazi war criminals. Bush noted the start of the Easter weekend _ he attended a sunrise Good Friday church service before leaving Washington. Asked about the service, Bush joked with reporters: ``We prayed for you.'' He turned more solemn when asked about East Germany and the Holocaust. ``For our family, Easter is a very special time of year. And it's a time to take stock and to be glad,'' Bush said. ``I'm a Christian,'' he said, ``and I think that forgiveness is something that I feel very strongly about.'' But while Bush advocated forgiveness he said the world should not forget the Holocaust. ``You learn from history, what not to do wrong, how to conduct oneself,'' he said. Bush said his feelings about forgiveness were a ``personal observation. It's not a statement for our country.'' In its statement, the East German parliament said, ``Nationalism and racial madness led to genocide, particularly of the Jews in all European countries, of the people of the Soviet Union, the Polish people and the Gypsy people. Parliament ... admits joint responsibility on behalf of the people for the humiliation, expulsion and murder of Jewish women, men and children.''

DOC.HEAD: Experiment May Light Up the Sky
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the north central United States and central Canada may see a rainbow of colors in the night sky before dawn on Easter Sunday if a National Aeronautics and Space Administration proceeds as planned. NASA announced Saturday that the Pegsat satellite would release a canister of barium at 1:36 a.m. EDT Sunday 362 miles above the earth over northern Canada, between Churchill and Yellowknife, if conditions are right for the test. The barium should form a yellowish cloud, which will change to green and white, then fade while a purple streak grows vertically, NASA said. The experiment is aimed at studying the interactions of the barium with the electric and magnetic fields of the earth and with other characteristics of space at that altitude, NASA said. Scientists at several sites in the United States and Canada will be watching the barium cloud. The Pegsat satellite was released from the unique winged Pegasus space vehicle launched from a B-52 on April 5.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Arrives In U.S. To Face Fraud Charges
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli who was indicted by his government for allegedly defrauding two U.S. banks of $6.1 million arrived in New York from Israel and appeared before a federal magistrate Friday. The case of Samuel Dagan marks the first time U.S. and Israeli officials have cooperated to prosecute an Israeli accused of crimes in this country, federal authorities said. Efforts to prosecute Dagan and his wife, Miriam K. Dagan, had been hindered by an Israeli law that prevents its citizens from being extradited to stand trial for crimes committed outside Israel. But following two years of negotiations between Israel and the U.S. authorities, Israeli authorities charged the Dagans in February with closely related charges in a 22-count indictment. Dagan, escorted by U.S. Marshals but not handcuffed, appeared briefly before U.S. Magistrate Allyne Ross in Brooklyn Federal Court in New York City. Dagan told Ross he understood that he was going to Hartford, Conn., to be tried there on charges of defrauding the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company and the Connecticut Savings Bank out of $6.1 million in 1987. He declined to comment on the case, telling reporters outside the courtroom, ``I don't want to say anything now before the trial.'' A former West Hartford resident, Dagan agreed to return to the United States voluntarily from Israel to be tried. His wife was also charged in a federal indictment but decided to remain in Israel, according to U.S. Attorney Stanley A. Twardy Jr. The Dagans, well-known business owners and prominent members of West Hartford's Jewish community, fled the United States in March 1988, just before a warrant was issued for their arrest. The federal indictment, returned Aug. 23, 1988, in Hartford, charged Dagan and his wife each with one count of conspiring to defraud federally insured banks, nine counts of bank fraud and 16 counts of false statements to banks. The couple allegedly participated in a check-kiting scheme involving accounts they had at both banks for local businesses they operated, according to the indictment. Dagan's lawyer, public defender Lori Levinson, advised the court Friday that Dagan recently underwent surgery and was in need of medical care. After spending the weekend at a Hartford jail, he was scheduled to appear Monday morning before a federal magistrate in Hartford.

DOC.HEAD: Death of AIDS Victim Ryan White Sparks Protest
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-five middle school students were suspended for staging a sit-in when school administrators refused to let them lower the school's flag in honor of AIDS victim Ryan White. The students at Madison Middle School sat around the school flagpole, saying they would not return to class until the American flag was lowered to half-staff. The students' planned tribute Wednesday coincided with the day of White's funeral in Indiana. The teen-ager, who was a hemophiliac, died Sunday from AIDS-related complications. He had contracted the disease from tainted blood products. When middle school officials declined to lower the flag the morning of White's funeral, a number of students left their classrooms and sat around the flagpole, school officials said. Assistant Principal Carl Ihle said officials were aware earlier that students wanted to lower the flag. Administrators scheduled an assembly to honor White Wednesday morning, but the students wanted more, he said. After a flurry of calls by school officials, parents and children to the Eugene school superintendent's office and to state and federal offices, Superintendent Margaret Nichols said she made the final decision not to lower the flag, based on the U.S. flag code. Nichols said she did not have the authority to grant the students permission to lower the flag. However, she said she supported their right to disagree with the decision. ``It's kind of like a little metaphor for what it's like to be an American,'' Nichols said. ``People make a decision you do or don't like.'' Students who refused to return to class were assessed a two-day suspension, Ihle said. The school's refusal to lower the flag raised questions among some parents. ``It's like we can burn the flag in protest, but our kids can't lower it for 15 minutes. I don't get it,'' said Kathy Dennis, whose daughter, Michelle, 13, was among those suspended.

DOC.HEAD: Two Prisoners Surrender in 13th Day of Prison Siege
DOC.TEXT: Two prisoners surrendered Friday at Strangeways Prison, leaving fewer than 13 rebel inmates inside as the prison revolt entered its 13th day, the Home Office said. Some of those still barricaded in the prison held up a sign to reporters saying, ``We will come down on Sunday.'' Solicitor Barry Cuttle, who has been acting as an independent observer at negotiations between the remaining inmates and the prison staff, said he had been hopeful the siege would end on Good Friday. But he added: ``We have been hopeful for a long time and have been let down and disappointed.'' Several of the rebel inmates remained on the prison roof, whistling and shouting to scores of spectators in the streets below. The standoff began April 1 when hundreds of prisoners rioted and badly damaged the overcrowded Victorian prison. Several inmates who surrendered earlier claimed they had seen dead bodies inside, but others insisted there had been no deaths. One prisoner accused of sexually assaulting three children died from injuries in the rioting and a prison guard died of a heart attack. The prison held more than 1,500 inmates in the 900-capacity facility at the time of the riot.

DOC.HEAD: Leona Helmsley Writes $42 Million Check for 1989 Taxes
LaserPhoto SAX1
DOC.TEXT: Convicted tax evader Leona Helmsley made out a check for $42,065,000 to the Internal Revenue Service on national television Friday to show she pays her taxes. Mrs. Helmsley said the sum will pay off the 1989 joint personal income of her and her husband, real estate and hotel magnate Harry Helmsley. ``And we've already paid $22 million, which brings it to a gross of about $65 million for this year alone,'' she said. ``We paid our taxes in the past, we paid them now and we'll pay them in the future,'' she said. ``I want the public to know that we're good Americans.'' Helmsley, wearing a white blouse, black slacks, black-and-gold sandals and a gold necklace, also noted that she and her husband have given $143 million to charity. In addition, she said, they paid $29.7 million in New York city and state taxes. Mrs. Helmsley, 69, was convicted last year of federal income tax fraud and sentenced to four years in prison, but is free on bond pending appeal. She still faces state charges that she, her husband and two former employees falsified $3 million worth of business and tax records from 1982 to 1986. Her attorneys have asked that those charges be dismissed but the judge has not yet ruled. Mrs. Helmsley faces up to four years in state prison if convicted. Her 80-year-old husband was found mentally incompetent to stand trial in federal court and is seeking the dismissal of state charges on the same grounds. Mrs. Helmsley said she agreed to be videotaped by the syndicated television program ``A Current Affair'' while vacationing at her Harley Sandcastle hotel on Lido Key to show that she pays taxes like everyone should. The segment aired later Friday. Mrs. Helmsley has steadfastly maintained she is innocent of tax evasion. She said an appeal will be filed April 25 asking for a new trial. ``We've had a very hard time,'' she said. ``It's been close to five years of them persecuting us. ... It's constant badgering, constant courtrooms, constant attorneys, constant pressure.''

DOC.HEAD: Idling Greyhound Bus Found Near Train Tracks
SUBS 9th graf, `The bus...,' to CORRECT to spokesman, sted spokeswoman.
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound bus was discovered parked near railroad tracks Friday, its engine still running, and police said it apparently was abandoned after a failed attempt to park it across the tracks. Officials of strike-bound Greyhound Lines Inc. had not reported the bus missing when police patrolling the suburb west of Chicago found it about 1:30 a.m., said Maywood Police Sgt. Donald Mobley. The bus was about 2 feet from the tracks. ``Apparently, they were trying to get it onto the tracks, but it got stuck on the rocks near the tracks and whoever brought it there abandoned it,'' Mobley said. Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers walked out March 2 in an argument over wages and job security. The company has been operating a reduced schedule since, using permanent replacements and drivers willing to cross picket lines. Greyhound has reported more than 30 shooting attacks on its buses, 70 bomb threats, and more than 100 incidents of violence. One picketing driver, Robert Waterhouse, 59, died when he was crushed by a bus driven by a replacement driver in Redding, Calif. The dead man's son, Bob Waterhouse Jr. of Wenatchee, Wash., picketed the Greyhound depot in his home town of Wenatchee, Wash., on Thursday in protest after a Shasta County, Calif., district attorney decided not to charge the driver of the bus. Bill Pearsall, an official of the Amalgamated Transit Union in Chicago, said strikers had nothing to do with the bus' disappearance. The bus arrived in Chicago on Thursday from Milwaukee, said Greyhound spokesman Bill Kula. The driver was told to drive another bus back to Milwaukee and another driver was supposed to take the bus to the garage for servicing. ``Somehow or another that didn't happen,'' said Kula. ``The wires got crossed.'' Someone started it and drove off unseen Between 8 p.m. and 12 a.m., Kula said. To prevent similar incidents in the future, Greyhound is requiring drivers in Chicago to show photo identification cards before they leave the terminal, Kula said. Elsewhere, a New York state judge signed an order Friday barring Greyhound from employing ``strikebreakers'' within New York City, but attorneys for striking workers said it was doubtful the order would be followed. The order did not spell out any penalties or sanctions against Greyhound if it failed to comply. Acting state Supreme Court Justice Diane Lebedeff actually granted the temporary restraining order verbally last week, basing it on an anti-strikebreaking statute passed by the City Council in 1962 but never before applied. Lebedeff also allowed Ronald L. Kuby, an attorney for Local 1202 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, and co-counsel William Kunstler to take depositions of Greyhound drivers in New York City. Kunstler, the noted civil rights attorney, said the interviews would allow the unions to learn if replacement workers have criminal records, bad driving histories or if they received bonuses to work for Greyhound. ``Our effort will be to show they're really hiring bums in order to break the union,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Leads Torchlight Procession in Good Friday Remembrance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with celebrations in Israel, Mexico, the Phillipines. Pickup 4th pvs, `All of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ROM2
DOC.TEXT: Lifting a slender, 5-foot-high cross before him, Pope John Paul II led a torchlight procession through the Colosseum Friday night to re-enact Jesus' march to his crucifixion. Thousands of people bearing candles in red paper cones watched the Good Friday ceremony, broadcast to millions throughout the world. The ceremony was one of several worldwide that marked Good Friday. Thousands of pilgrims retraced the traditional procession route through Jerusalem's Old City, and hundreds of thousands of Roman Catholics turned out for the 146th annual re-enactment of the crucifixion at an ancient Indian ceremonial site in Mexico. In the Philippines, more than 20 Filipino penitents were nailed to crosses today, and others whipped themselves bloody as Asia's only predominantly Christian nation marked the crucifixion. The penitents were nailed to the crosses for up to 10 minutes. Traffic jams snared holidary travelers in East and West Germany. For the first time, the ceremony in Rome was transmitted to the Soviet Union, the state-owned Italian RAI network said. ``All of us who belong to the priestly people of the new covenant gaze upon the cross, with veneration and recollection,'' John Paul said in a brief address in Italian at the end of the procession of the Via Crucis, or Way of the Cross. ``We draw nourishment from the impenetrable mystery, which human words cannot describe.'' The procession, from the Colosseum to the edge of the ancient Roman Forum, evoked the tortures Jesus suffered as he made his way to his crucifixion on Calvary Hill in Jerusalem. At each of the 14 stops representing the stages of Jesus' suffering, men and women read meditations written by the Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, Michel Sabbah. They asked for spiritual blessings for modern Christians. The pope, wearing white robes and a crimson cape trimmed with gold, carried before him a slender black cross made of lightweight wood. He was followed by two men bearing torches and a group of cardinals and other priests. Thousands of nuns, tourists and Romans outside the Colosseum prayed and sang in Latin as the pope walked slowly between the stations. A large cross made of candles flickered inside the Colosseum. The Good Friday ceremonies mark the most solemn day of the year for Christians, who celebrate Jesus' resurrection on Easter Sunday. The papal tradition of marking the Way of the Cross was revived in 1964 by Pope Paul VI after an interruption of nearly a century following the creation of the modern Italian state. Among the 14 Stations of the Cross are stops marking the three times Jesus stumbles and falls under the weight of the cross. In a Good Friday message issued earlier to Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, the pope appealed anew for a halt to the ``fratricidal'' fighting in Lebanon. ``The drama of Lebanon must end ... Lebanon must live again,'' said the telegram, which came on the 15th anniversary of the start of Lebanon's civil war. The pontiff also celebrated a ceremony in St. Peter's Basilica Friday afternoon marking Jesus' sacrifice. He prayed for a variety of groups, including Jews. ``May the Lord our God, who once spoke to their (the Jews') fathers, help them to always advance in the love of his name and in faithfulness to his alliance,'' the pope said. Catholic Church policy toward Jews underwent a major change with the 1965 document Nostra Aetate, which officially refuted the charge that Jews bore collective responsibility for killing Jesus. Just after noon, John Paul heard the confessions of 12 pilgrims in St. Peter's Basilica, continuing a Good Friday tradition he began 11 years ago to emphasize the importance of the sacrament. The pope will celebrate the Easter Vigil Saturday night, followed by an open-air Mass on Easter Sunday in St. Peter's Square.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Asks Canadian Company to Hire More Catholics in Ireland
DOC.TEXT: A city councillor from Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, arrived in Montreal from Northern Ireland to demand that Belfast's main employer, a Canadian-owned company, hires more Catholics. Pat Rice, a councillor in the Belfast suburb of Lisburn, began a series of meetings Friday to persuade the Montreal-based Bombardier Inc. to hire more Catholics at its Short Brothers PLC aircraft and missile manufacturing subsidiary. Bombardier bought the sprawling company, which employs 7,000, from the British government in October for $60 million. Since June, when the purchase was announced, the IRA has bombed Short four times to protest what it called job discrimination. No one has been injured in the bombings. Rice said the IRA bombings of the Short plant were ``not the ideal background for my visit.'' ``But I can see certain advantages, if you like, as a shot across the bow to Bombardier about a problem which they have inherited,'' he said. Rice said just 11 percent of Short's workforce is Catholic, although Catholics make up 36 percent of Northern Ireland's population. ``Short ... has always been a symbol of discrimination,'' he said. Bombardier officials were unavailable for comment Friday. But in a recent interview, Bombardier spokesman Yvon Turcot said the IRA had the ``wrong address'' in bombing the plant. He said Short had a strong record in recruiting Catholic workers and ``Bombardier is certainly not going to jeopardize that record.'' Rice said that Bombardier has ``expressed good intentions about hiring Catholics.'' But he added: ``We have an expression in Ireland: `Words don't feed the brethren.'''

DOC.HEAD: Northrop Plans B-2 Cutbacks To Make Program More Politically Palatable
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. has launched a cost-cutting program to protect the $75 billion stealth bomber program, including layoffs, a trimmed inspection program and reduced security, a spokesman said Friday. ``We have a cost-reduction effort,'' said Northrop spokesman Tony Cantafio, but he noted the reductions were part of a long-planned, companywide effort to trim expenses. ``We are streamlining throughout the company. Last year we announced that this kind of undertaking would take place throughout the company,'' Cantafio said. In addition to cost cuts, Northrop documents show the company also aims to boost profits on the so-far anemic B-2 program, increasing its goal from a 6 percent profit margin this year to 9 percent. The expensive stealth bomber program has been facing stiff congressional criticism. ``The public debate has been on the cost,'' said Oliver Boileau, stealth division president. ``It is prudent for management to always try to drive costs down. We are doing our part.'' Cantafio said delaying the program adds to cost. ``These are the things we are doing in the factory to cut costs. The big thing with the B-2 is the rate (at which) we build them,'' he said. Though the company has not set a cost-reduction goal, Boileau said the current reductions should do enough to lower the overall cost of the program. Among the steps is laying off as many as 500 of the 12,000 Northrop B-2 employees at the stealth operations in Pico Rivera and Palmdale. The final number of layoffs is being worked out, Boileau said. ``We had peak employment of 14,500 during development of the B-2 and now we are at 12,000, but we will also be hiring in Palmdale,'' said Cantafio. ``They are in a transition from development to full-scale production. ``Some positions will be eliminated, but others will be created.'' Led by California Democratic Sen. Alan Cranston, critics of the B-2 contend the per-plane cost could run as high as $1.95 billion if the government cuts back on its plan to buy 132 bombers. Another cost-cutting step involves reducing security, a high-price item on a program as highly classified as the B-2. For years, the company would not even admit the program existed. ``Security requirements have been reduced as far as the government wants to go,'' Boileau said. Other measures include having factory employees inspect some of their own work, consolidating three computer centers into two, cutting travel expenses and reducing outside contracting for labor.

DOC.HEAD: Ore., Calif., Ariz. Grocery Chains Announce Enviro Certification
DOC.TEXT: Four western grocery chains said Friday they would try to help consumers cut through deceptive environmental advertising. Manufacturers will be asked to verify their product claims with third-party certification under the program announced Friday by Fred Meyer Inc. of Portland, Ore., Raley's of Sacramento, Calif., Ralphs Grocery Co. of Compton, Calif., and ABCO Markets Inc. of Phoenix, Ariz. Companies that can prove their claims and use significant levels of recycled material in their products and packaging will receive a special label for their product called the Green Cross Recycling Seal of Approval. Another label, the Green Cross Environmental Seal of Approval, will be granted to companies that meet even stricter recycling standards, adopt aggressive solid waste reduction policies and adhere to ``zero tolerance'' production standards for emissions of any materials that cause cancer or are capable of causing reproductive harm. Signs will be posted in stores to alert customers to products with the seals of approval. ``We want to send the message to manufacturers of products that environmental concern is not some passing fancy,'' said Fred Meyer spokesman Rob Boley. ``Unfortunately, there are a few companies that are relying on Madison Avenue to develop their environmental policy,'' said Craig Merrilees of the National Toxics Campaign, who said the four chains ``deserve our support and praise.'' Fred Meyer operates 125 stores in seven Western states. ABCO has 75 supermarkets in Arizona. Ralphs operates 143 stores in southern California and Raley's has 58 stores in northern California and northern Nevada.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Says Cincinnatians Support Mapplethorpe Show
DOC.TEXT: Most Cincinnati residents believe an art gallery should be allowed to show Robert Mapplethorpe's controversial photographs, according to a poll published Friday by The Cincinnati Post. The poll of 561 adults in Hamilton County found that 59 percent support the Contemporary Arts Center in displaying the photographs. The art gallery and is director were indicted one week ago on misdemeanor obscenity charges for displaying seven photos that show naked children or homoerotic acts. County Prosecutor Arthur Ney Jr. tried to get the seven photographs voluntarily removed following the indictments, but a federal judge granted the art gallery a protective order prohibiting authorities from interfering with the show. Prosecutors will have to convince a jury that the photos violate community standards in order to get an obscenity conviction. The poll, conducted by the Institute for Policy Research on behalf of the newspaper, found that ``a substantial majority wants the photos to be shown,'' said Al Tuchfarber, who directed the survey at the institute. Roughly 38 percent said the photographs shouldn't be shown, and 3 percent had no opinion. Support for the show came from all demographic groups, Tuchfarber said. The strongest opposition came from the elderly and those who haven't attended college. Younger residents tended to support the art gallery, and men favored the exhibition in larger numbers than did women, the poll found. Religion appeared to play no major role _ a majority of Catholics (56 percent) and Protestants (57 percent) supported it. ``These numbers shatter the myth that this is a heavily conservative community,'' Tuchfarber said. The telephone survey was conducted last Wednesday and Thursday. It has a margin for error of 4 percent. Roughly 96 percent of those who were surveyed had seen, read or heard about the exhibit. ``That number is absolutely phenomenal for an issue like this,'' Tuchfarber said. On another question, about 55 percent said the government and courts should have no role in determining what is displayed at art museums. About 42 percent said they'd support government involvement if displays ``seriously offend community standards.'' In a related development Friday, Mayor Charles Luken accused Ney, the county prosecutor, of backing out of the obscenity case because he doubted he could win. Ney on Thursday transferred the case to the city prosecutor's office, saying his office couldn't handle the case because the charges involved were only misdemeanors. ``I think this is a politically hot potato, and the reason Mr. Ney is doing this is that he doesn't feel he can win,'' Luken said. Ney's assistant, Chip Gerhardt, denied the accusation. Gerhardt said Ohio law prohibits Ney's office from prosecuting misdemeanors. ``The law is clear on this, and Mr. Luken's a lawyer and he should understand the law,'' Gerhardt said.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalists Attack Algerian Concert
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred Islamic fundamentalists attacked a city theater to stop a music concert, and several dozen people were injured in the melee, the official news agency reported Friday. The confrontation late Wednesday night at the Atlas Hall in the capital's Bab el-Oued district was the latest of several such incidents. There were few details on the violence, but the concert reportedly involved a music group of Kabyles, a Berber group that has long had friction with Arabs. The official APS news agency said 20 people were arrested following the attack on the theater, which is near a mosque. It said the injured included eight policemen. A spokesman for the Islamic Salvation Front, a fundamentalist party, claimed the incident was the work of an unidentified ``third force'' trying to discredit fundamentalists. Witnesses, however, blamed Islamic fundamentalists. The fundamentalists are expected to make gains in regional elections June 12 in this North African country.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman's Wife Shoots Beauty Parlor Owner, Kills Self
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix spelling of name.
DOC.TEXT: A police officer sent to a shooting at a beauty parlor discovered his wife had used his handgun to shoot the shop's owner and then kill herself. Judy Gillette critically wounded the owner, Shari Carrano, before fatally shooting herself in the head Thursday, police said. Carrano was in critical condition Friday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport, a hospital spokeswoman said. Lt. Terry Gillette, a 24-year veteran of the police force and the shift commander on Thursday, was led away from the scene by another officer and is in seclusion, Police Chief Robert Wesche said. ``He did not know until he got there,'' Wesche said. ``He got there shortly after the others did.'' Police said they did not have a motive for the shooting. Authorities said Mrs. Gillette walked into The Only One beauty salon Thursday morning and asked Carrano for an appointment. When the owner sat down, Mrs. Gillette pulled out a gun and shot Carrano in the eye before turning the gun on herself, Wesche said. Mrs. Gillette, 56, died a short time later. Detective Sgt. Normand Mercier said there was no argument between the two women and that police had no knowledge of any feud between them.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Pro-Logging Workers Rally in Portland
LaserPhoto PD1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of loggers and mill workers jammed a downtown square Friday to protest the movement to remove large tracts of timber from logging production to save forest owls. Some 8,000 to 10,000 people protested an emerging national policy to limit logging the last of the never-cut timber in the Pacific Northwest. Timber families fear they will be ignored by policy-makers from outside the region. Environmentalists argue that the old growth timber must be protected to save the northern spotted owl from extinction. They say the owl cannot survive outside the complex ecosystem anchored by centuries-old trees. ``I know we care for our forests,'' said Audrey Barnes, whose family's ties to the timber industry stretch back three generations. ``I know we can live with nature and nature with us.'' Organizers said 350 businesses around the state closed so their employees could attend. Some schools excused students so they could join their families at the hourlong rally at Pioneer Courthouse Square. Douglas County officials gave 25 to 30 local government employees the day off with pay; about 105 businesses closed and 500 people came from the major mill town of Sweet Home. Bob and Susan Kasting, owners of the Busy Bee restaurant in Sweet Home, said shutting down the timber industry would devastate his business. ``If they can't work, they can't eat,'' he said. Republican Sen. Bob Packwood said he had run out of patience with environmentalists seeking to end all logging in the state. He told the crowd that their efforts could be condensed into two words: ``No jobs.'' ``You and I know we can have jobs forever,'' Packwood said. Coalition member Evelyn Badger said Congress would be asked to set aside forest land specifically for timber harvests. ``We are the dirty-hands people who feed, clothe and shelter this nation,'' she said. Environmentalist Mari Hoffman from Vancouver, Wash., who carried a sign advocating protection for old growth, said she thought the timber industry had forced the debate over logging by over-cutting the Northwest woods. ``We're not opposed to logging,'' she said. ``We're just opposed to the amount of logging that's taking place.''

DOC.HEAD: Chiles Depression Treated With Prozac
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after graf 7, ``I think ... the report,' to UPDATE with Chiles saying treatment near completion; picksup 8th graf, `Spokesman for.
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Sen. Lawton Chiles, the latest candidate in the Democratic gubernatorial field, acknowledges he is being treated for depression but his opponents Friday shied away from making it an issue. Chiles, 60, readily admitted Thursday that he has been treated for the past year with Prozac, a revolutionary but expensive new anti-depressant drug that came onto the market in late 1987. ``I wish I had known about Prozac earlier because it has helped me,'' said Chiles, who said his condition stemmed partly from his retirement from the Senate in January 1989. ``I've had depression and sought treatment,'' Chiles told The Palm Beach Post in a telephone interview Thursday. The Post attributed the initial report about his ailment to unidentified ``Republican officials,'' but GOP officials Friday distanced themselves from the report. ``I think I was depressed about what was going on in the state,'' joked Chiles, who said he takes one pill a day and feels great. ``Now I'm going to do something about it.'' Chiles said in a telephone interview Friday his treatment is near completion. ``I think I'm finishing up,'' Chiles said. ``It has really helped me. I really feel great.'' Spokesmen for Chiles' two Democratic opponents said their candidates were healthy and that Chiles' depression was not presently an issue. ``We're not making it an issue, certainly at this stage'' said Don Pride, press secretary for U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson, who had been considered the Democratic frontrunner until Chiles' entry. However, Pride said Chiles' decision to leave the Senate after his third term because the senator claimed to be ``burned out'' was an issue. Prozac, which costs between $1.25 and $1.60 a pill, is the most frequently prescribed anti-depressant in the country. Physicians in the United States write or renew about 650,000 Prozac prescriptions each month, according to published reports. A Tampa pyschiatrist, Walter Field, said it would be ``disgraceful and irresponsible'' if someone questioned Chiles' abilities because he is taking Prozac. Brian Ballard, operations director for Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, commented, ``Using this as an issue is not something we're going to do. ``The governor is saying it's up to the Democrats to decide whether that is an issue or not,'' said Ballard. ``I know the governor does not think the campaign is based on that type of thing. He wants to talk about the issues.'' The governor's campaign manager, J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich, said there isn't enough information available on the seriousness of the illness. ``We're not going to make it an issue now,'' said Stipanovich. ``We're waiting for a nominee.'' Scott Sokol, communications and political director for Democrat George Stuart's campaign, said Chiles' medical standing was a private matter and should not be available for public examination. Aides for Martinez, Stuart and Nelson said all three would make their candidates' medical records available. Nelson breezed through a complete NASA physical and mental checkup in September 1985 preceding his flight with space shuttle Columbia in January 1986, Pride said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Suspects Charged With Trooper Killing
DOC.TEXT: Two men being held on handgun charges in New York have been charged with first-degree murder in the slaying of a Maryland state trooper, state police said Thursday. Eric Tirado, 26, and Francisco Rodriguez, 20, both from New York, were already being held in the Bronx House of Detention on unrelated charges when they were served with the first-degree murder warrants Thursday, police spokesman Chuck Jackson said. Tirado and Rodriguez were awaiting extradition Thursday night, Jackson said. Cpl. Eric Wolf, 40, was shot to death March 29 after making a traffic stop on Interstate 95 near Jessup. His body was found slumped over in the driver's seat by an off-duty Washington policeman who stopped to investigate why the police car was parked on the side of the highway. State Police Superintendent Col. Elmer Tippett said the warrants were based on ``forensic evidence developed at the crime scene.'' He refused to offer further details because the investigation was continuing. Upon extradition to Maryland, Tirado and Rodriguez will be charged with first-degree murder, use of a handgun in the commission of a felony and possession of a handgun, Jackson said.

Environmentalists and lawmakers are hailing a decision by three U.S. tuna canners _ including the world's largest _ not to buy or sell tuna captured along with dolphins. Environmental groups predicted the move by companies selling the StarKist, Bumble Bee and Chicken of the Sea brands will save some of the estimated 100,000 dolphins that die annually in huge nets used to catch schools of tuna. StarKist Seafood Co. said Thursday it ``will not purchase any tuna caught in association with dolphins'' and ``will sell only dolphin-free tuna.'' The action was taken in ``recognition of increased consumer concern for the environment'' and because ``the greatest concern in the tuna industry is dolphin mortality,'' said Anthony A.F. O'Reilly, president of the H.J. Heinz Co., which owns StarKist.

A play about a sharecropper whose grandfather was a slave, a novel about Cuban musicians in New York and poetry by a Yugoslavian immigrant won Pulitzer Prizes. The 21 prizewinners Thursday also included two California newspapers, for their coverage of the Oct. 17 earthquake, and three newspapers awarded for reporting health threats _ in a city's water supply, in a dietary supplement and in blood supplies. The seven arts and 14 journalism prizes awarded by Columbia University carried $3,000 prizes, except for the public service award of a gold medal. Oscar Hijuelos won the fiction award for ``The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,'' about musician brothers from Havana whose claim to fame is performing on an episode of ``I Love Lucy.''

Texan Phil Gramm, one of the Senate's most ardent foes of abortion, is backing a proposal by home-state Republicans that would ban most abortions only after pregnancies pass the halfway mark. Yet Republican Gramm, who has co-sponsored five constitutional amendments to ban abortions even in cases of rape or incest, insists he isn't waffling. State Sen. Hugh Parmer, a pro-choice Democrat who is running against Gramm, sees a ``smokescreen'' and is accusing Gramm of trying to project a more moderate image on abortion to voters back home without really changing his stance. The ``legislative action plan'' was issued last week by leaders of the Texas Republican Party and endorsed by Gramm and GOP gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams.

The Justice Department is investigating charges that immigration guards beat and sexually harassed inmates at a detention camp for aliens seeking political asylum.
