Mike Lempres, who oversees the Immigration and Naturalization Service detention centers, flew to Miami on Thursday to check into the charges, which have been turned over to Justice's civil rights division. ``Should any of these allegations lead to a finding that there are abuses, the abuses will not be tolerated,'' Lempres said after touring the Krome Avenue camp. Krome is the only center in Florida that holds illegal aliens while immigration considers their claims for asylum. Most are Cubans, Haitians and Central Americans who claim political persecution in their homelands.

The FBI is investigating residents of this coastal community after several unearthed millions of dollars believed hidden by drug traffickers and went on a buying binge, the U.S. attorney says. U.S. attorney Daniel Lopez Romo said late Thursday that the money was believed inside drums dug up two weeks ago in a farmer's field in Vega Baja, 35 miles northwest of San Juan. Lopez said officials became suspicious after residents began buying luxury items with ``great sums'' of cash. Authorities found one drum with $1.5 million still inside but others had been emptied, he said. Newspapers said between 10 and 11 empty drums were found nearby.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv20
For Release PMs Friday April 20 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: No Peace Dividend for South Asia
DOC.TEXT: Arms reduction may be the order of the day for the superpowers, but India's drive to become the next military giant has scuttled hopes of a ``peace dividend'' in economically strapped South Asia. India's neighbors, especially Pakistan, are following its lead in the buildup. Western military analysts and Indian intellectuals fear another chapter of an expensive regional arms race is about to begin. While the Soviet Union withdraws troops from Eastern Europe and the United States plans defense cuts, The Indian defense budget for 1990 is more than 10 percent above last year. Between 1985 and 1989, India bought more weapons abroad _ $17.3 billion worth _ than any country in the world. In response, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan of Pakistan said his country would continue stockpiling advanced weapons. Pakistan already allocates 52 percent of its $6.8 billion federal budget to defense. China recently announced a defense spending increase of 15.2 percent over 1989. ``There will be no peace dividend in South Asia,'' said Ian Anthony, an expert on the Indian military at the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute in Sweden. ``India thinks a strong military will give it international prestige. I think they've got it wrong.'' Anthony and other Western military analysts say India is the engine driving the regional arms buildup. More important than recent tensions with Pakistan, they say, is India's desire to achieve military might. ``India already has enough troops to smother Pakistan in a protracted war,'' said a Western military official in New Delhi. ``They have their sights on a long-term military role.'' Western economists and Indian intellectuals say the buildup harms the Indian economy and those of other developing nations in the region. Pakistan's per capita gross national product of just $350 a year is the highest in the region, and it faces a host of domestic problems that include a burgeoning drug trade and ethnic violence. Bangladesh and Nepal, two of the poorest countries in the world, spend large amounts of their foreign exchange on weapons. Some say India seeks entry into the world military club for reasons of pride. ``Weaklings are not honored; we want to be strong,'' A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, father of India's intermediate-range ballistic missile, said soon after the rocket's test firing in May 1989. Others feel India wants to assume the role its former colonial masters, the British, once played in South Asia. India is not seeking to colonize the region, they say, but wants to be viewed as its protector. ``The British dominated the subcontinent. They guaranteed its security,'' said Giri Deshingkar, director of the Center for the Study of Developing Societies. ``India's military wants to do the same.'' The fall of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi late last year led development experts to feel the defense budget, which has risen 400 percent in a decade, might be reduced. Troubles with Pakistan strengthened the military lobby, experts said, and hopes that Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government would devote more money to education and health soon evaporated. On March 19, the new government announced a 10.5 percent increase in defense spending to $9.3 billion. Most of the extra money went for weapons. Adm. J.G. Nadkarni argued in a speech last month that military might, not economic development, was the key to power. ``There are few things that India can do that can get this country greater leverage with the great powers than interfere with their plans,'' said Nadkarni, chief of the naval staff. The mere capability to interfere with superpower movement in international waters, he said, would cause them to think twice about crossing India diplomatically. ``It's basic gunboat diplomacy,'' a Western military officer said. ``We don't think it will work.'' With 1.4 million men, India's military is the fourth largest in the world, after the Soviet Union, China and United States. The air force has 870 planes and is third behind Moscow and Washington in heavy combat airlift capacity. India has built a ``blue water navy,'' including two aircraft carriers with British-made Harrier jets. In 1988, a Soviet-made nuclear submarine joined India's 16 conventional subs. Since independence from Britain in 1947, India's soldiers, not its diplomats, have played the key role in most foreign policy crises. A border dispute with Pakistan over Kashmir led to war in 1948 and again in 1965. In 1971, Indian military intervention in the Pakistani civil war helped create the new nation of Bangladesh from East Pakistan. India annexed Goa, a Portuguese colony on its western coast, in 1961 by sending in the army. The next year, a border dispute with China brought India its only major defeat. China seized 38,000 square kilometers (15,000 square miles) during the short war. Middle-aged Indians still talk about the humiliation. Most recently, Indian troops spent 32 months trying to quell a guerrilla uprising in Sri Lanka, the island nation off its southern coast. The last troops withdrew March 24. In November 1988, Indian paratroopers thwarted an attempted coup in the Maldives. During a recent trade dispute with landlocked Nepal, India closed 13 of the 15 border crossings and curtailed the passage of essential goods. A bloody escalation of the independence movement in India's part of Kashmir has prompted saber-rattling toward Pakistan, which India accuses of financing and arming Moslem separatists. Pakistan denies the charge. The commitment to military growth could be weakening the economy. In the 1960s, India was about 15th in per capita industrial output, but now it's about 30th, according to United Nations figures. Arms purchas have contributed to a foreign debt of more than $63 billion, fourth largest in the world. Reliance on force is ironic in the nation that gave the world Mohandas K. Gandhi and his philosophy of non-violent political struggle, said Bhabani Sen Gupta, a leading social scientist. ``The rest of the world is changing, but we refuse to do so,'' he said. ``We are obsessed with the sound of our shotguns.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Congressman Seeks One-Time Return to Politics
LaserPhoto WX6 of April 11
DOC.TEXT: An unrepentant Charles Diggs Jr. is seeking a political comeback a decade after leaving Congress in disgrace, hoping voters will remember his accomplishments more than the kickback scandal that forced him from office. ``That happened 10 years ago,'' said Diggs, who is running for the Maryland Legislature. ``And we fought it right to the end. If that case had been brought up today it would have been thrown out. Should have been thrown out then.'' Diggs, a Democrat who represented Michigan in the U.S. House for 25 years, said he does not view his candidacy for the Maryland House of Delegates as a launching pad for a return to Congress. In fact, he said he wants to serve just one four-year term as a state lawmaker so he can help redraw Maryland's political district lines, a process blacks hope will boost their numbers in the legislature and Congress. ``Blacks are very underrepresented in several areas in this state,'' Diggs said. ``I have been through redistricting in Michigan. There's negotiation, give and take, and I would be lending my experience to a situation that needs a remedy.'' He was involved in Michigan reapportionment negotiations that followed the 1960 census. After the state's House boundaries were realigned, Michigan became the first state since Reconstruction with two black congressmen. Diggs, one of five Democrats seeking three delegate slots in Maryland's 26th House District, now runs a funeral business in suburban Prince George's County outside Washington. He said people in his district have not discouraged him from running because of his past legal troubles. Diggs, 67, claimed he was a victim of selective prosecution and double standards when he was indicted in 1978 on charges of mail fraud and skimming $66,000 from his staffers' padded paychecks. It was a position he maintained throughout a trial that produced guilty verdicts on all 29 counts, a lengthy congressional inquiry that ended with a formal censure, a six-month prison term and ensuing years of financial and legal trouble. He offers the same defense even now, saying he was dealt with more harshly than other lawmakers accused of ethical transgressions. He believes his outspoken criticism of U.S. policy toward Africa was one reason. ``I was the biggest anti-South African around,'' Diggs said. ``They were very upset with me, didn't allow me in the country for a long time. There was a lot of speculation that people were trying to derail me because of the influence I was exerting regarding Africa.'' It was nearly 40 years ago that Diggs launched his political career by winning a term in the Michigan Legislature. He went on to become one of the nation's most powerful black officials, founding the Congressional Black Caucus and chairing the House subcommittee on Africa and the committee that oversees the District of Columbia. John Kotelly, the former assistant U.S. attorney who prosecuted Diggs, said it was up to the voters to decide whether to give him another chance. ``It's ancient history,'' said Kotelly, now a private attorney in Washington. ``I don't believe that anybody has to wear sackcloth forever after being convicted.'' Diggs was born into a politically active Detroit family in 1922. His father, Charles Diggs Sr., was a wealthy funeral home director and real estate investor and the first man in town to sell blacks coffins made of material other than wood. The younger Diggs entered the family business and was elected a Michigan legislator in 1950. Four years later, he won the first of 13 terms in Congress, where his influence grew as he gained seniority. A federal grand jury indicted Diggs on kickback charges in 1978. He was convicted on all counts but won re-election a month later and continued serving in Congress while his sentence was appealed. In June 1979, a Republican-led effort to expel Diggs from the House failed by eight votes. A month later, he stood silently at the front of the House chamber as his formal censure was read. Diggs resigned from Congress in June 1980 after the Supreme Court declined to hear his appeal. Over the next several years he fought to regain his mortician's licenses in several states, clashed with the Treasury Department over payment of his court-ordered fine, and was charged with drunken driving three times. He also graduated from Howard University, more than 40 years after leaving college to serve in World War II. Diggs, who lives almost within view of Capitol Hill, said he doesn't miss his days in Congress. ``When I drive by or see it on TV, it's almost like an old dream,'' he said. ``It's part of my experience but I don't sit around crying about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Celebrities Join in Recording of Black National Anthem
DOC.TEXT: Ninety years after James Weldon Johnson wrote ``Lift Every Voice and Sing'' for a group of school children, the song known as the ``Black National Anthem'' has been given new life by a group of well-known artists and singers. The recording, recently released as a single by Capitol Records, features such artists as Stevie Wonder, Anita Baker, Bobby Brown, Jeffrey Osbourne and Dionne Warwick. Each artist has a solo on the recording, similar to the format used by Quincy Jones on the hit ``We Are the World'' record. Melba Moore, the Tony Award-winning actress and singer, was the creative force behind the new recording of the song written by Johnson, a lawyer, educator and civil rights leader who was born in Jacksonville. Two versions of the song are included on her new ``Soul Exposed'' LP. Moore recently talked about the project in an interview. ``The original was really a hymn. The new one has a contemporary sound. It sounds like a love song,'' Moore said. She said she told BeBe Winans about her idea to enlist the help of other artists, and the gospel Grammy winner quickly contacted musicians and singers and even took a sound engineer on the road to record celebrities' voices for the recording. Also appearing on the record are Freddie Jackson, Take 6, Howard Hewett, Stephanie Mills, BeBe and CeCe Winans, the Clark Sisters, Terri Lynne Carrington and Gerald Albright. On the longer version of the song, the Rev. Jesse Jackson also participates. In addition, actress and choreographer Debbie Allen directed a video in which Jasmine Guy (``A Different World'') dances to the song, with narration by Lou Gossett Jr. Moore said ``Lift Every Voice and Sing'' has been one of her favorite songs for a number of years, and she's performed it at meetings of the National Council of Negro Women. In the liner notes for the album, Dr. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the NAACP, said, ``Every time I hear `Lift Every Voice and Sing,' I am filled with a deep sense of pride. Ms. Moore's treatment of this classic ... gives it new zest, vitality and meaning. ``More than any other song, it represents our brave struggle for freedom and equality, and the faith that has sustained us over all these weary years. It is part of us, part of our culture and a treasure to be loved and cherished.'' Johnson wrote the lyrics to ``Lift Every Voice and Sing,'' and his brother, J. Rosamond Johnson, an accomplished musician, wrote the music, for the Stanton School celebration of Abraham Lincoln's birthday in 1900. A chorus of 500 black children sang the tune. Within 20 years, it was known around the world. The song became an anthem for black Americans during the civil rights movement in the 1960s. A portion of the proceeds of the album are being donated to the NAACP, the United Negro College Fund and the National Association for Sickle Cell Disease, Moore said. Moore, who was a schoolteacher in Newark, N.J., before going on to star in Broadway productions of ``Hair,'' ``Timbuktu'' and ``Purlie,'' said she hopes that young people take to the new version. It was important, she said, that children learn about Johnson's contributions to American culture. ``He is one of our heroes. As far as writers go, everyone knowns Langston Hughes and James Weldon Johnson,'' Moore said. James Weldon Johnson was a lawyer, author, civil rights activist, educator, foreign consul and newspaper editor. There was no high school for blacks in Jacksonville, so Johnson was sent to Atlanta University to complete his education. After graduation in 1894, he returned to Jacksonville and became principal of Stanton School, which he expanded into a high school for black students. Johnson said he was not confronted with racial discrimination until he was an adolescent. ``Neither my father nor mother had taught me directly anything about race. ... My vague, early impressions constituted ... an unconscious race-superiority complex. All the most interesting things ... were being done by colored men,'' he wrote. Johnson started the first daily black newspaper in Florida, the Daily American. He was the first black to pass the Florida Bar exam and be permitted to practice. In 1901, he moved to New York City, where he and his brother collaborated on 200 songs for musical comedies and light operas, including``Congo Love Song'' and ``Since You Went Away.'' As secretary to the NAACP from 1920 to 1930, he conducted the first statistical analysis of lynching, exposed U.S. Marine terrorism in Haiti and fought for the passage of the Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill. Johnson served as consul in both Venezuela and Nicaragua, and was the author of ``God's Trombones,'' ``The Autobiography of an Ex-Colored Man,'' ``Along This Way'' and numerous other books and articles. In January 1988, a postal stamp was issued in Johnson's memory in a ceremony at Fisk University in Nashville, Tenn., where he had been a professor from 1930 until his death in 1938.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting b0165 to fix key word line
NBC's ``Working Girl'' In Need of Situation
DOC.TEXT: ``Working Girl,'' NBC's new comedy series premiering tonight, is a harmless knockoff of the big-screen tale of a secretary with a whole bunch of spunk. But the TV version's shorthand needs work. It takes more than a title to convert the major characters of a two-hour movie into 22 minutes of mirth. The sitcom struggles of valiant, working-class Tess McGill, played here by Sandra Bullock, just don't make you laugh. The show's producers bought themselves a name, some characters and Carly Simon's theme song ``Let the River Run.'' The song, by the way, was the only Oscar winner among the movie's six nominations. And somebody else sings it on NBC's venture. The movie was a box-office success, largely due to the screwball premise that a clever, resourceful, ambitious secretary like Tess, forsaking her friends and upbringing, could wangle a major Wall Street deal and have Harrison Ford fall in love with her. But we knew we wouldn't have to come back to the theater next week to see how Tess prevailed. Situation comedy is different. You want the customers to keep coming back. ``Working Girl: The Series'' is about a Tess who tries to keep her Staten Island roots and make it in the junior executive program. The premiere episode's writers, producers Robin Schiff and Larry Konner, give Tess a couple of parents, played by B.J. Ward and David Schramm, who run an unbelievably spacious deli back on Staten Island. They provide a kind of Wonder Bread ethnicity along with the ``meaningful'' conflict. Sample: Dad: ``Oh, so you are gonna give up, ah? Just like dat?'' Tess doesn't fare too well in the dialogue department, either. One of her lines: ``Dad, you are driving me crazy.'' Presumably, while Mom and Dad provide confused family relationships for Tess, her co-workers and superiors at monolithic Trask Industries provide the laffs. This is theoretical right now: There aren't many yuks in tonight's show. And everything happens too quickly. And there's no romance! We only briefly meet the neighborhood hunk, played by Anthony Tyler Quinn. Tess, it seems, has refused to go out with him since the eighth grade. We can suspect this might change. Nana Visitor has quite a challenge in the Sigourney Weaver role, Trask's Evil Witch. She's as blonde, sleek and shallow as Tess is dark, sensitive and sweet. Her survival in the series will depend on how well she can vacillate between nasty and nice (Come to think of it, though, the Robinson family never did kill that awful Dr. Smith on ``Lost in Space''). Judy Prescott does a nice job in the Joan Cusack role of the diehard office pal with the nasal Staten Island accent. Tom O'Rourke, uttering five or six utterly convincing lines as self-made jillionaire A.J. Trask, was just fine. Still, even the greatest cast cannot overcome indifferent writing or the disappointed expectations of its likeliest viewers. Tess may do her best, but there's not much room for ``Working Girl'' to succeed. Let the river dribble.

Elsewhere in television ... EARTH WEEK AT NBC NEWS: Earth Day isn't until Sunday, but NBC News already is hard at work with environmental reports that began over the weekend. The reports will continue this week on the ``NBC Nightly News,'' ``NBC News at Suunrise'' and ``Today.'' The ``Today'' reports include an interview with the rock star Sting, a leading celebrity in the fight to save rain forests ... and Bryant Gumbel will co-anchor Friday's show from Cleveland. On Earth Day itself, ``Sunday Today'' will feature an interview with Czechoslovakian President Vaclav Havel on the many environmental problems of Eastern Europe. Mary Alice Williams, the former CNN anchor said to be the top prospect to succeed Maria Shriver on ``Sunday Today,'' will co-anchor Suunday's show with Garrick Utley, according to NBC.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher With A Mission
DOC.TEXT: Roy Benjamin would like to send hundreds of thousands of books each month to the Soviet Union and the nations of Eastern Europe, where he believes there is a huge market for them. Benjamin is a publisher, so you might think this just makes good sense, just as it makes sense, for example, to hundreds of American companies with consumer goods or manufactured products to sell. But his plan is very different. He would donate his skills and time. The books would be gifts. He believes those who finance the idea, those who read the books and the nations involved would be the better for it. In his 73 years, Benjamin has learned that while good ideas are appreciated, ideas backed by a practical plan of implementation are worth a hundred times more. And so he has done the preliminary work. His proposal, ``International Friendship Books,'' has been reviewed in publishing circles, shown to the U.S. government officials and tested directly on officials of the European nations that would benefit. The responses have been uniformly good. Rita Klimova, Czechoslovakian Amabassador to the United States, told him that the people of her country ``yearn for books that will tell the American story.'' As chairman of the Benjamin Co., based in Elmsford, N.Y., Roy Benjamin has helped create hundreds of titles and tens of millions of books, many of them under cooperative arrangements with corporations. He is widely connected in publishing circles and experienced in bringing various groups together, a requirement of the program he proposes. These are the basics: _Distribution of 100,000 to 500,000 or more copies of a single, selected title each quarter, eventually monthly, through foreign schools, colleges, libraries, education groups and other organizations. _Government agencies or book distribution organizations in the recipient countries would be responsible for seeing that books reach the selected organizations. _A second phase: Sending self-contained libraries or sets of books to business, professional and political leaders. It was added when he found professional organizations lacked basic texts _ even Roberts Rules of Order. _American corporations would underwrite costs of the books, their investment to be justified by the marketing and public relations dividends their sponsorship would deliver. What a great way for American companies to become known in the new market economies of Europe, he muses, contemplating how they might benefit from a simple notation on the rear cover _ Compliments of XYZ Company, for example. _Foundations, U.S. government agencies, associations and other groups might participate as joint sponsors. _Title selection would be made by a board comprised of U.S. publishers, editors, educators, librarians and government officials. Educators and publishers in selected foreign countries might also make suggestions. _Administration and development would be through a not-for-profit organization, perhaps ``International Friendship Books Inc.,'' that Benjamin is ready to develop and direct. For Benjamin, the idea isn't new. For years he has traveled the world, and wherever he went the idea was nurtured. Earlier, he had hoped to develop the plan for China and India, but scarcity of U.S. products there delayed him. When Eastern Europe's socialist nations decided on market economies, rather than economies dictated centrally by Communist officials, the idea became more urgent. Much depends on the cooperation of U.S. companies, but Benjamin thinks he'll get it. Why? ``First, as media, books are one of the few games in town,'' he says. In Eastern Europe, he explains, access to conventional advertising ``is either non-existent or severely limited.'' Next, he says, ``books are highly revered and respected by these people,'' read and reread, passed on to others, and read again. ``They're never discarded.'' It's a rare situation in which everyone seems to win. Benjamin, a well- trophied golfer who spends many hours on the course and who still must work at his own business, says he isn't afraid of the added task. He says simply, ``I'd like to repay some of the dividends and fulfillment my work has given me over the years.''

DOC.HEAD: Lost in Translation: Hollywood Butchers Books
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Atwood figures a really faithful adaptation of her book, ``The Handmaid's Tale,'' would run nearly six hours. The author, however, is not complaining about the 109-minute film now playing in theaters. She considers herself lucky, very lucky. The plot varies only slightly from her best-selling story about the Republic of Gilead, a country ruled by right-wing fundamentalists who overthrew the United States. But many writers aren't quite as fortunate when Hollywood takes their works and mounts them on screen. Something always manages to get lost in the translation. Hollywood tends to butcher books. Many authors understand William Holden's quip in ``Sunset Boulevard,'' in which he portrayed a luckless scriptwriter: ``The last one I wrote was about Okies in the desert bowl. You'd never know because, when it reached the screen, the whole thing played on a torpedo boat.'' Film is often stranger than fiction. By the time Bernard Malamud's ``The Natural'' reached the screen in 1984, slugger Roy Hobbs had magically reformed, turning down the bribe he accepted in the book and hitting a game-winning home run that caused Hollywood sparks to fly. The original ending of ``Wuthering Heights'' had Cathy and Heathcliff dying, just like they did in Emily Bronte's novel. But when a sneak preview was poorly received, producer Samuel Goldwyn superimposed ghostly figures of the two lovers walking hand in hand to heaven. The next preview was rewarded with a long ovation. In ``The Wizard of Oz,'' Dorothy's silver slippers become ruby on the screen for the benefit of Technicolor. The 1933 film of Noel Coward's play, ``Design for Living,'' was so drastically changed that screenplay writer Ben Hecht boasted, ``There's only one line of Coward's left in the picture _ see if you can find it.'' Even titles are in danger. The 1979 film of Ann Beattie's novel, ``Chilly Scenes of Winter,'' was called ``Head Over Heels.'' According to Beattie, the producers thought the original name sounded too serious, ``like an Ingmar Bergman film.'' So Atwood feels grateful that her novel didn't get lost in the translation, recalling that her reaction to the film was to ``breathe a sigh of relief.'' She never imagined that a movie of her controversial book would star such big-name actors as Robert Duvall and Faye Dunaway, have a screenplay by the celebrated English playwright Harold Pinter and attract a well-respected director such as Volker Schlondorff (``Death of a Salesman,'' ``The Tin Drum''). ``I thought it would take a lot of guts for anybody to do it,'' Atwood said in a recent interview. ``But once given that nerve, I could certainly see it visually and see it dramatically.'' Bobbie Ann Mason is also among the grateful, although the film of her popular novel, ``In Country,'' received mixed reviews. The author was pleased that it stuck faithfully to her story of Sam Hughes, a Kentucky teen-ager trying to learn more about her late father. Mason was also glad that the movie didn't ``stereotype the country folks.'' ``I think the story and the characters came across very well,'' said Mason, who had high praise for stars Emily Lloyd and Bruce Willis, and screenwriter Frank Pierson. ``I thought the actors did add something extra. Emily Lloyd really brought across Sam's energy and I thought Bruce brought (Sam's uncle) Emmett into a focus that I hadn't perceived.'' But include Fay Weldon among the less grateful. The author would rather not discuss ``She-Devil,'' which takes the sharp curves of her darkly funny ``The Life and Loves of a She-Devil,'' and turns them into flat, ineffective comedy. ``She-Devil'' retains the basic plot of the ugly housewife Ruth wrecking the life of beautiful romance novelist Mary Fisher who's run off with Ruth's husband, Bob. But that's about all the two works have in common. In the book Ruth is a giant of a woman. Not in the movie; she's played by the short, fat, compact Roseanne Barr. In the book, Ruth spends years and millions of dollars having painful and revolutionary surgery to make her face look like Mary's and to chop bone from her thighs to make herself shorter. None of this happens in the movie. In the book, Ruth commits several crimes and has several sexual encounters after her husband runs off with Mary Fisher, including a lesbian relationship. Not in the movie. The film was poorly received, especially compared to the acclaimed British Broadcasting Co. miniseries run on PBS. ``I thought Meryl Streep was wonderful,'' was all Weldon would say at first about ``She-Devil,'' which featured Streep as Mary Fisher. But the author, seeking a way to ``phrase this tactfully,'' then discussed the problems of handing over creative control. ``If you sign an American contract, you go to the American Embassy and you undertake to sell your rights to the story,'' Weldon said in a telephone interview from her home outside London. ``You also have to declare that you're in your right mind. ``I thought I would be able to look at it dispassionately, but I found that I wasn't.'' For Atwood, the real hero is producer Daniel Wilson, who has won 18 Emmys for his television specials, including five for the ABC Afterschool Special, ``The Late Great Me: Story of a Teen-age Alcoholic.'' The author said she chose Wilson because he was passionate about the book and that he would make sure the film had the proper feel. But Atwood had one major complaint. ``They did an outrageous poster in Germany which makes it look a `men-in-a-raincoat' film, kind of soft porn. There's going to be a lot of disappointed men in raincoats. It was really quite astonishing. That's what I was trying to avoid,'' she said. Still, Atwood is eager to try it again. She recently finished the script for her most recent novel, ``Cat's Eye,'' and says the earlier works ``Bodily Harm'' and ``Life Before Man'' have been optioned. Mason raved about the excitement of having ``In Country'' made into a movie and has written a screenplay for the novel ``Spence +Lila.'' Weldon said that a film of her novel, ``Puffball,'' is being considered and admitted that even the disappointment of ``She-Devil'' has not quite wiped the stars from her eyes. ``Yes, of course I would do it again,'' she insisted. ``Film's much more fun. I think the whole process is amazing, and there is a feeling on the set of major films that's like nowhere else.''

DOC.HEAD: What About Checkpoint Charlie? Make It a Tourist Office
DOC.TEXT: What do you do with an obsolete border guardhouse, especially if it's right downtown? ``Turn it into a tourist office,'' says a veteran U.S. Army sergeant at the Checkpoint Charlie crossing. Communism has crumbled in East Germany, the Berlin Wall is derelict and 30,000 people pass through Checkpoint Charlie every day, in both directions. The four-power agreements dividing Berlin into U.S., British and French sectors in the West and a Soviet sector in the East remains in effect, but Berlin has been caught up in the wave of change in Eastern Europe. For soldiers of the Western Allies, the changes include canceling this year's military parade and being able to visit East Berlin in civilian clothes. East Germany has even made three new border crossings for Western military personnel. To Air Force Capt. Janet Bent of Grand Terrace, Calif., and Army Staff Sgt. Nathaniel Brown of St. Louis, Mo., the differences are important. Brown has worked at Checkpoint Charlie since May 1987. He has grim memories of the days before the wall fell in the peaceful revolution that ousted East Germany's Communist government last fall. ``I've seen three people make escape attempts at this crossing,'' and East German guards ``grabbed them, kicked and beat them, really got down and dirty with them,'' he said. ``Now those same guards are out there smiling and waving people through,'' the 39-year-old sergeant said. ``I never believed it would happen in my lifetime.'' Before the wall opened, armed U.S. patrols regularly drove along the barrier to monitor East German guards and possible Soviet troop movements. ``There are no more patrols,'' Brown said in an interview. ``We're armed as military police, but about all we do is give out tourist information and advise people on visiting East Berlin.'' ``I'm thinking of putting in a work order to have a sign made up, `Checkpoint Charlie Tourist Information Office','' he said, laughing as an American soldier approached to ask advice about the East. Soldiers formerly had to sign a log at the checkpoint before crossing into East Berlin. Brown said that changed early in April with the decision that all Western troops based in Berlin could visit the East out of uniform. ``Before, West Berlin troops had to be back here by midnight,'' he said. ``Now they can stay for a weekend in East Berlin if they want.'' Allied soldiers based in West Germany still must wear uniforms when visiting East Berlin. Checkpoint Charlie is manned jointly by U.S., British and French troops. The United States has about 6,000 soldiers in West Berlin, the British 4,000 and the French about 2,500. About 350,000 Soviet troops are based in East Germany. City officials say most of them are at sites around Berlin. Capt. Bent, based in Berlin since July, said she often must cross the border to escort U.S. Air Force officials visiting East Berlin. She said being allowed to wear civilian clothes was important for her. ``From my standpoint as a female in uniform, which the Soviets and East Germans don't see very often, I got a lot of stares,'' she said. ``With civilian clothes, it's more comfortable.'' She said she recently crossed into East Berlin in uniform, ``and an East German guard smiled and saluted me.'' ``Now we can go across by car, on foot, on a bicycle or train, and can use public transport in East Berlin,'' she said. ``Before, we couldn't.'' Klaus Haetzel, a spokesman for Mayor Walter Momper of West Berlin, said the Allies agreed to cancel the annual military parade ``because it no longer fits in the current situation, with the wall open and military reduction talks.'' The first parade was held June 17, 1964, the anniversary of a workers' uprising in East Germany in 1953, to show Western resolve to defend Berlin. The wall was built in August 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Taking the Cure
DOC.TEXT: The way many analysts see it, the sluggish behavior of the stock market in the first few months of 1990 reflects more than just uncertainty about the outlook for interest rates or corporate profits. Stock prices have been left to drift in light trading activity, they theorize, as the very idea of acquisitive risk-taking has undergone a temporary fall from favor. The nation is preoccupied right now with cleaning up a series of financial messes _ among them the savings and loan debacle, Wall Street's junk-bond binge of the 1980s and a welter of bad loans in the banking business. At the same time, the free-spending consumers of the past decade show signs of adopting a new ethic, building up their depleted savings reserves instead of taking on bold new commitments. All this tends to put a damper on both the economy and the markets, which depend on the aggressive pursuit of wealth for much of their energy. Some say it raises the threat of a consumer-induced recession. Others worry about the possibility of a ``credit crunch,'' in which constraints on lending create a scarcity of money for investment in business, housing and big-ticket consumer purchases. But worrisome as these budding trends may be for the immediate future, observers also argue they could be a significant plus for the economy and Wall Street over the long term. If all goes right, they say, what is going on now could clear away past excesses and help build a stable base from which future opportunities and growth could arise. The latest example of investors' concerns is a sweeping inquiry by government regulators into the lending practices of banks, which has evoked visions of a long dry spell for borrowers. ``There is a lot to keep investors jumpy, if not downright scared,'' says Michael Sherman, investment strategist at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``Are bank regulators going to create such havoc in the financial markets as to create a credit crunch and an economic downturn? Is the S&L contraction an open-ended sewer?'' Such questions aren't easy to answer right now, Sherman says, but he argues that the picture nevertheless has its positive side. ``If you think the situation is fraught with peril today, you should be glad the government didn't wait for tomorrow to staunch open wounds in the financial fabric. At least we're not living in a fool's paradise. ``If we survive the cure, we will have a chance of living both better and longer, in a financial sense.'' Furthermore, Sherman contends, any squeeze on economic activity could well have a favorable impact by bringing interest rates down. ``That decline would come quickly,'' he adds, ``because the areas of the economy most affected are also those that are most credit-sensitive, namely construction and real estate.'' Most observers agree that, in intent at least, the drive to clean up the financial environment is sensible and directed at the right targets. The question, they say, is how decision-makers and the markets are able to negotiate the distance between where things stand today and the goal. As Neal Soss, economist at First Boston Corp., defined the problem: ``BEING prudent, like being sober or having a high saving rate, is a good thing. But GETTING prudent, like getting sober or raising the saving rate, involves a certain transitional discomfort.''

DOC.HEAD: Schools Receive Millions in Corporate Partnerships
DOC.TEXT: American businesses are becoming the Fairy Godmothers of the nation's schools, providing money, manpower and expertise to fulfill dreams of first-class programs and equipment. Even Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus is getting in on the act. ``Addressing the need for reform in education is everybody's business,'' says Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos. Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman and chief executive officer at RJR Nabisco, agreed, noting ``the need for business to be an active partner in improving our children's learning.'' The Nabisco Foundation late last month selected 15 schools to share $8.5 million in grants. The money is part of a five-year, $30 million program that funds innovative, community-based experiments whose successes can be replicated. The Education Department reports that business and corporate partnerships with schools tripled from 46,338 in 1983 to about 141,000 in 1988. Such partnerships provide support to 40 percent of all public schools, compared with 17 percent five years ago. ``The business community through partnerships and tutoring has been signaling for three to four years that it's interested in working with the education community,'' said Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association. Businesses are worried about the bottom line and an impending labor shortage. Of the 3.8 million 18-year-old Americans in 1988, fully 700,000 had dropped out of school and another 700,000 could not read their high school diplomas. ``It's good business to be involved in education,'' said Bernard Gifford of Apple Computer Inc. The Committee for Economic Development, an independent research organization, estimates that each year's class of dropouts costs the United States more than $240 billion in lost earnings and tax income over their lifetimes. The National Alliance of Business says employers already are spending $210 billion a year on job training and retraining. By 1995, it says, the figure could reach $300 billion a year. By that time, the alliance says, some 14 million Americans will be unprepared for the jobs available. ``Business has been involved for many years in helping schools and school systems,'' said alliance President William Kolberg. ``But much of this effort has been focused on tinkering at the margin.'' Now, he says, business is supporting ``systemic changes'' in educational programs. The quality and type of partnerships vary widely, from full-fledged programs aimed at producing long-term improvement for students, to public relations ploys designed mainly to promote a company's name. The Council on Economic Priorities said the most prevalent forms of business involvement in education are adopt-a-school arrangements, including financial grants, equipment gifts, awards ceremonies or plant visits, and tutoring. The Tandy Corp. last month gave a total of $350,000 in cash stipends and scholarships to 100 students and 100 teachers recognized for outstanding accomplishments in mathematics, science or computer science. Four years ago, Ringling Bros. decided to help tackle illiteracy _ an estimated 23 million American adults cannot read _ and kicked off a nationwide ``Ringling Readers'' program. It uses a 25-minute presentation performed by circus clowns to encourage youngsters to read. When the circus came to the nation's capital recently, ``Patches'' Jim Wade donned a clown face, a colorful top hat over bushy hair, and bright red-striped clown pants to visit 20 area elementary schools. His message: ``Reading Lets You Imagine.'' Apple computers are being placed in thousands of kindergarten through 12th grade classrooms as part of an ``Apples For The Students'' program in more than 1,000 communities in 38 states. Under the program, schools collect receipts from 34 supermarket chains, then turn them back to the supermarket in exchange for a computer. International Business Machines Corp.'s support for education is similarly broad. Its activities involve more than 22,000 employees in more than 750 local community partnerships. Kenneth Lay, director of IBM's education programs, said that in 1989 the company spent more than $28 million in support of elementary and secondary education. North Carolina National Bank last year began providing $2 million a year to support leadership academies for superintendents and other administrators in 15 southern states. Participants learn how to apply management theory to a school setting. The Coca-Cola Foundation has budgeted $50 million to support national education initiatives. Pepsico early last year announced a multimillion-dollar pilot dropout prevention program, while General Electric budgeted $20 million for education. US West in February announced it will invest $10 million over the next three years in early-childhood programs in 14 Western states. Campbell Soup Co., meanwhile, encourages teachers and students at more than 25,000 schools to collect labels and then redeem them for equipment offered in a catalog supplied by the company.

DOC.HEAD: Boatlift Brought Chaos, Hit ``Nasty Chords''
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: When reporter Maria Montoya first visited Key West, it was just after midnight, May 1, 1980, and the boatlift of refugees from Mariel, Cuba, was in full swing. But Ms. Montoya was on the other side of the cameras. A U.S. Coast Guard ship had rescued her, her husband, Eduardo, and 10 other people packed inside a disabled 18-foot boat adrift in the Gulf Stream after completing most of the 90-mile journey from Cuba. The boatlift was only 10 days old, and Ms. Montoya and her husband got a warm reception. They were cheered as they stepped onto U.S. territory, and welcomed by U.S. soldiers and volunteer workers who gave them food and clothing. One sight seemed strange, though. ``I saw 300 men, their heads almost shaved, sitting on the dock,'' she said. ``I asked, `Why are those men sitting apart?' Someone told me, ``Those are the criminals and the mental patients Castro is sending us.''' The boatlift then was being hailed as ``the Freedom Flotilla,'' an embarrassment to Fidel Castro's regime and a chance, as President Jimmy Carter said, to welcome ``with open arms'' those fleeing oppression. But before it ended five months later, when Castro closed the Port of Mariel, it had become a disaster, costing hundreds of millions of dollars, stirring murderous crime waves, and escalating prejudices. ``The whole Mariel boatlift struck very deep, nasty chords in the American public,'' said Frank Sharry, executive director of the immigration policy group, The National Forum. ``Marielito'' became a derisive label meaning misfits, crazies, hard-core criminals. ``But you know what? Most of them did just fine,'' Sharry said. Ms. Montoya, now 33, who risked a relatively comfortable life as a Cuban radio and television actress, is among dozens successful in the media and the arts. Others have made their marks in fields such as business, education and sports, and several boatlift children became honor students and valedictorians. But the stigma remains. Even after the initial crime waves blamed on Mariel refugees subsided, their image was furthered by such cases as the 1984 slaying of a Miami Beach police officer; 1987 riots and hostage-taking by refugees in Atlanta and Oakdale, La., federal prisons; and the fire last month that claimed 87 lives at the Happy Land social club in the Bronx, in which a Mariel refugee is charged. Unlike many of the refugees, Ms. Montoya, who recently returned to Key West to film a report for Spanish-language WLTV television on the boatlift's anniversary, never hesitates to tell when and how she arrived in this country. ``Bad people came, and a lot of good people came,'' she said. ``I held back a lot, when people were talking about how bad the Mariel people were. People would say to me, `Oh, you don't look like a Mariel person.' That bothered me. There was a stereotype, and I am an individual.'' Nearly a month before her arrival, Ms. Montoya and her husband had dashed into the Peruvian embassy in Havana, joining a confused, desperate throng that finally totaled 10,800 people. ``I think Castro never expected that many people wanted to leave. When he saw that, he wanted to spoil their image,'' Ms. Montoya said. U.S. Sen. Bob Graham was then in his second year as Florida's governor. He recalls attending a luncheon in Washington in April 1980 and being told by hastily scattering State Department officials of the embassy situation. Within weeks, the distant-seeming foreign policy question became his state's crisis when Castro abruptly announced that Mariel was open. A rag-tag armada of boats chartered by Cuban-Americans anxious to pick up relatives set sail, and returned with some surprising cargo. Along with parents, aunts and uncles, friends and former political prisoners, the boats brought passengers picked by the Cuban government. Castro and the state-controlled media crowed that the United States was getting ``the bums and scum.'' ``We don't want them,'' Castro told a cheering Havana crowd. ``We don't need them.'' By throwing in Cuban miscreants, Castro portrayed the boatlift as a sweeping out of his society. Unleashed on American society from spartan Cuban gulags, the boatlift's criminal element spurred street crime explosions in Miami's Little Havana and among the elderly of Miami Beach, then spread into other U.S. cities. Their crimes were the worst of many problems. ``It had a human impact by adding 125,000 people to the population,'' reflected Graham. ``It contributed to a tense community situation by surfacing tensions. I think it contributed to the (May 1980 Liberty City race) riots. ``Castro was able to unload criminals and undesirable elements ... and there was an immediate and continuing strain on health and social institutions,'' he said. With the Cuban economy stagnant and the government increasingly isolated by the crumbling of the Socialist bloc, U.S. officials say they have readied contingency plans to prevent a new Mariel. ``Castro has used opening up his borders as a tactic to relieve pressure,'' Graham said. ``We're in a dilemma because our national tradition is that we provide sanctuary, but we ought to discourage (a new boatlift) and make sure it's an orderly movement.'' About one-fifth of the Mariel refugees had served jail time in Cuba, but for the great majority, it was for petty offenses or political crimes. Today, most authorities say fewer than 10 percent of the refugees were criminals. Some 2,600 still are in federal custody, 173 were returned to Cuba under a suspended immigration agreement, and an estimated 4,000 are in various state and local prisons. ``I can tell you now that the impact was positive,'' said Miami City Manager Cesar Odio. ``Only a small percentage created problems. Most have been good citizens. But the immediate impact was negative _ for all Cubans.'' A Gallup Poll at the time indicated that Cubans, usually considered an immigration success story, had become one of the nation's most unpopular alien groups. That image made resettling the immigrants difficult. Many were placed in refugee camps at U.S. military bases in the Florida Panhandle, Arkansas, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. Frustrated refugees rioted in Arkansas, and there were disturbances in the other camps. Carter declared the boatlift illegal a month after it began. Boat captains were fined and had their vessels confiscated. But it was too late. About 70,000 Cubans already had arrived, and more were on their way. The only other time Castro had opened a port, Camarioca in 1965, the total number of refugees was fewer than 6,000. ``In the beginning, we completely missed the boat,'' said Gunther O. Wagner, who worked for the State Department's Cuban-Haitian Task Force. ``How did we know? Would we get 300, 3,000, 10,000? We got 125,000.'' The criminal image and the large number of single men, thousands of them homosexuals, made finding sponsors difficult. ``A lot of groups just gave up,'' said Sharry. ``The church groups we were used to working with were nice, suburban churches. And now here's Fileno with a tattoo on his eyelid ready to go to the church picnic?''

DOC.TEXT: The last resettlement camp, Fort Chaffee, Ark., was open until Feb. 16, 1982, nearly two years after the boatlift began. ``The refugees kept asking: `When are you going to get me out of here? I've been lied to and lied to,''' Sharry recalled. ``We failed a lot of them.'' Sharry and others involved in the Mariel resettlement can laugh now about some of their headaches. Sharry recalls one of the first refugees he found a sponsor for ``split for the coast'' with the sponsor's very willing ``nice church lady'' wife. Wagner says one ``very industrious young man'' stole a bus and was found in Seattle driving around town and collecting fares for his own gypsy bus service. And they have warm memories of the refugees who overcame frustration and finally succeeded. ``I am proud to have helped so many people find freedom,'' Wagner said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousand of Mariel Refugees Jailed in Legal Limbo
DOC.TEXT: Since five handcuffed Cubans from the 1980 Mariel boatlift boarded a government jet in December 1988 for the homeland they fled, 168 more have followed. Some, numbed by their years in jail, went voluntarily, feeling that as bad as Cuba may be, it beat the prospect of an indefinite stretch in a maximum-security prison in the United States. But thousands more who have completed their sentences remain behind bars with no idea when, or even if, they will get out. Many eventually are freed, but those identified as the tougher cases are not. By law, the United States can hold them as long as it wants, even for life, although no charges remain against them. ``Of those who have gone back to Cuba, we know of a few who have been released, a few who are still in jail,'' said Decatur, Ga., attorney Gary LeShaw, who represents many detainees. ``Of those who went back, I'd say about 30 of them went voluntarily, not because they wanted to go back to Cuba but because they thought they had a better chance for release there,'' he said. About once a month, a few more judged deportable are taken from the federal prison at Talladega, Ala., to Birmingham for the 90-minute flight back to Cuba. The great majority of the 125,000 ``Marielitos,'' as they are known, are law-abiding and have adjusted to American life in the decade since their arrival. An estimated 80,000 have become American citizens, and the others are on immigration parole and have been told they won't be bothered if they stay out of trouble. Thus, while Marielitos have been in this country for a decade, technically, they aren't really here and never have been. The courts have ruled they have no constitutional guarantees. People who enter the United States illegally must be released after six months if their native countries will not take them back. But Mariel Cubans, named for the port from which they left in an exodus authorized by Cuban President Fidel Castro, don't fit that category. They are classed as ``excludable aliens.'' ``I felt and I still feel that any person the attorney general holds beyond a reasonable time is entitled to a hearing to see if that reason is a sufficient reason,'' said U.S. District Judge Marvin Shoob of Atlanta, who ruled in 1983 that the Mariel Cubans were entitled to limited due process. He was reversed by a federal appeals court, and the U.S. Supreme Court declined to hear the case. Shoob said it is unlikely the case will get into the appeals court system again and that congressional legislative action is the only apparent avenue for change. ``It was not a happy episode in U.S. jurisprudence,'' Shoob said. But, he said, ``The vast majority of those who deserve to get out have gotten out.'' Initially, Cuba agreed to take back the 2,726 Cubans jailed as of Dec. 14, 1984. It accepted 201 before Castro ended the agreement in 1985 in retaliation for the American broadcast of Radio Marti beamed at Cuba. Of the 201, 156 were reported free in Cuba at one point after spending time in medical quarantine. In late 1987, Cuba agreed to accept the rest at a rate of up to 100 a month, sparking riots at federal prisons in Atlanta and Oakdale, La., where about 3,800 Cubans who had finished their sentences were detained by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. Of the 3,800, LeShaw said, about two-thirds have been freed after reviews by special Justice Department panels. The reviews were one of the concessions made to the Cubans in custody during the riots for surrendering control of the prisons. But Shoob said the review concession was less than it seemed. ``Under the agreements, there are no requirements for the government to supply attorneys or for the cases to be heard before disinterested parties,'' Shoob said. Duke Austin, an INS spokesman in Washington D.C., said reviews are all the law provides for. ``It is not a judicial process. It is an administrative record review only,'' he said. `` ... The majority are being paroled out. The INS has paroled every (detained) Cuban at one time or another but about 60. They all had a chance.'' The 60 were identified on arrival as hardened criminals or severe mental cases, and have been held since 1980. The rest are jailed for things that occurred after they got here. About 2,600 are in INS custody now, and the agency has detainers on another 4,000 who are serving sentences, Austin said. Lawyers who represent the Cubans complain of arrogance and ignorance on the part of some review panel members. ``I have never seen such a farce in my life,'' reads a memo from Lafayette, La., attorney Judith Gardner, who represented a woman jailed for theft. ``I will never forget the panel members. They were cynical and accusatory,'' Ms. Gardner said. ``They were disrespectful and seemed to revel in playing God over the lives of these people.'' She said they accused her client of crimes she had never been charged with and told her she never would be released to an area near where her mother lives. The treatment of those returned to Cuba remains uncertain. Roberto Martinez, sent back to Cuba in March 1989, wrote to an American friend from jail there, ``We received a good attention from them but it only was the first days. But we would not make any communications with our family during 54 days and we just didn't know why.'' Martinez' letter said he was moved to another prison and allowed to see a judge. ``He said that we are peligrosos (dangerous ones) and also he said that we are not ready to make our lives within the community. In other words we have received two and the half year sentence with the charge of peligrosidad (dangerousness),'' he wrote. The letter said he hoped to be free by the end of 1989. Whether he was is undetermined.

DOC.HEAD: The Naked Storm: Mapplethorpe as Martyr
An AP Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of grafs 9, ``In his...,'' and 13, ``But the intense...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In the early 1970s, Robert Mapplethorpe took his first photographs with a Polaroid camera. It was the perfect tool for radical art. What was radical about his work was not so much the subject matter but the process and materials he applied to a stagnant form, adding fabric, texture, tone. Form and technique, however, are not what spring to mind these days when considering the late artist. Today, it is the rough images he immortalized _ oral sex, bondage, homosexual fondling _ that make him an important force in 20th-century art. Perhaps Mapplethorpe never fully realized his destiny as an artist. He died in March 1989 at the age of 42 of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome. In death, he is embroiled in controversy and has become a symbol for artistic freedom. A Mapplethorpe exhibit last June at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington was canceled after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., declared some of the artist's photographs to be obscene. Helms' objections resulted in a move by Congress to limit federal funds to the arts. Mapplethorpe's works have been shown at the Whitney Museum of Art in New York, and in Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston, Berkeley, Calif., and Hartford, Conn. But a grand jury this month indicted the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati, Ohio, on obscenity charges for showing his works. The center and its director will be arraigned Monday. ``I wasn't starting out to make a statement, that isn't the way I work,'' Mapplethorpe once said. ``The statement grows out of what I do.'' In his 1976-77 work ``Bill,'' Mapplethorpe placed a mirror between two panels of a man masturbating. The idea is to have the viewer see him or herself flanked by two erect penises. He used the same technique in 1979's ``Easter Lilies With Mirror.'' Here, four panels form a cross around a center mirror. The lilies are shown in dramatic shadows, a dusting of light illuminating their inner and almost religious beauty. It is a way of engaging the viewer beyond mere voyeurism; the viewer becomes a part of the work. In the triptych ``Brice Marden'' (1976), Mapplethorpe shows the artist full-figure sitting with his own work in the background, a close-up in the center panel, and the last panel blank. It is a wonderful study in depth perception. But the intense shadow composition of another triptych, ``Jim and Tom, Sausalito'' (1977-78), is obliterated by the action in the picture, in which one man urinates on another. Around the same time, Mapplethorpe did a self-portrait, posed partly naked in leather with the handle of a bullwhip in his rectum. They are among his most disturbing photographs, part of a period in which he unraveled a violent homosexual mystique for an unsuspecting audience. They are terrifying, sadomasochistic tableaux _ chained men, leather-bound men, men prepared for pain in an aristocratic setting. But despite the frightening roughness of these sexual and psychological images, Mapplethorpe succeeded in crafting a rich tonal range. ``He was involved in an incredibly wide variety of life, the other side of which is death,'' said the artist Lowell Nesbitt, who first met and befriended Mapplethorpe in 1971-72. ``It's very clear that much of his photographs were mirrors of his personal life. I think that Mapplethorpe really wanted to be censored. He was pushing for it. He was pushing the artistic barriers, the way many artists have in the past, to see how far he could push before he could met a boundary.'' Back in the early '70s, a time of rainbow drugs and easy sex, of troubled politics and an unpopular war, Mapplethorpe was into jewelry. ``He was an artist, but he wasn't exactly painting,'' said Nesbitt. He would refashion jewelry by adding materials to customize a piece for the owner. Mapplethorpe was one of six children born to Joan and Harry Mapplethorpe. He fled his Catholic childhood in Floral Park, Queens, for the bohemian earthiness of Brooklyn in the 1960s. There, he received his art education at Pratt Institute. It also was there that he encountered and forged a lasting friendship with radical poet and musician Patti Smith. Together, they shared in each other's work and supported each other's dreams. They were avant-garde _ hippies while others were still beatniks, punk before the first British rude boy spat out the word, outlaws while others were simply radical. He spent his artistic lifetime photographing Smith. Her portraits range from early Polaroids to the portrait he used on her 1988 LP, ``Dream of Life.'' The 1978 triptych, ``Patti Smith (Still Moving)'' shows Smith in muted tones intertwined with a flimsy curtain, her clothes falling away, her features slightly blurred. A portrait in 1976 shows a vulnerable, naked Smith, curled up on her haunches, clinging to pipes in a barren studio. Mapplethorpe said there was little difference in photographing men or women: ``It's like sculpture finally, working with a three-dimensional form. Most of the people I photograph are not trained models or actors, but they all have strong personalities.'' He did portraits of actor Richard Gere, artists Louise Nevelson and Alice Neel, lawyer Roy Cohn, body builder Lisa Lyon and transvestite Candy Darling. And they were as varied as his classically poetic studies of flowers, fruit and vegetables. ``His great mentor was Sam Wagstaff, the museum curator,'' Nesbitt said. ``He introduced Mapplethorpe to what were the most advanced forms of art going on in the United States at that time. He probably helped develop Mapplethorpe's very personal eye and incredible ability to use light, which was somewhat prophetic. ``A lot of photographers are equally capable technically, but it takes an artist-photographer to distinguish himself, and what does this is a very personal eye.'' Mapplethorpe's eye consumed more than merely the flat surface of a photo. He infused light and shadow, certainly, but he also applied textures and tones, using fabric and paint such as platinum on linen or mesh wire overlays. His early work utilized collage for drama and movement. Photographs became not an end in themselves, but the raw material for a work's foundation. In 1971, he painted over a yellowed, torn childhood photo of artist Andy Warhol, leaving one smiling eye, his mouth and shoulder untouched. In his last years, his work was austere. Beauty was found in simplicity. A 1988 picture titled ``Nipple'' could be a parched desert, the moon's surface or a dried river bed. But it is a closeup of the human form. ``Calla Lily'' (1988) is a stark portrait of the sculpted flower. And his study of a man named Thomas in 1986 showed Mapplethorpe in classic form: A naked man strains against a circle, a geometric work reminiscent of Leonardo da Vinci. ``I'm sure he felt he had made an amazing achievement artistically,'' Nesbitt said. ``He had the self-satisfaction of considering himself a major influence.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Dolores Barclay has been the AP Arts and Entertainment Editor for 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Money Cushions Kingdom from Democratic Pressures
DOC.TEXT: An old man wagged his finger at Prince Sultan, second in line to the throne, and complained that his soldier son was assigned to a base far from his home in Riyadh. ``But your son has obligations as a soldier,'' said the prince, who also is the Saudi defense minister. ``He has obligations to his family,'' the man retorted. Sultan consulted his advisors and announced that the young man would be reassigned in Riyadh, the kingdom's capital. The exchange took place during a ``majlis,'' or consultation, Sultan regularly holds with the people. A foreign reporter was permitted to attend. Most days, Sultan and the scores of other princes in Saudi Arabia's extended royal family open the doors of their palaces to the people. They listen to complaints on all manner of issues and settle disputes. It's the nearest thing the Saudis have to democracy and there is little demand for more from the estimated 8 million citizens of this desert kingdom, which sits on one-quarter of the world's oil reserves. About 3 million foreign workers also live in Saudi Arabia. Representative democracy is overwhelming communism in Eastern Europe and making inroads in the Third World, including neighboring Arab countries. In Saudi Arabia, tribal tradition and huge oil profits let the royal bosses of the world's richest family-operated business provide opportunity, public services and security that make democracy a non-issue. The monarchy rules through wide consensus with all segments of society. Laws are based on the Koran, the holy book of Islam considered to be God-given to the Prophet Mohammed, who founded the religion in the 7th century. Prince Majed, brother of King Fahd and governor of the Red Sea province that includes the holy city of Mecca, told reporters recently that communism and other temporal ideologies ``are false and contrary to human nature.'' The majlis system gives an estimated 250,000 Saudis access to princes and senior officials every year on behalf of their families. In a social system fed by billions of dollars from oil revenue, citizens pay no taxes. Education is free through university, and each college student gets $800 a month in pocket money. Health services, extensive and of high quality, are free. A jet air ambulance makes at least 200 flights a month to ferry patients from remote areas to Riyadh for surgery at the lavish King Faisal Specialty Hospital. To build a home, each Saudi family gets a free plot of 625 square meters _ about 750 square yards _ and a 30-year loan of $80,000, free of interest. People who build clinics, factories, workshops or hotels get interest-free loans equivalent to 70 percent of the construction costs. Generous pensions are paid on retirement. ``So who needs democracy?'' a Western diplomat asked. In tense times, the Saudi rulers customarily say they may establish a Majlis al-Shura, or consultative assembly, a quasi-parliament with most or all of the members chosen by the king. Such a council, approved by Islamic tradition, was mentioned in 1975, when a deranged nephew murdered King Faisal and his successors were taking control. The nephew was publicly beheaded, a punishment decreed in the Koran and imposed routinely for murder, sex crimes or drug smuggling. Public executions take place in Riyadh's main square on many Fridays. More beheadings and new mention of a Majlis were decreed in 1979 after a group of fundamentalist fanatics seized the Great Mosque of Mecca. That event sent shock waves through the royal family, which pins much of its legitimacy to its piety. The fundamentalists demanded an end to what they considered excessive Western influence in Saudi Arabia's rapid modernization during the oil boom years. In 1987, after Iranian-backed sabotage in the oil provinces and during the annual Moslem pilgrimage to Mecca, Fahd was said to be studying the Majlis plan again. Still there is no council, appointed or elected. A handsome structure to house it stands empty in the grounds of Fahd's al-Yamamah palace in Riyadh. ``I believe it will come, but it's a matter of priorities,'' said a senior Saudi official. Like other sources, he did not want his name used. ``There's no groundswell of opinion for the Majlis,'' an influential newspaper editor said. ``The people are satisfied with the tranquility, stability, security, prosperity, the freedom to travel.'' Unrestricted travel to the West is a safety valve for middle class Saudis. They mingle with Westerners and indulge, often ostentatiously, in night life and the West's freewheeling culture. At home, they live under strict Islamic rules that prohibit alcohol, unveiled women in public, women drivers or shopping or recreation during the five daily times of prayer. Tourism to Saudi Arabia is all but non-existent. Apart from Moslem pilgrims, most visitors are businessmen or expatriate workers. Most Westerners live in walled company compounds where the women can play tennis or swim in bikinis. Residents receive unpublicized shipments of liquor. The royal family has more than 3,000 princes, 500 in the direct line of succession. This has ensured stability through family unity and tight control of extensive security forces. Free enterprise and generous social programs have been crucial in transforming a semi-nomadic society, with little upheaval, into a modern one with a strong sense of Islamic identity. Saudi officials say King Abdulaziz ibn Saud, who conquered most of the Arabian peninsula and founded modern Saudi Arabia in 1927 with British backing, established the consensus rule on which the country's government is based. Abdulaziz is quoted as telling his sons the ``thread'' of consensus ties to the people is stronger than the ``iron bands'' of autocracy. A Saudi journalist with access to one of the top princes said that, instead of creating a consultative council, the rulers decided a few years ago to expand the ``open majlis'' system with Fahd, princes and top officials opening their palaces for regular meetings with citizens. The atmosphere of the open majlis is informal. The king is not addressed as ``your majesty'' but as ``Fahd,'' ``Father of Faisal'' or ``Taweel al Umur,'' Arabic for ``long life.'' Religious leaders are brought in on important decisions to avoid dissension, and other important constituencies are consulted regularly. An expert in Saudi affairs said the 1990-95 economic plan was circulated for two years in advance among businessmen, economists and others, and many alterations were made as a result. ``This gave a large number of key people the feeling and reality of participation,'' he said. Saudis are concerned about tense relations with Iran, a major regional power, and about a new Arab-Israel conflict and the vulnerability of their oil facilities to bombing or missile attacks. They have forged close security ties with the United States and are a huge market for Western arms sales. To keep Palestinian guerrillas from causing trouble in the kingdom as they have in other Arab nations, the Saudis make generous contributions to the Palestine Liberation Organization. The only significant internal opposition to royal rule is the Shiite Moslem minority in the oil-producing eastern provinces along the Persian Gulf. More than 90 percent of Saudis belong to the mainstream Sunni branch of Islam, but some ``usulis'' or fundamentalists, among the several hundred thousand Shiites are influenced by predominantly Shiite Iran. They are blamed for the sabotage of oil installations.

DOC.HEAD: 3,000 Princes Hold Kingdom Together
With The Saudi Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: The 3,000 princes of the ruling Saud family are the cement that holds the kingdom together. Most experts agree any effective rebellion would have to be led from within the family. The royal family controls every aspect of life, and has remained united on the critical succession issue and important policy matters. It has produced the Arab world's first astronaut, Prince Sultan bin Salman, who flew on the U.S. space shuttle Discovery in 1984. Saudi Arabia's current rulers are descendants of King Abdulaziz ibn Saud, who founded the kingdom in 1927 by conquering the desert tribes of the Arabian Peninsula. The Saud family has been largely responsible for guiding a tribal society of impoverished nomads into a cohesive modern state whose oil wealth has made it a financial superpower. King Fahd, who has ruled since 1982, is believed to be the world's second- richest person. Fortune Magazine estimated his fortune in 1988 at $18 billion. The Sultan of Brunei is said to worth several billion more. Fahd has a lavishly furnished Boeing 747, a $60 million yacht protected by Stinger anti-aircraft missiles, and luxury homes in Spain, Britain and France. Secrecy surrounds the private life of the chain-smoking monarch, who in his youth was a playboy prince known in Europe's gambling clubs. He is 69, the fourth son of Abdulaziz to succeed his father, who had 43 sons by 22 wives. After Crown Prince Abdullah, 67, and Defense Minister Sultan, 63, the succession is expected to go to the eldest of 20 younger brothers who is considered able. The last son of Abdulaziz sons will have the job, with his inner circle of princes called ``those who tie and untie,'' of selecting the eldest, most respected from among the hundreds of male grandchildren. Family members who break the rules are dealt with quickly and firmly. One of Fahd's younger brothers, Prince Mishari, then 19, was imprisoned in 1951 after shooting the British vice-consul in Jiddah to death while drunk. In 1965, when King Saud's regime was discredited by widespread corruption and the king's profligate and irrational decisions, the family supported his overthrow in favor of the respected Faisal. After Faisal was assassinated by a deranged nephew on March 25, 1975, the crown passed quietly to Khaled, Fahd's half-brother. The nephew was beheaded. Khaled died in June 1982. The only significant, independent move against a Saudi ruler since the state was founded occurred under King Saud. A group of his younger brothers, critical of his misrule, were influenced by Egypt's revolutionary leader, Gamal Abdel Nasser. Led by Prince Talal, they organized the ``Free Princes'' movement to dump Saud and create a constitutional monarchy. The movement failed and the princes were exiled in 1962. Prince Turki, another of Fahd's brothers, was fired as deputy defense minister in 1978 for drunkenness and an embarrassing marriage to the daughter of Mohammed al-Fassi, a doctor. Al-Fassi relatives used Turki's money to buy a Hollywood mansion, which was then painted lime green. They shocked even Californians by highlighting the sexual organs of classical statuary in bright orange.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia at a Glance
With The Saudi Kingdom
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures about Saudi Arabia:

THE LAND _ Most of Saudi Arabia's 865,000 square miles is desert, with summer temperatures ranging up to 112 degrees Fahrenheit. The Rub al-Khali, or Empty Quarter, is the world's largest sand desert. The southwest has green, fertile valleys.

THE PEOPLE _ About 3 million of the estimated 11 million residents are foreign workers and one-third of native Saudis are nomadic Bedouins or farmers living around oases. Roughly 90 percent of native Saudis are Sunni Moslems of the Wahabi faction who live by strictly enforced Islamic codes. King Fahd has taken the title ``Guardian of the Two Holy Shrines,'' Islam's most sacred shrines at Mecca and Medina.
THE ECONOMY _ Saudi Arabia has one-quarter of the world's known oil reserves. Fifty years ago the country was poverty-stricken, but it has used vast oil wealth to transform itself into modern state.

HISTORY _ Islam swept the country in the 7th century, under the leadership of the Prophet Mohammed. Later, the Ottoman Turks ruled Saudi Arabia for 300 years. The British moved in during World War I, when Lawrence of Arabia led desert warriors against the Turks. Abdulaziz ibn Saud founded the modern state in 1927 after conquering the desert tribes of the Arabian peninsula.
