DOC.HEAD: Volkswagen's Eye-Catching Corrado
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Think small, think fast and think agile when you think about the 1990 Volkswagen Corrado. This is a car that's small on the outside, surprisingly quick, and an eye-catcher to boot. The Corrado marks something of a departure for Volkswagen, the No. 1 carmaker in Europe. The car is designed, as Bill Young, vice president in charge of VW-United States, put it, to change the way you think about Volkswagen. Forget about the no-frills VWs of old. The Corrado is the first to offer, at its initial debut in the market, a host of standard features that would normally be optional on VW's: power windows, air conditioning and heated outside mirrors. It's also the first VW to have a tilt steering wheel. That's not all. The Corrado has a body by the same master European coachbuilders who brought us the cute little Karmann Ghia years ago _ plus a dashboard readout that details average fuel economy, distance traveled and average speed just like the one you would find in many luxury cars. Most impressively, the Corrado also is the quickest Volkswagen ever, thanks to a special supercharger under the hood that spurs the little four-cylinder engine up to 158 horsepower. Helping the performance, both in speed and fuel economy, is a unique rear spoiler that rises automatically at 45 mph to help ensure the car's speedy movement through air with a minimum of rear-end lift. The spoiler begins to retract when speeds decline to 12 mph. The Corrado's sporty performance and well-packaged amenities come at a base price of $17,900. Competitors include the Ford Probe GT, which has a base price of $14,726; the Mitsubishi Eclipse GS Turbo at $14,169, and the Toyota Celica GT-S at $16,268. One difference between the Corrado and many other competitors in this segment, however, is the rear-seat room. VW says the Corrado's rear seating area is a bit larger than most other, similar cars. Indeed, despite the test car's compact size _ a bit over 13 feet long _ seating in back wasn't as bad as I feared. Though my view was well-blocked by the front bucket seats and headrests and my head brushed the ceiling, I found the sculpted seats to be very comfortable, and legroom was OK with the front seat moved up a ways. Legroom was at a minimum when the front seat was pushed all the way back, although my knees still weren't touching the rear of the front seats _ perhaps because the backs of the front bucket seats were designed to slant inward. The rear seats are split one-third and two-thirds so they can be folded down for more cargo space. But first, the rear center armrest must be raised and set between the two front seats. Watch when you replace the armrest in back so that you don't cover the seat belt connectors. The Corrado also has a nice storage shelf that covers the hatch area, if needed. The test car was fun to zip around in, and the power is surprising. The car is rated at a quick 7.5 seconds for its 0-60 mph performance. Top speed is 140 mph. Yet the Corrado got good mileage, more than 24 mpg in mixed city and highway driving during the test. The gearshift for the five-speed manual transmission felt notchy but the transmission worked well with the four-cylinder engine. The hatchback requires lifting items up and over the high rear body of the car, and the storage space is raised slightly in the middle, above the hidden spare tire compartment. The Corrado does not have airbags, but front-seat passengers do get lap belts that automatically come across the body when the ignition is activated. My complaints were minor: Having to use a large knob to recline the bucket seats; a high-pitched squeak that seemed to come from the lap belt connector on the driver side as I drove; no light in the glovebox, and a dashboard parking brake light that stayed on for nearly a block as I drove with a cold engine. VW has sold more than 2,000 of the cars since last fall's introduction and hopes to sell 10,000 a year. Volkswagen looks to attract both younger and older single men with this car. One target group has median age of 30 and median household income of $40,000 a year, spokesman Val Brown said. The second group has median age of 45 and household income of $75,000 a year. In both groups, men are expected to predominate, with 75 percent of buyers likely to be male, Brown said. Thirty-five percent will be married, 70 percent will be college graduates and 65 percent will be in upper white collar jobs. Because the Corrado is a new model, Consumer Reports magazine does not list owner reports of trouble.

DOC.TEXT: A late-starting Easter selling season and a continuing auto slump combined to push retail sales down for the second straight month in March, the government said. Sales fell 0.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted $148.6 billion after a 0.3 percent drop in February, the Commerce Department reported Thursday. The drop was the steepest in five months and marked the first back-to-back sales slump since October and November 1986. Only food stores posted higher sales.

StarKist, the world's largest tuna canner, said it will no longer buy or sell tuna captured along with dolphins, winning strong praise from environmentalists who have long sought to protect dolphins from fishing nets. Environmentalists and lawmakers said Thursday they hoped the move would save some of the estimated 100,000 dolphins that die annually in huge nets used to catch schools of tuna.

Oil futures prices continued gyrating after OPEC's acting president said the cartel ministers were weighing various steps, including an emergency meeting, to try to halt the slide in world oil prices. Market rumors that OPEC was considering a meeting to deal with the price declines, which have trimmed as much as $6 a barrel in recent weeks, helped support the market on Wednesday, with prices finishing higher in erratic trading. But on Thursday prices kept fluctuating wildly and in late trading were down from Wednesday's close.

The Federated and Allied retailing companies, operating under federal bankruptcy court protection, won approval for a two-year, $25 million plan designed to keep key managers from leaving. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. on Thursday approved the plan designed to benefit about 2,300 managers of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. nationwide, from senior executives to divisional merchandise managers.

Three clerical workers at the nation's second-largest public employee union charged in a federal lawsuit that the union had discriminated against blacks in its hiring and promotion decisions. The lawsuit, filed Thursday in U.S. District Court, alleged that the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees had violated federal civil rights laws by engaging in ``deliberate and systematic'' employment practices that discriminate against blacks.

Chemical Banking Corp. posted a 29 percent rise in its first quarter profit from a year earlier due largely to the sale of its interest in Florida National Banks, while Bank of New York Corp. reported flat earnings. Both of the major banking companies said Thursday that problem loans, led by debt to Third World countries, continued to pressure their results. Analysts said the results generally were in line with expectations.

Officials of the United States and Czechoslovakia have signed a trade agreement, the second economic pact negotiated with an Eastern European nation since last year's political upheaval. The new accord, reached Thursday, is one of the steps needed to cut tariffs on Czech products sold in the United States. The document also seeks to foster increased business ties and tourism between the two nations.

A federal judge fined Marcus Schloss & Co., a New York Stock Exchange specialist firm, $480,350 for securities fraud stemming from the ``Yuppie Five'' insider trading scandal. A federal jury last July found Marcus Schloss guilty of conspiracy to trade on inside information and of securities fraud in connection with its March 1986 purchase of stock in American Brands Inc. The fine was handed down Thursday.

A bondholder group said it supported Hallmark Cards Inc.'s latest tender offer for $270 million in junk bonds issued by Univision Holdings Inc., which operates a Spanish-language television network. Hallmark is offering $131 million for the two issues of bonds under a tender offer that expires Friday. The recommendation from the bondholders group, which said it represents holders of more than three-fourths of the bonds outstanding, is expected to help Hallmark get the 90 percent of each issue that it says it must have.

The stock market broke the stalemate of the past several sessions with a rally in quiet pre-holiday trading Thursday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 22.07 to 2,751.80, finishing the week with a net gain of 34.68 points. The dollar finished narrowly mixed in quiet trading. Bond prices slipped. Crude oil futures resumed their downward spiral; live cattle futures posted new record highs; pork futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Spring Lines Doing Well _ But No Blockbuster Fashions
With PM-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Despite the absence of a major new fashion trend, shoppers are giving this year's spring lines a warm reception, boosting business for apparel stores. Retailers specializing in clothing outperformed mass merchandise chains in March, according to reports released Thursday. Business was only so-so for retailers overall, reflecting a later Easter selling season this year, unsettled weather and generally sluggish economic conditions. Fred Wintzer, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore, said the specialty apparel retailers he tracks have indicated that their warm-weather collections appear to be popular with shoppers. But he said nothing has taken the country by storm or caused women to want to discard their old wardrobes in favor of newer styles. ``The general feeling is that there's nothing hot out there _ there are no fashion trends,'' he said. He said this season's offerings haven't sparked the shopping enthusiasm that the baggy look did. That style, featuring oversized blazers, slacks and other clothes designed for comfort, became the rage in 1984. Before that, the preppy look was in vogue. Among stores selling exclusively apparel that reported their March results Thursday, The Gap Inc. posted a 20 percent sales jump. Sales at stores owned by the San Francisco-based retailer open at least a year rose 12 percent. Results from stores open a year or longer _ known as same- or comparable-store sales _ give a more accurate reading of a retailer's performance. Baltimore-based Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc., which sells trendy clothes for teenagers, said its total March sales surged 61 percent, due in part to acquisitions. But even excluding new stores it had a strong month; same-store sales gained 32 percent. The Limited Inc., the biggest specialty apparel chain in the country, said its sales rose 8 percent but were up a more modest 4 percent on a comparable store basis. The chain is based in Columbus, Ohio. For more than a year, apparel-oriented retailers have done better than general merchandise chains that devote much of their business to costly durable goods. Subpar economic growth _ with workers in some industries worried about layoffs _ have made consumers cautious about spending heavily or going into debt to finance expensive purchases. The government's retail sales report, also issued Thursday, illustrated how a weak economy has flashed warning signals to consumers. Outlays have been curbed by the Federal Reserve Board's high interest rate policy aimed at diffusing inflationary pressures. The Commerce Department said retail sales fell a seasonally adjusted 0.6 percent in March from February. The report covered sales at a wide range of establishments including stores, auto dealerships and restaurants. The largest chain reporting Thursday was K mart Corp., which blamed the calendar shift for its so-so showing. The Troy, Mich.-based discounter, which ranked second in nationwide sales volume last year behind Sears, Roebuck and Co., said total sales for the five weeks ended April 4 rose 8.6 percent. But sales fell 1.1 percent at stores open at least a year. Last month's sales were compared with a strong March 1989, when stores drew customers because of holiday promotions pushing everything from spring clothing to candy. Easter fell on March 26 last year. ``Sales were strong in the first two weeks of March but, because of the later date for Easter in 1990 than in 1989, sales weakened in line with expectations in the latter part of the month,'' said K mart Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Joseph E. Antonini. Store executives and retail economists said April should turn out to be a better month as holiday promotions capitalize on a seasonal upsurge in demand for spring clothing and other merchandise. Rosalind Wells, chief economist at the National Retail Federation in New York, said, ``stores are looking forward to a successful Easter sales period in April'' after an encouraging March. Several major mass merchandisers, such as Sears, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., J.C. Penney Co. Inc. and others, already posted their March sales a week ago. Overall, those results were sluggish. The exceptions were the perennial star performer Wal-Mart and stores concentrating on apparel, including Penney.

DOC.HEAD: Cattle Market Can Withstand Record Prices, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: The rise of cattle futures prices to record levels this week hasn't brought euphoria to the industry, where memories are vivid of the beef-market crash that followed the previous high's a decade ago. ``Everyone is running scared right now, and it's the best thing,'' said Leon Miller, president of Eagle Pass-based Alta Verde Industries, one of the nation's top 20 cattle producers. ``Everyone remembers what happened when prices shot up last time. If producers just keep selling, especially with the prices up, the market will continue to stabilize,'' Miller said. Live cattle futures reached a record price for the second consecutive day Thursday on the Chicago Mercantile exchange, with the April contract finishing at $80.42 per hundredweight, up from Wednesday's $80.40. The previous high before this week _ $80.25 per hundred pounds of beef in 1979 _ lasted only briefly before prices plummeted about 25 percent. Although producers are mindful of that crash, they say the market now isn't as vulnerable to a similar turnaround. Today's record prices reflect a seasonal peak in demand for beef and supply tightness stemming from delayed cattle marketings because of dry pastures in the Southern Plains last fall and winter. ``We have a completely different situation,'' said Tommy Beall, director of research for Cattle-Fax, a Denver-based market analysis company for the cattle. ``The economics are different. The prices we have seen recently accurately reflect the state of the industry. The prices in 1979 did not,'' he said. Beall said liquidation by producers leaving the industry over the past decade has tightened the cattle supply and forced prices up. The supply situation was much different in 1979, when inflated prices and overpopulated feed yards gave producers a false sense of security. ``Producers took females out of the slaughter and placed them in the breeding herds to multiply and cash in on the high prices back then,'' Miller said. ``Suddenly we had too many head of cattle and the bottom fell out,'' Miller said. The 1979 crash caused prices to plummet from $80 per hundredweight to the $60 range in a matter of weeks. That drop, combined with rising production and grain costs and dry conditions, have reduced the number of cattle head by 16 million since the mid-1980s, Beall said. ``The industry is still recovering from the price drop,'' said Jim Gill, a market analyst for the Texas Cattle Feeders' Association in Amarillo. ``The tight supply of cattle right now reflects the changes in the industry since the sharp drop in prices.'' Feeders and analysts agree that a new selling philosophy of ``expect less for cattle tomorrow than what you can get today,'' has helped insure the market against another break-off, Miller said. Industry officials said today's record futures prices would not affect retail beef costs because futures prices had been around the $80 mark for two months. ``The retail price increase has already been passed on to the consumer,'' Miller said. ``When futures prices jumped from about $74 to where they are now in February there was an increase in a few cents per cut.'' Most industry officials expect prices will ease in the next two months, when grazing conditions are expected to improve and cattle can be beefed up more quickly. But declines should be moderate, they say. ``I would expect the price to land at about 75 or $76 by June,'' said Milton Rudder, vice president of AzTx Cattle Co. based in Hereford. ``The number of cattle ready to be sold will increase significantly.''

DOC.HEAD: Conner Out at Winnebago Less than Four Months After Being Named President
DOC.TEXT: A familiar figure is back in charge of day-to-day operations at slumping Winnebago Industries after directors of the recreational vehicle maker fired another president. The board of Winnebago fired Richard Conner on Thursday and said its executive committee had designated the company's chairman, founder and principal stockholder, John K. Hanson, as acting chief executive. Conner had been president and chief executive for less than four months and became the fifth president dismissed by the board since 1976. There was no elaboration and neither Hanson nor Conner was available for comment, said Sheila Davis, a spokeswoman at Winnebago's Forest City headquarters. Calls to Conner's home were not returned. The shakeup followed a series of recent setbacks for the company. Still, Wall Street appeared to shrug off the news. Winnebago closed unchanged at $5.12{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. ``There's been an awful lot of bad news recently,'' said Frank Rolfes, an analyst who follows Winnebago for the Minneapolis securities firm of Dain Bosworth. ``It's not like this is the first piece of bad news we've seen. ... The stock probably has bottomed out.'' Among recent problems the company: _ Reported a loss of nearly $10 million, or 40 cents a share, for the six months ended Feb. 24, compared with a profit of $6.3 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The market for its main product, recreational vehicles, has been sluggish. _ Disclosed it sold its portfolio of marketable securities and IOUs from dealers to reduce short-term debt when it could not negotiate the interest rates it wanted from its lenders. _ Has struggled to make a go of its Cycle-Sat subsidiary, which Conner once headed and which delivers television commercials to stations via satellite. The dismissal of Conner, who was named president Dec. 15, is a sign Winnebago is ``having trouble finding someone who runs the company the way John K. wants,'' Rolfes said. Hanson, 76, has a controlling interest in the company's stock. ``On the surface, it doesn't look really good,'' said Richard L. Hanley, who heads an independent New York research firm bearing his own name. ``Reading between the lines, it is not any great negative.'' Hanley said Winnebago does have several positive factors in its favor. It is nearly debt-free and has widespread recognition of its brands in the recreational vehicle market, which leave it in good position to capitalize on any rebound in the market for motor homes. He also said that despite Conner's ties to Cycle-Sat, company officials indicated his dismissal is not a signal of that venture's demise. Hanley said he thinks Conner's dismissal was related to the recent return of two former executives to take over product development and marketing. Winnebago realized ``it didn't need an active chief executive officer,'' he said. The executives are Rex Miner, who returned after an absence of 10 years to be head of product development, and Ronald Jacobson, who was appointed vice president of sales and marketing. Both executives moved to those positions when Conner became president late last year. ``It looks to me like the old regime coming back,'' Hanley said.

DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Says Buying Spree is Over, Plans to Build Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Media baron Rupert Murdoch says he is intent on improving earnings at News Corp. Ltd. and has no plans for more big acquisitions. The Australian-based News Corp. secured its place over the past decade among the global communications powerhouses partly by buying a U.S. movie studio, several television stations, magazines and book companies. But the acquisitions of the Twentieth Century Fox, Metromedia TV stations, TV Guide and Harper & Row Publishers, as well as costs in starting the Fox TV network and the British satellite-TV service Sky Television, have left the company with a debt of more than $6 billion. Murdoch disclosed his plans to forgo major acquisitions and focus on earnings improvement and the company's current businesses in an interview published Thursday in The Wall Street Journal. He confirmed some of the details of that account by telephone. ``We are not going to purchase anything major,'' the chief executive of News Corp. said in the phone interview. ``We are sorting out our portfolio of media assets. Our main concentration is going to be on developing our earnings,'' he said. Only a year ago, Murdoch was planning to create a second company that would be used as an acquisition vehicle. But the investment banker was able to line up only about half of the $1 billion sought and Murdoch dropped the plan. News Corp. reported in February that its earnings tumbled 67 percent to $117 million in the six months ended Dec. 31, 1989, even as its revenue rose 8.3 percent to $3.17 billion. It cited startup losses in Sky Television, higher interest expense and the impact of a labor dispute involving its airline in Australia. The company's stock also has been trading at relatively low levels. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, News Corp.'s American depositary receipts finished unchanged at $16.50 Thursday. The ADRs have traded in a range of between $14.87{ and $27.12{ over the past 52 weeks. Each ADR is equivalent to two common shares of News Corp. stock. Murdoch said one of his top priorities would be Sky Television, which offers four channels of programming and has 450,000 paid subscribers in the Britain. The service, launched last year, already has cost about $400 million and may cost another $150 million or more before it reaches the break-even point of 2 million paid subscribers late next year, Murdoch said. The service has been adding about 20,000 new subscribers a week, he said, partly because Sky Television changed its marketing plans to allow people to rent the receiving dishes rather than buy them. Sky Television may soon face competition, however, from a rival service from British Satellite Broadcasting Corp. News Corp. is among four companies attempting to reach agreement on launching an 108-channel satellite TV service in the United States. The service, Sky Cable, tentatively is scheduled to start operations in late 1993. Murdoch said he has no plans to make any major asset sales, although he said there may be sales of ``some minor activities'' such as in book retailing or distribution. The company announced in late March an agreement to sell Star magazine, a supermarket tabloid that features heavy doses of celebrity gossip along with health and beauty tips, for at least $400 million in cash and preferred stock to G.P. Group Inc., the publisher of the archrival weekly, The National Enquirer. Media analyst Peter Appert of the investment firm C.J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell, said he expected the investment community would take a positive view of Murdoch's plans to try to improve earnings. ``From a strategic standpoint, it probably makes sense for them to try to digest some of these properties. They are not precluded from going back to the acquisition marketplace at some time in the future,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gonzalez Says He's Satisified With Progress Of Fraud Prosecutions
DOC.TEXT: Fraud may have accounted for as much as 80 percent of the losses at the nation's failed savings and loans, regulators said, citing a ``predominance of lavish lifestyles'' among thrift insiders. Regulators and prosecutors also cautioned that it is difficult to prosecute wrongdoers, and may be harder still to recover substantial portions of the losses. Nevertheless, the chairman of the House Banking Committee said he was satisfied with government efforts to track down fraud at banks and thrifts. ``They have done as much as is humanly possible to do,'' Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez said Thursday after ending two days of committee hearings in Dallas. The San Antonio Democrat had convened the hearings to examine how effective federal agencies had been in finding and prosecuting fraud in the troubled financial industry. ``I don't think that the extent and depth of the problem is realized even now,'' he said. Gonzalez warned that although much of the focus has been on Texas, the problems already are showing up in the Northeast and elsewhere. Several times during the hearings witnesses were asked to quantify the industry losses attributed to fraud. Their estimates ranged from 10 percent to 80 percent. William K. Black, an attorney for the Office of Thrift Supervision in San Francisco, suggested that when fraudulent activity leads to an institution's insolvency, the entire loss should be blamed on fraud. As an example, he cited Vernon Savings and Loan Association, closed in 1987 in a then-record $1.2 billion federal bailout. Seven Vernon executives, including a former president and former chairman, along with three affiliated individuals have been found guilty of various crimes including misapplication of funds and bank fraud. ``Vernon was front-to-back fraud,'' Black said. James E. Cooper, deputy director of the Dallas office of the Resolution Trust Corp., said fraud was present in as much as 80 percent of failed Texas and Oklahoma thrifts. ``Our preliminary investigations have revealed instances of insider abuse and misconduct ranging from embezzlement and simple loan fraud to complex conspiracies and schemes to defraud institutions,'' Cooper said. ``We noted a predominance of lavish lifestyles, plush accoutrements, expensive automobiles, artwork, airplanes and compensation incentives benefiting insiders at the expense of stockholders and depositors,'' he said. The hearings were held in Dallas in part because the city has been the center of much of the activity and has the largest task force investigating bank and thrift crimes. Witnesses included FBI Director William Sessions, three Texas U.S. attorneys, plus current and former regulators from both state and federal agencies. Most said last year's Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act had provided adequate resources to find and prosecute the fraud. But the three Texas U.S. attorneys called for more judges to hear the expected increase in fraud cases. ``We can pour more cases in the funnel but every case must pass through the narrow neck of the judiciary,'' said Marvin S. Collins, U.S. attorney for the Northern District of Texas. The witnesses agreed that the complexity of the fraud makes it difficult to prosecute. In addition, many of those charged are prominent members of the community, making convictions difficult unless the evidence against them is overwhelming, they said. ``Unless we are able to put some money, a lot of money, in somebody's pocket ... it is very difficult to convict them,'' Collins said. The witnesses also warned there may be little chance to recover some losses. Rep. Thomas Carper, D-Del., and Rep. Martin Frost, D-Texas, both urged prosecutors to seek as much restitution as possible. But U.S. Attorney Henry K. Oncken of Houston said, ``It is my opinion that expectations of vast amounts of restitution and high fines that are collectible may be overly optimistic. Many of the cases being investigated involve real estate ventures that used up large amounts of cash to keep them going. ``When the real estate market fell, there wasn't much cash and the value of the land, buildings or other real property (put up as collateral) were greatly diminished,'' Oncken said. ``People in jail don't pay a lot of restitution,'' Collins said.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Gets Out of Expensive NYC Lease; Manager Retention Plan OK'd
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp.'s Federated and Allied retailers have won approval to start a two-year, $25 million plan designed to keep key managers from leaving for other jobs. Creditors of the two companies, which are operating under federal bankruptcy court protection, went along with the plan Thursday. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. gave his approval. The plan is designed to benefit about 2,300 managers of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. nationwide, from senior executives to divisional merchandise managers. It would provide a core of about 400 key executives with performance bonuses, job security assurances and employment and severance agreement terms. Aug also approved payment of about $1.5 million in 1989 performance bonuses to 396 executives of both divisions. The Cincinnati-based retailers have 260 stores and 100,000 employees in 28 states. The companies have been required to seek Aug's approval for spending since they filed Jan. 15 for Chapter 11 protection from creditors. The companies listed $7.7 billion in debts acquired when Campeau bought them in 1986 and 1988. The judge postponed a ruling on the request by Allied and Federated to hire Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as a financial adviser. The retailers said they need the advice of the Wall Street house to work through the reorganization. Shearson did work for the retailers in February and March and needs to be hired formally to collect $500,000 in fees, lawyers for Allied and Federated said. But U.S. Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern objected, saying Shearson should be disqualified under federal bankruptcy law from serving as a consultant because it underwrote Federated-Allied securities prior to the companies' Jan. 15 filing. David Heiman, a lawyer for Federated and Allied, acknowledged the bond underwriting but said it was ``ancient history'' that occurred three years ago and would not affect Shearson's ability to serve. Aug postponed resolution of the matter until a hearing April 26, when he is to hear further testimony. The judge also approved a request by Allied and its Allied Stores Marketing Corp. subsidiary to get out of a lease on six floors of office space in New York City, where Allied maintained its corporate headquarters until moving last year to Cincinnati. He did so over objections by New York businessman Robert Arnow, who leased the space to Allied for about $300,000 a month under a 25-year lease that was to run through 1997. Allied said it no longer needs the space and that continuing to make lease payments could reduce the value of Allied's estate for creditors. The judge also heard a plea on behalf of about 40 retired senior executives of Allied and Federated or their surviving spouses, who said some of their benefits had been stopped since the companies filed the reorganization petitions. Lawyer Jeff Ireland presented the claim behalf of former executives including ex-Federated chairman Howard Goldfeder and three members of the Lazarus family, which founded Federated and its Lazarus department store group. Members of the group are continuing to receive regular, federally protected pensions and medical insurance coverage, officials said. But Ireland said Allied and Federated have suspended other retirement benefits including supplemental pensions, deferred compensation and retirement allowances. Lawyers for Allied and Federated said they are aware of the retirees' claims and are trying to provide for them in the companies' reorganization plan. The lawyers declined to say when the reorganization plan will be filed.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of New England Sells Mutual Fund Custody Business
DOC.TEXT: The Bank of New England Corp. announced an agreement to sell its mutual fund custody business to Investors Bank & Trust Co. The two companies have completed an agreement on principle to exchange the business for an undisclosed sum, bank officials said Thursday. Bank of New England currently oversees mutual funds valued at $22 billion. Investor's Bank, which is 77.3 percent controlled by the Boston-based interstate bank Eaton Vance Corp., already holds custody assets worth an estimated $9 billion. The Bank of New England lost more than $1 billion last year, primarily due to its aggressive real estate lending policies in an overheated market. In response to its economic woes, bank officials have announced plans to sell off approximately $8 billion in assets. This week the bank sold its asset-based lending operations located outside New England, valued at about $665 million, to National Bank of Canada. That transaction brought the total value of the bank's assets sold so far to more than $3.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Cartel Weighs Urgent Meeting To Stop Oil Price Drop; Analysts Skeptical
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices continued to gyrate after OPEC's acting president said the cartel ministers were considering holding an emergency meeting in an effort to halt the slide in world oil prices. Rumors that OPEC might call an early meeting to deal with the declines, which have trimmed as much as $6 off the price of a barrel in recent weeks, helped support the market on Wednesday. But on Thursday prices kept fluctuating wildly and in late trading were down from Wednesday's close. Analysts said they were skeptical the oil ministers would take effective steps against the recent steep price drop and predicted weak prices over the near term. ``I think it's really all noise and very little action,'' said Geoff Pyne, an oil analyst with the London investment firm UBS Philips and Drew. Prices have fallen more sharply than usual during the traditional spring slump, when demand generally drops among consumer nations. Analysts blame the recent price drop on overproduction by some OPEC members. Acting OPEC President Sadek Boussena said Thursday he had been conducting ``intensive consultations'' with his fellow ministers about the price slide. Options under consideration included an urgent meeting of the eight-member ministerial monitoring committee and an extraordinary meeting of all 13 members, he said. OPEC's monitoring committee studies oil market conditions and makes policy recommendations to the full OPEC conference. While it formally has only the eight members, its sessions tend to be attended by all OPEC ministers. The acting president, who is Algeria's oil minister, made the comments in an official statement released Thursday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' Vienna secretariat. OPEC's 13 oil ministers have a full meeting scheduled for May 25 to set their output and price for the second half of the year. Nick Clayton, an analyst with Smith New Court PLC, predicted the ministers would gather in early May. But Pyne said he did not believe they would meet before May 25 unless prices fell further. Boussena's statement is ``a recognition that there are difficulties in the oil market,'' Clayton said. The spot price of North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, stood at $15.45 a barrel late Thursday, unchanged from late Wednesday. The price stood at $18.45 a barrel on March 16. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the May contract for West Texas Intermediate crude finished down 28 cents from Wednesday at $17.78 a barrel. By comparison, the near-month contract for WTI settled at $24.20 on Jan. 22. The average price of a basket of seven crude oils monitored by OPEC was $17.12 a barrel in the first week of April, off from $17.26 in the last week of March and below the cartel's minimum reference price of $18 a barrel. ``Stocks are very high. OPEC has been producing too much for too long and the obvious reaction was that prices have to fall,'' Clayton said. The cartel's production last week came to just over 24.5 million barrels a day, well over OPEC's cap of 22.1 million barrels a day for the January-June period, estimated Peter Gignoux, director of the international energy department at Shearson Lehman Hutton in London. ``It will be quite difficult to think of some mechanism by which they can reduce output,'' Pyne said. No member country is willing to take on the burden, he said. ``In the near-term there will be continual soft outlook for the markets,'' Pyne said. But demand should start to pick up in early May, he said. OPEC's members are Algeria, Nigeria, Iran, Iraq, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Venezuela, Libya, Qatar, Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Fines Trading Firm for Securities Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A specialist firm on the New York Stock Exchange was fined $480,350 for securities fraud by a judge who said he imposed the sentence as a deterrent. ``The trading while in possession of confidential material is a crime.'' U.S. District Judge Charles Haight said Thursday at the sentencing of Marcus Schloss & Co. ``It constitutes an affront to the fair operation of the marketplace.'' Prosecutors said Marcus Schloss was the first NYSE firm to be convicted of felony charges related to insider trading. The company was convicted last July of conspiracy to trade on inside information and of securities fraud in connection with its March 1986 purchase of stock in American Brands Inc. It was acquitted of securities fraud charges for stock trades involving three other companies. Marcus Schloss could have been fined a maximum of $1 million _ $500,000 for each of two counts. Haight, however, said he only considered a fine of $500,000 because both charges stemmed from the American Brands deal. From that amount, the judge said he subtracted $19,650 which the company previously paid the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle civil charges stemming from the American Brands trade. The SEC settlement, reached in February 1988, involved other trades and required Marcus Schloss to pay a total of $410,000. The firm's lawyer, Marvin Schwartz, said the SEC settlement was the company's ``plain acknowledgement of wrongdoing.'' He told the judge that any additional fine would ``be in the nature of a double hit.'' Marcus Schloss' former head of arbitrage, D. Ronald Yagoda, was tried with the firm but was acquitted of all charges, including perjury and obstruction of justice in connection with an SEC inquiry. Schwartz has said he will appeal the company's conviction on the grounds that it was inconsistent to convict the firm on conduct for which Yagoda was acquitted. The government had charged that Yagoda received inside information on pending stock transactions from Andrew Solomon, a former Marcus Schloss analyst. Solomon was part of the ``Yuppie Five'' ring. In 1986, Solomon, three other young Wall Street professionals and a client pleaded guilty to trading on inside information about corporate takeovers that they had obtained through their jobs. Marcus Schloss and Yagoda were indicted in 1988 along with two Wall Street arbitragers, who were convicted last week at a separate trial. Victor Teicher, 38, who headed the arbitrage firm Teicher & Co., and Ross Frankel, 33, former head of arbitrage research at now-defunct investment house Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., were found guilty of 18 counts of securities fraud, conspiracy and mail fraud. Teicher and Frankel were convicted of trading the stocks of eight corporations based on stolen information. They were to be sentenced by Haight in June.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Government Sues Honeywell, Alleging Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A $48 million federal lawsuit against Honeywell Inc. and Unisys Corp. alleges that a Sperry Aerospace operation Honeywell bought from Unisys in 1986 has been defrauding the Navy for the past 11 years. The business, which Honeywell resold in 1988, repeatedly inflated its estimated cost for flight simulators used to train pilots of F-18 and T-45 jets, according to a lawsuit filed Thursday by the U.S. attorney in Brooklyn, N.Y. The suit seeks $48 million in claims on government contracts, which is triple the government's alleged loss of $16 million. It also seeks $5,000 to $10,000 for each allegedly false claim for payment that was submitted to the government. Tim Morin, a Honeywell spokesman, said the firm had not seen a copy of the suit and declined to comment. The simulator suit involves a business unit that Minneapolis-based Honeywell owned from 1986 to 1988, although the alleged fraud occurred over a period extending back to the late 1970s. During that time the business unit was owned first by Sperry, based in New York, and later by Detroit-based Unisys, which was formed when Sperry was acquired by Burroughs Corp. in 1986. The government's suit claims that in 1979, Sperry deliberately underestimated the cost of an initial project for the F-18 simulator, hoping to obtain the contract for it and later projects. It succeeded in winning those contracts but then concealed its true estimates of what the later projects cost, the suit says. Instead, the suit says, executives padded the cost estimate by as much as 30 percent, presenting the higher numbers to the Navy and concealing the added amounts in labor charges. The suit says documents showing the added dollars were distributed to a committee of company executives then collected after each committee meeting. The result was inflated contract prices awarded by the government, the lawsuit alleges. The suit alleges the flight simulator project for the T-45 was similarly inflated. Officials at the U.S. Attorney's office said the suit was filed in Brooklyn federal court because the alleged fraudulent activities occurred in corporate offices in the New York area. The suit is the third legal obstacle Honeywell has encountered as a result of acquiring the Sperry Aerospace operations. The first episode involved hidden contract cost-accounting problems in the Albuquerque, N.M., military aerospace operations. Those problems were mainly responsible for Honeywell's record loss of $435 million in 1988. As a result of those problems, Honeywell in 1988 sued Unisys for more than $350 million, mostly over alleged misstatements about the financial condition of the Sperry Aerospace operations. The second episode arose last year when the government sued Honeywell and Unisys for about $48 million over alleged contract violations at operations in Albuquerque. Honeywell has said a significant part of that suit involves alleged incidents that occurred before it bought the operations from Unisys. Damages for the period before Honeywell's ownership would be covered by a contract clause under which Unisys would bear the costs for its period of ownership, Morin said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pays $101,382 Federal Income Tax
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBs 1st two grafs and 6th graf, bgng, By contrast... to add word `federal.' This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife Barbara paid $101,382 in federal income taxes last year and reported charitable contributions of $37,272 that included gifts to hurricane and earthquake relief efforts. A copy of the first couple's joint 1989 federal return, released Thursday by the White House, showed that the Bushes reported total income of $456,780. Both taxes and income were up sharply from the couple's 1988 return on which they reported total income of $287,171 and taxes of $62,106. The higher income came from Bush's better pay as president _ $200,000 a year against his $115,000 vice presidential salary _ and from a growth in business investments. The Bushes' tax return showed that the Bushes earned $208,274 last year from business holdings held in a blind trust, up from the $155,662 the trust earned the previous year. By contrast, Vice President Dan Quayle and his wife, Marilyn, made less in 1989 than in 1988, but paid more in federal taxes. The Quayles, whose return was released by his office, paid taxes of $25,479 on a total income of $133,696. The year before, they paid $24,314 on a total income of $156,546. Quayle's 1988 income was boosted by nearly $53,000 in speaking honoraria earned while he was a senator _ much of which was given to charities. Because he claimed fewer tax-deductible contributions in 1989, his overall tax liability rose. Bush, who has energetically lobbied Congress to lower the capital gains tax, paid taxes on $36,068 in capital gains posted by the blind trust. The trust, which masks the first family's investment portfolio, was established in 1981 when Bush became vice president. The joint tax return filed by the president and his wife listed $94,702 in itemized deductions. Among the contributions was $3,000 in cash for relief organizations to help victims of Hurricane Hugo in the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and South Carolina. An additional $1,500 was donated to similar efforts in the aftermath of the San Francisco-area earthquake. Bush divided profits of $14,282 from his biography, ``Looking Forward,'' between two charities: the United Negro College Fund in New York and the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center of Houston. In all, the Bushes gave $8,141 to the black educational fund _ their largest contribution. They also gave $5,000 to a private fund that is building a new chapel at Camp David, the presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains. Through a quirk of job and geography, Bush paid no state or city income tax. Texas, his adopted home state, has no income tax. He doesn't spend enough time at his oceanside home in Maine to be required to pay taxes there, according to White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. The District of Colombia exempts the president from its income tax. Most of Quayle's income consisted of his government salary _ $106,528 as vice president and $3,715 as vice president-elect before the Jan. 20 inaugural. He resigned as a senator from Indiana on Jan. 2, 1989. Although the Quayles hold assets valued at more than $1.4 million, the vice president showed relatively small business earnings in 1989. They reported $14,572 in dividends on family stock holdings in Central Newspapers Inc. Quayle also reported $1,858 in interest earnings on various savings accounts. The Quayles claimed a $5,435 loss in renting their house in McLean, Va., a Washington suburb. Aides said the loss came because the house was on the market for several months before the Quayles found a renter. They now live in the official vice presidential residence.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Decline 0.2 Percent in March
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 14th graf, bgng, Clothing prices.... Women's clothing fell, sted rose, and men's and children's clothing rose, sted fell. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Falling gasoline and vegetable prices pushed wholesale prices down 0.2 percent in March, the first drop in seven months, the government said today. The decline in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index followed no change in February and a huge 1.8 percent gain in January. A cold snap in December caused the January price spurt by killing Gulf Coast vegetable crops and producing a fuel oil shortage. Energy prices began their recovery in February and were joined by food prices last month. For the first quarter, overall prices advanced at an annual rate of 6.7 percent, well above the 4.8 percent rise for all of last year. However, analysts expect wholesale inflation for 1990 will be a little below last year's rate. They anticipate continued declines for food and energy in the next few months. ``We'll probably get further downard pressure, especially in energy, in April,'' said economist James Annable of First National Bank of Chicago. ``When we get into the spring, we're going to see that inflation is running about where it has been running, which is about 4.5 percent.'' Meanwhile, in a separate report, the Commerce Department said business inventories fell 0.4 percent in February while sales surged 1.3 percent. The report was taken as a sign of strength. Rising inventories can signal a recession. The March wholesale inflation report was better than expected. Most economists had predicted a slight increase of 0.1 percent or 0.2 percent. Food prices dropped 0.6 percent in March, the sharpest decline since June. Vegetables, particularly tomatoes, celery and cabbage, declined 25.5 percent, the biggest drop on record going back to 1967. However, that marked only a partial recovery from gains of 23.3 percent in February and 58 percent in January. Prices also fell for beef and veal, dairy products and coffee. They rose for eggs, rice, pasta, pork, chickens, turkeys, fish, soft drinks and cooking oils. Energy prices overall dropped 2.4 percent in March following a fall of 5 percent in February and an increase of 13.6 percent in January. Gasoline was down 2.8 percent and natural gas declined 2.5 percent. Fuel oil prices went up 10.6 percent, but they had fallen 30.2 percent the month before. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors rose a moderate 0.3 percent in March following gains of 0.4 percent in February and 0.1 percent in January. Economists look to these so-called core prices as a better indication of underlying inflationary pressures. Clothing prices for men and children rose, while the cost of women's clothing fell. Passenger car prices, in the face of weak auto sales, declined 0.3 percent in March after no change in February and a 0.7 percent fall in January. The various changes put the index for all finished goods, one stop short of retail, at 117.0 in March. That means a hypothetical selection of goods which cost $100 in 1982 cost $117 last month, up from $112.10 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process also eased in March. Intermediate goods showed no change while crude goods fell 1.4 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude. The moderate inflation report should please the Federal Reserve Board which has been using relatively high interest rates to dampen demand and thus cool inflation. But, analysts cautioned against reading too much into recent months' numbers, which have been sent on a roller-coaster ride by the effect of the weather on food and energy prices. ``The numbers in the next few months could give us a false sense of euphoria just as the number in January gave us a false sense of gloom,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Whirlpool Provides Lesson in European Expansion Drive
LaserPhoto LON11 of April 11
DOC.TEXT: When American appliance king Whirlpool Corp. wanted to expand into Europe as part of a strategy to dominate the world market, it ran into the business version of a rough spin cycle. The company found that although its name was a household world in the United States, few Europeans had heard of or could even pronounce the brand. Its big and American identity was no selling point either. So Whirlpool sought a kindred spirit on this side of the Atlantic. By entering a joint venture with the Dutch electronics giant NV Philips and adopting a pan-European marketing strategy, Whirlpool may provide a valuable lesson for other U.S. companies hoping to get inside the trade barrier-free Europe planned for the end of 1992. ``Our ultimate goal by the end of this century is to emblazon the Whirlpool brand supreme around the world,'' Jan Karel, managing director of the joint venture, told a convention of appliance dealers in France in January. Early last year, Whirlpool acquired a 53 percent stake in Philips' major domestic appliance business for $470 million. It makes Whirlpool the world's No. 1 maker of major domestic appliances, the company says, and gets it into the European market of 320million consumers without having to start from scratch. Whirlpool, based in Benton Harbor, Mich., had $4 billion in annual sales but none in Europe. It obtained instant access to Philips' $2 billion worth of European domestic appliance sales. The joint venture, called Whirlpool International BV, is based in Comerio, Italy, and employs 14,000 people. It has become the first company to sell a single brand of domestic appliances across Europe, an appliance market highly fragmented with a range of brand names and varying standards. Under the agreement, Whirlpool can use the Philips brand name until the end of the decade. After a year of research and development, Whirlpool has decided to use the name Philips Whirlpool, and will gradually drop the name Philips, one country at a time. ``Whirlpool is virtually unknown,'' said Derek Smith, editor of the British weekly Electrical and Radio Trading. ``Frankly, I can't think of what else they would have done, given that Philips is a well-established brand in Europe, and the U.K. particularly.'' Whirlpool has had past success with what is known in the industry as ``transitional dual branding.'' During the 1950s it acquired the air conditioning and electric stove businesses of Radio Corporation of America and called these products RCA Whirlpool for 12 years before dropping the RCA. For its latest branding attempt, Whirlpool's Paris-based advertising agency, Publicis FCS International, devised seven candidate advertising campaigns in three languages after hiring researchers to interview a total of more than 1,000 women consumers in Britain, France, Austria and Spain. The research helped the company learn the common denominators, and what to avoid. Nick Mote, Publicis' international coordinator for the account, said, ``It is difficult. It took us a year of development to find the key to the door. We wanted to be as broadly appealing as possible.'' Whirlpool wanted to target housewives rather than professional women working outside the home, who are proliferating in Germany but remain a relative novelty elsewhere in Europe. Because Whirlpool is hard to pronounce in Spanish or French, the company decided to go with the English pronunciation. The researchers found that the women interviewed were skeptical that the company's large size would guarantee quality, and they discovered strong anti-American sentiment among the British and Austrian women. ``They associated American with the disposable society and not technology,'' Mote said. The end result is a $100 million ``Philips Whirlpool Brings Quality to Life'' ad campaign launched in mid-February. The first television ad, shown in 14 European countries, looks futuristic, with a touch of magic. It shows a young mother entering a transparent kitchen made opaque by a golden swirl. The Whirlpool name and logo are spoken and shown repeatedly, with no reference to the United States or the company's size. A dark-haired actress was chosen because brunettes are spread throughout Europe, and blondes aren't. Even her outfit was a headache, because skirts are shorter in France than Spain. She wore pants because the chosen skirt turned out too tight. ``You could alienate a lot of people if you went too sexy,'' said Brian Kennerley, managing director of Whirlpool (U.K.) Ltd. Asked his opinion of the campaign, a buyer for a major British department store chain said, ``People thought that Philips Whirlpool was a product. They think it is a Jacuzzi or a special product as opposed to a brand.'' The buyer, who requested anonymity, added, ``It occurred to me that it might have been better to promote it Whirlpool Philips ... to avoid confusion.'' Whirlpool says it went with Philips Whirlpool because Philips already is a well-known name in Europe. It says the Whirlpool brand is catching on more quickly than it had hoped. ``There is a total acceptance,'' Kennerley said. ``I'm not sure we need to go beyond two or three years'' with the dual name.

DOC.HEAD: Some See a Sneaky ``Soft Landing''
DOC.TEXT: If you don't like the way the economy looks on the charts of Wall Street economists, just wait an hour or two. In keeping with the spring weather in the environs of New York City, the prevailing forecast of the business and investment outlook seems especially changeable right now. Within the past few weeks alone, recession fears have faded amid signs of gradually reviving growth, only to be replaced by new worries about a slump induced by a shrinking supply of credit. Consumers, meanwhile, are variously portrayed as all spent out, restocking their depleted pocketbooks, or ready to launch a new assault on the malls. Some observers believe all this turbulence may have distracted the attention of many participants in the stock and bond markets from a favorable development of more than passing significance. It is just possible, they say, that the economy has experienced its long-awaited ``soft landing'' almost unnoticed. If that is indeed the case, Federal Reserve-watchers add, people who worry that the Fed is trapped in a tight spot between the conflicting perils of inflation and recession could be missing an important point. They suggest that the Fed may be avoiding any overt changes in its credit policy right now simply because it is satisfied, maybe even pleased, with the way things stand. It is axiomatic in the financial world that whenever things are moving in a favorable direction, there is usually some prominent and highly publicized worry to serve as a sort of smoke screen. In the optimists' view, that purpose is being fulfilled right now by talk of a ``credit crunch'' arising from a risk-averse mood among bankers and other would-be lenders, including those who once were eager buyers of junk bonds. ``If tougher lending practices are now producing a serious credit crunch, then an economy-wide recession could unfold,'' says Edward Yardeni, economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ``However, we aren't convinced that the current credit crunch is severe enough to cause an economy-wide recession. ``Low-quality borrowers, who need to finance very risky activities, are being turned away by the bankers. But that leaves more lendable funds available for high-quality borrowers.'' Or as Kevin Logan at Swiss Bank Corp. puts it: ``Business borrowing is stronger than many people think, and economic growth may be more robust than many expect. Credit crunch? Don't bet on it.'' Given the uncertain climate of recent days, many stock traders seem unwilling to stake much either for or against such a possibility. But the market did manage to post some spotty gains in the past week before shutting down Thursday night for a long holiday weekend. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 34.68 points to 2,751.80, on top of a 9.91 advance the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 2.02 to 188.80; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 5.41 to 436.31, and the American Stock Exchange market value index dropped 3.13 to 357.88. Volume on the Big Board averaged 133.63 million shares, against 143.97 million in the previous week. A steady-as-she-goes approach ``is likely to remain the thrust of Fed policy for quite some time,'' maintains Paul Boltz, financial economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. The Fed isn't likely to launch a major new offensive against inflation until the pace of business activity gets a good deal stronger than it has been lately, Boltz says. ``Similarly,'' he concludes, ``ease would be called for only if the economy looks headed for a recession _ something not on the horizon.''

DOC.HEAD: Environment Overtakes South Africa As Hottest Shareholder Resolution Item
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds new last graf with Cyanamid comment.
DOC.TEXT: A record 300 shareholder resolutions on social concerns ranging from South African divestment to teen-age smoking were filed this year for votes at annual meetings, 40 percent more than last year. But the fastest growth came in resolutions urging more corporate sensitivity to the environment. ``People are so fed up with things like garbage barges and Exxon spills,'' says Rosalyn Will, a researcher at the Council on Economic Priorities, a New York-based public-interest group that follows shareholder resolution trends. ``Enough is enough,'' she said. The growing concern reflects an anxiety over pollution, atmospheric warming and other signs of global deterioration that perhaps has been heightened by publicity about the 20th anniversary of Earth Day on April 22. The biggest corporate target appears to be Exxon Corp., the oil giant that came to symbolize recklessness for many nature-lovers after the March 1989 oil spill that fouled Valdez, Alaska. The company will face eight environment-related resolutions at its annual meeting April 25, ranging from dismissing chairman Lawrence Rawl to pledging commitment to the ``Valdez Principles,'' a set of guidelines for corporate behavior devised by a coalition of environmental groups after the spill. ``The average person realizes that large companies can change what they're doing environmentally,'' Hill said. To a lesser extent, shareholder activists say, the environmental theme of the 1990 annual meeting season just getting under way also shows that South Africa no longer is drawing the same level of attention it once did. Part of the reason is that many U.S. companies have left South Africa voluntarily already, and the white-minority government recently has taken some dramatic steps suggesting it's willing to give the black majority more power. ``The situation is moving there now,'' said Gordon Davidson, outgoing director of the Social Investment Forum, a national association of 375 investment funds that promotes what it calls socially responsible investing. ``It's a sign of the work we've done,'' he said. ``It's not that we're giving up on that issue.'' South Africa remains the biggest single area of social investor attention, with about 120 resolutions filed this year, the same as last year. By contrast, 45 environment-related resolutions were filed this year, vs. six in 1989. ``I think a combination of environmental factors is responsible,'' said Timothy Smith, executive director of the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, a New York church-activist group. ``Obviously the oil spill galvanized America's attention,'' he said. ``The concern about global warming, the ozone layer, the rain forests, reminds us of an international environmental crisis.'' Other recurring resolutions range from a moratorium on nuclear weapons to animal-testing bans to a review of business operations in British-ruled Northern Ireland. But a couple of important new themes have emerged as well. The most notable are resolutions opposing tobacco product manufacturing and advertising, which are on the agendas of leading cigarette producers such as Philip Morris Cos., American Brands Inc. and Loews Corp. The Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees what resolutions can be included at annual meetings, reversed an earlier position that cigarette smoking was not an area in which shareholders were entitled to vote. Infant-formula marketing also has surfaced as a potential battle issue. Activists have introduced resolutions at Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Gerber Products Co. challenging the companies' practice of advertising formula directly to mothers, claiming it undermines the practice of breast-feeding. Many companies facing shareholder resolutions on political and social issues fear the adverse publicity such issues create, even if they have little chance of approval. Some have successfully negotiated settlements with the sponsors that get the measures off the agenda before the annual meetings. Amoco Corp., Chevron Corp., Mobil Corp., Texaco Inc. and Waste Management Co., for example, agreed to provide ``report cards'' on areas covered by the Valdez principles, and the sponsors agreed to withdraw their resolutions. Fast-food giant McDonald's Corp., facing a resolution sponsored by church groups challenging its use of styrofoam packaging, agreed to explore alternatives. The sponsors withdrew their resolution. ``They're beginning to see the handwriting on the wall, that the environmental movement isn't going away next year,'' said Davidson. ``They're trying to figure out how they're going to cope with it.'' On the other hand, Exxon, Atlantic Richfield Co. and several other leading industrial corporations declined to make any concessions on environmental resolutions, so they will come to a vote. Historically, most social resolutions have been defeated easily by large-scale shareholders who support management's position.But under SEC corporate governance rules concerning annual meetings, a resolution needs only 3 percent support the year it's introduced to remain on the ballot the following year. The next year, it needs 6 percent of the vote, and 10 percent thereafter. Of the total resolutions filed this year, a record 250 are likely to come to a vote, a 43 percent increase over 1989, when 175 of the 214 proposals filed were voted upon, Ms. Will said. Some companies have been particularly singled out this year for what shareholder activists call unacceptable behavior regarding both South African involvement and the environment. On Monday, for example, American Cyanamid Co., a worldwide pharmaceutical and pesticide producer, faces what organizers call a massive protest planned for its annual meeting in South Portland, Maine. Two South Africa divestment resolutions are on the agenda. Activists contend the company has been dumping mercury contaminants in South Africa, mistreating black South African employees and selling products and services there that strengthen the apartheid system of racial segregation. ``They're on our strategic companies focus list,'' said Diane Bratcher, a spokeswoman for the Interfaith Center, one of the protest sponsors. ``What they do is pretty heavy stuff. Toxic dumping, providing strategic chemicals to the goldmining industry. That makes Cyanamid a pretty worthy target.'' Cyanamid issued a statement this past Friday rebutting the criticism. It said the mercury waste shipped to South Africa is safely recycled. The company also said it has strictly adhered to the Sullivan principles of racial equality signed by many American corporations that still operate in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Computerspeak, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the more popular bits of jargon used by the computer industry in talking about its products: _Enterprise: a company or division of a company. _Solution: a computer industry product, such as a new software package. _Platform: the electronic components of a comptuer. _Architecture: a set of specifications for a computer system. _Server: a computer that acts as the central data bank for linked personal computers. _Mission critical: important. _Networked: computers that are connected.

DOC.HEAD: Burger Chain to Sell Arizona Outlets
DOC.TEXT: Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc. will sell or franchise its 40 company-owned Carl's Jr. restaurants in Arizona, which were losing $5 million a year and contributed to a 73 percent drop in annual earnings. The regional fast-food outfit said Thursday it would take a $14.5 million special charge against its earnings to cover the costs. ``We're putting our bets elsewhere,'' said Loren Pannier, Karcher's chief financial officer. ``We have over $50 million in capital that we plan to use to expand our California operations next year.'' He gave no details. Karcher lost $8.9 million during the fourth quarter ending Jan. 29, compared with net earnings of $4.2 million in the same period the year earlier. The loss came despite a 6 percent rise in revenue to $118 million. For the year, earnings fell from $20.8 million to $5.6 million. Sales rose 15 percent from $511.3 million to $445.9 million.
