DOC.HEAD: The AP
Dollar Nearly Motionless, Gold Markets Closed
Precede: LONDON
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was little changed in virtually motionless trading Friday as most world financial centers closed early for the Easter weekend. Precious metals markets were closed in London, Zurich and New York. Most European markets were closed for a four-day weekend. In Milan, Belgium and Austria, where trading was conducted, dealers said activity was practically nonexistent. ``It's a good day to read the newspaper,'' said one dealer for a major foreign bank in Milan. Trading in New York also was extremely thin, and most dealers headed home by midday. ``Volume is basically nil,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston. He noted that the only players in the market were a handful of banks and a few Asian investors. Earlier in Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.42 yen to a closing 158.42 yen. In New York the dollar traded at 158.70 yen, up from 158.18 yen on Thursday. In New York the dollar fininshed at 1.6722 West German marks, down from 1.6724; 1.4835 Swiss francs, up from 1.4818; 5.6195 French francs, up from 5.6160; 1,230.25 Italian lire, up from 1.229.50, and 1.1645 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1617. In New York one British pound cost $1.6368, less expensive than $1.6420 on Thursday. In Milan, the dollar stood at 1,229.50 lire, down from Thursday's close of 1,231.50 lire. The dollar also sold for 1.6727 West German marks, down from 1.6730 marks in late European trading on Thursday. Other currency quotes were not available.

DOC.HEAD: Railroad Purchaser, Unions Reach Labor Agreement
DOC.TEXT: An investment group trying to buy assets of the Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Co. said Friday it had reached tentative labor agreements with unions representing railroad employees. Railroad Development Corp. said the agreements cover 80 percent of the union-represented workforce, including conductors and workers who handle car repair and inspection, track building and maintenance. All agreements are subject to approval by the unions. The railroad announced Feb. 9 it had agreed in principle to sell most of its track, rail yards, cars and locomotives to Railroad Development of Pittsburgh. That same day, the unions sued the railroad in federal court, challenging the sale, but the action was dismissed in March. The railroad now employs about 525 people, and 150 of them would be hired initially by Railroad Development. Terms of the acquisition, which investors hope will be completed by April 26, were undisclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Hallmark Gets Strong Response to Univision Debt Buyback, Extends Tender Offer
DOC.TEXT: Hallmark Cards Inc. said Friday that holders of more than 84 percent of the $270 million in junk bonds issued by its Univision Holdings Inc. unit have accepted terms of a buyback offer. The response reduced the chance that Univision, which operates a Spanish-language television network and eight TV stations, would proceed with its threat to file for bankruptcy protection should the tender offers be unsuccessful. Hallmark, a privately-held greeting card company based in Kansas City, Mo., said ``in light of the latest results'' it was extending until 5 p.m. EDT Tuesday its tender offers of $131 million in cash for the two debt issues. The company has said that it must get at least 90 percent of the two issues before it will be obligated to buy any of the securities. ``We are hopeful that all bondholders will now tender their securities and that the Univision restructuring can be completed promptly,'' Hallmark said. Hallmark, which owns 63.5 percent of Univision, offered to buy the securities at a sharp discount from face value after Univision was unable to make $10 million in interest payments in February on its debts to bondholders and bankers. Univision was authorized to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law if the tender offers were unsuccessful. The offers were to have expired at 12:01 a.m. Friday. On Thursday afternoon, a bondholder group which represents holders of more than three-fourths of the issues said it planned to accept the tender offers. Hallmark originally offered $106 million for the bonds, but those offers attracted fewer than 10 percent of each issue tendered. Hallmark sweetened its offers on March 30 by about 25 percent and said it had reached an agreement in principle with Univision's bank lenders. Wilbur Ross, senior managing director at Rothschild Inc., which is the financial advisor to the bondholders' committee, said his company considered the offers fair and recommended that a committee representing the bondholders support them. The committee said it intended to accept the offer. Hallmark is offering 55.3 cents on the dollar for Univision's $165 million in senior subordinated discount notes and said it had either been tendered or promised in excess of 90 percent of the notes under its tender offer. It is offering 37.9 cents on the dollar for $105.8 million in subordinated debentures and said nearly 85 percent of that issue was either promised or tendered. Hallmark has said it plans to defer the interest payments on the securities purchased in the tender offers for seven years. Univision was put together over the past three years as Hallmark and First Chicago Venture Capital, which owns 21.5 percent of Univision, bought eight television stations and the Univision network for $600 million. The company offers Spanish-language programming on a network that reaches an estimated 92 percent of the U.S. Hispanic population.

DOC.HEAD: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Down in Week
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.25 percent this week, down from 10.26 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. said Friday. One-year adjustable-rate mortgages averaged 8.50 percent this week, down from 8.56 last week. The rates, compiled from a national survey, do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: After Six Months, St. Louis Sun Still Not Shining
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, On April... to CORRECT that circulation guarantee was for first six months of 1990 sted first six months of publication. Picks up 8th graf, And the...
DOC.TEXT: It's been more than six months since Ralph Ingersoll II and his St. Louis Sun swaggered into this Midwestern city, armed with catchy slogans and ideas about the newspaper business. Ingersoll, chairman and chief executive officer of Ingersoll Publications Co., named himself editor-in-chief and promised that the new tabloid would be the first profitable startup of a daily metropolitan newspaper in 40 years. Today, the colorful newspaper's future seems anything but clear. The Sun is struggling to overcome higher-than-expected costs, revolving-door circulation, limited advertising and a murky image that has turned critics into fans and fans into critics from day to day. ``It seems as if things are not sailing along as smoothly as Mr. Ingersoll had planned,'' said Charles Klotzer, editor and publisher of the St. Louis Journalism Review. Ingersoll says rumors of the newspaper's imminent demise are greatly exaggerated. On April 1, the newspaper had circulation of 109,000 _ its highest yet and up from a low of 80,000 during the winter _ thanks to the start of a new ``Bingo'' promotion, Ingersoll said. Ingersoll has guaranteed advertisers circulation of 105,000 for the first six months of 1990. And the paper had 181 pages of advertising in the first week of April _ the Sun's best week since it began Sept. 25. ``We have plenty of good news, but we also have some problems and we need to make some changes,'' Ingersoll said in a telephone interview Thursday. ``The changes are all evolutionary, not revolutionary.'' Ingersoll said that debt problems facing Ingersoll Publications had cast a shadow over the Sun, although they had no impact on the newspaper's success or failure because they involved a separate company owned Ingersoll. Last month, Ingersoll announced a plan to buy back some of Community Newspapers Inc.'s high-interest junk bonds at cut-rate prices to appease some of his bondholders who were worried about the company's fiscal health. ``We felt we might have a good business opportunity, so we made the offer,'' Ingersoll said. ``The reaction has been what you would expect. The bondholders who bought the bonds at a low price are enthusiastic. The bond holders who bought them at a higher price are less enthusiastic. And that's where we are.'' But although the two don't have a direct connection, the publicity the bonds generated has spilled into the Sun and its newsroom. Richard Stevens, the Sun's metro editor, said editors are working hard to make sure the newsroom focused on business rather than rumors and gossip. ``Any time that we spend dealing with this kind of stuff is a negative, but as far as it wasting a lot of our time, it's not a factor,'' said Stevens. It's unclear what the general reaction has been in St. Louis to the new newspaper. Although the Sun has not weighted its local coverage toward sensational or titillating tabloid-type topics, it still has gotten complaints from some readers that it sensationalized certain stories. Drawing criticism, for example, were its coverage of a politician involved in a sexual assault and of the five-year anniversary of an accident in which a man nearly was sawed in two. The newspaper also has been chided for running photos of new women's swimsuits and lingerie. But the Sun also has been praised for its coverage of the effort to build a new domed stadium downtown and for its attention to the troubles facing St. Louis' major air carrier, Trans World Airlines. Some critics look down their noses at the Sun's flood of promotions, fluorescent green billboards and many contests, but Sun executives defend the practice as the best way to attract new readers. The paper's marketing and editorial aspects are the least of Ingersoll's troubles. The Sun is losing more money than it expected, according to Ingersoll, mainly because of higher-than-expected circulation costs and a whopping turnover rate among home subscribers. Ingersoll said the company has been forced to spend $5 million more than planned to distribute the Sun because twice as many readers as expected wanted their papers delivered. ``Advertisers consider that to be very good, but it's much more expensive than we planned for,'' Ingersoll said. Home subscribers also have been canceling their subscriptions at a high rate, which has left the newspaper with a 300 percent ``churn'' rate. The ``churn'' rate is the rate at which a newspaper must sign up new subscribers to keep circulation at existing levels. For example, if a newspaper has 50,000 home subscribers and it has to sign up 25,000 new subscribers each year to keep its home-delivery base at 50,000, the newspaper would have a churn rate of 50 percent. Ingersoll said the paper was researching the cause of its extremely high churn rate.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Post Rare Decline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs `Prices rose ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT time element to last year, sted this year. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices, helped by a record drop in vegetable costs and lower gasoline prices, fell in March for the first time in seven months, the government said Friday. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index declined 0.2 percent last month after no change in February and a huge 1.8 percent gain in January, the largest in 15 years. Vegetables prices were down by 25.5 percent. An unusually severe cold snap in late December, followed by unseasonably mild temperatures in January and February, caused the topsy-turvy price pattern. Fuel oil and vegetable costs rocketed in January. Energy recovered a month later, but food prices didn't start their decline until March. In a separate report, the Commerce Department said business inventories fell 0.4 percent in February while sales surged 1.3 percent. That report was taken as a sign of economic vigor; rising inventories can signal a recession. Analysts say more good news is ahead. ``Energy prices are still coming down and in fact we have a little more to go in vegetables. April should be a minus sign,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. Excluding the food and energy gyrations, wholesale inflation has been remarkably stable for nearly two years. Economists look to these so-called ``core'' prices _ up 0.3 percent in March and 0.4 percent in February _ as a better barometer of underlying inflationary pressures. They foresee little change, at least until next year. The Federal Reserve Board, they said, is keeping interest rates high enough to dampen both growth and price pressures but not high enough to derail the economy into a recession or substantially cut inflation. ``I think this year inflation is going to stay stuck,'' said economist James Annable of First National Bank of Chicago. ``Without a recession, you can't bring down inflation quickly.'' Prices rose 4.8 percent last year. Although the annual rate for the first three months of 1990 hit 6.7 percent, economists expect the wholesale inflation rate by the end of the year will come in close to last year's rate. The March wholesale inflation report was better than expected. Most economists had predicted a slight increase of 0.1 percent or 0.2 percent. Food prices dropped 0.6 percent in March, the sharpest decline since June. Vegetables, particularly tomatoes, celery and cabbage, fell 25.5 percent, the biggest drop on record going back to 1967. However, that marked only a partial recovery from gains of 23.3 percent in February and 58 percent in January. Prices also fell for beef and veal, dairy products and coffee. They rose for eggs, rice, pasta, pork, chickens, turkeys, fish, soft drinks and cooking oils. Energy prices overall dropped 2.4 percent in March after a decline of 5 percent in February and an increase of 13.6 percent in January. Gasoline was down 2.8 percent and natural gas declined 2.5 percent. Fuel oil prices went up 10.6 percent, but they had fallen 30.2 percent the month before. Clothing prices for men and children rose, while the cost of women's clothing fell. Passenger car prices, in the face of weak sales, declined 0.3 percent in March after no change in February and a 0.7 percent fall in January. The various changes put the index for all finished goods, one stop short of retail, at 117 in March. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $117 last month, up from $112.10 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process also eased in March. Intermediate goods showed no change, while crude goods fell 1.4 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude.

DOC.HEAD: Nabisco Brands to Sell Pet Snacks Division
DOC.TEXT: Nabisco Brands plans to sell its pet snacks division, which makes Milk Bones dog biscuits, to concentrate on making ``human foods,'' a company official confirmed Friday. John Manfredi, a senior vice president of the RJR Nabisco Inc. subsidiary, said the decision was announced to employees Thursday. The company had not yet received any offers, he said. The pet snacks division employs about 275 people at a plant in Buffalo and 12 at a kennel in Sherburne, 40 miles southeast of Syracuse, where its products are tested. Those jobs should not be in jeopardy, Manfredi said. ``Our assumption is that anyone who buys that Milk Bones business will certainly want to keep it going,'' he said in a telephone interview from his home in Montville, N.J. ``It's a very profitable business.'' The pet snacks division had about $150 million in sales last year. Its profits were not disclosed separately from Nabisco's, Manfredi said. The division makes a variety of Milk Bones brand biscuits, such as ones formulated to curb tartar buildup on dogs' teeth. Nabisco decided to sell the division because it was not a ``strategic fit'' with the rest of its business, he said. ``Their business is all in the human foods area,'' he said. ``This is the only one that's not.'' Since RJR Nabisco was bought out for $24.53 billion by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. last year, the company has sold numerous assets to reduce debt. Among other assets, the company has sold five European food businesses for $2.5 billion; its Chun King division for $52 million; its Associated Biscuits International Ltd. for $44 million; Del Monte fresh fruit operations for $875 million; and Del Monte's canned food business for $1.48 billion. In a related move Friday, Nabisco said it plans to disband the 12-member sales force of its Nabisco Foods division, headquartered in Parsippany, N.J., which had included the pet snacks operation. Manfredi said the company believes sales could be handled more efficiently by independent brokers than by in-house salesmen. The majority of the sales force likely will take jobs with those brokers, who already handle about 70 percent of the company's sales, Manfredi said. Others might take jobs elsewhere at RJR, and few would be left without a job.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Fail to Reach Lumber Agreement But New Talks Planned
DOC.TEXT: Trade negotiators ended talks Friday without reaching an agreement on U.S. demands that Japan remove restrictions on imports of wood products but another round of discussions is planned. Lumber products trade is the only unresolved issue among three areas in which Washington has been seeking to remove trade barriers under a section of U.S. trade law known as ``Super 301.'' ``There are still significant differences in our positions,'' a U.S. official in Tokyo told reporters. ``We have made substantial progress on many points, but some issues remain to be discussed further,'' said a Japanese Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We have concluded our talks at this round after agreeing to hold another round of talks in the near future.'' The U.S. official, who also spoke on condition he not be named, said U.S. negotiators felt they could reach an agreement before June 16, when the U.S. administration is legally required to decide whether or not to take retaliatory action for foreign trade practices it says are unfair. ``I think there is momentum to resolve the negotiations. There is strong interest in a resolution on both sides,'' the U.S. official said. Last year, the Bush administration designated Japanese trade in wood products, satellites and supercomputers as areas in which U.S. products face unfair trade practices under the ``Super 301'' clause. The two governments recently reached agreements on greater access to Japan's satellite and supercomputer markets, but talks on lumber trade, which began Monday, faced mounting disagreement mainly because of Japan's complicated housing and construction regulations, the Japanese official said. U.S. industry and government officials say a Japanese law banning the construction of three-story wooden apartments unfairly limits wood imports. They also say Tokyo's product specifications and tariffs for lumber unfairly discriminate against imports of high-value finished and semi-finished wood products. By importing mainly raw timber, they say, Japan is protecting its own uncompetitive, traditional timber processing industry. Japanese officials, however, argue that such restrictions are necessary safety precautions in earthquake-prone Japan, and thus cannot be eased unconditionally. While traditional Japanese architecture is based on wooden construction, modern Japan has strict building codes to minimize the risk of damage and fire from earthquakes. Wooden structures are limited by law to single-family dwellings up to three stories, and to two-story multiple family housing. Most apartment buildings in major cities are built of steel and concrete. Officials from both sides said they felt technical questions regarding the safety of wooden housing had been cleared up. They said progress had been made in all areas of discussion, but declined to explain remaining disagreements. The U.S. official said he expected the talks to resume ``very soon,'' but did not say exactly when or where the next round of negotiations would take place. Last year, the United States exported $2.8 billion in wood products to Japan, mostly unfinished logs. Industry officials estimate that if trade barriers were eliminated, the market would expand by an additional $2 billion and between 17,000 to 20,000 new U.S. jobs would be created.

DOC.HEAD: Iacocca Gets Raise in '89 over '88
With AM-Chrysler Proxy-Table
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca was the only Big Three automaker chief executive who got a raise in 1989, pulling in $4 million, or 8.1 percent more than he collected in 1988, the company's proxy statement said Friday. Earnings last year for the nation's No. 3 automaker were down 65.8 percent from the year before. Iacocca's compensation in 1989 salary and stock and in bonuses earned from the year before topped the $2.5 million received by General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith. It was less, however, than the $6.6 million awarded to Ford Motor Co. Chairman Donald E. Petersen, who retired March 1. Earlier this week, after GM and Ford issued their proxy statements, the United Auto Workers union called the executives' compensation levels for 1989 a ``disease.'' The union's offices were closed for the Good Friday holiday. Last year's proxy statements showed that Iacocca and Smith collected $3.7 million each and Petersen got $10.5 million, mostly in stock. Iacocca would have received more for 1989 had the company not withheld bonuses because of low corporate earnings. The Chrysler-UAW contract calls on executives to forego cash bonuses in years when earnings don't reach the threshold for profit-sharing checks for union-represented workers. In 1989, Chrysler earned $359 million, far below the $1.05 billion in profit the company reported for 1988. GM and Ford made enough money to give their eligible workers profit-sharing checks of $50 and $1,025 apiece respectively. Chrysler's proxy statement said Iacocca's $889,151 salary for 1989 was increased by $525,000 in cash compensation paid last year from 1988 earnings. The colorful executive also was awarded $2.6 million worth of stock. Other top Chrysler executives' compensations contained in the proxy statement included: Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald, $1.1 million; Chrysler Motors Chairman Ben Bidwell, $976,709; Chrysler Motors President Robert A. Lutz, $951,436; and Executive Vice President Robert S. Miller Jr., $874,266. Although none of the executives will be receiving bonuses based on 1989 earnings, the board of directors has set aside $22 million from corporate earnings for compensation later. The two issues up for shareholder votes at Chrysler's annual meeting would change the number of votes each shareholder could cast in elections for the board of directors and require that each director hold at east 2,000 shares of Chrysler common or preferred stock. The board opposes both motions.

DOC.HEAD: Record High Cattle Futures Portend Higher Beef Prices
DOC.TEXT: Retail beef prices are likely to keep rising at least through this month because of unusually tight cattle supplies, a situation already reflected in record high prices for live cattle futures, analysts say. But prices should ease significantly toward the end of May as cattle placed on feedlots during the winter reach marketable weights. Record-breaking cattle futures prices shared the spotlight with tumbling crude oil and gasoline futures prices on the nation's commodity markets in the past week. Elsewhere, precious metal prices fell and grains and soybeans were mixed. Live cattle for April delivery rose to 80.40 cents a pound Wednesday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, surpassing the previous high of 80.25 cents set in the spring of 1979. On Thursday, the last trading session before Easter, the contract climbed to 80.47 cents before settling at 80.42 cents. The high futures prices reflect conditions in the cash cattle market, where meat packers reportedly paid 81 cents to 82 cents a pound for top-quality cattle in recent days. On the retail level, a weekly price survey of 15 cuts of beef in nine U.S. cities by the Knight-Ridder Financial news service found an average price of $2.41 per pound Thursday compared with $2.39 a week earlier and $2.29 a year ago. Analysts said the main reason for the rising prices is tight supplies of market-ready cattle. The situation reflects a decline in feedlot placements last year after cattle prices fell during the summer to less than 70 cents a pound, said Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill. He said cattle typically are marketed within five months of being placed on feedlots to be fattened. Morgan said feedlot placements picked up again last fall and winter, after dry weather caused poor grazing conditions in the Southern Plains. ``The winter wheat wasn't growing enough to pasture so they pulled cattle off the pastures and sold them to feedlots in October through January,'' he said. Morgan said those cattle were lighter in weight than the average feedlot placements, so they are being kept longer before marketing. ``They'll start coming mid-May through July,'' he said. That should bring cattle prices down, with retail beef prices likely to follow within a few weeks. How far and quickly prices will fall is anyone's guess. The 1979 highs were followed by a collapse of more than 20 cents in less than three months. ``I think people are cognizant of that,'' said Phil Stanley, an independent futures trader and consultant for DEC Futures Inc. in Lincoln, Neb. ``On any sign of weakness in the cash market you'll probably see some pretty active selling come into the futures,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Energy
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures fell dramatically on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a petroleum industry newsletter reported Monday that OPEC oil production had reached a nine-year high of 24.1 million barrels a day in March. Selling pressure increased after the American Petroleum Institute said Tuesday in a weekly report that U.S. stocks of crude oil had risen by about 8 million barrels, a far bigger weekly increase than the market had expected. Crude oil for May delivery plunged to a 14-month low of $17.28 a barrel Wednesday morning, rebounded above $18 by the end of that session, then fell back below $18 by the end of the week.

DOC.HEAD: Financing Plan Extension Granted to Troubled Home Builder
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankrupcty judge on Friday extended the deadline for General Development Corp.'s financing plan and ordered the troubled real estate giant to honor back paychecks. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge A. Jay Cristol gave General Development until Monday to present a short-term financial plan. He also scheduled a series of status hearings through May on the company, which pleaded guilty last month in connection with a scheme to sell overpriced homes. ``We want to get things moving along,'' said Cristol, who ruled General Development must pay wages earned prior to the bankruptcy filing. ``This case will be conducted fully and clearly in the sunshine.'' General Development filed for Chapter 11 bankrupcty protection on April 6, claiming a severe cash shortage after failing to secure about $60 million in short-term credit. Meanwhile, a special master appointed by U.S. District Court Lenore Nesbitt is reviewing an estimated $100 million restitution program for about 10,000 victims of the overpricing scheme. The program is part of a plea agreement that settled a 16-count indictment against the company and two former executives. During the past two months, General Development has cut its work force and halted most projects at its nine Florida communities. The bankruptcy filing does not affect General Development's time-share and utility subsidiaries, but company officials said the filing could be expanded.

DOC.HEAD: Wells Rich Greene Agrees to Join French-Led Ad Network
DOC.TEXT: The advertising agency Wells Rich Greene Inc. said Friday it will sell a 40 percent stake to a French firm and join an international ad agency network, in an effort to give its clients more worldwide services. In a separate development, Wells Rich founder Mary Wells Lawrence said she was stepping aside as chairman and chief executive and that the agency's board had elected Kenneth Olshan to succeed her. ``Ken and I have been moving toward this day for five years,'' Mrs. Wells said, calling it ``another step in the natural evolution of the agency.'' The 60-year-old Mrs. Lawrence has been withdrawing from day-to-day involvement with the agency over the past three years to spend more time with her family. She said she also wanted an orderly succession. Olshan, 56, has been with the agency for 15 years and most recently has been chairman of its Wells Rich Greene Worldwide unit. The privately-held Wells Rich Greene handles billings of about $850 million a year and its clients include International Business Machines Corp., Ford Motor Co., Procter & Gamble, Hertz and MCI Communications Corp. It has created ads for Alka-Seltzer Plus cold medicine, Benson & Hedges cigarettes and Pringles potato chips and developed the ``I Love New York'' theme for the state of New York. The agency said it was joining a union of advertising agencies formed by the French ad agency BDDP over the past six years that includes agencies throughout Europe and the Far East. As part of that agreement, BDDP has agreed to purchase 40 percent of the stock in Wells Rich Greene for an undisclosed amount. In turn, Wells Rich's management group will obtain an unspecified stake in BDDP through stock purchases and exchange of shares, the firm's statement read. Olshan said BDDP executives approached Wells Rich Greene about joining its agency network several months ago. ``BDDP needs a major American agency for their union, just as we need the right partners in their markets,'' he said. He said the association would build the BDDP network into ``the kind of substantial, talented and realistic resource we want for our clients.'' BDDP was founded in 1984 by a group that included the managers of the ad agencies Young & Rubicam and Ogilvy & Mather in Europe. Its clients include BMW, Grand Metropolitan PLC, Polaroid, Hertz, McDonald's and Electrolux. It has developed its ad network by setting up agencies and buying stakes ranging from 20 percent to 100 percent in others. The agencies are selected for the creative capabilities and management of each agency is kept in local hands. The BDDP-led network's billings now exceed $1.4 billion. In a telephone interview, Mrs. Lawrence said there was no relation between the two announcements. ``It was all evolving at the same time,'' she said. Wells Rich Greene has offices in five cities _ New York, Chicago, Detroit, St. Louis and Los Angeles _ but no international presence other than a stake in an agency in London. ``I had been looking for an international solution for quite awhile now,'' Mrs. Lawrence said. But she said the prospective partners either wanted to buy her whole company, served clients who may have posed a conflict with clients of Wells Rich Greene or were simply ``not people we wanted to deal with.'' The prospective removal of trader barriers within Europe in 1992 made it more important that Wells Rich find an international partner, though. ``The time has come when it would be dangerous not to be fully represented there,'' Mrs. Lawrence said. She said she had been the agency's majority shareholder but would be selling some of her stock as part of the transaction with BDDP. She declined to say how much she would be left with or how much she was being paid for her interest nor how large a stake she planned to buy in BDDP.

DOC.HEAD: Getcha Clean Gasoline, Recyclable Ketchup Bottles and Dolphin-Free Tuna!
DOC.TEXT: Companies call it good corporate citizenship, skeptics call it greenwashing and some hard-line environmentalists call it eco-pornography. They're talking about the deluge of products, services and business advertising timed to coincide with celebrations and publicity marking the 20th anniversary of Earth Day on April 22. This past week, for example, Shell Oil Co. announced an ``environmentally enhanced'' gasoline to cut pollution, H.J. Heinz Co. announced a new effort to turn empty plastic condiment bottles into carpeting, and the nation's biggest tuna canners promised to stop buying or selling tuna caught in nets that also snare dolphins. Many of these efforts stem from what business executives call a sincere sensitivity to the environment spawned by growing problems that range from groaning land fills to acid-rain pollution and beaches tainted by oil spills. Shell's chief executive Frank Richardson, for example, in explaining the motive for selling a reduced-emission gasoline, said it ``reflects Shell's ongoing commitment to make environmental considerations a priority in our development of new products and processes.'' Environmental groups generally have welcomed this trend. But as Earth Day draws closer and more companies seek to exploit its popularity by touting themselves as environmentalists, some activists are growing alarmed that the event is turning into a hype-ridden corporate sales campaign. ``We think Earth Day is a good thing. We're also convinced it has some extremely negative side effects,'' said Peter Dykstra, spokesman for Washington-based Greenpeace, one of the most visible and militant environmental groups. ``There's a lot of `greenwashing' going on,'' Dykstra said. ``It is frequently pursued most energetically by the companies with the worst records. The dolphin problems have been known for a quarter century. That canners timed their policy change now is certainly not coincidence.'' Some industries accused by the environmental movement of the most serious pollution history, such as lumber-product companies, have incensed Earth Day celebrants by claiming to be their allies. The American Forest Council, for example, a group of timber and paper companies, has taken out large magazine ads that say ``For Us, Every Day is Earth Day.'' ``That goes beyond greenwashing,'' Dykstra said. ``It's eco-pornography. It exploits environmental concern, just as pornography is commonly considered offensive and exploitative.'' Still, the announcements this past week by the nation's three largest sellers of canned tuna, Heinz's Starkist Seafood Co.'s subsidiary, Van Camp Seafood Co.'s Chicken of the Sea brand and Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc., were regarded as a major victory by environmental activist groups that long have sought to end the killing of dolphins in giant fishing nets. At the same time, the only substantial proof of a policy change was offered by Starkist. Chicken of the Sea and Bumble Bee, both owned by foreign companies, by Friday had not disclosed precisely how they intended to ensure they only will use dolphin-free tuna in the future. ``We do know that Heinz is willing, finally, to go the limit,'' said Brenda Killian, a national organizer for the Save the Dolphin Project of the Earth Island Institute, a San Francisco-based environmental group. ``If the others don't, we'll expose them.'' To some extent, the so-called greening of corporate America is founded on consumer-based economics. Surveys have shown that a majority of shoppers will avoid buying a product if they know it will hurt the environment, and will spend a few more cents for a product packaged with recyclable materials. Marketing Intelligence Service, a research group in Naples, N.Y., has tracked the introduction of more than 700 products described as environmentally friendly since 1985, ranging from biodegradable diapers to ``dioxin free'' coffee filters. ``Unfortunately for the consumer and the environment, not all of these products are as green as they claim,'' the Council on Economic Priorities, a public-interest group that monitors corporate behavior, said in its April newsletter. ``Many questions about green products remain unanswered. Who will distinguish between true environmental product improvements and false ones? Is there any agreement about what `safe for the environment' really means?'' In other business and economic news this past week: _ Executive pay in Detroit and on Wall Street reflected lower earnings in the auto and securities industries last year, but nobody was crying. The chairmen of General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Merrill Lynch & Co. took cuts of between 32 percent and 38 percent in 1989 salary, bonuses and stock options. That still left Ford's Donald Petersen with $6.6 million, while GM's Roger Smith and Merrill's William Schreyer took home $2.5 million. Lee Iacocca even got an 8 percent raise to $4 million despite a 66 percent plunge in Chrysler Corp.'s earnings. The top three executives at highly profitable Morgan Stanley & Co. each got a 26 percent raise to $5.475 million. _ Lockheed Corp.'s board won re-election, beating a proxy challenge from Dallas investor Harold Simmons by a clear margin. But Simmons claimed a partial victory as four shareholder rights initiatives were approved, including one requiring the company to opt out of Delaware's tought anti-takeover statute. Chairman Daniel Tellep said the board would have to review its ``poison pill'' defenses. _ California launched a $28.6 million advertising campaign that officials hope will persuade three-quarters of the state's smokers to kick the habit by the year 2000. The drive is funded by a 25 cent-a-pack tax hike authorized last year in a referendum.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions April 14-15

DOC.HEAD: Members who used AM-Ames Woes, which moved April 12 as f0314, are asked to use the following:
DOC.TEXT: In a story about suppliers reportedly refusing to ship goods to Ames Department Stores, The Associated Press incorrectly said Ames had announced it lost an estimated $288 million in the year that ended Jan. 27. The company said it lost an estimated $228 million.

Wholesale prices, helped by a record drop in vegetable costs and lower gasoline prices, fell in March for the first time in seven months, the government said. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index declined 0.2 percent last month after no change in February and a huge 1.8 percent gain in January, the largest in 15 years. Vegetables prices were down by 25.5 percent, the department reported Friday.

Business inventories fell in February for the second time in three months while sales surged in another sign that the economy has avoided a recession, the government said. Inventories on shelves and backlots shrank 0.4 percent, the steepest drop since December 1986, to a seasonally adjusted $794.6 billion in February, the Commerce Department reported Friday. Sales, meanwhile, rose 1.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted $535.4 billion. It was the largest increase in seven months.

Boeing Co. said it would begin producing a new commercial jet under an agreement with three Japanese companies that will produce parts and provide up to 20 percent of the capital for the venture. The so-called 767-X is intended to fill the size gap between Boeing's 767, another jetliner that uses some Japanese-produced components, and its 747 jumbo jet, company officials said Friday. Under the agreement, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries would get a share of any profits but would have no equity in the project and get no proprietary information.

Big Mac is on the attack, warning newspapers around the country not to reprint a full-page ad placed by an Omaha industrialist who claims that McDonald Corp.'s food is too fatty. ``We think the papers just didn't check the facts,'' said McDonald's attorney Joseph Califano. He said the fast food company had advised the newspapers that the ad was misleading and asked them not to publish it again. The fat flap began April 4, when industrialist and anti-cholesterol crusader Phil Sokolof placed ads headlined ``The Poisoning of America!'' in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and several other papers. The ad asked McDonald's to reduce the fat in its hamburgers by 10 percent as a ``contribution toward lowering cholesterol levels for Americans.''

Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca was the only Big Three automaker chief executive who got a raise in 1989, pulling in $4 million, or 8.1 percent more than he collected in 1988, the company's proxy statement said. Earnings last year for the nation's No. 3 automaker were down 65.8 percent from the year before. Iacocca's compensation in 1989 salary, stock and bonuses earned from the year before, disclosed in the proxy statement Friday, topped the $2.5 million received by General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith but was less than the $6.6 million awarded to Ford Motor Co. Chairman Donald E. Petersen, who retired March 1.

Trade negotiators ended talks without reaching an agreement on U.S. demands that Japan remove restrictions on imports of wood products but another round of discussions is planned. Lumber products trade is the only unresolved issue among three areas in which Washington has been seeking to remove trade barriers under a section of U.S. trade law known as ``Super 301.'' ``There are still significant differences in our positions,'' a U.S. official in Tokyo told reporters Friday.

The advertising agency Wells Rich Greene Inc. said it will sell a 40 percent stake to a French firm, BDDP, and join an international ad agency network in an effort to give its clients more worldwide services. In a separate development, Wells Rich founder Mary Wells Lawrence said she was stepping aside as chairman and chief executive and that the agency's board had elected Kenneth Olshan to succeed her. The privately-held Wells Rich Greene handles billings of about $850 million a year and its clients include International Business Machines Corp., Ford Motor Co., Procter & Gamble, Hertz and MCI Communications Corp.

Competition for students and drops in government support were the main reasons for huge tuition jumps at private and public colleges during the 1980s, says a new study. And while experts predict some relief in the 1990s, they say the price of higher education will still rise faster than inflation _ at least until the baby boom's babies start to hit college age.

A federal bankrupcty judge extended the deadline for General Development Corp.'s financing plan and ordered the troubled real estate giant to honor back paychecks. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge A. Jay Cristol on Friday gave General Development until Monday to present a short-term financial plan. He also scheduled a series of status hearings through May on the company, which pleaded guilty last month in connection with a scheme to sell overpriced homes.

The dollar was little changed in virtually motionless trading Friday as most world financial centers closed early for the Easter weekend. The nation's stock, bond, precious metals and commodity markets also were closed Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Court Convenes Hearing That Could Determine Fate of Airline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-12, `Lifland gave ... or Tuesday' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with hearing adjourned until Monday, Texas Air spokesman saying Eastern has enough money to keep flying until end of month; picks up 13th graf pvs, `Pressure to ...' Stands for AMs
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge should appoint an outsider to take control of Eastern Airlines because management is ``unable or unwilling'' to face market realities, an adviser to the carrier's unsecured creditors testified Friday. Arthur Newman, managing director of investment banking at Chemical Bank, said he had never seen a company miss its financial forecasts as frequently or by such large amounts as Eastern has. Newman was the first witness at a hearing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court to consider the creditors' request for the appointment of a special trustee to run the airline, something Eastern's unions have long sought. Present in the packed courtroom were Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., and Eastern President Phil Bakes, who have opposed the idea of relinquishing control of the financially pressed airline. Joel Zweibel, attorney for the committee representing the unsecured creditors, said they wanted a trustee not to liquidate Eastern but to sell it as a going concern. ``This debtor has lost an extraordinary amount of money since commencement of the case,'' he told the court. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland expressed impatience with Eastern, which has been attempting to reorganize since it entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings more than a year ago. The judge, who repeatedly has postponed proceedings to address the trustee issue, told the company's attorneys, ``you people have been squandering the time that's been allotted to ou.'' At about 7 p.m. Friday, Lifland adjourned the hearing until Monday morning. Newman, the first of three witnesses the creditors planned to call, was the only one to testify on Friday. In arguing for a trustee, Newman said the airline's management ``was unable or unwilling to face the realities that are there in the marketplace for Eastern.'' Eastern plans to call eight witnesses and they are expected to include Lorenzo and Bakes. It would be the first time Lorenzo has testifed in court since the carrier filed for bankruptcy. Eastern also is asking the judge for permission to withdraw $80 million from an escrow account for to cover second quarter operations, a request Lifland said he would consider Monday. Bruce Zirinsky, one of Eastern's attorneys, said the airline needs the cash by Monday or Tuesday. After the hearing, though, Texas Air spokesman Art Kent said Eastern ``has sufficient resources to keep flying at least through the end of the month.'' Pressure to appoint a trustee mounted this past week when the unsecured creditors voted to reject the airline's latest reorganization proposal and later asked the court to name a trustee who would sell Eastern. ``Eastern's devastating, constantly expanding and unending losses are extremely damaging to unsecured creditors,'' the creditors' motion said. Before that, the creditors' committee had supported Eastern throughout its 13-month-long bankruptcy proceeding and had objected to the unions' calls for the appointment of a trustee. The pilots, Machinists and flight attendants unions struck Eastern on March 4, 1989, forcing the Miami-based airline into bankruptcy protection five days later. The Machinists union remains on strike against Eastern. The unions long have accused Lorenzo of funneling Eastern assets to parent Texas Air and sister carrier Continental Airlines. A report by court-appointed examiner David I. Shapiro filed in early March suggested Texas Air had victimized Eastern by underpaying for the airline and some of its assets by hundreds of millions of dollars. Eastern recently asked Lifland to accelerate approval of a $280 million payment by Texas Air to settle the potential claims raised by Shapiro's report. The trustee issue prompted the collapse last spring of a proposed buyout of Eastern by the unions and former baseball commissioner Peter V. Ueberroth. Eastern came under additional pressure Monday, when the committee representing its preferred shareholders proposed a reorganization plan that would give the airline to the shareholders, unsecured creditors and new managers. It was the first competing proposal to Eastern's own reorganization plan. Eastern owes the unsecured creditors around $980 million, while the preferred shareholders are due $680 million. The airline's most recent reorganization plans proposed to pay the two groups only a fraction of what they are owed. Eastern also has about $830 million in unfunded pension liabilities, according to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., a government agency. Eastern claims its liability is only $376.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: MGM-UA Loses $9.8 Million in 2nd Qtr
DOC.TEXT: MGM-UA Communications Co. said Friday it lost $9.8 million in the second quarter and revenue fell 27 percent, primarily because it had few movies in release as a result of trying to sell the company. The loss for the quarter ended Feb. 28, the equivalent of 19 cents per share, compared with a loss of $14.7 million, or 29 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue fell from $241.8 million to $176.8 million, with the feature films segment declining by 33 percent to $140.8 million. Controlling shareholder Kirk Kerkorian had MGM-UA in the auction block for the better part of two years, nearly drying up the pipeline for movies. Pathe Communications Corp. is trying to complete a buyout of MGM-UA for $1.27 billion. Analysts say restarting film production will cost hundreds of millions of dollars extra. For the first six months of fiscal 1990, MGM-UA lost $11.9 million, or 23 cents per share, compared with $54.2 million, $1.08 per share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenues fell 6 percent, from $412.2 million to $388.3 million. ``Operating revenues decreased during both periods primarily due to a lack of feature films in theatrical release,'' MGM-UA Chairman Jeffrey C. Barbakow said. ``However, for the first six months of fiscal 1990, the company posted operating gains due to our successful control of overhead costs, as well as the continued outstanding sales performances of the home video and pay television groups.''

DOC.HEAD: Puts Neodata, Petroleum Information, Zytron Services Up for Sale
DOC.TEXT: Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said Thursday it plans to sell three small service companies that assist publishers, large computer users and the oil and gas industry. The business information marketer said the planned sales are part of its previously announced strategy to sharpen the company's focus on key markets. The three businesses, which are being offered for sale separately, had combined revenue of $200 million last year and were said to be profitable. They are: _Neodata Services, based in Boulder, Colo., a leading provider of subscription-fulfillment services for more than 270 publications. _Zytron, based in Menlo Park, Calif., a company that transfers data generated by large computer users onto microfilm and microfiche. _Petroleum Information, based in Littleton, Colo., which publishes information on drilling, production and natural gas transportation for the oil and gas industries. The company said the absence of operating income from the three subsidiaries is expected to be offset by investing and redeploying the cash proceeds from the sales. ``While all these are profitable businesses, we believe that it is in the best interests of D&B's shareowners to simplify D&B's business mix and focus our investments and resources on those key markets in which D&B's participation and leadership positions are strongest,'' Charles W. Moritz, chairman and chied executive, said. He said those markets include risk-management information, marketing information, directory information and business applications software. Last month, Dun & Bradstreet announced plans to sell Datastream International and Interactive Data, which provide historical investment information.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Awards AT&T a $121 Million Contract
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. has awarded AT&T a $121 million contract to design and provide a worldwide custom voice and data communications network, AT&T announced Thursday. The five-year contract covers nearly all of the interstate and international long-distance services for the U.S.-based operations of Xerox, AT&T said. The network will link more than 300 company locations including sales and service offices, distribution centers, manufacturing locations and billing operations, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said in a release. Services included in the contract will provide Xerox with digital communications across its network, said Fred Bolton, Xerox manager of telecommunications services.

DOC.HEAD: National Intergroup Files Two Lawsuits
DOC.TEXT: National Intergroup Inc. filed two lawsuits Thursday to try to stop the hostile takeover attempt by the New York-based Centaur Partners. One suit filed with the U.S. District Court in Pittsburgh seeks an injunction to stop the defendants' efforts to gain control of the Pittsburgh-based holding company. The suits named Centaur Partners, Walker Street Associates and its affiliates as defendants. Centaur said it would vigorously defend itself. ``NII's board of directors is desperately trying to intimidate us and other shareholders,'' it said. The federal suit alleged the defendants furnished false and misleading information to NII shareholders in order to gain control of their stock. ``Defendants' false and misleading consent materials and the apparent infirmities in their disclosures about their cooperative efforts have resulted in irreparable harm by creating confusion in the marketplace and interfering with the free and informed exercise of the shareholders' franchise,'' NII's court documents said. Centaur is seeking to gain seats on National Intergroup's board, restructure the company and sell off assets. It has claimed it could receive $29.34 a share by breaking up NII. Centaur said its figure of $29.34 a share is based on an independent analysis conducted by PaineWebber Inc. and is $3 less than National Intergroup's book value. But National Intergroup said in the lawsuit that those figures are wrong because PaineWebber would earn 10 percent of whatever profit Centaur may make from breaking up the company. The second lawsuit filed in Common Pleas Court of Allegheny County is seeking a judgment from the court that ultimately would decrease the percentage of National Intergroup common stock owned by the defendants and increase the percentage owned by other shareholders. As of Jan. 26, Centaur Partners owned at least 16.53 percent of NII's outstanding shares, and Walker Street has increased their ownership through open market purchases to about 8.4 percent, the state lawsuit alleged. National Intergroup stock closed at $15.87{ Thursday, down 87{ cents on the New York Stock Exchange.
